reviews.review: My favourite part of Sydney. It is like an oasis in the city. Walking through the gardens are magical. It offers the most beautiful trees and gardens. Apart from the paths through the garden, there is a path that follows the water from Woolloomooloo to the Opera house with the most spectacular views of the harbour and the city. It is also a wonderful picnic spot.

Lovely place to chill. Love visiting the botanical gardens! I visit at least one a week. The place is quite big so even when it's busy you can still find a quiet area to have a picnic or just chill out. You can also walk round and get a great view of the opera house and harbour bridge.Would definitely recommend a visit if you are in Sydney.

Lots to see and enjoy. Well worth the visit, the gardens are full of wonderful trees shrubs and flowers of every description and a very informative section about the abororiginies. There is a lovely shaded cafe area and gift shop where you can purchase seeds of the surounding plants and the usual souvenirs. There is a train that takes you around all the park for those who are unable to walk the distance, all the staff are very friendly and helpful, a wonderful day out.

Botanical Gardens for beauty and relaxation.. While visiting in early Australian spring, I saw a well kept and spacious garden. While many of the plants were just beginning to flush out, I was impressed with the blend of old buildings and architecture that gave the garden its bones. There are also great views of the harbor from the garden.
Beautiful. I'm a bird watcher and visiting the gardens gave me the chance to see the birds, flowers and to get familiar with the beauty Sydney had to offer
Wonderful. This is must do attraction just next to the Opera House. Great for a stroll enjoying the trees, plants, flowers, birds and well kept lawns. Worth a second and third visit. Really nice.

A beautiful view and walk. If visiting the hrbour hpuse, a short walk will talke you to the botanical gardens. You will see the most exotic trees and u usual plants in its best form. Apring is a great time to viait.Make sure you are in comfy walking shoes!

Hour Visit after Seeing Opera House. These gardens cover a large area. You could spend an hour or all day. We walked over to the gardens after seeing the Opera House. There was a cute train that you can buy tickets for and the ride is about 30 minutes long. Since we did not have unlimited time, this was a wonderful way to see much of the gardens. Also very convenient for those with small children or elderly due to the amount of walking you would do to see the gardens.
Peacefull. Nice leisurely walk after the hussle and bustle of the city ! The herb garden is beautiful ...Lovely quiet pond to sit around

Tranquility in the city. As you wander through the gardens, you are oblivious to the busy city only a few hundred yards away as the gardens are quite and calming. A magic place to stroll through and a wonderful great showcase for the trees and plants of Australia, as well as some other countries. The layout is exceptional and as with everything in Australia, well maintained to a high standard. There are also water features that you can stop and sit at to relax with the sound of the water bubbling away in the background. Or you can stop at the café and have a coffee or snack on your way round. The paths lead you around the park and eventually to the Opera House and Harbour Bridge.

Wonderful gardens. The botanical gardens are definitely worth your while. You could spend less than and hour or a few hours exploring all the pathways and different inspired gardens. Spring was in bloom and the flowering trees beautiful! The walk to the harbor is very nice.

Peaceful gardens . Visited the gardens on a rainy day. Good variety of trees, bushes and flowers. Nice sculptures and walks. Easy waterside walk, plenty of photo opportunities and sitting areas. Nice place for a picnic on a sunny day .

Oasis in a city. An enormous area of varied gardens with wide open spaces for use by families. The restaurant and cafe are delightfully situated.
Easily reached from the city and leads straight to the Opera House and ferry terminals.

Romance. Right on the Sydney Harbor, an easy walk from the Opera House. Families, joggers, and at least one bride being photographed. Coincidently or not, a sky writer aloft in that clear blue sky wrote: "Forever", with a tiny heart beneath. Who knows what you'll experience. Doesn't get much better.

Absolutely fantastic. The gardens are a must while you were in Sydney. It's close to many of the major attractions. They are pretty big and well paved so it's nice running and walking. The fauna varies and the park is well manicured so it's interesting to see where the little paths will take you.
The Garden. Walk through this garden means connecting with nature and the opportunity of having a relaxing time!
As beautiful as ever. The gardens are a special place. Strolling through this peaceful area after a business day is a great way to wind down and well within walking distance of the city centre.

Beautiful place, great vistas, easy to walk. Right next to Sydney Opera House. Free! Great walk, beautiful variety of plant life. Quiet, large walkways and many paths.Take the time to walk through the entire location - you won't regret it!
relax. this is a nice place to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Very interesting as they have informative nameplates for many different plant species.

Stroll the Gardens on a nice day. Take enough time to find not only trees, but to watch the antics of the sacred ibises, the cockatoos, and find the eels who live in the pond near the harbor shore--they actually slither to the pond from the ocean on high tide nights. When I first came years ago, I was mesmerized by the tall and unusual trees--now I enjoy seeing the unusual sports played on all the lawns. Think twice about the new Calyx building--you pay $20 to read posters about how chocolate is grown and eat a "free" chocolate chip--just pass by and enjoy your stroll.
Absolutely gorgeous. This is a beautiful walk to take while in Sydney. The views are stunning with trees and flowers to your right and water views to your left.

Bring your camera!. It is always a great place to take pictures at the Royal Botanic Gardens.
So be sure to bring your camera.
The heavy and cumbersome DSLR will be worth the trouble to bring here, especially during a sunny day!
Very interesting, very beatiful.. Be sure to find time for a leisurely stroll in the park. And an espresso while watching the birds that whizzed around you.

An oasis by the harbour. The cool green of the gardens in the sun combined with the magic of the harbour leading to mrs Macquarie's Chair is one of the magic activities in Sydney. The exhibition gates lead to pretty pavilions and down to the fern houses and the cafe, with its view down to the harbour.
Relaxed area of a beautiful city. We strolled through the beautiful gardens with the amazing backdrop of Sydney Harbour. A sensational spot to relax in the heart of a busy city.
Great place. It's a great botanical garden with some excellent views and a great walk. We took the mini-train ride with the kids and it was great fun as well as educational

Beautiful area. The Gardens were filled with the shields from the Skin and Bones Installation of Jonathan Jones and Kaldor Art Projects. The area was the original site which related to the installation story. A beautiful place to stroll around and take in the beauty of nature and forget about the hustle and bustle of city life.

Harbour views. The botaniclal gardens are located right on Sydney harbour, and offer fantastic views of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. It is in close proximity to the Art Gallery which is also worth a visit. The gardens are beautifully maintained with a large variety of plants. The three colours of Wisteria are spectacular to walk under in spring. Take your own picnic or have lunch at the cafe or restaurant located in the gardens. There are public toilets. Enjoy a walk around to Mrs Macquaries Chair for an even more spectacular view up the harbour. Grassy slopes for kids to roll down, and trees to climb too.

Spectacular garden experience. The RBG is a drop-dead gorgeous spot to spend at least three hours when it's a fine day.The gardens are a tranquil spot, ideal for a picnic lunch to be enjoyed on the grassy slopes overlooking Sydney Harbour. There are many rare and exotic plants and there are usually plenty of volunteers on hand to answer any questions.On this visit we went through the new Calyx exhibition space that replaced the old glass pyramid. It currently houses a living green wall made up of thousands of plants that illustrates the history of chocolate. Beautifully presented, with many interesting exhibits. Also of special interest is the Fern House and the nearby Orchid House.Free entry to the gardens but there is an entry fee to Calyx, with a discount available if you book online. We dined at the very good cafe onsite. An excellent meal for reasonable cost; wait staff, who seemed to be mostly young backpackers, were pleasant, very friendly and courteous. Highly recommended.

A walk close by the city but miles away. We usually visit botanical gardens, or national gardens etc.. in most major cities we visit. Sydney has one the most beautiful settings of any we've seen. I would save that Melbourne has more plant diversity and numbers but for location this is ideal. Its the 200th year anniversary of the gardens, so check it out!

Nice walking park. Took most of a day to explore the Botanical Gardens. So many trees to view and birds to observe. The restaurant was efficient and delicious. Too many tourists lined up for a good picture of the Macquarrie Chair. People forget others want a chance too. Saw a few wedding parties there for photos and one ceremony. Great view of the Opera House and Bridge from the bay. I think there needs to be two gates open to access Government House. I realize it is probably for security reasons, but we walked all the way around the whole darn thing and then found we were too late for a tour.

A peaceful visit. It has been a while since we visited the Botanic Gardens and we found the environment to be better than we remembered. The new Calyx was really interesting with an amazing vertical garden and the general gardens are well kept and beautiful. It was a lovely place to relax and enjoy nature.

Sydney and Mother Nature at its best . We visited on Sunday after a long absence . ( I use to come as a child regularly, my husband and I use to come here for romantic picnics, out door movies , and a few glorious weddings all pre children) On Sunday with Sydney weather at its glorious , I decided that the family could be out in the sun shine , walking and taking in the rose garden , the duck and eel ponds. Seeing incredible ferns, the chocolate exhibition( who doesn't like free chocolate and a chance to see a wall of Lindt chocolate whilst learning incredibly interesting history about chocolate. )not to mention the incredibly gorgeous indoor vertical gardens Whether your a visitor to Sydney or have the gift of having this beautiful parkland on your doorstop. Take advantage We walked , we marvelled , we ate at the cafe , we all got out in the sunshine ( without the internet ) and got reacquainted with a priceless gem. I have visited many botanical gardens throughout my travels around the world. This one is special as it shares space with our magnificent harbour. Looking forward to returning soon. It's just like catching up with an old friend you haven't seen in a while and picking up where you left off. Questioning why you don't make the time to truly enjoy yourself more often. Highly recommend

Best Botanical Garden I've Seen. I'm not much on botanical gardens, but the gardens in Sydney are wonderful. I spent an afternoon wandering around the grounds. Many unusual plants and lots of people watching. Strolling around the gardens is both interesting and relaxing.

Beautiful inner city walk. The botanical gardens are just out of the city and are beautiful haven that is a perfect place for lunch on a week day or a slow meander on the weekend. Go early on the weekend though, that's when the tourists are there en masse.

Simply solendid. I am so glad i was in Sydney during spring season. Flowers were blooming in the garden and the smell of flowers are oh so divine. Great landscape and great view of both Sydney Opera House and Sydney Bridge. Entrance is free, so go and smell the flowers

Great meanders . I seriously could not face any more shopping haha ! So I got an alone day with only myself to please. I especially enjoyed wandering around this gem . The spring gardens although slightly past their prime were still outstanding. If you are time poor see the kiosks at the entrances and they will help you plan ☺

Wonderful park to spend the afternoon. . We came here to enjoy the sun and found a lot more. There are many interesting species of trees and flowers and as a new traveler to Australia its great to see the variety of birds.Bring your best walking shoes and definitely visit the fernery.

Beautiful place to explore. Wow, these gardens took my breath away. They are so beautiful. We spent 3 hours here but didn't see it all. You must walk to Mrs Maquarie's chair and make a wish!! The plants and trees are gorgeous and there are lovely statues etch. The cafe is good too. Just wish these gardens were in Manchester!!

Beautiful gardens in a beautiful spot with exceptional views. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a dream. You can walk along the shore of Sydney Harbour right next to the Sydney Opera House. In the gardens there are specimens of all kinds of trees, bushes and flowers. You can even take a tour with a guide if you want to and even ride a road train around the gardens. If you want to see all of the gardens you will need to give a couple of hours to see everything. Take my advice and after seeing the gardens walk along the harbour side promenade around to Mrs Macquarie's Chair about 5 to 10 minutes away. The Governor's wife in the colonial days used to sit here and look out over the beautiful harbour - I wonder if she was dreaming of home?

Lots of plants, space and walkway paths to meander along. A gateway to other suburbs. If you walk from The Opera House around to Surrey Hill, The art gallery, museum, and St Mary's Cathedral.....walking along the waterways is a good relaxing meandering path. It is picturesque and relaxing.
I enjoyed seeing the military ships and the vista of other suburbs like Wooloomooloo.

Love a good walk. Wow amazing started walking enjoyed looking over the different plants from various regions. Love the eels in the pond. Found we could pay $10 ea for a great ride and history tour on the red train. This was a must the young lady took us all over.

A relaxing, beautiful garden. Numerous walking paths allow visitors to wander through a variety of plantings in this 200-year old garden. Unique endemic species as well as a succulent, fern, tropical, and herb garden all add to the variety of this public treasure. The garden also provides habitats for numerous bird species, allowing often easy observation of many individuals.The garden is a delight to the senses as spring fragrances were in abundance during our visit. Free tours are offered by knowledgeable volunteers twice a day in spring and summer. Check their web site for other activities.

Nature in Sydney. The Royal Botanic Gardens is a must see for all travellers to Sydney. Commence at the State Library and walk around or thru the gardens to Lady Macquarie chair. view the harbour scenes all the way to the Opera House. If walking thru the gardens you will see native plants to Australia. Also lots of statues and lovely gardens as you walk around the beautiful winding pathways.I really suggest you visit here. I have been here many times and each time I feel revitalised by the beauty of the gardens and surrounding bay. The stark contrast of the CBD also is picture perfect.
Lush and vibrant. Beautiful gardens best done on foot but the little train (not just for kids) is also quite a novel experience. Worth wandering around and taking in the views too.

Definitely add this to your top to do list in Sydney!. The royal botanic gardens are stunning, and a must see in Sydney in my opinion. Located just beside the opera house, it's simple to fit in. There are so many different sections to explore, you could spend 30 minutes or 3 hours in the gardens, depending on your interest in plants. Even if you just want a great photo opportunity of the opera house and bridge, this is a great choice.
Beauty all around . Great park to walk and talk and observe the flora and fauna Right near circular quay A splendid day out

Beautiful gardens. I walked through here after a light rain storm and it was spectacular. Amazing flowers, and you'll see exotic (to me) birds which. It is a nice place to take a walk, enjoy the scenery and just clear your mind.

Botanical garden of high quality. Extremely nice place to visit - a "must" when in Sydney. We walked there every day. Really good collection of plants an a good introduction to Australia's flora. Nicely kept in all ways. And free of charge.
Peaceful walk. I am glad that we haven't missed this spectacular garden.Each path and stairway holds its own secrets with different trees from all around the world.Touch,smell and explore.

Nice place to relax on a warm Spring or Summer day. I am so thankful to live nearby to the Botanic Gardens. The Gardens are lovely to walk around, sit down to relax and read a book or do exercise during anytime of the year. I like to go during the warmer months and soak up the sun. The views of the harbour and Opera House are iconic.

Very pricey; rude staff. Tickets cost $15 for an adult with discounts for children and seniors. A bit expensive for what you get. It really is a very small garden inside a temperature-controlled environment. Nothing like what you see in Gardens by the Bay in Singapore. The tour would not be more than 15 minutes. There is a feature called Sweet Addiction which is a slightly unique offering and you get free chocolates which is a plus. There is an interactive video area which we tried and enjoyed, however, a rude staff named Annaleise told us to hurry up and leave as she has a class to do for a small group of kids! There was no sign anywhere indicating that if a class was to occur, visitors should leave. Besides, we were there first and no one else was in a queue waiting for their turn. I got upset and gave my feedback but there was no manager there so I had to write my comments on a piece of scratch paper which the other staff gave me and I was so sure would not be passed on. Granted this was the only thing we enjoyed in that experience, it was such a disappointment to get that kind of rude treatment from their staff. Please, more training on respect and customer service!

Blooming in Springtime!. The grounds are extensive but they have helpful maps to guide you along the way, especially if there's a specific section you care to visit, from the rainforest to the tulip garden, to the desert plants. It's peaceful and lovely.

Must see!. Little did I realise the layers of history and importance this garden holds for the City of Sydney. As the Royal Botanic Garden welcomes its 200 years birthday, it's a MUST VISIT on anyone's itinerary, tourists or locals alike. There're tours lead by volunteers, and you'll discover a gold mind of enjoyment, on a both meaningful and scenic journey, through this natural wonderland for all seasons.
Beautiful gardens that are free. Many Botanical gardens charge you, this is free and it's a nice walk. It's also downtown so it's very convenient to get to.

A beautiful escape on the edge of the city. The Botanic Gardens run from the edge of the city all the way to the Opera House. The meandering pathways give many different views of the harbour and the surrounding city. there are free guided tours and constantly changing exhibitions and events.
Beautiful. Was great. Was feeling down and great to feel insignificant again in the grand scheme of things. Would go again.

Beautiful. Walked through here on our first day. Just listening to the tropical birds flying around with views of sunset over the harbour and opera house was majestic. Loved see wild cockatoo in the trees.
Relaxing. Just a stones throw from the city the botanic gardens is a good place to chill. Find the spot were you can find the bridge and opera house it's amazing.

Lovely park with beautiful views. Don't think of this as a big flower garden but rather as a large peaceful park with ponds and nice views of the harbor. It's a very pleasant place to visit if you have the time. Begin your walk at the Opera House and make it as long or short as you want it to be.

Gorgeus gardens. Although we didn't have much time to spend in there, so glad we did it! The gardens are just next to iconic Opera House and Harbour Bridge, which made it a bonus. We had a perfect stroll on a warm sunny day and we loved it. Pay close attention to the local wildlife!

LOVE. Its priceless, its wonderful. Also have dined at the restaurant. Lovely surprise. Walked through also to watch ellen within sydney. I once dreamt i was going to a ellen show. In the dream, i waz at the ellen show. Woke up, and was like the GODS are crazy.
Great jogging route. Perfect for a midday jog, with views of the opera house and harbour bridge. Also home to diverse range of pokemon.
Always gorgeous. Amazingly expanse of gorgeous gardens any time of the year, and the view over Farm Bay and the harbour is an added bonus. Particularly lovely in Spring.

Royal Botanica Gardens something for everyone.. The gardens are a great place to relax. Stoll amongst the flowers. Sit watching the harbor. Dine at the café. Sit by the ponds and at all places watch the birds. Right next to the iconic opera house and circular quay.

Beautiful park & gardens nestled in the centre of a beautiful city. Stopped in as part of a tailored day tour of Sydney (Spendour Tailored Tours) for a quick visit to take in the views fro Mrs Macquarie's Chair & brush up on local aboriginal & settler history behind this lovely area. Great spot for picnics or just to walk around the foreshore admiring the amazing views.

Just Beautiful. These gardens are a great showcase for the trees and plants of Australia. They are laid out beautifully and maintained to a high standard. Paths lead you around the park and areas are well signposted. Just gorgeous on a warm day

Beautiful and worth a look. Didn't want to do this but so glad I did! Just gorgeous, and a wonderful way to walk off a big brekkie! So many different and sculptural areas to experience - plus the wildlife. Saw water dragons, wild ibis and cockatiels - would definitely recommend. Just a beautiful and serene place to visit right on the harbor.

The best picture. This place is worth the visit because it is very nice, but specially, because it has THE picture of Sydneys skyline, and specially, the Opera with the bridge behind, so, you take a nice walk on the park, enjoy a couple hours and get a great souvenier of the trip. I liked it.

Beautiful gardens. If you are in Sydney, I think visiting these gardens is a must do. Often they have art shows and different exhibitions. Lovely to just stroll around, have a picnic or read a book. You can walk around gardens then down to the Opera House. Highly recommend grabbing a Messina ice-cream before or after visiting here. They are located outside gardens opposite Ferry terminal
lovely to visit for a chill out picnic or walk. well worth a visit. stunning views lots to see and easy to get to from the train station if visiting from outside Sydney

A distracting walk on the edge of the city. The gardens are a gorgeous fringe on the edge of the CBD linking the city and the harbour in a relaxing and peaceful environment. It would be easy to spend longer in here than you intended, it's a beautiful and distracting antidote to the hectic city only a few hundred metres away.

Beautiful and calming. Whether you spend a short time walking through or a long time lingering, you will enjoy your time in the garden. There are several unexpected treats throughout the garden, which make the time more pleasant.
Very Good. A very pleasant park to walk around, within easy reach of the city centre. It also has a good shop and cafe.

Wonderful gardens in the middle of Sydney. Do not miss.. This is a wonderful garden in the middle of Sydney. A real jewel especially if you walk up from Hyde Park. Lots to see and enjoy. Many green houses and lots of different pants to see and admire. Each one has a botanical tag so you will know what you are looking at. Nice cafe in the middle of the garden. You can also walk to the Opera House easily from the gardens along the bay.

View of splender. The Sydney Royal Botanic Gardens were spectacular. The weather was perfect and the views from the gardens were fabulous. Easy walking from Circular Quay. It is hard to believe that it is so close to major roads as there just wasn't any road noise. It is such a peaceful place to visit.

Sydney Lover.. A must for any traveller to Sydney.If you arrive by cab,train, bus or ferry this is a really relaxing area of central Sydney with great views.Combine this with a visit to the Opera House (next door), The Finger Wharf, Circular Quay and The Rocks on a short walking tour and you won't want to leave Sydney.

Spring in the garden . I always try to take a walk in the garden every time I visit sydney. This time is in early spring. The experience is beyond I could describe. The colour, the scent, the deep blue sky and shimmering harbour makes very of your brain cell on a 100% happiness.

Beautiful Scenery - Relaxing Atmosphere. On a free day during our Australia tour, my wife and I started with a leisurely walk through these beautiful gardens which were just across the street from our hotel. As the day progressed there was a nice crowd - clearly both tourists and locals. There are a lot of separate paths - but enough maps around to prevent you from getting lost.

Beautiful place to spend an afternoon. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a great spot to spend an afternoon or evening. We were there in Spring as some of the flowers were just beginning to bloom. The Gardens are very lovely. The Gardens are also in close proximity to the Sydney Opera House as well as the Circular Quay ferries. Take some time to relax there.

These garden are well kept and a great place to relax. Most tourist will walk around, but you need to stop and just watch harbour life go by on one of the numerous seats that await you to fall sleep on. Great place to go for lazy Sunday afternoon. Shops are not cheap so bring water.

A lovely place to relax in the city. Never tire of going to the gardens, always changing always something beautiful to see. In such a wonderful setting near the Harbour the views of the water just wonderful! I really love the cactus display!

A great stroll. We walked right round the gardens. Tried out the micro function on the new camera on some exquisite flowers. Sat and relaxed watching the boats going in and out of the harbour. A great relaxing place to be.

Beautiful gardens . We were very impressed with the variety of flora on show here and the kids were delighted with the various statues dotted around the gardens. The views from various spots of Sydney's iconic vistas were amazing and the gardening staff most friendly. Although the weather was showery and overcast the gardens turned on an impressive display of which the whole family were very much in awe of.

Beautiful park by the Sydney Habor. The Botanical Gardens are an expansive park in a prime location. Full of beautiful flower and plants while also providing beautiful sights to the Opera House and Harbor.
Beautiful day. Beautiful way to spend a day exploring all of the different areas of the Botanic Gardens, once finished you can walk around to the Opera House for more stunning views.

An oasis in the city!. The Botanical Gardens are beautiful, especially in Spring. There is always something going on from Operas with amazing views to exhibitions, walks etc. The views of the harbour from this point are stunning.

Piece of Paradise. Always stunning, always engaging and always something new to look at. With Sydney Harbour as the backdrop, the City skyline above the Gardens are a oasis to adore and absorb every time. Always doing new exhibitions. #garden200.

Pleasant Stroll, Lovely Views over Sydney Harbour. Lovely Oasis in the heart of Sydney City. Ideal for a stroll to view the variety of plants, have a picnic and enjoy the views of Sydney Harbour. The Opera House on one side and the Art Gallery of NSW on the other side - Lovely Botanic Gardens. During Summer they have Moonlight Cinema and Opera productions. Very special indeed!
Park by the water. This was a lovely walk through the gardens ,viewing some great plants and trees and not to forget the birdlife.it leads you towards Sydney bridge so well worth a visit.

Peace and tranquility in the hear of Sydney. Just 5 minutes from the CBD is the real heart of Sydney. This park is spacious, beautiful and has some of Sydney's oldest trees. It also houses a wonderful shop and has a history all of its own. It's celebrating its 200th birthday this year so it's also home to some of Sydney's oldest introduced and native plants. Volunteer guides are also around at specific times.
One of the best Botanical Gardens!. These gardens are huge and well kept. To walk through it, is fantastic! At certain spots you will see beautiful views of the bridge and Opera House.
Very well kept . The grounds of the botanic gardens are very large and well kept. Beautiful spot for a walk with great views of Sydney.
Beautiful. Loved coming here with the kids , we were able to take it easy and stroll through the beautiful clean gardens .. lovely

Well worth a visit on a nice day . Thoroughly recommend a walk through the gardens. The views and the beauty of the place are superb and it makes a great break from the shopping and madness of the city central. We also went to the chocolate exhibition in the gardens. Was very interesting and done very well. Probably a gardeners interest rather than teenagers.

Beautiful. At the moment there is a spring time walk through a section of these beautiful gardens. I was there on a fine sunny day and it was glorious . Follow up your walk by going across to the state library and view the Gardens exhibition which is first class. This exhibition traces the history of Australian gardens but also documents outstanding current ones. A great way to spend at least half a day, the botanic gardens and then the library.

Last day. We went to the botanic gardens on the last day of our holiday and Sydney really turned on the weather for us. It was beautiful walking around the gardens in the spring sunshine and exploring all the various areas and displays. I had two teenagers with me and it was a highlight of their holiday!

A cooling area on a hot day!. Walking from the Opera House, along the shores of the Pacific Ocean up to the Botanical Gardens is an experience that induces the walker into a trance of marvel by just looking at the enormous variety of plants and flowers and now and then, stop at the Cafe/Restaurant in the middle of the gardens to try a delicious meal or a refreshing drink.
Beautiful trees, birds and nice sea view. We liked the royal botanic gardens a lot. You should definitely take a walk, and breathe in the air.
Sunny stroll . Beautiful, well maintained gardens with loads of variety. The grounds were well signposted and is a must do when visiting Sydney.

Beautiful trees. Went for a few hours. Unfortunately, it started raining. The gardens are beautiful with lost of different trees, flowers and plants. Saw a tree with cotton on it, which was very cool!

Glorious in spring. We wandered through the gardens which are in full bloom at present. I was pleased to see the new signage around local plants, including in the area with the flowering grass trees (complete with spiders and birds feeding on the flowers). We visited the new Calyx Centre which as some informal displays of the gardens from the past plus a display on chocolate. This exhibition seemed a bit overpriced, although the glasshouse of Sth American tropical rainforest plants was worthwhile. We also visited the glasshouse which told the tale about the Palace that was built in 1879 and then destroyed by fire three years later. A fascinating part of Sydney's history.The highlight of the day was watching some young men strip down to their undies and jump into the harbour to rescue a small flock of very young ducklings while the duck parents wandered about looking for them.If you have an hour or two to spare, I would strongly recommend the gardens at present. The shop is worth a visit as is the cafe.

Gorgeous Garden Oasis. This is the 200th anniversary of this magnificent garden accessible from city streets or down at Circular Quay near the Opera House. The flora and fauna are magnificent and the groups simply beautiful. This is a perfect spot to sit, walk and/or contemplate the beauty that is Sydney.

Relaxing Greenspace. This greenway made for a beautiful walk. It offers some great vantage points to get harbor views. On a bright day, the afternoon sun is a disadvantage for opera house photos. Go early in the morning for better opportunities. The early Spring visit meant everything was very green. Just a little disappointed in the lack of flowers. It may be better later in the season.

Nice city gardens. Nice gardens in the heart of the city. The botanical gardens offer a nice walking path and a variety of flowers. There are also some art installations that are interesting. They are free and worth a walk through.

Simply WOW. Even on a rainy day!. Just to walk around, grab a cup of coffee, have a picnic or eat your lunch in a scenic park.. This place is a amazing, clean and full of wonder with various types of trees, plants and flowers. We walked around in a rainy day and managed to get some great pictures of the opera house, learn a bit about aussie vegetation and get some great pictures of beautiful scenery. Loved it!

Had to visit again . These gardens are beautiful with very old large trees. I visited a few years ago and had to go back. It's a large area but it's possible to do a small part of it to get a sense of its beauty. You can pay for a trip on a "train" if you want to see the whole area.
Very relaxing. We explored the Gardens at a slow and leisurely pace taking in the things that we found interesting. The views are lovely and in Spring there are lots of flowers in bloom.

Relax and enjoy the city from a different perspective. An Oasis in the middle of the cityWalk run picnic eat and just enjoy this special place in our city Walk around the waterfront walk and soak up Sydney from a different angle. A must do for down time
Nice garden and very nice view. You can walk and look at thecplants and trees. The view of the water , you can sit and realex at the park.better to do in a nice day.
Walk. We had a beautiful walk through the gardens to Mrs Macqueries chair at the point. The view again was incredible and the gardens /trees/shrubs really interesting.

Beautiful tea break. . I was entertaining an international guest & our meeting was postponed by 1/2 hour so we walked over to the botanic gardens dipped in a hot coffee & enjoyed the wonderful harbour views & beautiful surrounding nature & sculptures.

Lots to see. It is a beautiful and peaceful place to visit that is just so close to the city. In addition there is always some type of special exhibition or walking tour available. Definitely a nice place to spend a few hours.
Rose garden . We had a lovely walk to the rose garden and along to the opera house. The flowers were just starting to come out. A good walk for a sunny morning

If you want to relax..... A delightful place to just wander or sit and relax and take in the stunning views of the harbour and Opera House.There is always something going on in the gardens by way of exhibitions or displays.At this time of year it is really colourful.

Great place!. The Gardens are so nice! There are a lot of flora and fauna. It is really clean and green. You can go there to have a picnic, take a nap or just sit and enjoy the view of the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge.
Shady and peaceful. Always a great walk in a tranquil environment leading down to the sea and the opera house and along circular quay

this is the place where Mrs Macquarie would lie back and think of England. here is the view of Sydney harbour you must visit once at least, Mrs Macquarie's Chair , here on the hot days in Jan old Mrs Mac would lie back in the shade drinking strawberry harbour rum waiting for another shipload of convicts to come in, to replace the ones that did the Harold Holt to Parramatta , here you can sit down and have a picnic and see why she enjoyed this spot so much

If you think Melbourne is pretty, do a running tour of the Gardens. Did a recovery run post the Sydney marathon and was awarded with fantastic views and a great running circuit. I could spend hours in here.

Harbourside and city views. The Royal Botanic Gardens must be one of the best value attractions on offer in Sydney - entry is free! You can choose to follow the harbour-side path that winds its way from the Opera House, past Mrs Macquarie's Chair, practically all the way to the Art Gallery of NSW. Alternatively, roam across the grounds to the many niches and botanical treasures scattered in the gardensOur group, including eleven overseas guests, chose to visit over several days. The gardens are a short walk from Circular Quay. The grounds are extensive with a superb array of trees and plants. The paths are predominantly wheel chair friendly.
Fascinating. Even if you aren't interested in plants, this is a fantastic city-centre green space to explore. There's a great cafe too.
Nice Botanical Gardens. Quite large and has interesting plants, but not so appealing for teens. Lots of beautiful places to just enjoy the day, and lots of rare plants.
Suites many activities. Lovely for a picnic, a walk, run or jog, Lots of info on all the flora. Visit Mrs Macquarie's Chair will you're there.

nice and spatious collection of trees and plants in park like setting. Although this is more a park than a botanic garden, the large green area in the middle of town (with the most expensive property prices) is pretty and relaxing.

Great way to take in Sydney (wheelchair friendly). I visited with my family for my birthday. We hadn't been to the gardens in 20 years. We parked at the domain and we had easy access to the gardens. The eateries were delightful and easy to access in a wheelchair. The views were incredible and it left me wanting to return as soon as I can. The staff were helpful and we learned a great deal about the history of the garden. I'm so glad that Aboriginal culture is embraced and showcased. A treat.

A garden missing the wow factor but a great place to visit. The views and the pleasant walks are a reason to visit at any time of the year and in any weather. I seem to remember there being more floral displays on the past. The pathways, if used carefully, allow for access to all parts of the garden with minimal uphill gradients.We had been interested in visiting what was the tropical glass house, now the Calyx, but were not willing to pay for this small collection. I trust this extravagant piece of architecture didn't cost to much as it adds little to the garden and should be free.The gardens shop was well stocked with quality items at reasonable prices.

Very beautiful Garden. It's a beautiful garden .. You can take a 15 min train ride which will take a full round of the park ($10) or you can just take a walk... There are places where you can capture the opera house and the bridge at the same time.

No trip to Sydney is complete without a walk through the gardens. I would suggest anyone traveling to Sydney take a walk through the Botanic Gardens - if only for the wonderful views of the Opera House and Bridge you get at the bottom of the garden. I am only giving it 4 stars as they shooed off the fruit bats which were my favourite part!
Nice place on a sunny day. Nice gardens with great view of harbour. Nice place to walk through on sunny day. Not far Kings Cross so easy to walk to Opera House via the gardens

A tour of the Calyx. My sister and I were treated to a Tour of the Calyx, a relatively new feature of the Gardens. The exhibition was all about chocolate production! The plants were gorgeous and luscious, felt like we were in a warm rain forest, the various 'plant' animals were pretty amazing! Congratulations to Dale Dixon and team.

Calyx Sweet Addiction Royal Botanic Gardens. Agree with other review. This is a disappointment. Large sculpture entrance and pond which is lovely and then its downhill. In you walk to find out you can not buy a ticket ($15 or $9.50) with cash , go back to the Cafe to purchase. There is a machine that will take your credit card though. But its just not worth it. Very small glass house display with plants on a wall, and jars colourfully lined up in rows - and that's it. A free Chocolate machine (which was left in the sun ! ) and out the door you go.The Botanic Gardens are wonderful, and you get the feeling this area is really a Function Centre for Events. It should be free to wander thru with a small cafe and voila ! - it would be great.

A good place for hideout in the busy metropoliton. Nice walkways for jog. Landscape well taken care of, trees growing strong, flowers are blossoming although spring has yet to come over to say Hi. Nice place for catching pokemon too... we hv got nice viee of the harbour, harbour bridge and rivers. An afternoon well spent.

Trillion dollar views and a stunning place to spend time. . Running around the foreshore of the Royal Botanical Gardens in Sydney is one of my favourite things to do whenever I'm in Sydney. It never gets old! The views are amazing, the gardens are looked after perfectly and there is so much to do. If you run or walk, run and walk around the gardens. If you want to have a fun picnic with your family or a big family reunion the Gardens are for you. A true icon and in the league of Central Park, Londons Hyde park, Barcelona Gaudi Gardens as one the greatest Gardens/ parks of the world! Don't come to Sydney and not go to the RBG!
Sydney Break. The Royal Botanic Gardens is a must to do when in Sydney, its relaxing and you surrounded by beautiful Sydney sights. Great place to see.
Great place for a stroll.. Great place to take a stroll with view of the harbor and free to visit. The place is well maintained and also has a great spot for pictures.

A Must See. So, yes, I am into pretty gardens and landscapes. That said, this is an attraction that everyone will enjoy. The combination of the manicured lawns with fabulously wonderous tree specimen are sure to thrill anyone. Add to this the fact that the garden lines the water and you can see how this is a special place. The park is also filled with curious and friendly cockateels and other little parrots that literally will land on your hand or shoulder if you bring some bread or seeds. Just the best, trust me.

Lovely Gardens, Fabulous location. I recently took my grand-daughter to Sydney for a visit, and went to the Royal Botanic Gardens. The location is great, being right on Sydney Harbor and right beside Sydney Opera House. While there we took the 20 minute imitation train ride (costs about $10) around the gardens with a good commentary throughout, hopping off and on at the various stops to look around and get a coffee and ice cream. Although we didn't do any, there were free guided walks, etc. It was a very pleasant way to spend the morning.

A Place of Beauty. This to me is the most glorious place to visit in Sydney. I have been coming hear all my life and have never tired of it. The quality is world class and it has such deep historical roots. This place is apart of me and always will be. A true treasure for an already beautiful city. Take the time to enjoy it and notice how good you feel after your visit.

Lovely views of harbour. Nice way to spend an afternoon in Sydney. Walkable from our hotel at the Rocks. Very pleasant botanical gardens where you can walk along the harbour and see many of the Australian white Ibis.
An oasis in the middle Sydney. Easy to find these gardens . Slap bang in middle of park .. Very well maintained . Great to while away an hour
Rest and relax. Acres of lawns, gardens and quiet nooks here to spend a couple of hours on a hot Sydney day. Really worth the time.
Gorgeous gardens. Gorgeous gardens and it's free! The walk offered amazing views of the city. We loved exploring the themed gardens.

Beautiful views of Sydney Harbour and the city. A lovely way to spend a relaving day. The views of the harbour are amazing. You will get great photos of the city, as well as the gardens. Any time of the year there is always something interesting to see.

A Right Royal Visit to Beautiful Botanical Gardens and Calyx Exhibition. What can be more inspiring, relaxing and beautiful than spending a sunny hour or two in this very special place in Sydney. Wonderful flora, lawns, trees, colour, pathways and vistas to soothe and relax the spirits in this now 200 year old haven - all with Sydney Harbour's Farm Cove in the background. A must visit is to the marvellous Calyx Exhibition which not only gives a history of cacao agriculture and chocolate making, but displaying a spectacular wall consisting of 20,000 plants forming differing patterns, colours and textures. A must place to see for any visitors to Sydney as well as a great morning or afternoon visit for locals.

SCENIC FLORA GARDEN. Royal botanical garden is a very big garden having variety of species of flowers and trees. One can pleasantly traverse the entire garden looking at both sides. Many spots are good for photos addicts and the other end of the garden lead to opera house. It looks great during the evening to view sunset. A must see for Sydney travellers.

Chu chu train in the Garden. I went to Sydney on September. The weather was perfect. I love garden so went to the botanic garden but, the garden is massive and takes time to look around. But there is perfect way to look all around the garden in 30 mints which is red little Chu Chu train. It's fun for kids and adults. The driver gave us lots of information during the tour. Why don't try to get on the train?
Stunning spot for a picnic. I can not believe this place exists in the middle of the Sydney City madness! With lots to do and to see! perfect place for families with small children.

Spring is the best time in the gardens. It is amazing how beautiful and peaceful it feels in the Botanic gardens considering it is so near to the heart of the city. There are always lots of people but, you will always find a spot to relax and have a picnic or just sit and enjoy the views. As a free amenity there really is nowhere nicer.

Beautiful . These gardens are absolutely beautiful and walking around them is a great experience. From some locations inside de garden you can find some of the best views of the opera house and the bridge, great for taking pictures.

Great for a lazy day in the sun. There is a great loop to walk from the city, through the Botanic gardens, down to Mrs Macquarie's chair and past the Opera house. You could easily spend anywhere from 1 hour to several, depending on activities. There are some stunning spots for picnicking, both in the Botanic Gardens themselves, however those special are down near Mrs Macquarie's chair overlooking the harbour. For those not bringing food, The Opera house has a number of eateries nearby, however there is a kiosk at Mrs Macquaries chair and a number of cafe's restaurants dotted throughout different corners of the gardens.

My favourite place to enjoy Sydney harbour views. In Sydney for the weekend and made the most of the beautiful weather by wandering through the gardens. The gardens are beautifully maintained, feature so many interesting plant species and offer numerous vistas across Sydney harbour (our favourite is from Mrs Macquarie's seat. The fact that it is free and so well set out with paths means it an experience that everyone (families, couples, disabled) can enjoy. Highly recommend spending an hour or two here when you visit Sydney,

The beautiful Botanical Gardens. We visited the Botanical gardens several times in August. The gardens are exquisite with beautiful themed garden areas like the rose garden and the camellia garden and palm grove to name but a few. There are glass houses too. Walking through this spectacular garden is so uplifting with wonderful views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. We visited the Pavilion café in the Domain which is next to the Botanical garden. Here you can sit outside and enjoy excellent coffee.

Free and fun. If you are Sydney take a couple of hours to visit the gardens.If you start at the south entrance and walk through the gardens you will see some amazing plants and wildlife ( a colony of flying foxes) , a great shop and lovely cafe and finish your walk by the Harbour with fantastic views over the water , the Opera House and the harbour bridge.Well worth the walk.

amazing place. i went there in april 2016 because i get my residency i traveled to australia, and the weather in this month was so nice and i can say that the garden was so unique that i didnt see before such an amazing place including unique flowers from this area and a view to opera house

Beautiful gardens in August.. We walked the gardens in late afternoon. It was beautiful. Well worth spending some time there. Take a picnic lunch and sit and enjoy it. i hope we get to return and experience it in other seasons. I can only imagine...

Take a rug and lie in the sun. . Beautiful gardens to relax in and escape the noise odd the city. Lovely views over the harbour and plenty of open grassy places to rewild a little, kick the shoes and feel connection to mother earth again. Take a picnic and great for a romantic daytime date.

Wonderful. This is one of the nicest botanical garden I have been to. Wonderfully kept with huge amazing trees and multiple ponds The proximity to the bay makes it even more fabulous. This is the perfect place for a stroll in a sunny day. I found the eels in the pond particularly interesting. Quite a change of scenery from the usual kois.

Peaceful. Such a peaceful place in the middle of a busy city, when we ravel down to Sydney, we pack a light picnic lunch, visit the art gallery of new and then sit in the gardens, relax and enjoy our picnic overlooking the harbour in peace and quiet.

A paradise within a busy city. This is a beautiful experience even if gardens are not your favourite. They are well laid out, easy to get around even in a wheel chair and there is both a restaurant and a cafe

Spectacular lush gardens at the foot of the harbour and city. Perfect location, superb gardens for strolling, picnicking, jogging - any time you need to reconnect with greenery. The pools with their giant waterlilies are full of eels and fish and water birds. There are many paths crossing the gardens as well as running around the harbour. And with the multiple access points you can drop into the Opera House or NSW Art Gallery or the Boy Charlton swimming pool. The Spring flowers are superb. This is a special place so close to the city. Just check the gate closing times so you don't have a long walk out if you stay too late.

Surprise Fathers Day Picnic at Iconic Location. My family treated me to a surprise Father's Day picnic on what turned out to be a glorious day in the beautiful Botanic Gardens. The Botanic Gardens Cafe offer a service whereby they will provide you with a picnic rug and a basket full of delicious food to enjoy inter gardens. We sat under a tree down by the water with spectacular views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. There are many areas to explore including the new Calyx, the Succulent Gardens as well as the Eel Pond where if you're brave enough, you can stick your finger in the water and pat the Eels.

A must see of the area. These gardens are absolutely gorgeous! Don't miss the small train tour. The train driver/ tour guide was friendly and full of information on the area. The views of the Harbour and Opera house from the train are amazing.
Botanic Garden Free Walking Tour. 10:30 walking tour guided by Jill was great - informative and just the right bayou the of tme. Lunch at the Garden Cafe was a bonus!

Nice pleasent walk after the Opera house.. Interesting walk after being stroke by the Opera. Pleasent with interesting flora and fauna. There is a pond with eels and some very unusual birds in another dry pond. Worth walking for a while or jogging around.

Royal Gardens are very special. We walked the entire Royal Botanic Gardens and sat in Mrs Macquaries' (sandstone) Chair at the very spot where she watched for ships entering the harbor. The gardens are lovely. Plan to enjoy them.

City Escape. My husband and I took the River Cat to Circular Quay on a Sunday and strolled to the Gardens. The high point of our wanderings was visiting the Calyx. It was a wonderfully interesting and informative experience as well as enjoying the beauty of the wall gardens. A most original concept. The gardens were so well maintained except for the herb sections which were in need of some rejuvenation and new plantings as well as better labeling of plant names.As there appears to be only the restaurant and one other cafe in the gardens it would be beneficial to have either a coffee cart or pop-up food outlets around the waterfront and other places to serve refreshments.We also wondered about the difficulties of elderly people accessing the gardens as it is a massive area for aged people to walk around. Are there any transport options for elderly or disabled people to use?On a positive note we thoroughly enjoyed the wide open spaces and the feeling of total relaxation as we discovered many little hidden areas as well as the magnificent old trees which must hold a wealth of history in their branches.We'll be back for sure!
200 years is a big deal. A garden that is maintained so well for 200 years is definitely one of the things to see, nice to walk from city to opera house
Beautiful place. Quiet scenic and historical ...the place should be included in your iternary ... Or st least a walk through it . It's a great spot to take pictures.

A place for the people to relax and be educated. Stunning 200 year old landscaped gardens beside the central city and on the harbour at Farm Cove. Wander for hours, or just relax on the lawns. Eat casually or at a restaurant. Expore the pavilions or visit the amazing vertical garden at the Calyx.One of teh world's best city gardens.

Lovely Garden and a relaxing walk. The Sydney Botanic garden is very well set up and great location with a view to the seafront and the Harbour bridge. The first vegetable plot in Australia was set up in the garden with the historical facts showing on the boards was rather interesting, also the stolen generation history was quite eye opening what and unfortunately how our forefather think and doing things that we will never even thought of. It is a worthwhile visit to the gardens even just for a walk with the beautiful flowers, vegetation and environment. The improvement can install a couple of toilets in a few places for convenient. Otherwise it is a long walk back to the toilets.
Good Review. It is close to Sydney Opera House and Harbor Bridge. You can see the ocean at the end of garden. A good spot for a weekend family picnic!

Sweet Addiction Display. What a disappointment! We love the gardens and were keen to see this new exhibit. Decided to make it a family trip on Fathers Day. The garden wall was lovely but took 5 minutes to walk through it. Considering the cost of entry ($17.50 adults and $9.50 concession)we were not impressed. Gold donation would be more than sufficient.
Walk through the Park. Royal Botanic Gardens are absolutely beautiful especially at this time of the year with many plants beginning to flower. Particularily the hippeastrum put on a delightful show.
Lovely walk. Worth walking to the Gallery from Circular Quay through the gardens - the garden shop is a treasure trove and the seeds purchased will remind me of my trip as they grow.

Beautiful garden so close to the city. I spent a lovely few hours wandering the paths meandering around the garden. A magical location on the harbour to the east of the city and Opera House. Would highly recommend to anyone.

Heritage tour. A new perspective on the tragic story of the Aboriginal people of Sydney following the arrival of the settlers. Leon Burchill was a top class guide who painted a picture that we won't forget. The gardens are beautiful and the setting iconic. Gardens were free to visit, the tour cost but was well worth it.
Must do.. A walk around the Royal Botanic Garden definitely figures in my must do for Sydney. If you can go for morning walk and then for a breakfast at Botanic Garden Restaurent.

Great place close to the center. I walked from the Opera area and found myself in the botanic gardens
A beautiful place with great views towards the harbor
I saw a sign about a daily tour at 10:30 with an aboriginal guide which sounds very interesting

What a wonderful afternoon. We spent an afternoon strolling through these gardens, exploring its huge collection of plant life and also people watching.
I would recommend this to anyone who wants a quiet day out while not leaving the city.

Lovely location, clean beautiful park. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a great location right next to the Opera House and Circular Quay, covering a large area and offering a variety of paths to follow for a great walk, whether that's along the waterfront or through the Park itself.The views are majestic and the Gardens are clean and well maintained.It's normally busy of a weekend and mini trains run for those who won't want to walk.It's the perfect place to go a walk or jog and is close to plenty of other Sydney attractions and public transport. Whether you're on your own, going for a romantic walk or a family, this is a great choice and a memorable place to visit. Public toilets are also available within the Gardens and cover is limited so I wouldn't recommend during rainy weather.

relaxing walk through the Gardens. After we marveled at the Opera House grounds we walked right through the road to the Botanic Gardens. It's a well-kept place with benches and a pathway for hikers and joggers alike.

Fabulous . Thoroughly enjoyed the gardens. Lovely walks very accurate sign posts re how long each walk is. Beautiful view along the coast. Free activity peaceful surroundings. Stench by pond not great though

Flora, fauna and vistas aplenty. I visited the Royal Botanical Garden on a glorious day in late August 2016. I was amazed at how much there is to see and the sheer beauty of this green oasis in the heart of Australia's largest city.The garden was far larger than I had imagined and I could have spent a whole day exploring and still not seen everything it has to offer. to cap it all, there are also spectacular views of the Sydney Harbour area and the city.

Take the ChooChoo train for a quick tour of the gardens. These gardens celebrate 200 years in 2016. They claim it is the most visited public gardens in the world. This is a HUGE park, so take the train for a 25 minute overview and stop at Mrs. Macquaries' chair for a spectacular photo op.

Botany, history and beauty. This is one of the most enjoyable gardens around. But it's in the middle of the city, easily accessible by different means of public transportation and a short walk to everything in downtown Sidney.
Nice walk. Quite a nice place to walk around. Also don't miss the sunset around Farm Cove, you cant miss it there are a lot of people there for pictures!
Beautiful. Not a lot to say other than its lovely. Great views, great walks (or runs). Put on your itinerary if it isn't already!

Enjoyable wildlife experience . For none locals this park is beautiful. But has a wide range of native trees and animals. The birds in particular were a thrill to our family with cockatoos and rainbow lorikeets landing on our shoulders with the odd ibis and pigeon being friendly too. On one visit there was also a fruit bat very active during daylight. The pond fish plus eels were an experience too. Lovely experience of local nature with fantastic views.

Stunning Gardens. I couldn't believe how beautiful these gardens are with such a variety of plants and flowers. I got lost at one point because it's so huge and I had entered at one point but exited near the Sydney Opera House. Plan on spending several hours here taking a leisurely stroll through its magnificent grounds. Be sure to take lots of photos. There are benches and places to sit throughout the gardens if you find yourself tired.

Beautiful cool southern hemisphere plants.. Botanical Gardens in Hobart is always a wonderful place to visit. easy to walk around in with some wheelchair friendly paths. something is always in bloom. "Must see"is the Antarctic plants room, with acclimate control the same as Maquaire island, such an interesting little room!!! ( But wear your scarf and and coat!) Lovely reminder of grnd 19C gardens. Stop off in the orchid house - its amazing!

I love this place, it is my back yard!. I live in Sydney CBD and it brings me so much pleasure to walk through these gardens. They are literally a couple of blocks from the hustle and bustle of the city. I never cease to see something new every time I walk through.It is a must do when in Sydney.

The Calyx at the gardens a must visit. We visited the gardens on a Saturday morning and found the tulips in the garden a blaze of colour. However the main reason was to see the display at the Calyx, It had a theme based on the jungle and chocolate which was very informative as well as been stunning in the presentation of planting especially the wall.This is a must visit with a camera which sadly I Left at home.

Royal Botanical Garden. We visited Royal Botanical Garden last week. it was very fantastic experience, the garden is very beautiful, clean, tidy, and many of old trees and lot of open space with background to the Sydney Harbor and sea. The entry gate is near Macquarie street, which near our hotel at Intercontinental at Circular Quay. You can walk through the route with clear information sign in every intersection. There is also many birds which can be closed with you. We really recommend to you to visit this very nice garden when you stay in Sydney.

Definitely worth a Visit. Entry to the Royal Botanic Gardens is free and definitely worth a visit. It is very tranquil and the air is fresh as I believe smoking is banned! As the place is big, do keep in mind the closing time which varies depending on months, so as to prevent being accidentally lock in! Mrs Macquarie's Chair provides a vantage point for photo enthusiasts to catch the beautiful setting sun!
Nice place to stroll.. Has a walk through here with my wife over the weekend and loved it, we are not green thumbs by any stretch but appreciated the gardens.
Visit Mrs Macquaries point for good views.. A lovely place to visit to see tge plants, wonderful birds and amazing views of the bridge and opera house.

Surprised . We were really surprised by the gardens especially as our teenage sons enjoyed them. We loved looking at the plants and the boys were wildlife spotting - parrots, bats, fish and eels! It was a really enjoyable afternoon finishing off with a delicious treat in the cafe.

Great day out. Plenty of information on everything within the garden, lots of things to see and in a great location. Food is available but it is close enough to circular key that you could easily walk to the city for food. Great day out, would definitely recommend to anyone who enjoys a relaxing day out!

Beautifully maintained gardens. It was a pleasure to walk round such well maintained gardens. As the gardens are large you may not be able to see everything in one visit. The spectacular views from the gardens of Sydney's iconic sights (Opera House and Harbour Bridge) are am additional treat, Well worth a visit,

Great place to stroll around. I really enjoyed my walk through the Botanical Gardens. It has been meticulously maintained, and there are small billboards around the area. I lost track of the time while here and spent a few hours walking around. Perfect for a lazy day.

A day in the sun.... The Royal Botanic Gardens have a wonderful place right on Sydney Harbour where you can picnic, wander the grounds, admire the trees and flower displays, stop for a bite to eat or just a coffee. There are water areas and ponds and sunny spots or secluded areas to picnic. It really is a lovely space and has been visited many times before but a garden you can just keep going back too. Great for families, couples, sports people and singles alike.

Aboriginal Heritage Tour. The Aboriginal Heritage Tour was a great way to enjoy the gardens. Learning about native plants and how indigenous people used and/or currently utilize these natural resources was interesting and important to not only those who live in Australia but also those who are visiting. Well worth your time and money!

Great place to relax. Botanic Gardens is a great place to relax... is "big" so if you really want to have a good time plan for at least 2 hrs. unless you just want to "run thru". There is a train that can take you to a quick tour.. but beware that they DON'T take credit cards... for the tickets...There area lots of "peacful" places.. wonderful views.. keep in mind that they close around 5-6pm (at least during this time of the year).
Well worth a visit. Lovely walks around the garden and just off the harbour and Opera House with stunning views. Bit of an incline in some parts so not good if mobility problems?

Fun to explore. I don't know my plant names. There's something relaxing about walking through the gardens -- but this one has extra interest. Picturesque view of Sydney Harbour and Opera House. Path right along the ocean. Interesting rocks at the Mrs Macquarie's chair area. Some flat areas, some slopes, ponds and different collections (tropical, herb). Park benches with a view. Still very close to the city. And the birds! Wild Cockatoos by the dozen in the trees, colorful lorikeets too. Many flew down and interacted with us.
Excellent experience. Took in the Royal Botanical Gardens on one of our many walks. Beautifully set out with amazing plants and wildlife.

Beautiful gardens - why wouldn't you go?. The Royal Botanic Gardens are wonderful. Its more of a park than a garden (though there are some very gardeny areas), and it offers a break from the hustle and bustle of nearby downtown Sydney. I like it because its big, green, peaceful, it has lots of [to me] exotic plants and flowers. It also has the backdrop of downtown Sydney nd its right up against Sydney Harbor. There's a greenhouse and some terraces, and some other things. It really is a beautiful garden/park, and I'd recommend going there. After all, it's right next to the Opera House, and you're probably going there anyway. In late May and June, part of Vivid Sydney is in the gardens, and that is certainly a sight to see. In short, go to the Royal Botanic Gardens - you won't be disappointed.

Lunchtime Strolls. Working directly across the road. This is where my Lunch's are spent. Amazing grounds, very clean and neat. Beautiful plants, trees and flowers. A lovely walk around the harbor front to Mrs Macquarie's chair.

Peaceful and Beautiful. Even in the Australian winter these gardens are fantastic. Huge and incredibly well maintained. Took me a couple of hours to walk round and they had a train tour as well which was ten dollars and would have been useful for those who didn't fancy the long walk. Beautiful views out across the bay and a perfect scenic view of both the Opera house and Harbour bridge. Lovely place to go for a picnic or just to chill. Plenty of benches to sit and relax. Would recommend taking own drinks as the cafe was quite pricey. However the gardens are free entry which makes it an ideal location to visit for those on a budget!

Beautiful . The gardens are enormous! Well maintained and inviting. (Your allowed on the grass!) Great views of the Opera House from Mrs Macquarie place, only downside was the tours buses full of tourists, who were quite aggressive in asking people to move so they could get their perfect pictures.

The place to think and just relax. Royal Botanic gardens are the place i will never forget. Nice place to think or just relax. I would stay and walk all day long. Beautiful flowers threes birds grass. Worth a visit and shoot a snap or two. Also there is the signs saying please walk on a grass. Enjoy Royal Botanic garden experience.

One of our best days in Sydney. I was so surprised to find that there was no cost to enter the Royal Botanic Gardens (other than special exhibits, like the Sweet Addiction exhibit in the Calyx). We happily spent the day wandering the trails throughout, discovering different flora (and fauna--we had a decidedly unexpected wildlife encounter when a baby possum fell out of a tree near us, poor thing. We're happy to report he was okay!Do take the "do not feed the birds" signs seriously--we found some folks were trying to get close up photos with the cockatoos on the grounds by offering them tidbits. And at first, the cockatoos were very willing to perch on folks and pose...and then they got a little aggressive.

Large & Well Stoked Garden. We walked through the gardens at lunchtime and were impressed with the scale and variety of the plants. The signs were frequent and helped us navigate our way round the gardens. There were a number of interesting birds visiting the ponds.

beautiful and relaxing , one of my favorite places. we go to Botanical Garden a number of times a year . Was there last week and the tulips and Orchids were beautiful. We always walk around the Garden especially along the water side, usually spend an hour or so there .

Very beautyful and professional arrangement. It was a pleasure for me and my wife to enjoy very beautiful and professional arrangement of these gardens, as well as to expand our knowledge in Australian flora
Botanical Gardens are a must see. Every time I travel to Sydney I take time to walk around the Royal Botanical Gardens. The setting is spectacular.
Relaxing in natural beauty. Was amazing to relax and just take in the tranquil atmosphere of such beautiful gardens, hard to believe the city is so close!

Well worth a walk and lunch. We enjoyed walking around these lovely gardens on a very hot day. Of special interest was the fabulous cafe. The herb salmon was amazingly tender. Lamb shanks and focacia bread were also much appreciated. Make a reservation so you can get a table next to windows.

Fantastic place. As we walked through the Botanic Gardens, we were astounded by all of the plants, and the incredible numbers of birds that were allowing the vistors to hand feed them. It affords beautiful views of the Opera House and the Sydney Bridge.

Very nice. Lovely gardens with plenty for everyone to see. The gardens were so clean and well kept. Make sure you visit the chair on the end of the gardens. Many different sections to look around and there is a small train that takes people around for those less able. Really lovely place and great views of the harbour in a less busy environment.
Boring. Botanic gardens nothing more special than any other botanic gardens nice plants but really no biggie

Stunning walk. Fantastic way to get through to art gallery and lady Macquaries chair where I used to dive into harbour to swim till a diver got taken by a bull shark so don't stay in the water long. Try the many pools around harbour that are free. Salt water pools

Beautiful scenary. The gardens are a great place to take a stroll on a warm day. The grass shines, the flowers flurish, the harbour waters twinkle and the views of the Sydney Opera house with the Harbour Bridge in the background are immense. For nature lovers, there are various areas in the gardens, with different trees and plants. There are also several ponds, statues, waterfalls and green houses for you to explore. For those who are less keen to walk, there is land train that will take you around, and up to the Opera House. There is also a small cafe offering snacks, lunch, hot and cold drinks overlooking the ponds with inside and outside seating areas. This is a great place to relax and recharge the batteries for more exploring.

Nice Relaxing Walk. We arrived in Sydney on an overnight flight from LA. Our room at the Intercontinental Hotel across the street from the garden was not ready. So they said we might enjoy a nice walk around the gardens. We found this garden well laid out with lots of trees, flowers, statues. With great plaques and signs describing what you were viewing. They also had a nice little coffee shop on the grounds. Also the signs have maps telling you where you are now and how to get around. This is a must see garden.

Gorgeous Even in Winter. Its a lovely place to visit, whether you are a gardener or not. The plants and birds are a sight to behold. The outlook on to Sydney Harbour is breath-taking. The shop has lots of gifts and seeds to plant.
Really beautiful place. We spent a whole afternoon strolling around this beautiful space and stopped for refreshment in the cafe. There is a really lovely gift shop there too.

Beautiful Botanicals.... A haven in the hustle of Sydney and Circular Quay. Somewhere to wander into from the Opera House or head to for time out.For newbies it offers a plethora of native and non native trees, plants and birdlife lying next to the harbour with amazing views out. It also had my hubby and I in tears with the history boards, quite profound the paradigm of effect from our own history books or lack of the opposite coin recorded. I was not impressed by the cafe, thought it could be so much better given the amazing surrounds and captivity of visitors...maybe that's the problem! We wandered through the shop and spent some coinage there then continued through and out the gardens to the art gallery.My one disappointment this time (2nd) was the lack of bats, I was mesmerised by them on my 1st visit a few years ago. I so wanted to give my other half that same experience but it seems they were the cause of much mischief and had to go...I can imagine, if I were to work near by, this would be the place I'd have my picnic lunch with a good book, if I could take my eyes away from my surroundings...also a place to enjoy photography/sketching/painting/discovering...

Looking its best. I don't think the Royal Botanic Gardens have looked better than they do for their 200th anniversary celebrations. Many gardens have been revitalised and replanted and hours can be spent wandering from place to place. We visited TreeCycle - an exhibition of arts and crafts made from culled and pruned timber. We will certainly return regularly for future exhibitions.
Chocolate Experiece. Great opportunity to see how chocolate is made from origin the tree, the pod and the processes it goes through; to the final product delicious.

Beautiful gardens and walk along the harbor!. If you don't want to take an organized tour, just take a leisurely stroll around the harbor then up into the gardens! Very serene and different views of the Opera House and harbor. I especially loved finding the cockatoos all munching in a section where I could get some great close up photos of them and watch them interact with each other!

Fantastic 'Green' Experience. Beauty all around! Even though we went in Winter, there was amazing colors and beautiful greenery around. There is fair bit of walk so ensure easy shoes. There are various good photo locations. There is also a governors mansion and you can enter as long as there is no private event on. Behind that, there are some more beautiful views. This can be done in conjunction with Opera house adjoining it.

Best on a Sunny Day. It's the 200th Anniversary of the gardens this year and there are now a lot of new attractions that have been built. Spectacular views of the harbour and you would not know you were in the middle of a city.

Outstanding Natural Beauty.............. You could not get a better example of gardens anywhere in the world with sensational views of the world's best harbour all within walking distance of two of the world's most famous landmarks, the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge.Well maintained and planned gardens with a variety of local and imported plants and trees make a visit very worthwhile. Plenty of space to get away from the maddening crowds and to enjoy the peace and quite as well as the views from all areas of the gardens.You can even enjoy a meal and/ or coffee from one of the cafes that are situated in the gardens or close by.A great place to visit and highly recommended.
An afternoon stroll. Beautiful gardens surrounded by water and the city skyline. Good bird life and flora and fauna. Bring a picnic on a lovely day and you won't regret it.

Beautiful place to relax, right in the middle of the city. This review has two parts: one with an appeal to Sydneysiders and one to travellers.To locals: we often tend to forget to enjoy some of the local spots of our beautiful city, which is a complete shame. I've overheard so many saying "One day is more than enough to get to know Sydney!" and I think to myself... "What?"Sydney has heaps to offer (sadly for night party animals this city might be a bit dull as some of our rulers are complete idiots), from the parks to the sights to the food. Out of all these I love the Botanic Gardens. After I've been to a meet up or going to the CBD for any reason I spend a while walking around the garden, laying on the ground or just looking at the beautiful sight.To travellers: once you have walked to the Sydney Opera House, you are (literally) steps away from these beautiful gardens, lots of local fauna and an enjoyable relaxation time. Walk from SOH (Sydney Opera House) to Mrs Macquarie Chair, the breeze takes almost any problem away (with the exception of feeling cold if you are not properly suited) while you walk away from the noise of the city. Once on Mrs Macquarie Chair, look back at the Opera House and be amazed at the beauty of this the scene, with the Harbour Bridge as the background of it all.At that moment, you could escape for a quick swim on the lovely pool next to it (you'll have to pay) or get a cultural afternoon and just escape quickly to the Art Gallery of NSW.Best views are around dawn and sunset (I prefer sunset).Enjoy!

One of the best places to hang out in Sydney. This is one of my favorite places to go in Sydney. A great place for a run, walk, bike ride, picnic, a read, a game of ball, a relax. The view is to die for and the plant life, artwork, and gardens are amazing. You can run through the gardens or stay a whole day. Breathtaking with history and natural beauty.
