Always enjoyable and relaxing. Tge Royal Botanic Garden is always worth a visit no matter what the season.Really cool plants, nice strolls, cool bat colonies and perfect views across tge water. What more could you want from a park? Top notch. :)

Royal Botanic Gardens--Sydney. Beautiful and serene 'in city' gardens. A short walk from the Opera House, the gardens are well maintained and clean. We also found the gift shop here to be among the best in the city for original souvenirs. Also, lots of space to run and explore for kids.

I've seen this too many times but srill enjoy it. I used to run around this part of Sydney for decades during my lunchtime. You can become a little bored with a daily jog but never in this location. Plenty to see and do.

Beautiful gardens. These gardens are beautiful and we only saw them in winter, I bet they'd be stunning in Summer. But still had lots of plants flowering.Loads of places to walk and different parts of the garden to see.Lovely spot to have a picnic lunch while overlooking the harbour. Lots of room for children to play too.

Relaxing environment. Well arranged gardens with lots of space to enjoy the sunlight and fresh air on a fine day. The area along the waterfront is the most beautiful with a good view of the harbour. Perfect place for exercise or simply a walk to refresh your mind.
Beautiful. Plants Flowers Trees. Just beautiful to all around and relax or enjoy lunch outside. Some exhibits cost extra
Beautiful. Such a lovely spot to walk around, you don't realise you're in the middle of the city sometimes! Definitely worth checking out on a trip to Sydney.

Thankyou to all involved! . Our visit to the Gardens coincided with a day of blue sky perfect weather. The Spring Flower Walk was a picture - as was the Palm Garden and many other areas. A beautiful way to spend an afternoon!
Want a few days ago. I went with family and a friend and we thought it was amazing we all loved it and had some real good experience there. Would recommend.

The best view of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. Near the Mrs Macquarie's Chair, there was this spot in the Royal Botanic Garden where we could enjoy the iconic view of both the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. We were there for the sunset. We spent about 2 hours there just to wait for the sunset and for the sky to turn dark and lights to turn on at the bridge and opera house. Taking up a stroll to this place and it was really amazing to listen to the sound of the waves with this breathtaking view of the city.However, kindly take note that parts of the Royal Botanic Garden follow strict visitation hours. Only the domain is open 24 hours to the public except for special and ticketed events.

Special moments . The gardens are very well looked after and a great way to spend an afternoon. I had a special moment where a group of cockatoos came to rest around me and it was so lovely to see them at peace with the world around them. Lots of interesting plant/bird life. There is a cafe available in the middle should you need refreshments.
Nice view and walk. Nice walk, very relaxed, good for sportand opera view. Very safe and also nice for a short brake. Lots of bars and restaurants inside and close by. Nice breeze in summer.

Beautiful gardens with sea views.. My husband and I spent a good part of the day walking all along the walk along the harbor beyond the Sydney Opera House, returning back via the beautiful Royal Botanic Gardens where we saw many beautiful trees, gorgeous tropical plants, as well as several cockatiels, a juvenile great blue heron, and many other beautiful varieties of birds. The grounds are meticulously maintained with some of the best views of a Botanic Garden I have ever seen,
Amazing . Could spend all day there, so beautiful, relaxing, maintained so well. Absolute must see if you want amazing views too.

Take time to walk the gardens. Even though we were walking the gardens in a winter month, they are still beautiful. We only wish we had more time for our visit there. The park is huge, and though in the middle of the city it is amazingly well insulated from traffic noise once you are away from the entrances. There are all types of plantings, small lakes, and lots of birds around. The park is right by the Opera house, so it is easy to fit both in. If you enjoy nature and have liked botanical parks in other cities, you could certainly enjoy several hours or more wandering this park.

Beautiful makes you feel a million miles form the city. The royal botanical gardens is celebrating some sort of anniversary and they have it seems to me cleaned it up for the occasion making it even more important a place to take a wander than before.

Walk in the gardens. Pleasant few hours wandering the gardens just looking at the area and enjoying the atmosphere. Plenty to look at. The areas are well maintained and clean. Lots of people about but not crowded.

Beautiful. A real must when visiting, especially on a sunny day. Make sure you walk all the way round to Macquarie's Chair and take in the views.There is a little red train you can take around the park but not really worth it as gardens not that big and very accessible to all.

Beautiful and Romantic . I would definitely recommend to anyone visiting Sydney to devote an afternoon to the Royal Botanic Gardens. It's really lovely. I particularly enjoyed the Rose Garden, the Herb Garden, and the pond. It's perfect for a romantic stroll, or spending some time relaxing, talking, or reading. The Art Gallery of North South Wales is also within walking distance, and is a nice addition if you are looking for other things to do in the area.

Beautiful!. One of the highlights of Sydney! You must visit here if you are coming to Sydney especially on a sunny day. The contrast of the nature of the gardens and water against the city buildings is quite a sight!

Incredible Visit for Plant Lovers!!. I was visiting from Seattle and walked through the gardens at the last minute....How impressive!! I am a gardener so it was an instant love for me. I was there during the winter months but was so amazed at the variety of plants. I wish I could go back during more of the "blooming" months but the cacti/succulent garden was my favorite and then found the begonia garden....so many favorite spots. Well worth the walk through.

Royal Botanical Gardens - Sydney. Beautiful, peaceful, great views of Sydney Harbour. Fantastic plants and trees.There are restaurants to eat great inexpensive foods. Often there are evening musical shows in the gardens.

Very Relaxing. With different species of trees, flowers and birds, you will surely enjoy staying at the garden. It's a perfect spots to jog, read books, do yoga, picnic with family or just watch the sunset. The atmosphere is so relaxing and rejuvenating that you would just want to lie down or sit back and savour the beautiful scenery.
As good as in Melbourne. Even though not as big as in Melbourne, but the ambient is almost the same. You can imagine in a paradise with all the green tree and flower and lots of bird.

Serene, visually enticing, perfect!. You must set aside time to stroll through the gardens. I can only imagine what it must be like to work in Sydney and walk through the gardens to and from, as I saw many people doing. It was so serene, with something interesting around every corner. A must see not just for the gardens but also great views of the Opera House and Harbor Bridge.

Beautiful . What a great place. Perfectly manicured lawns, huge variety of very rare plants, a lake, monuments, multiple paths to follow. There are many ways to enter and exit the park and since it's so close to the opera house and the port it would be nice if one can combine them together
A good scenic walk. Especially on a spring/autumn day. Also hosts great events year round, and is a good walk to the Art Gallery, pools, Woolloomooloo etc
Relaxing. Something for everyone here. Great place for a picnic or if you came on the fly, there's always the cafe. Beautiful gardens.

a perfect Sydney day. A walk at any time in the Botanic Gardens and along the harbour front is great, but perfect on one of those sparkling Sydney days as in last week. Add in a walk in the grounds of Government House for something special.

The most beautiful park in which I have been. Great Park to the Sydney Opera House and the business district . There is a wonderful view of the bay of Sydney. Besides the many trees there are many birds and a flock of cockatoos. Very good place to relax ...

Peaceful beautiful gardens. This is a great location to wander, jog or improve your botanical knowledge. It is centrally located, very close to the Opera House and Circular Quay. The views of the harbor are stunning. Keep to the left on the pathway and listen for joggers coming up behind you. There are lots of birds in the trees to enjoy. I really liked the water globe in the Herb garden. You walk around the inner circle to turn it on. I will be going back when I can. I enjoyed the walk through and just enjoyed the peace.
Beautiful . We had our final day in Sydney here. A bitter sweet end to a fantastic year. Beautiful to walk around and a a great picnic spot in front of the bridge. Defiantly go.

Perfect on a Nice Day. The Sydney Botanic Gardens and the Sydney Opera House are very close together and close to the City. From the Opera House it's a walk down the steps and a turn left and you're in the Botanic Gardens, which also overlooks Sydney's beautiful Harbour. Obviously best on a sunny day. The Botanic Gardens have several sections of different flora. There are Cafe's and in the Summer, many events, such as outdoor plays and Open-air Cinema. If you walk "too far", you will end up at the NSW Art Gallery or another wonderful "play" area of Woolloomooloo.

Free attraction!. The Royal Botanic Gardens are beautiful and in a great location, particularly to get good photos of the Opera House. It is free to enter the gardens and we spent a couple of hours there. There were lots of people jogging at the time we went but there's room for everyone.
With a five year old?. Just passing through on foot but Yes, he loved it. We picked up a few brochures from the volunteers and went bird spotting.
Best Park. Beautiful place. Got little herb garden as well which heals your stressful mind. Better to go during warm day. Cold during winter cause it's next to sea

Gorgeous!. The Botanic Gardens are right next to the Opera House, so easy to see both on the same day. The gardens are large and there is a walk along the waters edge. In the summer there is an open air cinema showing movies on the big screen, and also Symphony Under the Stars is held. Both really great to do.

Botanical Garden Sydney. There are two Botanical Gardens located in the Sydney area. One is geographycally in the Western part of the Greater Metropolitan Sydney area, and this Botanical Garden is beautifully located in the City of Sydney, right on the harbor fore shore. Stunning views towards the City, the Harbour and across the Harbour. The Garden itself is well maintained, has beautifull exhibited plants and trees from a wide region of the world. There is a nice Restaurant, and other Amenities located within the Garden. Entry is free, and the place is very popular with Locals, partcularly on the weekends and public holidays. Definitely worth a visit.

ONE OF THRE GREAT WALKS. There is nothing better on a sunny day than to take the walk from the Art Gallery down Lady MacQuaries Chair , through the Botanical Gardens and onto the Sydney Opera House. The views are spectacular and the gardens are a lovely spot to stop for a picnic.

A breath of fresh air.. The Royal Botanical Gardens offers wonderful walks and pleasant scenery. There are several different entrances and exits.You can start at the Opera House and walk around the cove to Mrs.Macquarie's Chair which offers a great photo opportunity of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge and Harbour views. Walking back you can head to the Glass house and fernery and Palm Grove.You exit near The Art Gallery and Domain. Other exits are Government House Gate and Palace Garden Gate which exits to Macquarie St,The are several places to eat. The Botanical Cafe near the Duck Pond offers a good range for dine or take away also you pre order Picnic Boxes 02 92412419. It is a lovely place to escape from the City.
Great place on a sunny day. Lovely inner city gardens, plenty of walkways, nice break away from the concrete buildings. Art Gallery worth a visit too.

Relaxing spot. Lovely way to spend a couple of hours wandering round the beautiful gardens to have a break from the city. Worth a ride on the 'choo choo train', which for a small price goes for a loop around the gardens.
Amazing. This was an unexpected find. We were on our way the Sydney Harbour and came across it. So many different plants and birds. loved it

Lovely gardens. We walked from circular quay, checked out the opera house and the Botanic Gardens is along side. We caught a train that drives you around the gardens showing you the main points of interest. This ride finished so we decided to walk the gardens and this was just wonderful, we had lots of stops to take in the beauty and peacefulness of the gardens. Easy walk around the gardens and walked around to Mrs Macquarie chair. Great way to spend a morning or afternoon. Took lots of photos. Just be mindful of the runners doing their thing as they were running in groups. Lovely spot to go to.

Beautiful botanical garden in the heart of Sydney!. Our first trip to Sydney was in March. Of course you cannot miss the Royal Botanic Garden - a major botanical garden located in the heart of Sydney. The garden was opened in 1816 and it is the oldest scientific institution in Australia and one of the most important historic botanical institutions in the world. It is open every day of the year and access is free. It is positioned on Sydney Harbour and immediately adjacent to the Sydney Central Business District, the Sydney Opera House and the large public parklands of The Domain. You can spend hours in this garden. There are many walks with beautiful views of Sydney Harbour and Central Business District. A lot of different birds and specifically Cacadu parrots are everywhere and very noisy bunch. Beautiful garden with beautiful views! Highly recommend!
Peaceful. Meander through the trees ,bushes and flowers ,little ponds ,birds and fishes, very restful and a good coffee at the cafe

Calm, peaceful and magical space. Botanical gardens have so much to offer and many hours could be spent wandering through these beautifully kept gardens. Fabulous parkland, well signed, easy walking track, cafes and restaurants and an easy access from circular quay to the art gallery. Allow plenty of time to simply meander and take it all in.

Lovely walk and views. Enjoyed our walk around the gardens. Great views and wonderful wildlife. Saw lots of birds and different types of trees.Well kept and located close to the Sydney Opera House and the Harbour.
Great harbor views. Great views of the harbor, nice walking paths. Worth it if you only have a few hours in Sydney. It's probably better in the summer, but still worth the time in the winter.

What's not to love?. The RBG are located right alongside Sydney Harbour and the Opera House just a minutes walk away.A bit like Sydney's version of New York Central Park. There's always people jogging, picnicking, office workers enjoying a sunny day. And unlike many places, you are encouraged to walk on the grass. I even use it sometimes to pop the laptop open and sit and work for an hour in the sun.Lots of variety in the plants on display with plants groups into like for like, some nice ponds and wonderful old Moreton Bay fig trees.Cafe and facilities are OK, and don't let the masses of fruit bats put you off.A great way to spend a couple of hours on a sunny day.

Good little area but avoid the cafe. Nice afternoon walk but a little boring if you have small children. There doesn't seem to be any park/ play facilities for children which I thought there would be. The cafe was disgusting. The service was slow and the drinks were horrible and overpriced.
Lovely wal. Really nice to walk though. Plenty to look at. Nice cafe and shop.We were staying in Woolloomooloo and walked to CBD through. You can also get Circular Quay and The Rocks.
A must do. Everyone should visit this place, so pretty and some of the best views in Sydney. Can be done in a short visit or a nice big walk, lots to explore.

Walk in the rain along the Garbour. I visit the Royal Botanic Garden on every visit to Sydney- all my favourite trees remain - I also follow the Director on Twitter re plants and coloured flowers & leaf varieties. Cafe a pleasant place to relax to eat own picnic or bought food. I love walking from the Art Gallery of NSW to the Sydney Opera House seeing the sails emerge in view as you turn the corner walking along the foreshore- lots of bridal groups on a Saturday
Great way to spend the day. Lots to see as far as foliage and lots of interesting spots to discover. There is also a mini-train that you can ride around for minimal cost.

Beautiful Gardens and Relaxing Walk. If you are visiting Circular Quay and the Opera House you should definitely continue your walk through The Botanical Gardens. There is a quaint little cafe if you just want a coffee. You can get breakfast lunch or dinner as well. Make sure you see the Dracaena tree that fell over. You could also visit the Calyx on your walk. We did not do it as we thought it was overpriced.
Pleasant gardens. This runs beside the busy road leading down to the harbour and opera house so it's a relaxing way to walk there without the traffic. Well tended and with interesting plants.

A gorgeous garden with views . We love the gardens and try to visit here as often as possible. The figs are so remarkable, and the gardens are set out in a lovely way to explore. The views back on the opera house and Harbour bridge never disappoint, and it is a peaceful pocket Ina busy city.
A walk. This is worth a visit, though weekends can be busy, crowded and noisy. For a peaceful time here, go during the week. OK when it's winter, but messy when raining.

Perfect place to relax in the sun. So close to the centre yet this small botanical garden is an oasis of calm and tranquility. There are so many areas to explore and the views across to the Opera House and Harbour Bridge are spectacular. There are some wonderful trees as you'd expect and my only negative comment is that many of them are not clearly signed. There's a cactus area, some ponds, lots of beautiful grass and a really nice quality cafe. The birds are quite loud and tame but all in all, this is about as perfect a way to spend a day that you can get.

Beautiful place to spend a lazy afternoon or during weekends. A sea of green and calmness awaits you when you visit the botanical garden. Do not forget to carry your camera, a cap, water , your shades and whatever other necessities you need. You can spend hours walking through the garden and enjoying the sights and sound. Take time to sit under the beautiful trees in their shade and enjoy serenity by being one with nature.
Royal Botanic Gardens. great place for spending hours in natural beauty by the river and opera house.... the entry is free and it's a huge garden with lots of beautiful trees and walkways
Royal Botanic Gardens. The Royal Botanic Gardens is one the most beautiful gardens I've ever saw. It's a great place to relax and see wonderful landscapes. Visually stunning!

Quite nice but not excellent. Joined the free guided walk conducted by a volunteer. The guide who is a retiree is patient though he is quite old. The good news: it is freeDo look out for the movement of the aborigins how they fought hard to be recognized as Australian citizens. Some parts are being renovated in end of May. During lunch time there are many people sleeping on the grass at the Rose Garden. Nearby there are some old statues. Visited it during Vivid Sydney 2016 again but only for the installations because it was pretty dark at night.Overall the garden is a nice place for everyone. There are some cafes there too inside and outside the garden.

Breathtaking views of the Harbor!. If you are visiting Sydney and looking for views of some of the most iconic sites we have to offer then the RBG is for you! Be sure to visit the eel pond with plenty of bread - just don't get bitten! Fantastic day out for the family - be sure to pack a picnic, wear your walking shoes and take a ball to enjoy some of the rolling greens.

Most amazing place. I loved walking around the gardens, seeing plants from various countries, my son couldn't stop going from plant to plant, it doesn't feel as if you're stood in the middle of the city! Coupled with the amazing views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge and its one of the most breathtaking parts of Sydney!

A must visit. Let's keep this review short and simple. Whether you are a tourist or a local, you need to visit the Royal Botanical Gardens.This place is huge, peaceful, beautiful , green, and a great display of a diverse flora. You can sit by a pond and read a book.. knit a sweater or do your favorite craft...listen to music...chat with your friends..take a walk or run around the gardens...view all the beautiful plants...Take a sip of your favorite cup of drink...The only thing holding you back is yourself! Come and enjoy this place

Worth exploring.. A historic and significant heritage site. Great place to wander through and visit the various theme gardens, sites and exhibitions (even on a rainy day). Nice vistas. Take a picnic. Mrs Macquaries Point/Chair for great views of the Sydney Harbour and city. Nice around the main ponds. Interesting horticultural, scientific and educational displays.
Beautiful..... We were from the train station, walking through the garden to the The Opera House. It was a nice walk. The roses were blooming & the weather was fantastic.

Beautiful views. A really nice way to spend several hours in Sydney. The grounds are next to the Art Gallery. The gardens are well maintained. There is a nice restaurant inside for lunch. Wonderful views of the Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge. Must visit when in Sydney

A must-see. I cannot understand why anyone would give this less than 5 stars. The botanical gardens are an amazing free place to visit. If you like plants, trees, birds, etc, and a little history, you will be in your element. Absolutely gorgeous.Earlier review talked about bats (actually flying foxes). They are no longer in the park having been "dispersed". I am not sure the creatures enjoyed being "disbersed" (sounds like a euphemism for something a bit harsher to me) but apparently they were killing trees, and this is a botanical garden after all.

Take a stroll this is a beautiful location.. Take a stroll along the path. Beautiful trees and plants along one side and an ocean view on the other. Lots of benches to stop for a spell. Take your camera. If you walk to the end, there is a bus you can take back to the city.

Lush gardens. Very large grounds with many different areas. I wish I had more time but came here after the Art Gallery of NSW and only had three hours to do both. Great side view of the opera house and CBD. I highly recommend it.

Two hundredth anniversary of Australia's first botanic gardens. How easily one forgets that compared to the rest of Australia, Sydney is very, very old. The Royal Botanic Gardens were founded in 1816; they are virtually in the heart of Sydney, Australia's first city. Access is gratis, The gardens are just yards from the Sydney Opera House, on the harbour. The Gardens are sad to be Australia's oldest scientific institution. If you have a chance to see the Royal Botanic Gardens, take it, the visit is well worthwhile..

Beautiful in any season. My husband stayed near Hyde park for a little "staycation" Easy walk to the botanic gardens.Really nicely laid out with themed areas like a tropical garden, succulent garden, camellias and orchids. Plenty of seating around and wide paths. There are Cafes along the way too as well as a little train that will drive you all the way to the opera house

Gardens lovely as ever, shame about the cafe. Sydney was home till 5 years ago and the gardens a favourite place to visit. This week the gardens looked beautiful as usual but we were very disappointed with the food in the cafe. Nowhere near as good as other cafes nearby eg on Macquarie Street. The staff were friendly but struggling to keep up on a not very busy day. It took 15 minutes for a (very ordinary) ready-made sandwich to be toasted! This used to be an ok spot for a basic light lunch but not now.

Lovely gardens. A huge expanse of green space which is definitely worth visiting to escape the hustle and bustle of Sydney. Not sure if there is a large variety of plants but a lovely park nonetheless with a good walk by the water.

Nature walk. These gardens are absolutely gorgeous...and HUGE! We spent a morning walking around before the Sydney museum opened, and the amount of vegetation, landscaping, wildlife, art, and trails were endless. The bamboo forest was especially intimidating as it was a blustery morning. We had a beautiful view of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House as well as the Navy ships in the bay when we found Mrs Macquaries' Chair. So bizarre for us Yanks to see a flock of cockatoos hunting and pecking in the morning sun. If you love nature, this is a great escape in the middle of a bustling city.

Very relaxing. We walked from the harbour, to the opera house to the gardens. It was lovely viewing the plants in the immaculately kept gardens. My wife visited the shop and was delighted with her purchase. The gardens kept our teenage sons interested.

Good enough for Tom Cruise to film here. If Tom Cruise can finish Mission Impossible 2 here, with balloons and a crane shot, then it's got to be worth a visit, right?Right!They are huge, and easily accessible from the city, Circular Quay, or the Sydney Opera House.A great morning's outing (or afternoon, I guess, but we went in the morning) and away from the traffic and city hassle. Unlike other city-bound botanic gardens, you have the harbour bounding it. Great views from Mrs Macquarie's chair.Highly recommended.
great venue. plenty to see & do, great venue, well maintained would visit this loaction again if holidaying in Sydney, recommended
Great walk in the garden. Had a great walk from the Opera House to the Botanic Garden. Weather was great and there are nice plants and trees along the way. We also saw many cockatoos .
Hidden gem in Sydney!. In the Spring time this is my favourite place to be in Sydney. Amazing views and nice hidden spots with plants and sculptures.

Historic site.. For many years I worked opposite the gardens and loved to go over for a walk at lunch time.Just strolling around really clears your head.Beautiful part of the city and of course the first farm in Australia
Beautiful and well-kept. The gardens are beautiful and they're so big you never feel crowded! The bats are loud and stinky but apart from that, it's a fantastic place for a picnic!

SYDNEY HARBOUR BOTANICAL GARDENS. A lovely spot with the most beautiful view in the world, well worth a visit, maybe have a picnic and it's suitable for everyone, but, try to visit on a sunny day, it makes a huge difference.

Wonderful place to spend a morning or an afternoon in. Not only do the grardens have an amazing diversity of plants (including unusual trees and flowers) from all over the world, but you'll also see fruit bats (also called flying foxes) at close distance. There is a nice restaurant here, and they often have interesting exhibitions. The gardens are within walking distance of the Opera House.

Excellent. An excellent way to spend a day, if you like plants and trees and birds and all those sorts of things you find in Botanic Gardens. But here you are likely to find much more. The Gardens are practically on top of the Harbour, so think of all the possibilities. This is Sydney with many surprises. The Opera House is next door, the whole city of Sydney is five seconds, or less, away. All you have to do is just walk, take just a few steps and you are there in a millisecond, literally.

Not to be missed. Winter, Spring Summer or anytime really is the perfect time to visit this iconic Sydney location. With vistas ahead and behind you it is possible to feel as if you are standing at the edge of the earth. Sydney is at its beautiful best from this perspective. Do not miss this travellers AND Sydneysiders.

one of my favourite place. I love the Royal Botanic Garden in the city found between the Sydney Opera and Mrs Macquarie’s Chair.They are so so well looked after and also a great place to just relax when weather permitting.These garden hosting all sort of plants trees and the famous giant bats will send you amazed

I took my daughter when she was young and it was the best day of my life. The day was sunny and calm, my daughter was young and we had just met for the first time. The garden was full of colour and very peaceful to look at.

Stunning place excellent for a cheeky nap in the sun. Beautiful gardens to walk through , you can go on a little train for 10 dollars I think that takes you from one end to the other , there is a stunning Japanese garden with a cafe near by and if you go to the waterfront you can get a great view of the harbour bridge and opera house

Nice, but Not the big deal at all.... To be honest I was a bit disappointed because in comparison with other botanical gardens this was not so coloured. But it´s a nice place to have a walk on a sunny day in summer.

Amongst the hustle the Gardens are a sanctuary. You recognise history the moment you walk through the gateway(s). Huge trees and old buildings including the Palm house - now a gallery; lace the peace within the gardens with a feeling of convict nurturing - see Macquarie's wall. Thank goodness for the inclusion of botanical gardens and all the green spaces within the metropolis providing a refuge from the dynamic and potent hordes that take to the streets of Sydney.

Beautiful gardens in a gorgeous location.. With views of the harbour bridge, the opera house and the harbour, there are photo opportunities at every turn. Even I, an individual totally disinterested in flowers, plants and lawns, found the botanical gardens very interesting on our latest visit. We actually paused to read some of the signs & descriptions and found the studies very interesting.The view was further improved as there was a police operation taking place on the edge often the park *wink*.

Garden joy.. Top class gardens. Great cafe. Would definitely take little ones to see the wishing tree and fish pond. Take them for a ride on the train, which does regular loops. Get on their websit to check events.

Refreshing!. On a visit to my brother, my sister-in-law & I decided to wander around the Botanical Gardens. Birds singing, a slight warm breeze, families young & old, individuals all wandering to look around. Most amazingly was the noise level was so low. From various angles we could see Kirribilli Point where the Prime Minister "stays" during their time in government; Pinchgut Island, snippets of houses across the harbour.It was so amazing that amongst all this, the noise level was so low, you wouldn't believe that just over the rise was the Opera House full of visitors walking along Circular Quay, many others having a drink or something to eat!The ferries sounded more like a loud hum as they took passengers to or from their destinations as we approached the end of our walk. The little gift shop was a delight to visit with so many treasures to choose from; without a doubt you certainly walk out with something not only for yourself but other family members!Staff members willing to answer any queries about the gardens, sign posts to help with plant names, maps to show where you are within the gardens or a small map to carry with you so you can go any way you like!So if you have some spare time, go for a walk, you'll feel refreshed & better for it! I did!
Fabulous gardens. Another great attraction, lovely walks , lots to see, Beautiful gardens, a must see for Flower Arrangers and gardeners

Beautiful place to visit. Overlooking Sydney Harbour this is a lovely place to walk and enjoy the beauty of Sydney's harbour. You can take a picnic or just walk around the gardens towards the opera house and then have lunch once you get to the Opera house.

Surprise your interstate or overseas visitors and watch their reaction. Begin the visit to the Royal Botanic Gardens from the macquarie street entrance and show them the beautiful different areas of the park then walk toward the waters edge and watch their faces light up with a vision of the Opera house and the Bridge. Dont' forget Mrs Macquarie"s chair. It is a stunning walk.
sunny afternoon relax. a great place to wonder through and check out the different views of the amazing harbor. grab a book and a coffee and chill out
Not a garden buff but can appreciate the location. Get a book, snap a picture, or have a picnic. This place is like a little piece of heaven tucked away in plain sight. Day time is best.

Peaceful spot of green calm in the city (free). Bit of a fan of visiting gardens in every country and these gardens are up with the best. Unbeatable vista with plenty of grass picnic spots with magnificent harbour bridge and Opera house views. Many large shade trees, some benches,rose garden and an arid garden. The glass house (paid entry) is home to beautiful tropical plants and is closer to Elizabeth street. There is a cafe in the centre and a restaurant with small take away cafe attached near the free art gallery. Parking is very expensive so try to walk or bus. Easy access for wheelchairs/prams. Sundays Government house is open for tours well worth a look. Small train tootles around, for a fee , on weekends. Can be busy with weddings and tour buses run constantly up and down the single file Art gallery Road. Friends of gardens have their own shop and there are often botanical exhibitions and talks in the Maiden theatre. Summers has plays and outdoor cinema/opera so it is well used. As it backs onto the Opera House great for a meet up before a show although beware gates close at sunset.

A Sydney highlight with no cost. in good weather this is a great way to spend the day for familes, couples and solo travellers. It is well used and certain areas can be busy ie: Mrs Macquarie's Chair but plenty of space to take a picnic and enjoy the space. Lots of areas to see and if you're interested in the plants that's a bonus. Great educational space for kids as there are lots of signs and information points. I'd recommend it for a half or full day dependent upon the weather.

A pleasant easy walk. The botanic gardens are situated alongside Sydney harbour .It is an easy walk through scenic parkland with great views of the harbour scene and only five minutes walk from the opera house and ten minutes from some great harbour side restaurants . It's totally free although some areas are locked up over night and a good way to fill in a few hours . There are organised tours for anyone interested in the history and varieties of plants and trees .

Come watch the birds by the pond!. If you enjoy nature, then come and enjoy the pond. The birds around the pond are lots of fun. We were there in early June, and the cormorants ( black birds that look like cormorants any way) were nesting in the tree by the big pond. They were fun to watch. There was also a duck family teaching the duckling to hop up to the curb from the pond, and failing. It was just a joy to watch the interactions.

Lovely Garden. I recently visited Sydney for the first time last week. One of the first things that I did was take the Sydney Free walking tour! Very nice tour. It took us all around Sydney. The Botanical gardens were Beautiful! Highly recommend seeing!! Lovely flowers & birds. Very peaceful walk. Must see!!
Great for a walk to chill out. Great for a walk and chill out in the middle of this busy city. So clean quiet and peaceful. Takes you away from city life.

Beautiful Park with lovely cafe and garden themed gift shop. Beautiful park do close to CBD and the Harbour. Beautiful walks and views. There is a great cafe and an adjoining large garden themed gift shop.

Just a look around. Haven't been to the gardens in years. We walked to The Calyx to see the Sweet Addiction which they charge to see. We walk a little to the Garden Shop & then walk down pass the Main Pond towards the harbour wall & wandered towards the opera house. We wish we had a little more time to explore .
Lovely park. A great park for a waterside walk. Sometimes you see weddings in the park or events. It's quite relaxing and great for a picnic as well.

Best walk in Sydney. Beautiful well maintained gardens with the best ever view.A great place to stroll at leisure, taking in the information, stopping for a coffee before venturing back to the Quay for lunch.

Tranquility. What a beautiful spot! Expansive gardens right beside the CBD and harbour areas. Very relaxing and peaceful. Lots of walkways and signage and also bench seats if you want to take a rest or just soak up the sights.
Gorgeous...so much effort put in here to make it awesome.. It's easy to use a whole day here...so much to see and walk through. The chocolate making exhibition was terrific.

Well worth a visit. Took a stroll through the gardens as they were en route from our hotel to the gallery and found them surprisingly good. Could have spent much more time there than the 15 minutes it took to get to our destination.

Best place to get a Marvin/Dory shot of the Opera Houseand Harbour Bridge. The Roya Botanic Gardens is a similar type of attraction found at all colonial state houses. It features a manor, several pieces of installations, making the garden ideal for a romantic afternoon. My rating was given as such because the place is not distinct, and the Mrs Macquarie's Chair is overhyped. Still, it is a decent place to visit when you're in Sydney! Tip: Check ahead if you want to go for a free tour in the state house, sometimes it may be closed for official functions.

I've been over 1000 times. Love it!. I lived near the Botanic Gardens & have visited it over 1000 times. I even got married there & had reception with family/friends at Lion's Gate LodgeI highly recommend taking good walking shoes; a daypack; a lined picnic rug (grass can be damp); water; sunglasses & sunscreen; and some food. I used to stop in at David Jones Food Hall on the way for great bread, salads, dips, olives & vino. It is just near St James train station & you can stroll up to gardens via Hyde Park and the Archibald Fountain & magnificent St Mary's CathedralEnter via the Domain & stop in at NSW Art Gallery (if you have an extra hour or so), then along coastal route to east past the Andrew (Boy) Charlton pool to Mrs Macquarie's Chair. This is great view back to the Sydney Harbour Bridge & Opera House. Keep following the coast path back south to Farm Cove. This is where you'll officially enter the Botanic Gardens from the DomainFind some higher ground & enjoy your picnic. If you find the right spot you'll be able to see Harbour Bridge &/or Opera House, plus all the sail boats and ferries. Then continue around the Farm Cove coast to the Opera House. It's a great way to spend 3-4 hours, but you can walk it in around 40-60 mins otherwise. Have fun!Note: opening hours are available on the website & gates into the gardens will be locked (The Domain is never locked). Unfortunately, they don't open early enough in summer (7am, yet sunrise is 530am). Such a waste of a fantastic walking track

Nice walk. The Royal Botanic Gardens is a great walk on a nice day. There is lots of different paths to take lots of plants to look at, places to have a picnic or just sit down and relax. It's free and fun!

I loved strolling through the Botanic Gardens. There were quite a variety of trees and shrubs that I couldn't quite identify. I looked for some identification plaques around but didn't find any. I would have loved to have had a docent give me a tour.

there is much to do in the gardens. There are actually a lot of courses run in the gardens, which on the first look might not be easily noticed. Aborginal dot painting, bush foods tour, it is a great place to visit.

Finest Gardens. These really are unusually beautiful parklands and gardens. They are at the best in the morning or late afternoon hours when the light is not as harsh as midday. Our only regret, having walked through in July, was that the roses were out of season. Even so, there was lots of color and the diversity of plantings was both beautiful and educational. This is a lovely place to spend time. Many walking paths, benches tucked beneath trees, and inspiring views of the harbor and city.

Leisurely walk in the park. It is easy to spend a very relaxing afternoon in these beautifully maintained gardens. Celebrating 200 years, they have a new addition in The Calyx a glasshouse to grow and display plants not normally seen in Sydney. Special exhibit focusing on chocolate is currently on at The Calyx. A leisurely 15 minutes from The Calyx walking mostly through the well sign posted gardens you can take in Farm Cove, you pass a monument signifying where Queen Elizabeth II first stepped on Australian soil and then continue onto Mrs Macquarie's Chair, a location that provides one of the better viewing points of the harbour.A great place to take in the city skyline, the garden's plantings and the fresh air.

Not to be missed - See Sydney Harbour from a different angle. Lovely Layout.My main purpose of visiting Sydney on this visit was to walk around the Botanical Gardens. I entered near the opera house, and walked along the side of the bay and around to Mrs Macquaries Chair. The gardens are well laid out, plenty of open space, quiet areas away from the crowds, and plenty of shade to site under and take it all in. The blot on the landscape was walking past the Opera in the Bay, metal fences and block plastic sheeting was everywhere. The bins had been covered up, and food and waste was just lying next to the bins. Obviously no one had bothered to collect the waste. Returning to the opera house I walked on the city side pathways.Well worth a visit, just to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city and circular quay crowds. Great views of the bay, and from the furthest point great views of the city, opera house and bridge.

The trees are beautiful, many kind of birds. It is next to the Opera House. The park is very big and the plants are beautiful. It is very comfortable, you can just sit or lay on the grass. You can play with the various kind of birds. You can spend whole afternoon in the park if you have time. You can see both Sydney bridge and Opera House at the point of Mrs Macquaries Chair.

Cradle of Sydney. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney are an enduring memory for me since early childhood when my parents held my birthday parties there.There are wide open spaces for children to play as well as lovely duck ponds .One perimeter borders Farm Cove-part of the foreshores of Sydney Harbour .Adjacent is Lady Macquarie's Chair which offers commanding views over the Harbour.For horticulturalists the Botanic Gardens are a must

Beautiful and peaceful. We spent several hours of a sunny and cool afternoon enjoying the garden. It's very peaceful and relaxing. The next time we visit Sydney we want to take one of the guided tours to learn more about the garden, which we also cut through every chance we got while visiting nearby parts of the city.
You're never too old to learn something new. It's nice to see different plants and herbs from around the world. The botanical gardens is a nice place to sit and have a sandwich as well.

Beautiful gardens. My hotel in Sydney was in Woolloomooloo so I walked through these gardens each day to get to the CBD and main harbour area. The gardens are beautiful and immaculately kept. There are a few sights to see within the gardens and some of the best views of the harbour bridge and opera house can be found by walking though the gardens. The cafe serves good coffee.

Lovely Gardens. I tend to visit Gardens in every major city of Australia. They are all different and all seem to focus on certain plants. Any garden lover will have a great day. The food and coffee can be expensive though.

Hugh park and good photo spot. Very relax and quiet park next to the city. The Calyx (Chocolate exhibition) opens 10am-4pm each day. Garden shop also closes around 4pm. Don't miss the Macquiries point where you could take photo with Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Best period is in the morning. Tripod and flash are required for late afternoon photo, as the sun sets behind the operahouse.

Beautiful way to experience Syndey - with a family. I love these gardens - by the water, spectacular views of the bridge and Opera House, stunning flora. The Gardens tend to meet all of our family needs - there is plenty of space for the kids to roams and my husband and I to meander and slow down. For me it is a piece of peace in the buzz of city life. The stroll along the water from the Art Gallery to the Opera House is just beautiful.

Perfect place to walk around leisurely and get great views of the Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge. One of my favorite things we did in Sydney was walk along the Royal Botanical gardens and see the Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge from this vantage view. It was absolutely beautiful, and it helped that the weather (in winter might I add) was about 73 degrees Fahrenheit with little to no winds. It was perfect!

wow what a location. Take your time and enjoy this location in the city the gardens are well maintained with plenty of park areas to enjoy picnics overlooking the harbour at Sydney the botanic gardens are spectacular

Magnificent trees and well planned gardens throughout. You can enter these gardens from different entrances so be sure to collect a map of the gardens overall. Apart from some very majestic and certainly mature trees (one of which is simply stunning) the plants, bushes and flowers have been carefully selected to maximise the visualise brilliance of this area. (I was saddened to see a sign saying that if you see any thefts being carried out, you needed to report these to the authorities.) Simple seating, benches and unobtrusive arbours are available for relaxation. Lots of opportunities here for ornithologists - and budding artists.

Probably 5stars in the spring. We went on a beautiful day.The garden was lovely, I just wish it was a little more colourful, perhaps during the spring and summer it would receive full marks from me.I have nothing to complain about and would look forward to seeing it again. The best part of it is that it is so big with so many trails that you can go multiple times and enjoy new sights.If I go in the future I would try and get a free tour thata run at 10;:30 daily from the info kiosk.

Glorious gardens and views of Sydney Harbour . A sunny Monday morning in Sydney was the excuse for my son and I to visit the Royal Botanic Gardens.Arriving just after 10am, the weather was absolutely gorgeous with clear blue sky and a warm 20 degrees as we strolled around enjoying the great range of plants that the Garden staff carefully maintains. We also walked to Mrs Macquarie's Point for the fantastic views across the harbour to the Bridge and Opera House. I guess the Gardens will delight both the enthusiastic amateur (like myself) and those with a serious passion for horticulture. As lunchtime approached, the Garden filled with tourists, and Sydney residents taking a run around the Garden. There was also a big film crew filming what looked to be a 1920/1930s period piece. For me this is one of Sydney's real treasures.Entry is free and it's a wonderful civic amenity holding informative events regularly throughout the year, which complement the standing educational displays. Breakfast, lunch and drinks are available in the Garden's Restaurant and Cafe. There's also a Garden Shop and Plant Sales. A terrific place to spend a morning, afternoon or all day that should be on everyone's Sydney 'must do' list.
Beautiful even in winter. Walking through these garden was a wow experience. Even though it was winter they are just beautiful. Very beautiful.

Worth coming to Sydney for. If you are going to the Sydney Opera house or anything in central Sydney you will see signs for the Botanic gardens. They are so worth going to. Beautiful, relaxing, not crowded, historical interesting...sheltered, whats not to like?!
Lovely place for a walk. Great views along Botanic Gardens - great place to exercise and have a great view as well - a few up and down areas but well maintained walking paths. wheelchair friendly
Very Beautiful. If time permits, the gardens are worth visiting. The best part about it is the view - the best of the Harbour.

Lovely walk. The Botanical Gardens are worth a visit, they are free, there are numerous indigenous species of trees and shrubs and the view from there of the Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge are excellent. A word of warning though, there is a gate half way though the gardens that is locked at sunset and we couldn't re trace our steps and had to walk back to our hotel via the City Centre.
Beautiful garden in the city. So much to see in the garden, even in the middle of the winter. A nice way to spent a few hours. Make sure you check the closing time. We did not have enough time.

A tranquil oasis. Located on the shore of world largest natural harbour, the Sydney's Royal botanic gardens are short walk from the city centre , the world famous opera house, Hyde park and circular quay.there are thousands of beautiful plants, specimen trees ,flower beds , colourful birds and walking routes, restaurants and cafes beside guided tours and aboriginal history to enjoy.

Majestic walk. The Royal Botanical Gardens is a beautiful area of trees, flowers, and plants. There is an easy entrance to the gardens from the front of the Sydney Opera House. If you start at the Opera House, there is a way to exit near the Art Gallery of New South Wales, which is another Sydney and Australian treasure.If you love plants and flowers with a great skyline backdrop, this is your place. Morning jog? Afternoon coffee at the cafe in the centre of the park? Endless photo ops? Absolutely.There is no charge for entry, and they offer guided tours for those who are interested. You can take a 15 minute stroll or spend hours in awe. The choice is yours. Either way, this is a must.

Great botanic garden with a lot of nature. It is a worth place to visit in Sydney. Very close to CBD, walkable from St James station and close to Arts museum of NSW. You can spot a lot of flowers, plants and small animals and birds which are native of NSW. Great for leisure walk and spending an evening good. Follow the timings as they have different closing times on different months of a year based on the season.

Peaceful Walks. My partner and I walked through these grounds multiple times during our trip (admission is free!). Great views of the Opera House and bridge. The multiple types of birds you can see is amazing! The cafe inside is nice as well.

Nice gardens, shame about the birds. Loved the Botanic Gardens and the walk from the Opera House around to Mrs Macquarie's Chair but if you tried to stop for a minute on a bench (any bench), these big white birds with long black beaks (I have since find out are called Australian white ibis) would not leave you alone. I had never seen this type of bird before so it might have been harmless but it meant I couldn't just sit and relax and take in the view.
Relaxing walk!. The walk from the Opera House to the gardens on a warm winter's day is gorgeous. The views are spectacular and the overall harmony and peace of the area is uplifting. Loved it!

Train ride was great . Botannical gardens are huge and beautiful. Did a train ride which goes on for half an hour and that's the great way to see the gardens of travelling with young kids.Great views of Opera house and Sydney Harbour bridge plus has the guide which tells about everything in the gardens.

Take time to visit. The Royal botanic gardens in Sydney are well worth at least a half day visit. Public transport to the gardens is easy but it is just as easy to walk from the Opera House or Circular Quay railway station to get there. The gardens are adjacent to Government house and to the Conservatorium of Music so there is much Sydney History to be done just getting there. We spent a lot of time at the first encounters garden and although there is a guided tour explaining the early Sydney landscape at settlement there are also excellent boards highlighting the history of the Cadigal people at the time of colonisation. Food and drinks are available from stalls in the gardens and I personally found the tour both educational and extremely interesting. Well worth a half day visit.
Beautiful city location. A great place to wander around. Great views of the city and harbour, along with beautiful botanical gardens.
ordinary by world standards. don't expect too much and get disappointed. good, friendly staff. nice place for a cuppa and a cake. go all around

Beautiful gardens and well worth the walk around, or catch the road train. My husband and I spent a really enjoyable couple of hours here last year and it is a beautiful spot to spend time. As we can't walk too far these days we caught the road train which takes you around the park and is also very informative and not expensive. Of all the photos I took in Australia, the one I took from the gardens is by far my favourite, a brilliant view of the Opera House and bridge.

One of the most diverse and attractive botanic gardens I have visited. The gardens are very extensive - beautifully maintained and situated beside Sydney harbour. A must-see for anyone who likes plants!

Lion Gate Lodge great for weddings. We celebrated my daughters wedding in July. The sun shone and the wind didn't blow, we had a great day it felt like we were having a wedding in a private home thanks to our stylist.
Contacts for suppliers by the RBG would have saved a lot of searching.

Walk and run . Beautiful park, loved European feel and variety of plants. Unwanted to go to cafe but didn't like th atmosphere so went to library cafe instead. Could spend more time later in the year when more plants are at their best. So worth it!

Nice Morning Stroll. A very nice garden located near the Opera House with the view of Sydney Harbour. My kids enjoyed watching the birds at the park and lake. Bathrooms are clean. A very quaint place with a cafe as well. Highly recommended.

Sweet addiction at the Calyx, Botanical Gardens- Extremely Disappointing!. My family and I went to see the Sweet Addiction Attraction at the Calyx, which was sponsored by Lindt. For concession, we had to pay about $45. This was about as much as we payed to see the Frieda and Carlo exhibition at the gallery, which was excellent. I thought, this better be good!On entry, we received a single ball of Lindt chocolate each, and didn't receive any more throughout the whole exhibition! This attraction is LAME!!!As Lindt is a company with lots of money, and they were sponsoring this attraction, I would think that they would have been able to spare a little more chocolate then one piece each... I mean come on! It's meant to be a chocolate garden!!!Yes, it was full of jungle plants, but when Dad exclaimed in excitement at seeing a real cocoa plant, Mum was quick to point out that the cocoa beans were literally tied on with string!!!It also had some panels full of information about cocoa bean processing, and a few interesting facts, but none of this information washout the Australian cocoa industry. Finally, the whole thing was mainly advertising for Lindt chocolate. I strongly advise you don't waste money on this!!!!! DISAPOINTING.

I walk around these gardens every morning.. If you have to walk each morning and all of us need to there is no better place than the Royal Botanic Gardens.You can drive there and park your car...meter parking and walk around for as long as you wish. It is invigorating it is gorgeous as you can see the bridge and opera house and the flowers plants and trees a delight.There is also a restaurant opposite the NSW Art Gallery where you can breakfast or lunch.

Beautiful. Beautiful gardens with fantastic unrivalled views of the opera house and harbour bridge. Would definitely recommend for some peace and quiet away from the city. Also you can see some incredible wildlife in here too !

A big favourite !. Spend atleast half a day at the gardens. Take your time and walk about and experience the different gardens, the flowers, the weird and the grand trees, the wonderful lawns and the many birds. It's just a great place to spend a relaxed day. I have always loved it !
Great location. Beautifully maintained, and great location in the city centre. Perfect spot for children to get some fresh air and unwind during a busy day exploring the busy city that is Sydney.
Botanic garden. This place is amazing. They have many plants here. And they're really take care of the plants. It's cool there not too hot. I think it caused by the amount of the plants.

Walk to the harbour. I walked from my hotel in Potts Point to the harbour to catch my ferry across the river. Was a lovely stroll through the plants and tress and was very well signed post in order to figure out your way.Was my favourite way to see the opera house and bridge from the gardens.
Australia with children. Very nice, green oasis in a big city. There is a pond with some fish in it to entertain kids. No playground.

Absolutely beautiful. This is one of the greatest parks/gardens in the world. If you are interested in bird wildlife, plant life or relaxing in a beautiful park, you will love this place. It hugs the harbour and is incredibly well maintained. Your stress level reduces by 94% and happiness level increases by 206% by going here.

Nice breezy walk on a Winter afternoon. It's 200 years' anniversary this year and there is nice 200 sign erected to commemorate the event. A short walk from Opera house and you can enjoy the nice breezy walk along the coastline with view of the central business district across the harbour. After the walk you can either take the ferry or train to wherever you are heading. It's a nice place to spend the afternoon with family and friends. If you take the ferry, it's a nice change as you have different views of each ferry stop if you have at least half hour to spare to enjoy this.
Worth a visit to see the birds if nothing else. Watched kookaburras in the trees. Watched ibises on the ground. Followed lorikeets and cockatoos around the trees. Loved it.

Lots to see . You can get lost in this place. The palm house and fernery are great places. If you get a chance see if you can manage to see the Friends of the Botanical Gardens stall, do so as there are a good variety of plants and flowers you can buy to take home and recreate your own botanical garden.

A stroll through Sydney's botanic history. Not a botanist myself, but I like the feeling of walking around the lush Royal Botanic Gardens. Kids playing hide and seek around the bases of the large trees, playing catch in the vast grassed spaces, joggers running along the paths, and older folks just strolling along the sea wall watching for fish on the harbour's edge. Great on a sunny day, not great on a wet one. The gardens are full of native plants from all over the world. There are enormous trees covered in vines and beautiful roses in beds near the entrances. There are stone covered shelters for humans to protect you from the hot sun. There are loads of places for picnics, too. Even fauna abounds, including fruit bats in the evenings. There are free guided walks around the gardens every day at 10.30 am, but look at the web site for other times. The park is very romantic and would be a great place to propose marriage or have a romantic meal at the restaurant. Even on busy days, I find the park a tranquil place to think and ponder life. If you are botanically minded you will love reading all the labels on the tags on the plants and trees all around the park. Also visit the Growing Friends' Nursery at the rare and endangered plants. Lots to see if you want to and a good place to relax if you don't.A place that is highly recommended.
A beautiful walk. These gardens a definitely worth a walk around, they are beautiful. While there visit the original Government House,

Botanic beauty. We visited on a cold wet day in July but were rewarded with a magnificent vista with very few others.They are currently celebrating the 200th anniversary of the gardens.There is currently an exhibition of chocolate in the Calyx centre which has a fee to enter.We really enjoyed the palm grotto and the areas of bamboo.The huge spreading fig trees make you wonder how the tree can support the weight of the huge branches.As it was wet there were large numbers of water birds foraging in the soaked lawn areas.A great way to spend the day no matter what the weather.

Not much to do with small kids. Very pretty gardens. I sat on a bench overlooking the harbour watching the ferries. I could see Mrs Macquaries chair and people jogging and walking along from the Opera House around in a u shape.Did the kids have a great wow time? Yes nature is calming. Nature is free. But a whole lot of stuff to do. Picnic lunch was nice by the little lake.

A beautiful sight. I have lived in Sydney a few years now and I will never get bored of the botanical gardens, on a sunny day there is nothing better to do that take a stroll in the park and enjoy the thousands of beautiful trees and flowers!

Loved it!!!!! Beautiful!. We took the train tour which is a 25 minute trip through the botanic gardens. It cost $10 adult and $5 kids. It's amazing and huge! Beautiful views of the harbour, bridge, and Opera house. And Fort Dennison.

Get your green fix in the city centre. A beautiful little gem in the middle of Sydney! Walk around enjoying the gardens, Old Government House and views of the harbour, the Opera House and the bridge, or just lay on the grass and soak up the sunshine. A little piece of paradise.

Gardens by the harbour. Entry to the gardens are free. They are located right next door to the Opera House and are an easy walk from Circular Quay. You can walk along the sea wall to Macquarie Point where there are excellent photo opportunities for getting selfies with the Opera House and Harbour Bridge lined up behind you. In the gardens themselves there is plentiful bird life, mature trees and ponds. Very relaxing. You also see fitness enthusiasts everywhere.

Beautiful gardens.. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a must when visiting Sydney. They are very well situated; walking distance to the opera House, the Bridge, the Rocks and the city. The Royal Botanic Gardens are absolutely beautiful with plenty to see and admire.

A fee stroll or five!. This is a must and do it several times of you can as there are so many options - many of the routes lead to other worthwhile Sydney landmarks be it view of harbour, art gallery or onward to Woollomoloo and finger wharf - drop into the Ovolo Hotel on the wharf for a tipple in the Sip Happens Bar or the many excellent restaurants...

An oasis in the middle of the city. The Royal Botanic Gardens is an oasis between the city and the harbour. @00 years old and not only a wonderful piece of history but a fantastic place to see incredible views of the Sydney harbour bridge and the opera house Great botanic specimens and shop and cafe We go regularly afternoon having some retail therapy in the nearby shops

Beautiful! . My self and my family did a walk around the botanical gardens on the first day we came to Sydney. The gardens are beautiful and the train tour is well worth the money. It takes you around the full garments and gives you some historical context which is always pleasant.

The Aboriginal tour is fantastic!. The botanical gardens were beautiful, and a fascinating place. But I'd REALLY recommend taking the Aboriginal tour. Our Aboriginal guide told of his tribe's history, and gave us a fascinating tour, describing the history, and telling us of medical uses for various plants. It was really a highlight of the Sydney visit.
nice. Went early in morning through gardens and down to the front. Nice with not many around, lovely to sit and watch.
Lovely picnic. We walked to the café and got some chips and a hot chocolate then sat on the grass in the sun overlooking the opera house and harbour bridge.

Naturally Beautiful!!. Now it's incredible adventure to nature!! My first visit to Royal Botanical Garden in Sydney, not it was bueatiful!! :)
The walk to nature and the peace you find here is amazing!

Pretty place for a walk and gorgeous views. So many trees, plants, and flowers make the paths a lovely place to wander on a nice day. Follow the path directly from behind the Opera House steps along the water to gain one of the best Harbour views in Sydney by Mrs. Macquaries Chair.
Kids loved it!. Lots of beautiful birds around as well as beautiful trees and plants. Had a nice time while sipping on a cup of coffee while kids ran around.

Walking distance from Opera house and lovely garden. Weather was lovely as my husband & I walked from the Sydney Opera house. Near by the botanic entrance, there is a hop on and off tram ($10/pax) in the garden which enables you to view the garden without walking. Worth going!

200 Year Old Gardens with fabulous Sydney Harbour views !. Beautiful Sydney weather invites tourists and Sydneyites to enjoy magnificent Harbour views whilst walking through various paths within the 200 year old Royal Botanic Gardens !
Lovely place. Well worth walking through this at your leisure. The planting and views are simply beautiful. don't miss it

Peaceful. A huge open space on the Harbour side, close to many attractions including The Opera House, State Gallery of NSW, Governor's House & more. Lots to see or if you'd prefer a place to just chill out or picnic. Several cafes/bars within the park. Most exhibits are labeled and there are glasshouses containing more exotic displays. An icon in Sydney and well worth a stroll around or through enroute to somewhere else

There are no words.... I've travelled a lot (yes thats a boast), I've seen some of the most stunning places on earth, natures beauty at it's most raw from Africa to the US and back again. However I've never found something manmade quite as calming and beautiful as the Botanic Gardens.I'm going to be honest here, I get terrible hay fever, so plants etc are not really my cup of tea. However I was staying at Potts Point and thought a nice walk around to the bay would be the perfect way to see the Harbour etc. I wasn't actually that fussed about walking through the Gardens until I got in there. The animals, the plants, they all just took my breath away, and as you follow the water around you get some stunning views of the Opera House and the Bridge.I stopped for some food in the cafe in the gardens (one of the best chocolate brownies I've ever tasted) and sat outside on the benches. A kookaburra decided it wanted to share my brownie, as did a couple of other local birds. I felt like a Disney princess! After the rest I walked the rest of the way around the bay, in some of the most beautiful scenery on earth. It's a stunning place..as long as the sun is shining obviously.
A truly magnificent garden. The botanic gardens never fail to delight. Amazing and its free. Very nice gift shop. The cafe is disappointing.

Lovely and peaceful. Lovely way to spend a sunny afternoon. The Royal Botanic Gardens is quite large with lots of open space for relaxing, picnics, or just admiring the beautiful flora. Great for the family or for those looking for a scenic jog through the park.

Beautiful gardens in the heart of a beautiful city. The Royal Botanic Gardens are delightful. Walking around the gardens is a wonderful way to spend an afternoon. The gardens are well laid out and offer some stunning views of the Sydney Harbor and the Opera House.

Not much. Didnt recon much to these botanical gardens compared to others id seen.
Its more a huge park and used alot for weddings.
Nice walk though from the harbour area so other parts of Sydney.
Winter by the water. What a wonderful place to spend a winter's day. No words can describe the beauty of this harbourside garden of eden. I even like the flying foxes and cockatoos.

Magnificent gardens. Whatever you do in Sydney, make sure you visit the Royal Botanic Gardens. The gardens are close to every place you would want to visit: the Sydney Harbour, the Opera House and the Art Gallery of NSW. The gardens have different exhibitions --the Calyx aka the sweet addiction (the story of chocolate) and is a must watch. The gardens are beautiful and divided into various themes. One day is not enough!

Love the fauna diversity. What a collection of plants. Enjoyed the visit viewing the variety of different trees collected by botanists over the centuries and planted in the Royal Botanic Gardens. An excellent free visit.

Best located gardens that I have seen. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney have an enormous advantage over most other similar type gardens, being located within easy walking distance of the city and also the Sydney Opera House, yet there is very little traffic noise but as a bonus amazing views of Sydney Harbour, The Gardens are well planned, clean, tidy and safe to walk around. Having been to a number of overseas Gardens I have yet to find an equivalent venue. if you are travelling to Sydney please consider a visit to the Gardens and entrance is free.

A special place during VIVID. One of the best gardens at any time and so easy to get to from the CBD and public transport at Circular Quay, it was even more special during VIVID, an amazing show by the Harbour to celebrate 200 years - only problem was that it was so popular that it took more than 40 minutes to complete the walk.
Great stroll!. Beautiful stroll around beautiful plants, flowers and trees. Enough places to sit and enjoy the beautiful view with your loved ones!!
botanic gardens. Nice walk to gardens via Domain and Hyde Park. Map is helpful but still difficult to navigate. Helpers are throughout the garden for directions.

Drinks before the Opera. Sat in the Botanic Gardens before we went to Opera on the Harbour and had drinks. Is the most wonderful place and to think that we are right in the middle of a huge city. You can see all the beautiful trees and watch the boats go by on the harbour. Would be hard to fine another city with gardens and a view like this

Lunchtime stroll. These gardens are awesome. A must visit for anyone in Sydney.
Views are incredible, not only of the harbour but also of the city buildings and opera house.
amazing place to feel peace. although this place is very close to the city and have a view of opera house as well, it's very quite and peaceful which makes your visiting the city complete.

Calyx - Sweet Addiction. Together with 3 friends, we visited one of Sydney's newest attractions, the Calyx, a great looking building in the Royal Botanic Gardens. The entrance fee was $15 each to visit an incredibly small indoor garden which provided no value, no amusement, and no chocolate, which is interesting for such a sponsored exhibition.All in all, we were very disappointed in this event, and something which could have been much more turned into a waste of time and waste of money. Do not visit!!!

My favourite place to walk in Sydney. This is an oasis of gardens, grand trees, sweeping lawns leading to the harbour, and exotic plants and flowers. I love to escape th concrete jungle of Sydney city to come here for a walk. Had a coffee this morning at the cafe in the sun. Average coffee but pleasant location.
Beautiful Gardens. Great photo opportunities of both the gardens and the harbour. The governors house is also outstanding. I would recommend the Choo Choo Train Tour!

Leisurely walk from the Opera House to St Mary's Cathedral or Vice Versa. Whilst not the shortest route, it certainly is the most picturesque. If you begin at St Mary's Cathedral, the walk to the Opera House through the Botanic Gardens will be down hill, obviously vice versa in the other direction. Be sure not to miss Mrs Macquarie's chair.
Unmissable. This is a must see when in Sydney. There are beautiful plants everywhere, lots of places to stop and take photos of the Gardens, city view and boats/water.
relaxing among nature. A well planned garden which hugs the harbor. Very peaceful to gently walk around. Even though it in the city center, you can still find a quiet spot to watch the world go by.
Beautiful strole through these lovely gardens. Great views all around from this lovely sanctuary! Nice coffee shop and gift boutique. Great assortment of plants!
Tranquil.. Great to be steps away from the city in such a tranquil space. Great 2 hour to 1/2 a day self guided tour. Would recommend for traveler to get away from the touristy areas.

All cities should have one. Of everything we saw in Sydney we returned for a whole afternoon to the gardens. So much to see, so diverse yet so peaceful. Signs telling people "to walk on the grass" and enjoy the surroundings. So different from the UK.As well as plants, birds, lizards and eels you also get views of the bridge and the Opera house.We were there on Anzac day and there was a party atmosphere with the locals enjoying picnics, salsa dancing and generally having a good time.We would highly recommend these and suggest you allow a good 3 hours to explore all of the gardens.

Beautiful!. Great place for a run, picnic or stroll! The views of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge were STUNNING! My husband and I enjoyed our morning runs here while staying in The Rocks District.

Come to the Calyx. What an amazing, informative experience to visit the brand new exhibition space in Sydney's Botanic Gardens! It's a botanic wonder of plants, collages, sculptures and stories about the history of the growing and uses of the cacao plant and chocolate. Detail and devotion have gone into the assembling of this display.The Botanic Gardens are a jewel in the crown of Sydney; a stone's throw from the Opera House and right in the heart of the city. Beauties past, present and futuristic are all on display here.Well worth a visit - a place for many hours of pleasure and picnic.To visit the gardens is an activity free of cost.Calyx has a charge - discounted if purchased on internet.

Beautiful Start. First real day in Sydney and walking to the Opera House and the views of the Bridge, the botanic gardens are superb. Well maintained, pristine and in location that is unmatched. also saw them at night during Vivid with the light shows. A bit crowded then for me but during the day, well worth a visit.

All season feast. What a great vision 200 years ago to establish this beautiful park right on the waterfront in the heart of Sydney. We have enjoyed hundreds of visits since 1995. There is always something new and in bloom. Picnic, read a book, jog the foreshore, walk, eat at the cafe. Just get there and take in the beauty & serenity of nature and this green area in the heart of Sydney. Ample public transport to get you there. Set next to iconic Sydney landmarks like the Opera House, St Mary's Cathedral, Hyde Park, The Domain....a must experience by nature lovers.
Beautiful clean garden. Just by the opera house.clean and well maintained. People exercise and sit on the grass mainly. Lovely walk around the garden.very beautiful.
Beautiful and tranquil. The best cities have good parks and this has a great one. It isn't big by NYC or London standards, but its location and landscaping is incredible. Wonderful place to chill

Don't miss!. Every time we visit Sydney we try to come down here to the Botanic Gardens even if its just for a quick walk. There is so much to see here - the grounds are impeccably kept and the ambience is very peaceful and relaxed even with busy Sydney in the background. This is an incredible place to visit while here!

A vivid experience !. The Sydney Royal Botanical Gardens are well worth a visit at the best of times but if possible visit when the Sydney VIVID Festival is on. In 2016 the dates ran from 27 May to June 18. The Gardens were transformed by the most imaginative and spectacular use of lighting and were breathtaking. The whole CBD has the same treatment and from the ferries one can see all the office blocks change colours, The Festival has been running for some years now but this was the first time I'd been able to visit. Allow yourself sufficient time. I only had two nights and one was spoiled by heavy rain. There was much I was not able to see.
Beauftiful. Wondering around the gardens is just beautiful. Loved seeing the ducks on the water and the beautiful flowers coming out in spring were well worth the walk.
Love the Birds.. We spent a very enjoyable couple of hours wandering around the gardens but the highlight for me was seeing the birdlife. It's a very pleasant spot down by the harbour.

Well worth it. We walked from the Rocks to the Botanical Gardens and then took the Choo Choo train ride around the gardens, it cost $10 pp it took around 25 minutes and the commentary was very clear and informative.
Would recommend this tour especially for those with mobility problems.

200 Years of Beauty. We walked through a portion of the Royal Botanic Gardens and were very pleased with the beauty of the site. We saw many people picnicking, lounging in the grass, and even practicing yoga. It was a beautiful place for a relaxing walk! The Royal Botanic Gardens is celebrating its 200th year.
Beautiful grounds. Beautiful flowers and foliage even in winter. The Sweet Addiction exhibit at the Calyx was informative as well as providing a beautiful display of rain forest plants.
Beauty!. This place is so beautiful. Spend a lot of time there exploring every hidden corner. See Mrs Macquaries chair, huge trees and marine.
A wonderful relaxing walk. Choose to walk through these gardens instead of the shorter routes along main routes if you can. The gardens are well laid-out and sign-posted.

Awesome as always. What can one say? Great place to spend an hour whilst in Sydney and fantastic place to unwind if you work in the CBD.
I come here often (less so now I work in Barangaroo as it is the opposite side of the CBD).
One of the crown jewels of Sydney.

If you are nature person. I personally liked it. If you are a nature person into plants and everything, you might even love it. I want for a walk and loved it. The weather was windy so in turn chilly but it's a good place to just go and relax, maybe jog/run a bit.

Always a great place to visit. Great place to take tourists to visit.
Great view of the harbour and many plants and trees to view. Great backdrop for photos.
Very picturesque. Very peaceful and natural environment.
Amazing Sydney spot.
Can always have a picnic or just relax and people watch.
Throughly recommend

200 years old - Sydney's Royal Botanic Gardens. Regardless of the season, a visit to the Royal Botanic Gardens on Sydney Harbour - and linked to the Sydney Opera House - is always one of Sydney's greatest pleasures.
