This was informative so I would definitely recommend you hop on the train which goes on the hour & half hour & is 10 AUD takes about 25 mins. opportunity to take some pretty pics too.
Absolutely lovely - worth the visit.. I am so glad we decided to visit the gardens. This is a must see if you go to Sydney We where there in December which is summer in Oz so everything was in bloom.
Incredible. Perhaps some of the best gardens that I have visited. Wonderful, free and accessible to all! Truly one of the treasures of this city.
beautiful flowers. day was sunny and beautiful, we lived a stroll garden, the garden is nice arranged, there are plenty of beautiful flowers

Don't miss these beautiful gardens!. Excellent (free) Botanic Gardens where you could spend a whole day or just an hour strolling along the waterfront. They have a little train you can ride around on if you are not up for the walking.

Very good views of the Opera house and the bridge.. My wife and I walked by the waterside from the Opera house through the park on a wound earful sunny day. Very peaceful only the noise of the local wildlife in the trees, the cockatoo's. When we walked all the way round to the head we looked back at the Opera house and the bridge and got some wonderful pictures. Nice on a sunny day.

One of my favorite places in Sydney!. The Royal Botanic gardens is one of my favorite places in Sydney! it has the best landscaping in the CBD and the wildlife is full of life as well. i have visited this place many times in my life and have never had a bad experience here. its great for travelers on a budget, most of the time my girlfriend and i will just grabs some fish and chips from circular quay and take it down to the gardens and have a cute little lunch with a view and it will barely cost a thing. Also the Art gallery of NSW is about a 10 minute walk. Theres no entry fee for that either so once again a great place for travelers on a budget. if you circle around and find yourself near Wooloomooloo, try out a hot-dog at Harry's cafe de wheels. Once again you'll get a cheap great meal with a view of the navy ships. if you are a hardcore nature lover i suggest you also visit Wendy Whitelye's secret garden, its well worth it.

Beautiful, peaceful and wonderful mix of plants. One of the highlights of our visit was the wander about the botanical gardens. Good views of the harbor and lots of great plants to view. Just a great place to spend time in Sydney.

Lovely. It is a lovely garden, full with great variety of plants and animals. Great place to sit downrelax and look at trees and birds there. I liked a lot a small exhibition there illustrating the history of Aborigines. Also the succulent garden is great. Generally this is a lovely place

Nice place to sit down and relax. My colleague and I bought lunch elsewhere and walk here to sit on a bench to enjoy our ouch under the sun. It's so amazing that it's free to the public and so well preserved. A beautiful place to take a walk, sit down, have a picnic, and even go for a run during lunch. I've been to other botanic gardens before but you normally have to pay for them so the free part is a nice touch. You can also walk to the opera house from the garden so you can see big sights at once easily.

We Thought It Would Take Us an Hour, But.... Our Hotel was close by so when I saw they had a free one hour tour at 10:30 AM I told my husband we should run across the street and check it out. We made it just in time, but we did not spend an hour. We landed up hanging out and walking around the local area all day. So the free tour was not that great, but the gardens speak for themselves. Once we left the tour we continued to walk. Stopping to sit on a bench or rest in the grass and take in the views. We saw local joggers, kids on school trips it was fun. As we meandered on we made our way to Ms. Quarles' bench and then finally to Wooloomooloo. Don't ask me how we got there but it we did. We had lunch and then made our way back via a different route and saw other parts of the garden we had missed. It made for an awesome day and I highly recommend spending a day.

Nice place to walk and enjoy the weather. If you like to do picnic and enjoy trees, this is the place to be. Take a ride on the trolley (you have to pay) and enjoy the garden; no bicycle, skateboard, roller blade allowed in this area. Nice place to jog as well. nice place to take picture of the harbor bridge and opera house.

Walked through it every day we were in Sydney. The gardens are beautiful. The gift shop delightful. After miles of walking around the city site seeing, it was so great to take our shoes off and enjoy sitting on the grass watching the people and relaxing.

Lovely walk. We walked through the Royal Botanic Gardens often as it was a cut through from our hotel to the Sydney Harbour and it was such a nice walk. The gardens are well maintained, they overlook the harbour and they're lovely.

Peaceful location, not as many flowers as expected. The Botanic Gardens are very nice to walk through and provide a break from the business all around it, but it didn't have quite as many flowers as I pictured from other descriptions I read. Could have been the time of year, though. There is ample shade and lots of places to sit and relax all throughout. Well maintained grounds.

One of the great botanical gardens of the world. The Royal Botanic Garden Sydney is a major botanical garden located in the heart of Sydney, Australia. Opened in 1816, the garden is the oldest scientific institution in Australia and one of the most important historic botanical institutions in the world. It is open every day of the year and access is free. Its stunning position on Sydney Harbour and immediately adjacent to the Sydney CBD, the Sydney Opera House and the large public parklands of The Domain ensure it is one of the most visited attractions in Sydney.

Get out with the locals. Our gardens are not just for visitors, Sydneysiders love them. See people walking, jogging, looking at plants and just hanging out. Try the cactus garden anytime. The annual gardens in spring, the tropical pyramid, the vege garden or just wander aimlessly. Bring a picnic or try the cafe or the restaurant in the gardens. Wander around from the opera house to the art gallery and check out the sculptures on the way. Lie on the grass with a friend, sit by the lotus pond, volunteer with the gardens society or sit on Lady Macquarie's chair. Just enjoy our gardens!
Beautiful. Amazing gardens. Beautiful. An oasis in the busy city. Good cafe. On my list of places to visit again. Recommend.
Simply beautiful!. Don't miss this beautiful garden with a huge range of foliage with comfortable walking paths and a beautiful café.
The settled Oldest Botanic Gardens in Australia. Take the mini trainride around the gardens and make the most of the tour around this fabulous landmark

A peaceful haven right in the city!. The botanical gardens are celebrating their 200th birthday so that I dictates the maturity of these gardens! They are very well kept and provide a wonderful walk and/or train ride through a peaceful part of the city. The added bonus is that you either start or end at the Opera House and harbour!

Easily leads you down to Sydney Opera House. Sudden downpour left us open for sightseeing options. Per recommendation to go to the Gallery of NSW by taxi, we ended up walking through the Royal gardens toward the right. One of reviews said you'd get a good view of the opera house from there. We decided to walk down hill and amazingly came up front and center to the famed Sydney Opera House. Perhaps another season from their autumn might display more things in bloom.

Well designed Botanical garden.. Very comfortable walk around the Garden.. Very spacious and the land highlights the different trees and plants. Several trees are from Australia and New Zealand and are not normally seen outside of their habitat. A nice plus is that it next to the Opera House and that creates a special setting

An amazing walk in the heart of the city.. The Botanical gardens will not be a disappointment should one take the time to meander along the various splendid walkways. Peaceful and relaxing with a wide variety of well marked flora. It is very nice indeed and extremely interesting.

Great Gardens, Fabulous History. We went to the Gardens on our path to the Opera House. At the start we were met with the "Train" to take us through the gardens and although it hadn't been our plan, we jumped on.... cost $10 per adult and $5 per child... quite expensive, but we were exhausted and the info it gave us was fabulous.We learnt a lot in a quite quick train trip, which then dropped us at the Opera House steps. Perfect for our tired legs. I am sure there was a lot more to see and we missed a lot, but the informative commentary on the train was well worth it. We saw Bottle Trees, Gingko Bilhoba Trees, learnt where the phrase to knock on wood came from and many interesting facts.There were the gardens of the first settlers and the herbarium where they store all the seeds from the past for future generations and for scientific research.It would be great to revisit and do it when our feet weren't so tired.....
Nice botanical garden . Nice and relaxing atmosphere. Except for the cockatoo flying and screaming around. But still loved it to see them. There are lots the garden is beautiful nice to walk through
A very nice walk. We spent about two hours walking through the Botanical Gardens, beautiful trees, plants and birds. Recommend it from top to bottom.

The worst so call "garden" in the world. *Hardly any flower, hardly any interesting vegetation at all*Badly managed , rubbish and homeless creepy people all over the place*Hard to get to , bad public transport system *And is damn boring....barely anything worth seeing

Exquisite grounds - splendid scenery. An enchanted walk with a view of Sydney Harbor. Variety of vegetation and beautiful blooms, even in their late Summer/Fall. Included was the Wollemi Pine tree, a primitive tree from the time of the dinosaurs that had long been thought extinct but was discovered growing in the Blue Mountains outside of Sydney and planted in this botanic gardens. The cafe was exquisite with sweeping views of the harbor as well as delicious and fresh fare.
Photographers heaven, 2nd to Singapore this rates very high. Fantastic collection of Aussie classics and some tropical (was closed for renovation) photographers wonderland
The greenery. There are so many exotic plants, trees and flowering plants indigenous to Australia. Take a leisurely walk as you go the opera house.
Lovely to walk around. Very pretty gardens and park to stroll around in. Walking around the edge of it, along the harbor was especially enjoyable. We were here in April.

A pleasant walk on a sunny day. The gardens are beautifully set out and well sign posted, so once you have entered the gardens you can choose where you would like to go. The herb garden is very interesting, and the lawns and views across the harbour are spectacular from there. We spent about an hour walking from the top of the gardens, ending up at the Opera House. There will be displays to celebrate the 200 years of the gardens this month. We were sorry we were just too early.

Gorgeous Gardens with views across the harbour.. You feel miles away from the hustle and bustle of the CBD (Central Business District - City Centre) yet, it's only minutes away! Following the path from The Opera House takes you to the entrance of the Royal Botanical Gardens. The day we went there, it was an overcast afternoon and we'd walked all around the harbour. The gardens are so beautiful with plenty of places to rest. Good pathways for walking or for those in wheelchairs/prams. lots of families and couples walking about. People resting quietly, sitting under trees as well as on the grass and benches dotted about.The views are beautiful and you can see the harbour and beyond and you stroll about. It was very peaceful and relaxing and very well kept.

A great place to take a break and enjoy the suroundings. There are a number of parks in Sydney but this is one of my favourite. The array of flowers and plants is great and some really good spots to find to have a picnic.

Great place to chill out . Tip - you can get amazing views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge if you go up the steps on the right hand side after leaving the Opera House.We visited twice and sat in the park to read our books. Really enjoyed it on both occasions.The park is deceptively huge and we only managed to get round a very small section of it.
Stunning landscaping. Very well kept and well signposted with beautiful harbour views and a cafe. I look forward to coming back and enjoying a walk through these beautiful gardens.

Excellent garden in the heart of Sydney . We live locally and come to the garden every now and then. If you are visiting Sydney then this is a place which you should definitely visit. The big pond is known for the bird nest in the middle of the artificial Lake.

Nature's beauty beside the blue harbour.. Personally, I think that Sydney's Royal Botanic Gardens are one of the best positioned of any in the world. Lush greenery, fantastic walks with photogenic water views. Lovely eateries, quaint souvenir and gift shops and a modern day 'castle' top off a fantastic visitor experience!

Magnificent Urban Park. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney is an exceptional park in the middle of the city. It is beautiful, and I really enjoyed the two hours we spent exploring the gardens. We caught it on a beautiful day over the Easter weekend, and the gardens were alive with people enjoying themselves. There is plenty of room, and we never felt crowded, rushed or unwelcome. Everybody seemed to be having a great time.The walk from the Sydney Opera House to Mrs. MacQuaries point will take about 90 minutes, but will provide you with excellent views (and photo ops) of the opera house, Sydney Harbor and the Harbour Bridge. Its well worth it.The Royal Botanic Gardens are very clean, well maintained and safe. However, they do close at night.The gardens are celebrating their 200th anniversary in 2016. Plan to stop by and join in the fun.

The best way to start the day!. I stayed in Sydney for a few days after my cruise, Being an early riser I looked for somewhere to stretch my legs in the morning and found the gardens to be the best place to start the day. Lots of walks, great views plus lots of interesting birds and animals.Highly recommended as the place to get some fresh air and

had a train ride. Lovely day but after walking around Sydney and Opera House our feet were stating to ache so decided to take the little train ride around the garden, you can get on and off at different stops. Thoroughly enjoyed the gardens they looked lovely.

Simply magnificent!. After visiting the Harbour and the Opera House, one organically walks into the Royal Botanic Gardens. What a lovely walk! I would suggest spending time walking the gardens, the further you walk, the more it surprises you with its sights and when you're almost at the end of the Gardens, the views back to the Opera House are equally stunning. A perfect spot to take a nice picture without other people standing between you and the Opera House. There are water fountains, public and clean restrooms and a lot of natural shade. If you're lucky, like me, you'll see more than one wedding. Purely magical!

Amazing and free to the public. We can't say enough about the Botanical gardens. There are miles of trails and we walked it every morning of our stay in Sydney. Simply incredible and a not to miss place. Its directly next to the Opera house so you just keep a walkin' and you'll make a day of it. The trails are amazing, but the views are better. This place is incredible. Run, walk, or jog it day after day and you will be amazed at how many trails there are.

Lovely Walk. The pontifical gardens are very well-maintained and they are a great place to walk around and see unique views of the city. I would've liked to seen a little bit more information about the plants inside the Gardens.

One of the great walks on our planet. You can spend hours in this place.The variety of plant life within these gardens is fantastic.Trees and plants from all over the world - most of them labelled so you can identify their origin.A small but comfortable café in the middle supplies good meals and refreshments.The walk around Farm Cove to Lady Macquarie's Chair along the Sydney Harbour foreshore is an experience in itself. And on the return walk there is always the Sydney Opera House or Bridge watching over you.You can make the visit short or long but it is an energising and reflective experience.

Botanical garden Sydney. What a great place to spend all day Plenty of room to sit and relax while enjoying greenery that frame all garden There is huge amount of plants many natives to see many different section and big glass house My favourite is rose garden where the smell of roses of all kind colour and shape dominate while area Highly recommended

Somber and Placid. A nice place to enjoy the late morning or late afternoon, It was beautiful, just a pleasure to see the different plants, flowers and more. If you are lucky you will see some interesting birds. Nice to see the beauty at it's finest.

For some, Sydney's most beautiful place!. Located in the most central part of the City, the place connects some of the most famous spots in town (The Rocks, Domain, Hyde Park, Sydney Harbour…)The Park has the best views from the Opera House and Harbor Bridge. Bring your blanket or beach towel, lay down on the grass and just watch the sun coming down with two of the most symbolic icons from Australia as part of the landscape. For some people, the Botanic Garden is the most beautiful place in Sydney. A place which deserves to be visited along all seasons of the year, as the colors and the landscapes completely change with the stations. Each part of the Park has a garden representing the different kinds of plants from Australia and other parts of the planet. With so many different species, that is also the paradise for birds!
Peaceful haven. A really peaceful spot right next to the Opera House, beautiful gardens and walks and all for free, would recommend for a breather away from the hustle and bustle.

Stunning . There's so much to see here. Gorgeous flowers, unique trees, beautiful birds and gorgeous statues. The Gardens are very expansive so allow yourself some time to explore and take in all the sights.
Great for a couple of hours!. Lots to see here. Especially see the cactus garden (lots of hanging spiders). Not enough for a full day out though. Lots to see nearby too.

Amazing gardens so close to the city. Been here on many occasions.
Still impressive.
Great varieties of trees and plants, and well arranged.
Superb harbour views which is a plus, compared to Hyde Park down the road.

An oasis in the heart of the city. Taking a walk through Sydney Cove past the Opera House to the gardens along Farm Cove, the views are spectacular and the sea breeze most enjoyable. Despite people along the various pathways, we felt the ambience and serenity. We ambled around admiring the variety of bamboos and tropical species, amongst the call of the birds. There were shady spots to take refuge from the sun, and a cafe to quench our thirst and hunger. One could spend hours in this rather expansive park continuing from Mrs Macquaries Chair through to the Domain. Alternatively, one could head towards Macquarie Street exit to return to the hustle and bustle. The place is magic.

Lovely spot in downtown Sydney. We enjoyed strolling through the gardens after leaving the very busy Opera House area and Circular Quays. The tree varieties are stunning and we loved catching glimpses of the harbour, bridge and Opera House through the gardens.

The Gardens with a view. We were in Sydney for a few days, while we were at the Opera House we decided to visit the Royal Gardens, we were tired so we took the train, if you prefer you can get off the train to walk around and take the next one that comes by. I believe the train ride was $5.

A must visit for locals and tourist. Botanical gardens are magical and locals as well as tourist should visit and take the most of what these gardens offer.Mrs Macquarie is just one section of these garden. You need a whole day to take it all in. My daughter in October even had her wedding ceremony in one of the lawns over looking the gardens and the Opera House.

Charming gardens. A short walk from The Rocks takes you to these lovely gardens that hug the ocean wall. A charming cafe awaits you in the middle of the gardens. A lovely break from the buzz of the city.

Turandot-Italian Opera about a Chinese Princess on Sydney Harbour. On a perfect Sydney autumn evening we visited the open air theatre at the Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney. We entered a magical world of pagodas, fire breathing Chinese dragons and 5 story high towers looming down on the audience high above the purpose built stage. Turandot is the age old love story of love finally conquering all but it has many overtones of traditional east vs west distrust. It is a wonderful spectacle with a huge cast combining elements of traditional Italian and Chinese Opera directed by Chen Shi-Zheng. It is sung in Italian but there are subtitles in English and Chinese. Outstanding performances were from Hyeseoun Kwon who play Liu, the ill fated slave of Prince Calaf who is wooing Turandot at great stakes. She sings with passion and great beauty. Riccardo Massi does a beautiful job of the famous aria "Nessum Dorma" meaning no one sleeps while he waits for an answer regarding marriage from Turandot. Dragana Radakovic playing Turandot could bring more passion to the piece but she is playing an " Ice Princess". The three advisors to the Emperor "Ping, Pang and Pong" provide excellent comic relief. As the sun set on the stage before the performance it provided a wonderful spectacle with the backdrop of the Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge. We dined before we came as we found food was expensive and limited choice. It is nice to have a drink at interval gazing over the harbour. We took cushions to make ourselves more comfortable. We parked in the Domain carpark and caught the shuttle bus to and from the venue which worked fairly well. A memorable experience for 35th wedding anniversary!

What a Gift to Sydney. The gardens give the tourist a break from the crowds around the harbor front but more importantly offers some of the best photo opportunities in Sydney. The opera house, bridge, skyline, and harbor can be photographed from many different views. Add to that the lovely landscape, trees, flowers and walks the gardens should not be missed.

Wonderful gardens with great views. These gardens bring something new every time that I visit them. The vast gardens has a huge range of plants and animals and my most recent visit saw Cockatoos, Eels, Bats, fish and many other different birds. The views are also very good as the gardens are next to the harbour so you have some very good views of the Opera House and Bridge plus some good views of the city itself.As this s free it is worth a visit as you will probably get more out of this than you would from some things that you would actually pay for

Beautiful sanctuary just strides away from Sydney's huddle & busstle. Had a couple of strolls through the gardens to admire the eclectic collection of trees and plants and to escape the busyness of the city. These are beautiful and historic gardens, lovingly tended, litter and yob free - a credit to Sydney. Lots of quiet spots for resting and contemplation and a couple of coffee shops as well for refreshment.
nice Botanical garden. Really nice, lots of tree and plant which i never had seen my life. Nice place and nice weather at month of June.

Great views. This place is huge so don't plan to walk the lot. If you stick to the water you'll get amazing views of the bridge and opera house. More inland the variety of plants, flowers, statues and art can keep you enthralled for a couple of hours.
Worth a visit. The Royal Botanic Gardens is well worth a visit. The walk to Mrs Macquarie's chair is lovely with beautiful views of Sydney Harbour.

Serene oasis. What a jewel in the lower cbd this is, surrounded by many historic buildings, as well as having its own historical sites, including the oldest bridge in Australia, built in 1817, for Lady Macquarie, over the Botanic Garden creek. Fascinating buildings, statuary and artworks dot the beautifully maintained grounds. Allow several hours to meander through this oasis, where somehow the noise of the traffic only tens of metres away disappears and instead you can enjoy the green serenity or the Harbourside walk. Lovely.

Gorgeous grounds and free for everyone!. I was very surprised that the Royal Botanic Gardens was free. I was expecting a minimum $20.00 entrance fee and would have gladly paid. The grounds are expansive, beautiful and very well maintained. Unfortunately I was there during the autumn, I could only imagine how impressive and beautiful it would be during the spring. I highly recommend this attraction for absolutely everyone. It's open daily until sunset.

Best opera house + bridge views. The gardens are spectacular, so well conserved and kept. And you can't beat the views of the opera house, the bridge and some part of the city from there. Really lovely.

Take the little tourist train to see the sights.. The Royal Botanic Gardens offer magnificent views of Sydney Harbour and surrounds. If you are visiting the Opera House it's just a short walk to the right hand side of the Opera House to hop on the botanic garden tourist train. It's a great way to see the gardens and you can stop off at the cafe and toilets for a break and walk the gardens from there. Lovely day out around the harbour.
Beautiful landscapes. It's a beautiful setup and beautifully landscaped.Look closely to spot the beautiful birds in the park

Free and worth a visit. We walked around and went round on the little red train for a 20 min tour. Good size gardens, with plenty of plants, shrubs and trees, some art. It is well used, people are sitting on the grass, jogging, strolling, etc. Not many flowering plants at this time of the year, but nice place to escape from all the traffic

Lovely with great views of harbour. A lovely walk around. You can easily forget you're in the middle of a busy city, within a few minutes the noise of traffic and tourists vanishes. Yes you still see other tourists but everyone just gently strolls around peacefully. There are various signs around explaining some of the structures and species of wildlife which can be interesting. The views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge are amazing. You can walk around as much or as little as you like. It's a large place but many exits to get back to the harbour area if you want.

Impressive. Spent an entire day strolling through the gardens chatting with a friend. Lots of huge, amazing old-growth trees. There is one in particular not far from a sculpture of a mare and foal toward the south (?) side, facing the water. It resembles a huge spider coming out of the ground with a large bulbous trunk resembling the body of a spider and all the branches are the many legs. There is a shaded bench right in front of it on the walking path that really gives you that great perspective. See if you can find it.

Beautiful & Peaceful. We visited the Botanic Gardens again as on a previous visit we were restricted for time . This visit was less rushed and we had time to appreciate the Beauty and the serenity of the Gardens . This should be a "Must do " for all visitors to Sydney .

Beautiful place for a walk. We enjoyed a pleasant walk on paths through the gardens. There were not many flowers still in bloom as it was the end of the summer season, but we enjoyed seeing the wide variety of trees and other vegetation.

Stroll though spectacular gardens. Follow the stairs up opposite the opera house and stroll along the side adjacent to Macquarie st, Hopefully you will find an unspoilt piece of Sydney's history that barely gets much traffic at all. Peaceful and relaxing stroll past the large figs that adorn that side of the gardens.

Fabulous Stroll . I love the gardens, adjacent to the Art Gallery you can stroll through the grounds and enjoy the different aromas, flowers, plants, trees, bats, ponds and lawn. The pathway weaves around and there's plenty of places to sit and take it all in. Very relaxing and a really beautiful place to be with families, friends and with the cafe makes it perfect.
Great place to go for a run. The botanical garden is a quiet place to go for a run in the city. Nice views and easy to get in and out from several directions.

Lovely walk. Waiting for other members to join our party we took a walk through the gardens which were quite lovely. How lucky to have these gardens available. I would imagine myself jogging here everyday after work if I lived here. Beautiful city!
Very nice nature. I love this place, the nature and animals around. There is a nice view of the Opera House. You can take a picnic with you and spend the day on the grass near the water.

Historic and varied beauty in tranquil setting. On an overcast weekday this can be one of the most relaxing places in Sydney. There are quiet dells, formal gardens, sculptures and wonderful views of the harbour. A must for tourists.

Lovely gardens and very relaxing. A walk around this fabulous gardens can take a coup,e of hours or so but are well worth the effort. All plants have good signage, the gardens flow into different styles as you meander around the pathways There is a good sized flock of sulphur crested cockatoos which appear to be fairly accustomed to humans. From the park corner nearest the opera house hou have a raised view of both the opera house and harbour bridge.

A rain forest in the middle of the Sydney. The gardens are definitely worth a visit in Sydney. Huge, lush plants dwarf you on your walk; a beautiful rose garden still somewhat in bloom in March; a walk in the sun along the bay as you watch the boats and ferries; a beautiful way to spend a sunny day.

Perfect Photo of Sydney Opera House and Bridge Together. This is the best place in Sydney to capture both the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge in the one perfect photo. We did this as part of our Gray Line City Tour with Driver Glenn.

Beautiful spot to relax and go for a walk. Best time is early morning with the sunrise - if you are a runner there is a very relaxing path which runs next to the water. It's also a great spot for a picnic and the park is quite large so you don't feel inundated.
Beautiful gardens. Beautiful gardens , nice walk around the area, close to our hotel and right next to the opera house.
Escape the crowds. Nice relaxing stroll, lots of different trees and plants etc. There is a cafe and water fountains. Cut through from the museum to the opera house.

Outstanding gardens with stunning views of the harbour. We visited Sydney in early March and met friends for a day out in Sydney who gave us a guided tour starting in the Botanic gardens, which are close to Circular Quay.The gardens are stunning and an amazingly tranquil oasis in the heart of Sydney.We walked through the gardens, enjoyed a coffee at the cafe and then walked on the harbour side path via Woolamaloo, the naval base and to Mrs Macquaries chair with stunning views of the harbour, and then onto the Opera House and Circular Quay.Highly recommended

Fantastic gardens. We visited the gardens twice whilst on our three day stay in Sydney. The gardens were very spacious and beautiful trees and plants, all very well labelled. For me the main attractions were the birds, especially the sulphur crested cockatoos which were everywhere. Plenty of toilets and beautiful views over the harbour, a great place to visit.

Amazing place in the heart of the city. If you want to take a walk and clear your mind, it's there, just a few minutes walk from the busiest Sydney streets in the heart of the city.Beautiful nature and view of Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge.If you bring children you can go for a tour by mini train which goes about every half an hour.

A walk through the gardens - not to be missed. The gardens are certainly worth a visit. Whether you are from overseas or a local what's not to like. Beautifully maintained gardens with a gorgeous outlook. Plenty of appropriately located benches or big shady trees to sit under for a while. Take the time to stop and just listen to the birds or to look at some of the exotic plants on show. Really is a beautiful location and easy to walk around. Lots of opportunities for some great pictures to be taken.
A pretty park for a walk. The botanic gardens is a great place to go for a romamtic walk, enjoy nature in the city, or simply get a bit of exercise. It a great way to finish a tour to Sydney Harbour.

Bright green lawns roll down to the harbour. Tehre is so much so see that most never see all there is in the botanical gardens. Lots of gardens of course with an amazing variety of greenery in shrubs, tree, flowers etc. A calming walk along part of the harbour foreshore is an added bonus.
Stunning. What a beautiful place to take people & spend time, they encourage you to walk amongst the plants! Awesome!!
Pleasant peaceful gardens. Enjoyed daytime walking around in and early morning run through the gardens. Lots of people at both times. Interesting flora and birds.

Beautiful gardens and walk. Beautiful gardens and walk to the harbor. The actual gardens aren't that large but they're nice. There is lots of greenery, birds and water views so it's great place to relax and take a stroll or just sit and enjoy the views.

Peaceful spot on the middle of a bustling city. 200th birthday this year for the royal Botanical Gardens. Loved the architectural graveyard , the rolling lawns, the different plants and trees and the green-ness in the middle of the concrete city
Fascinating wildlife. You can wander at your leisure and see lots of flora and fauna that we don't see in the UK. We saw our first ibis ever, just pottering about, oblivious to the humans

A Fantastic Day. Always something different to find around a corner here. All the plants a labeled, so you can 'plant spot'. Yu can meander on the various paths or just do a circular route. Plenty of places to rest and when around the far end, excellent view back towards the Opera House. Various drinking fountains are dotted about. Surprising bits of art, ornate pools and a dollop of Japanese pagoda's to boot. Mostly on the flat, so good for people a little slower on their feet. There is a mini roadtrain that your can travel on to minimize your walk if you need too.
A Quiet Spot. Looking for a peaceful moment in the busy city to get away from the tourist hustle and bustle - look no further.

Beautiful gardens, plenty to see, wander around for hours!. Absolutely beautiful gardens! So many different sites and places, you can walk around for hours! There are maps regularly placed so you can check your route and decide on where to go next. From the more northern part of the gardens, you can find good spots to take pictures of the Opera House, too. Not for a rainy day, but if it's nice weather and you like gardens, this is a must-do!

Huge 75 acres of gardens. We took the little train for $5.00 pp to view the Gardens, you could hop on and off at various points along the way. It is very big so to walk it expect to take a day if you wish to do that. It was nice to have the narrative of the train driver for some of the area, such as the pink bananas, and various other plants you wouldn't know about unless someone told you.

Harbourside beauty and open green space on the city's doorstep. Take a walk through the many gardens in this gorgeous green space with a harbour backdrop.Join a guided walk with an experienced and knowledgeable guide or sit and enjoy the view from the cafe or restaurant.It's the Botanical Gardens 200th birthday this year so lots of things are happening.Get down there and get involved!

Must do for Sydney visitors and locals a like.... With amazing flora and fauna and stunning views of the harbour, opera house and harbour bridge, this is a must do for all those in Sydney. Take a picnic or just go for a casual stroll, great way to spend a day.
One of the best botanical gardens. When ever I am visiting a city I am going to have a look at it botanical garden. Sydney's one is a very lovely one with a lot of things to look at.

Beautiful. Lots to see here. A lovely quite experience with several different areas of plant life. This is an enormous area to cover so set a goodbye of time aside. You can access from Hyde park end which takes you through to the opera house. They have a little train that goes through the gardens at a cost of 10 dollars. Well worth it for the not so able bodied. Lovely areas for picnics. Lots of areas to sit and enjoy. Views when approaching the opera house are stunning across the bay.
Place of relaxation. Food and coffee limited but a few food trucks offering basic goods. The fitness lovers go crazy for this place but I just love the salty smell of fresh blooms everywhere.
Royal Botanic Gardens. Walking distance from Opera House. A huge place to walk and see but you can ride their mini train to have a quick look around for a fee.

Stunning gardens, great walk.. I´m not much for parks, but these gardens are worth checking out. They are wonderfully kept, with rose gardens, patches of grass from different states and countries, a huge variety of international trees and flowers, lagoons, statues. It´s amazing!! There are also a couple of cafe´s and a few toilet blocks around. Great view of the opera house and harbour bridge too without the crazy crowds. Much more relaxing!!
a beautiful place. This is a beautiful place depends on the season. We went in March, nothing much to see, other than trees and trees.

Nice place to spent some peaceful time amidst the buzz of the Sydney CBD. Nice place to spent some peaceful time amidst the buzz of the Sydney CBD. Within the garden is like a nature's retreat peace quiet and serenity with great view of the harbour yet aloof from the crowd n buzz of the busy streets just outside
Nicest picnic spot. Such a great place for picnics and walks. Excellent place for kids to run around, or adults actually. Beautiful views over the harbour - photo opportunities!

STUNNING - make time to see this. Beautiful gardens - filled with colour, scale and life. And really well thought out and laid out. Trees, flowers, birds, secret places and streams and pools - all totally delightful. Spend all day if you want.

Guided Walk. Learn about the plants, trees and shrubs of Australia. The guided tour was very good. The group was a variety of ages and the information was broad. The guide took questions as we were going along which kept things very interesting. The pace of the tour was easy for everyone. Wheelchairs can even make it thru these paths- a real plus.No matter what time of year- there is always something to see in an Australian Botanic Garden!

Free to visit. Huge gardens, be prepared for a lot of walking! we didn;t allow enough time to see it all unfortunately, but what we saw was well kept, there was plenty of information available. Make sure you pick up a map before wandering around.
Pretty . Nice way to spend half a day. Smaller than I expected - you can do it in a couple of hours. We sat with a beautiful view of the opera house for a few hours reading under a tree- lovely.

Frame the Opera house and Bridge from here. Vast well maintained grounds. Provides good photo vantage point to frame the opera house and bridge. The Governor's house is good too. Walk to the domain and see the Art Gallery of NSW while you are at it.

huge and wonderful. you can spend days discovering those beautiful gardens, very well maintained and wonderfully located on the waterfront. A nice way to enjoy it is to walk all the way from the opera to wooloomooloo! Don't miss the fern garden

Spacious clean and pretty gardens.. This year the gardens celebrate 200 years of being in existence so they are running little trip rides for a small fee around the gardens. Ideal for me as it takes only 20 minutes and I was short of time. You can hop on and hop off when you want to view on more detail the various areas. Plenty to see and great views across the harbour. I would love to go back to explore it more thoroughly.

Spend at least half day to visit this gardens. Garden is very well taken care. Perfect location for my families with young kids. Also from this location can have a good view of Sydney bridge and the opera house for taking photos.
So beautiful. We could spend all day here exploring the range of beauty, history, and special places to soak up nature. You can tell how both locals and visitors enjoy this destination.

Botanic Gardens are Sydney's lungs. The Royal Botanic Gardens are in the heart of the city of Sydney. I like to take a stroll through them whenever I'm in Sydney. Entry is free and the Gardens are open while it's light. The diversity of plants make for a pleasing viewing for an hour or so, more if you feel like it.

Garden Fantasy. The most beautiful, well-kept Botanical Gardens we have ever visited. The plant varieties are clearly indicated and the pathways have good signage. It was particularly exciting for me to see the cockatiels fly free.
Fine garden. Located centrally just South of the opera house this is a great place to visit. I recommend getting the little train to have a full experience of the gardens
Tranquil gardens. This is a great place for a relaxed stroll or an impromptu park bench picnic. Lots of birds, interesting botanicals, especially for those of us not from Australia.

Delightful. Full of interest, fabulous trees in particular.
Virtually next to Circular Quay and the Opera House.
Free to enter.
A delightful and fascinating country walk in the middle of the city

Beautiful Gardens, stunning location. The gardens are beautifully maintained with some wonderful fountains, statues and a great café and shop. Did not eat there the day I visited but did enjoy browsing through the shop, I was able to locate some seeds I had been searching for and bought a wonderful pair of kid gardening gloves for $25 that are so much better than the cheap stiff ones I had been using. Back to the gardens, I live in Sydney and had not visited these wonderful gardens for many years. It it worth a visit just for the amazing harbour views from some sections. This is one of the best kept botanical gardens I have visited, unique trees, flowers and shrubs all dislayed in beautifully manicured gardens and right next to the Sydney Opera House.

afternoon walk through the gardens. This was an unexpected treat for us. We hadn't had the gardens on part of our itinerary, but had a little extra time while we visited the CBD (Central Business District) and I am so glad we made it a point to get there. The gardens are really extensive, they seem larger than Central Park in NYC, and really quite beautiful. It's so peaceful, and for someone like me who loves to explore the flora of the place I am visiting, it was really special. I was in awe of the large fig trees which seem almost surreal and alienlike - so different from what we have in upstate New York. On my next visit I will be sure to take a good book and maybe a bottle of really good Australian wine and sit under a fig tree for the afternoon.

heaven.... Always forget how great it is to enjoy peace and quiet at this garden. Plenty of amazing spots to rest and enjoy the park its inhabitants. Sulfur crested cockatoos are a mischievous bunch, watch your fingers if want to pet them..
Soft and nice walk. So we arrived really tired in Sydney, because of the long flight.This was a pleasure visit, with birds, a well keeped garden, and finishing with the view of the bay.

Lovely oasis of calm in the city. I always love wandering around the Botanic Gardens - late afternoon is good on a hot day. Lots of birdlife and lovely trees and flowers. You can sit and relax, no need to rush. also head to the Art Gallery from here but the best way is to go via Lady Macquaries chair and follow the path that runs along the sea towards Boy Charlton pool then up to the AGNSW.

Beautiful place . The gardens are full of blooming flowered and fantastic trees with lots of amazing wildlife to look at too. It's lovely to walk round as there are lots of shaded areas to cool off in on a hot day. Plenty to look and and the views are incredible. Well
Worth a visit

Layout and plant markings lacking. All areas (rest rooms, dining, etc.) were "a 1 minute walk" but then the trails wound around so deviously that things were difficult to find. Even a sign for the rest rooms from the dining cafe was off: it said to go around the side of the "gift shop" for RRs, but they named the gift shop a "Garden Shop" so it was confusing. Plants were not groups pleasantly or marked consistently. It's just fine for a park, but not the greatest for seeing a great variety of native species. That said, the walks just out side it (to Mrs. Macquaries' chair, for instance) were lovely!

Need some exercise?. The gardens are very extensive. Bring some water but spacious and beautiful. With great views of the harbor and the opera house government house should not be missed. The sulphur crested cockatoos are everywhere letting you know they are watching you. The restaurant is nice and so is the garden shop. You will walk a couple of miles regardless of where you enter. Enjoy

Serene . Enjoyed visiting this place as part of our walking tour. Well kept with lots of interesting foliage. It's free to go in. To have a botanical garden and the city skyscrapers on the background is inspiring.
Amazing place. All day between beautiful plants, sometimes you can expect nice attractions like tomato festival - try everything!
Gorgeous . The roses were in bloom. It is a beautiful place to walk around, take some pictures and enjoy the beauty that surrounds you.
As Gardens. This is also a must see when anyone comes to Sydney, I will be back one day. things here are so beautiful

The Green Heart of Sydney. Look at a map of central Sydney and you will notice that the city has been blessed by sharing as much open space and parks as it does with the built up landscape. The three major green spaces that make up much of this area, Hyde Park, The Domain and The Royal Botanical Gardens are all linked and not unlike St James' and Green parks in London, flow naturally from on to the next. In Sydney's case however, it is down towards the Harbour that you are drawn.It's a great way to relax by strolling through the whole green space or start outside the old Sydney Hospital at the top of Martin Place, cut through this historic precinct and out onto the Domain which also doubles as playing fields for the "office bound" to let off steam at lunchtime. Directly across the Domain is the Art Gallery of NSW - worth sometime on its own - or turn left (North) and stroll into the Botanic Gardens where in the early colonial days, gardens were established to help feed the infant Sydney Town. One of the early Georgian gardens declared in 1816, the "RBG" is a priceless jewel for any city and is still an active botanical laboratory. Shaded palmways, bubbling creeks and sweeping lawns head down hill to the semi circular stone harbour wall. To your left is the Opera House, the right hand point is "Mrs Macquaries Seat" named after the wife of Sydney's most progressive colonial Governor, and arguably Sydney's finest viewpoint.There are a couple of reasonable food outlets, great for a sunny lunch, and in early Autumn, there is Grand Opera performed on floating stages along side Farm Cove with the Opera House and Harbour Bridge as a magnificent backdrops. 2015 was Aida - the best Ive seen - 2016 is Turandot...not to be missed.Feel like a swim on a warm day, visit 'Boy' Charlton Pool on the Harbour's edge. A swank public pool that enjoys a reputation for eye candy!So The Botanical Gardens in Sydney - a green lung for the city that overlooks it...

Beautifully Kept, A Great Stroll. We were short on time and happened to get lucky, grabbing a little tram that whisked us in and around the Gardens. What a wonderful getaway, just steps away from the Opera House. Beautiful.

Worth taking the train around. Well worth the little train ride around the gardens. It was informative and we would have missed parts on foot. Walking around the gardens along the foreshore afterwards was delightful and peaceful.

One of the world's nicest public gardens. So relaxing, such beautiful gardens and flowers, one of the best views in the world and such a contrast to the nearby CBD. Close to transport at Circular Quay so very accessible. Now celebrating its 200 years of existence.

Beautiful gardens . I absolutely loved the gardens. Even better than Central Park in NYC. The gardens have multiple different areas of specific gardens as well as lovely path along the harbor. Great place for a run in Sydney or to just stroll through
Gorgeous. There are so many interesting trees and little spots to chill out. Perfect place to spend a day with friends.

Lovely gardens with some outstanding views of the harbour. The views from the gardens are outstanding and great for photographers. The cafe was nice too and the food quality was good. Great place for some shade on hot days too. Shame the fruit bats aren't there anymore but i guess i can understand why.

An amazing collection of plants from around the world!. Unique collection of plants from Australia & overseas! It's a major botanical garden located in the heart of the city, opened in 1816, the garden is the oldest scientific institution in Australia and one of the most important historic botanical institutions in the world. It is open every day of the year and access is free. Its stunning position on Sydney Harbour and immediately adjacent to the Sydney CBD, the Sydney Opera House and the large public parklands of The Domain ensure it is one of the most visited attractions in Sydney.

Amazing city park. This must be one of the best city parks that we have visited, with beautiful views of both the city and the harbour. We were amazed at the amount of wildlife in the park and how well the gardens were kept. Very pleasant time spent exploring here.

dont miiss it !!. it's a wonderful place full of birds. you can walk around have a coffee or a nice lunch in the restaurant or just admire the view.. you can see many people lie on the grass eating drinking or reading... why don't do the same? don't miss it, it's worth to spend even a whole day there...

Chair above the Gardens. Visitors always love to visit this area - but first we take them to Mrs Macquaries Chair - offering (parking of you are fortunate) and a view of the Botanic Gardens, the harbour, the various coves across the lower North Shore.When we have the time we walk thru the Bot. Gdns - they are lovely - but to do them justice you need a couple of hours to take all the various harbour views, gardens, lawns, hillsides and stands of trees_ the landscaping is a mix of 19th & 20th centuries

Gorgeous . With one of the most beautiful harbour views possible, the botanic gardens is a glorious place to get lost in. Either visit to actually marvel at each plant specimen, or laze on the lawns with a picnic, the gardens are a special place we should all encourage to protect and enhance.

Take a picnic and enjoy the view. With one of the best views in Sydney this is the place to have a family picnic. Watch the eels in the pond or marvel at the native flora or just watch the boats go by.

Important for City Folk. I found them acceptable and somewhat interesting. What interested me was the abundance of normal garden vege patch plants. Probably good for apartment dwellers to see where food comes from, :).

A serene beautiful place!. Have you been travelling for a while (too long) and are looking for a relaxing time but you still want to be out in Sydney rather than snoozing on your bed then the Botanic Gardens are for you. You can walk a lot or as little as you want. Lots of people go there from the surrounding offices to eat their lunch or have a jog. You can have a snooze or your your book as you lie on the grass. There are many beautiful gardens- I love the rose gardens when in season. There are wonderful views from behind the Opera house or Mrs Macquaries chair where on the weekend you can see yacht races. If you have children there is enough space for them to run wild without getting in the way. As you enter one of the entrance gates have a good look at the map to work out where you want to go. Their is a restaurant there too.

200 years old . The Gardens are celebrating the 200th Anniversary this year - Oldest Gardens in Australia. Very scenic location, right next to the Opera House and with beautiful views of this, the Harbour and the Bridge. We took the Choo Choo Train around the 75 acres - $10 for each adult. There are 4 stops and you can join the next train in 30 min. The Garden Shop is charming with garden-themed merchandise.

Peace and quiet in the midst of the city. Its truly amazing to find this jewel in the midst of the metropolis. Its a hidden jewel. You don't want to miss the joy of enjoying this beautiful garden. It starts by the harbour and ends in the midst of the busy city. Much beauty exists between.
Just as I remembered . There is a nice little palm cove by opera house, cool and palm and fern covered relief from the heat of summer

My peaceful place. I lived in Sydney for 2 months. And whenere I needed a quiet spot (you cannot find that in sydney centre) I went to the Rotal Botanic Gardens. You have so much to see there. Different plants and trees from all over the world. Magnificent paths through the park.It is a great place to walk or to just sit and read a book
Great opportunity to see some native birds. As well as being packed with plants this large park is home to loads of cockatoos, ibis etc. A great green area in the city and makes a lovely walk.
Lovely. Right in the centre of the city in a super position near Sydney Opera House, easy to get to and well laid out. A very relaxed feel.

Pleasant gardens, but prefer Melbourne. Sydney Botanical gardens have great views of the harbour and bridge/ opera house, but fewer flowers than Melbourne. That said, still a very pleasant area, despite the really big spiders!!

A beautiful place to spend the day. I love this garden, you can really get lost in here. Pack a picnic, and take your time, there are so many beautiful and varied species of plants here and the fig trees are beautiful and majestic. Along the water, a nice place to spend on a sunny day, too, with lots of respite in the shade.

Beautiful Park. This is a lovely Botanical garden and super location on the bay in the heart of Sydney.Very accessible.The Garden covers quite a large area,so it is a place you can revisit.It is always a privelage and a pleasure to walk through a green space in a city.This is well maintained and deserves a visit.Spring would be a better time to go for the flowering time.

Majestic and grand. Easy to enter, walk around, relax, and marvel at these old majestic trees. There are many spots from where you can overlook the harbor, and get the best views. And there are, close by, the Cathedral, the Public Library, the Lookout, and the war memorial.

Sweet place. Didn't see enough of this place but was only in Sydney for a day so visited on the little train that runs through the gardens. What we saw was amazing and would love to see again when more time. It was a very hot day when we were there and lovely to get some shade from the many trees and flora there. The little train is good if you are not able to walk to far and so not to miss out. It runs not far from the Opera House and is reasonable price.

Extensive and impressive..... Enjoyed a lovely walk through these well-maintained gardens so close the the Opera House. Would have liked to take the tour and look through the shop but was closed on the day of our visit (New Year's Day)
Loved the fern house. The fern house was thebestbit forme. Visited on a very hot day. The fern. House was a great place to keep cool.

Delightful . These gardens are delightful whether you are looking for flora to admire, a spot to picnic or just take a walk. The gardens also contain a restaurant and a boutique as well as Government House.
A Beautiful walk. The gardens are just gorgeous and always well maintained. It is lovely to stroll through them during lunch or on a lazy afternoon

Free park, has a free guided tour. We went in the morning and took the free guided tour at 10:30am. We walked around a little bit before the tour, looked at the plants and read some of the information on the plaques in front of the plants, it was pretty good, I would rate that a 4/5. The guided tour is what made it amazing for me and my husband! We love hearing the story behind the plants and the history. Our guide was very knowledgeable and patient. We had quite a large tour, probably 15-20 people (the guide said it was the largest he had ever had), but it worked well. The guide answered all questions and there was plenty of time for pictures. The tour ran a little more than an hour. Very worth the time!! If you go to the gardens, try to catch a tour, you won't regret it!

Nice place to watch running. The gardens are lovely, and best of all FREE! There is a ton of people running through the gardens at all times of the day, so that was an interesting site. We strolled through here to see the opera house at sunset and it didn't disappoint.

Beautiful Oasis in thee Heart of Sydney. Adjacent to Opera House, gardens has beautiful walks, historic buildings and for the "lazy" a choo choo ride with several stops that will take you through gardens. This is 200th anniversary of park and well worth a visit.

Free park with great views.. The park is nice panoramic view of famous Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Unique flowers. Road train runs periodically inside the park which most kids may like. Garden shop is also very nice.
free fun aweful toilets. bad terrible aweful disgusting dirty gross icky gunky toilets but very beautiful parks and museums and history loved it a lot

A beautiful place to stroll, especially with overseas visitors. To be in such beauty a few minutes from the pulsing heart of the noisy city is just bliss. It is such a lovely place to wander. Love the shop, and we always have a coffee and a treat. On your own, feeling blue, take a book, sit under a tree and watch the people passing parade and the sun on the harbour.

Beautiful Botanical Gardens!. Walked over and spent a fabulous day walking around the gardens in gorgeous sunshine! A great place to visit! The flowers, trees, lizards were all amazing! The cafe was excellent especially the fresh fruit pot!! Just what was needed! Great views over Sydney Bridge too!
RBG. Lovely walks, great gardens with excellent views across the Harbour. The Opera House and Bridge stand out in all their glory

Simply Beautiful!. Beautifully relaxing. Well maintained with stunning gardens all within a stones throw of the Opera House and all that Circular Key has to offer. Well worth a gentle stroll to take in the beauty, the calm, the birds and the weather!
Beautiful gardens to wander. The Sydney Botanic Gardens are lovely to wander through, particularly on a hot day. Lovely to walk to Mrs Macarthur's Chair from The Opera House through them.
Botanic lovers. The Palm walk and fernnery were spectacular. Lovely peaceful place to relax for a while. Good views over Sydney harbour

Wonderful to stroll thru. wonderful location....and an easy walk many seats to sit and gaze at the wonderful harbour....also you will learn about Australian flowers and trees...anytime is a good time to visit
If you like plants. Great relaxing spot in the heart of town. Some really interesting specimens if you are interested in plants. Nice harbor views.

Little quiet oasis. Great to get away from the hustle and bustle of Sydney and see the locals out running at lunchtime. Lovely area to walk around with good informative notes about the plants and the different gardens. Good cafe, not at all expensive. Go and enjoy the peace and quiet.

Great views for a walk or a picnic. Such a large park! Great place for a picnic, stroll or just someone to take a nap in the sun. So many plants including native and foreign. A few ponds and great signs for directions. There is even a restaurant in the middle of the park. Good water views too from here. Best enjoyed during sunny days.
Fantastic views of the Harbor. Unbelievable views of the harbour plus the grounds are immaculate. Lots of visitors so go early in the day. Well worth taking a couple hours just to stroll around.

A very pleasant morning. Beautiful gardens that offered a peaceful walk in the middle of a very busy city. Went there whilst they were having a celebration of tomatoes. Sounds strange but it was hugely entertaining.
A must for travellers to Sydney, along with the ANZAC memorial in Hyde Park, very moving place.

MUST SEE in Sydney-See it together with Hyde Park. Sure this is highlight place to see when you are in Sydney. We went there in January with family. We also saw some other family travelers with young kids. Very leisured experience, we can sit down and enjoy the time, reading, thinking, playing with your kids, It is a must see area.

Wedding Venue. We recently attended a wedding in the Rose Garden at the Sydney Botanic Gardens.Unfortunately there was no shade on offer during the ceremony and it was a warm and very sunny day. But apart from that, it was a peaceful & scenic venue, virtually in the heart of the city.What I saw of the gardens were well maintained and thoughtfully laid out. I would have liked to spend more time exploring.
Lovely gardens. One of the best botanic gardens I've been in, far better than all of the other little parks in the area (e.g Hyde Park). You could spend hours here

Excellent day out. On arrival in Sydney, we chose to visit the Gardens on recommendation of our friends. We weren't disappointed. Lovely views & immaculately kept gardens. Well worth a visit to view the Harbour Bridge & Opera House.
Beautiful gardens . Loved the serenity of this garden. Beautiful flowers, trees and birds. Walking and having a picnic in this garden is a wonderful way to spend your day with your loved ones.

An oasis of calm on a hot day!. A short walk along from the Opera House and well worth visiting, especially on a hot day as the many trees offer nice cooling shade and there is also an air conditioned café in the centre. It is a very good way to get a feel for the flora and fauna of the area from when the first visitors arrived and there is a section of the gardens devoted to telling the story of those first pioneers. There is also a lovely rose garden which is worth a look at and is often the venue for weddings. On certain days you can also visit the Governors Palace although it is best to check as the opening times are quite restricted.

Beautiful and relaxing. The gardens are a real jewel in the heart of the city, a bit of a cliche but true. There are some great walks, wonderful views of the plants and the harbour as well as some interesting wild life. Very restful after all the hubbub of a busy city. And there is a cafe.

Definitely worth a visit!. These are perhaps the best gardens I have ever visited. The displays are immaculate and flawless! There is a beautiful array of plant species and floral varieties around the gardens and plenty of areas to relax with a picnic. The shop is very good with lovely gift ideas. Views of the Opera House are also good.
great stroll. If want to get away from city noise etc, afternoon stroll in garden great way to relax. Great views of Opera house and Sydney Harbour also.

Lovely views!. I've visited Sydney a number of times and never get tired of the Gardens. Such a beautiful and peaceful place right in the heart of the city. Nice for a walk or a picnic. Definitely worth a visit if you come to Australia.
Relaxing gardens. Great place to go and relax. Great views of the bridge and opera house. Lots going on in the gardens as this is their 200th year

Lovely place - such dramatic backdrop . Great place to explore, with over 25 acres of gardens , with greenhouses and other exhibitions .
Some reasonable places to eat
Stunning views, lovely gardens.. A beautiful little pocket of calm in the chaos of the city. What a lucky park - and one of the best views over the harbour too. Take a picnic, relax & enjoy.
Sit in the chair!. Mrs. Macquaries Chair was carved out of rock because she so loved the view. Not so great anymore, as it looks out on to the naval ships, but the Botanic Gardens are lovely.

Beautiful gardens. On nice day walking the gardens is a pleasure, the gardens are well maintained, watch out for wild Australian lorikeets that fly by ,you can sit and relax in the park, best enter from gardens and walk to Sydney harbour and opera house side ,you can also walk on outskirts garden to mrs maquarie chair .Its really quiet and relaxing spot

Huge garden for everyone. It's a huge gardens near the Mrs Macquaries point, Sydney opera house, government house and Art gallery of New South Wales. Wonderful place to spend as long as you like. Superb.

Green space near the CBD. This green space is an oasis in the city, it sprawls from the CBD to the harbour next to the Opera House. The trees offer some shade in the summer months and you can always get a cool drink in the reasonably priced cafe.
Oasis in the city. What a great place to find in the city of Sydney. It offers those nice green and quiet spots that can be a delight to relax in.

Wonderful! . Royal Botanic Gardens were wonderful & very enjoyable. Walking around seeing the beautiful gardens & varied wildlife. It was soon approaching Anzac Day so the gardens had a memorial display which was lovely. Me & partner walked the length of the gardens & to the harbour Opera which looked fantastic. They were setting up a theatre show however, after enquiring all the tickets were sold out. It would of been a fantastic setting with the bridge & opera house in the background. Botanical gardens is another must see in Sydney! Try not to get lost!!

Nice stroll. If you want a slower paced adventure in Sydney, then a walk in this park would be a good option. The park is filled with a good variety of plants and flowers, and the scientific names of each are even posted, which could actually turn your sightseeing into an educational trip, if you are into that stuff :) There are also some interesting spots for those souvenir shots. And when you get to the other end (towards the Sydney harbour), you will again be rewarded this time by magnificent views of the harbour and the Sydney Opera House

World Class. Simply beautiful. We thoroughly enjoyed spending a few hours in this wonderfully established, set out and maintained resource in the heart of the city. Native species, supported by informative display and labelling, local birdlife coupled with outstanding vistas across the city and the harbour in particular.These Royal Botanical Gardens as good as it gets and provide those rich in experience as London’s Kew Gardens and those in Singapore.Outstanding!

Okay sort of gardens. Went for a walk here before a cruise out of Sydney. To be honest it is good for a walk, picnic or relaxing stroll with friends but there is nothing really in the form of tourist attractions here. It is just a good place to relax.
Stunning Views. You have a gorgoues Garden to walk through which can take a few hours, you will be blown away with breath taking views.It is a great day activity in the city of Sydney.

Great place to check out. Well worth taking a walk around here and seeing all the nature that surrounds you. There is a cafe should you be too hot and needing a quick drink or bite to eat while there.

Great Place For A Stroll Or a Picnic. We enjoyed several strolls around the Botanical Gardens during our stay in Sydney. There is a nice restaurant and cafeteria here and a good gift shop. Well worth a visit.
Perfect way to spend a few hours!. We walked all around this beautiful garden. The flowers and trees are amazing. A great place to stroll and have a picnic lunch or a nap!
Beautiful botanical gardens walk. The Sydney botanical gardens walk starts from next to the opera house and we spend about 2.5 hours exploring the bird life and plant life. Well worth a visit.

Breathtaking. The gardens are well kept and the amount of forna is amazing. Was such a beautiful walk through the gardens around to the opera house. Would love to do it again when it's not quite as hot.

Stunning beauty and experience in nature!!. Spent hours, literally hours in the Botanic Gardens. So beautiful and a great place to sit and have a picnic lunch. Lots of walking to take some water with you.

A Beautiful Place. My wife and I walked through the Sydney Botanical Gardens are were absolutely amazed at the beauty of the Gardens. There are so many areas with so many beautiful plants and tress that represent so many different environments. Really a great place to go spend a nice walk.
As a bonus - there is no charge!!

Beautiful . We walked from our hotel through the city to the Botanic gardens, such a beautiful place lots of plants, wildlife and areas to talk beautiful pictures We stopped for breakfast a the Botanic cafe which serves various food options, soft drinks, juices and alcoholic drinks. You can sit outside whilst the many species of birds roam around you. After a short walk you end up at the Opera house, Sydney harbour and the Bridge.

Very relaxing. What better way to spend the afternoon than a picnic in the sunshine. I would suggest to all to head to the gardens and enjoy all the open space and wildlife, you will not be disappointed!

Free and relaxing exercise with views of the harbour. Entry to the Gardens is free.This attraction has all the things that one would expect from a botanic garden. There are garden plots with ground plaques giving information about flowers and plants. Also there are fountains and statues, rolling grassland, huge Morton Bay fig trees, and a lake.Even if you are not an avid gardener, this is a beautiful place for a walk. At the north western end of the gardens is the Sydney Opera House. To the north east is Mrs. Macquarie's Chair. From the headland at Mrs. Macquarie's Chair you can get the best views of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge together.At the south eastern end of the gardens is the Art Gallery of NSW. About 300 metres south of the gardens along Macquarie are St St.Mary's Cathedral and Hyde Park.So enjoy a walk in the most beautiful park of the city.
Lovely place to walk . Called on my way from my walk in this area a real good place very colourfull with all the flowers and other intersting things

Oasis in the middle of Sydney. Sydney Botanical Gardens is located next to the Opera House, and is a fantastic area to visit. The gardens are well maintained, there is plenty of grass to sit on and relax, or have a quick nap, or just take in the views of Sydney Harbour or the Opera House. The grounds are free to visit and is highly recommended if you are in the vicinity of the Opera House.
Oasis in Sydney. Pretty place to see very well maintained large area nice to have a picinic stunning photo good place for a wedding there were a few when. We visited

Beautiful gardens. It was great to see such great outdoor space being used so well in the centre of such an iconic city. We were there over the weekend so families were out enjoying the sun and picnicking. A good venue for outdoor weddings too.

Fabulous gardens. For any horticultural lover these gardens are amazing, so many different plants in a fabulous setting. Lots of interesting facts that children can absorb as well as adults. A mini train that takes you around and commentary ensures you don't miss anything. A cafe where you can sit outside and enjoy coffee and a cake, a must not miss attraction!

Pleasant. A most pleasant hour spent in these beautiful gardens which are well laid out and have a great variety of different areas to enjoy. Many quiet places to sit and relax away from the busy quayside.

Perfect location. We had my cousins wedding here yesterday and it was simply perfection. The view was outstanding, the set up was beautiful and the grounds were in immaculate condition.Our only grief was that the Rangers didn't do anything to assist the guests turning up, we had to locate them ourselves to understand where the wedding was so it would of been nice if they were being proactive about assisting people.

Beautiful oasis of calm centrally located within sydney. These gardens are wonderful. Something for everyone - including a cho cho train ride starting at Opera House gates entrance with 4 stops at different parts of the garden, Hop on hop off as long as you keep to the circuit. Allows you an overview of the gardens otherwise be preapred to spend a full day walking to take in everything. I managed 2 hours and will go back for more... Restaurant/Cafe and shops. Plenty of options to sit and ponder or have a pic nic under one of the huge shady trees....

This is a beautiful, relaxing place!. I run around the perimeter of this beautiful part of Sydney most mornings. On weekends, I will frequently just spend an hour or two walking the grounds or just finding a quiet spot to sit on the grass and enjoy the views of the Sydney Harbor. There are many birds to watch and occasionally a opossum wandering through. The plants are well-maintained, beautiful, and commonly have a placard next to them to tell you their official species' name. You can also look for eels and carp swimming in the ponds. You can also just take a walk past the Opera House and thru the Gardens to Mrs. Macquarie's Point and have great views of the Harbour Bridge, Opera House, and the Harbour itself.
beautiful garden. Its big, refreshing, clean and soo green.Love all the unique kinds of flowers here.I get to touch and smell the tulips!great to come at any time during the day!

Beautiful and fun to explore. Definitely check out the Botanic Gardens in Sydney. We walked from Hyde Park up through the Botanic Gardens to the Opera House and it was perfect. Make sure that you leave ample time to explore the gardens thoroughly as they are stunning, particularly when everything is in bloom. Don't forget to explore the paths along the exterior that are on the water to see some amazing views of Sydney. Many locals use the park to run, workout, picnic, etc and it is a beautiful spot to relax in as well as explore! Would absolutely recommend!

Free guided walk adds to the interest and relaxation . A great place to wander,relax and enjoy plant and bird life.Also a great view of the opera house and bridge.coffee shop is good for snacks.quiet spot in the centre of the city .The free guided walk by volunteers was fascinating
Great, relaxing walk. Right next to the Opera House and worth the time if you enjoy well manicured grounds with a wide variety of foliage.

Nice gardens, great harbor view. It's not the greatest botanical garden I've ever been to, bit it was still quite nice and worth the price (free). Being walking distance from Sydney Harbour and having great views of the harbor also make it a great reason to come here.

Lovely gardens. A walk in these gardens is a wonderful escape from busy central Sydney. The views across the harbour are fantastic and the gardens are full of life and interesting specimens. Go over to the Andrew 'Boy' Charlton pool afterwards for a swim and/or visit the cafe. Green reviver!

Pleasant day for a stroll . We spent an afternoon in the park. It was very stroller and young children friendly. There was ample to see, and loads of green space to roam around. The Lady Macquarie lookout was definitely worth the trek as it afforded a fantastic view of the Opear House and Sydney bridge. It was also not overly crowded, which was also nice.

Total relaxation. We had an early evening walk after a long hard day touristic. It was delightful. We walked to Mrs Macquaries chair and then back along the sea front in about an hour, and enjoyed the variety of trees and plants and the profusion of strange (to a European) birdlife, parakeets, ducks, ibis, and many others. There are many interesting corners to investigate and from the viewpoint near the chair, there are great views with the Opera House lining up with the Harbour Bridge. Well worth a visit, and a nicely maintained facility.

Beautiful. It's an oasis in a busy city. Close to the harbor, major hotels, Opera House, and Circular Quay. If you're in the area, you owe it to yourself to take a quiet walk through these beautiful gardens.
You have to go. It's a great place to run, to take pictures and be with friends. I loved. Theres a coffee shop and good restrooms. Definitly if you are in Sydney you have to go there.

Nice stroll around the gardens - but easier to take the train. Strolled around the lovely gardens, but quite large so decided to hop on the $10 train which circumnavigates the gardens every 35 mins or so - bonus some nice young ladies normally drive ! we saw all the gardens this way and also around the harbour with views of the bridge and the opera house, where the train tour starts. Nice gardens, but nothing wonderful.
Beautiful well kept gardens. You can not come to Sydney and not visit this park, it is beautiful.So well kept and the views of the Bridge and harbour etc are spectacular.Very special
Good for morning walk. Very good place for morning walk and take some photos.... Big garden... And lot of sight seeing places around in tha lt area.... Worth a visit!!

A must visit when you are in Sydney City!!. This has to be one of the best places to visit when you want to have a wander around the harbour or want to have a picnic. The views are to die for and there are many places to sit and just watch the passing parade. We put a picnic basket together and spent bout 4 hours here. Could have spent the whole day very easily!! Come and check it out. You won't be disappointed!!!

A must visit. Even as locals we tend to visit the Botanical Gardens every few years, not only as a relaxing, peaceful stroll but also to see the various seasonal changes and to take in special events that are held there on a regular basis. Then there is the backdrop setting of Sydney Harbour, a sight in itself. Our last visit coincided with the Sydney Tomato Festival. We bought some produce but overall it was on a small scale.GL

Sydney Sunshine and the beautiful botanical gardens - well worth a visit. The botanical gardens were recommended by a good friend and it certainly lived up to the recommendation. There's something here for everyone, great wildlife, water features, stunning scenery and above all a place to take time out relax and enjoy the stunning views. We thought the garden cafe was very good value for money, with quality menu choices over and above the standard expectations. The sunshine made it a very memorable day, so what are you waiting for, get going and see for yourself !

A must do attraction for lovers of nature..
