More of a park than a Botanic garden. We enjoyed a walk here but discovered that much of it is open parkland with mature trees. There are small specialist areas with native plants. It was very pleasant but not what we expected.

Beautiful!. Beautiful gardens, and fantastic views of the harbor and the Sydney Opera House. A great place for a walk or to catch some sun. I've been to many similar parks and botanical gardens in many world class cities, and the Royal Botanic Gardens is one of the best I've seen.

Beat the heat in summer. As a family we try and see a Botanic garden where ever we go, when it comes to Sydney all I can say is what a view and if you want to escape the heat find your self a tree and it drops 10 degrees. Enjoy
Nice, expansive, diverse, relaxing. Nice large gardens centrally located with lots of diversity. Lots of open space. Especially liked the rose garden and the rainforest area.

Beautiful gardens by the Harbour. The Botanical Gardens are well worth the visit. There are beautiful walkways through the gardens, which lead down to the harbour side. There are some magnificent trees well worth a photo. Plenty of places to sit in the shade and chill out. Photos back towards the Opera House and Harbour Bridge from Mrs Macquarie's chair are well worth the walk. It's a real break from the hub of the city.

Massive Botanic Garden. It was a rainy day when I visited this botanical garden. It is massive and I was not able to cover 1 or 2 parts of it but I was amazed on the flora and fauna available here. They are amazing and I am myself a fan of botanical garden. Also, there is one side of the garden that has a seaside view of the Opera House too.

Spectacular Sydney . The botanical gardens are just great for a free thing to do with kids. Walk around to the main pond, there's fish and what looks like eels in there. On a sunny day it doesn't get better. The ice creams at the Cafe are a rip off, if you can wait walk out to Macquarie Street and buy one from the convenience store

We Walked Through the Gardens Rather Than Take a Train. We went to the NSW Art Gallery. Rather than taking a train from St James to Circular Quay, we walked through the Gardens back to the ferry. It is a lovely place where, incidentally, our son was married some time ago. Even though that marriage is no more, the place brings us fond memories. It is so peaceful.

Beautyful and perfect view of Sydney Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge. The Royal Botanic Gardens offers plants of a very various nature from all over Australia. The gardens further more offers the perfect view of Sydney Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge

Botanical gardens. The botanical gardens are opposite the Sydney national gallery. I combined these on the same day. Very helpful ladies at the entrance who gave me a map showed me the best locations and how long it would take to walk to these. I went on a very hot day. They recommended the ferns which were spectacular and cool to walk through. I then walked to Mrs Macquarie 's point which has a great view of Sydney harbour bridge and the opera house. It takes about 20 minutes to walk to the point and lovely flame trees and plants to look at on the way. A really lovely walk mainly on the flat. It is well signposted and there is a nice cafe for lunch.

Beautiful and Informative!. I entered the Gardens from one of the downtown accesses and was impressed right from there to the exit at the Opera House. The Harbour Bridge entrance was also there and the traffic was insane, but crossing the pedestrian pathways was quick and efficient.The trees and other foilage is all labeled with information. There is several areas to rest or take a seat. The sculptures were plentiful and a great addition to the flora. I saw business exec's and families all seeking refuge in the park, it was great!

Choo Choo Express Tour of Royal Botanic Gardens. For something different as a local (and at my wife's urging), we took the Choo Choo Express tour of the Royal Botanic Gardens. Our guide, Amy was very knowledgeable and kept the tour interesting. The tour takes you on a loop tour from and back to the Opera House going through the gardens. There are four stops along the way and you're entitled to one stop (if you choose) as part of the ticket. The price is very reasonable and suits those time pressed for sight seeing or those who might be less physically able. It lasts about 25 minutes without stops. For those who have more time, then the gardens have hours of walks to enjoy.
Royal Botanic Gardens. Great place to relax and enjoy the day, whether you just take a stroll through or have a picnic there.
Superb!!!. The Royal Botanical Gardens are absolutely beautiful! Very well done in terms of walking trails, vistas, plant variety and upkeep! Worth visiting many, many times!

A quiet respite in the big city. This is an oasis in the city. It provides a lot of history of plants and trees as well as the history of Sydney and the effect of Europeans on the original people and landscape of the island. A great view of the Opera house as well as colourful plants and trees.

Ok but not a must see. Walked around here after going to see the opera house. It's not incredible but it's a nice casual walk.
It's just south of the Opera house and takes you back towards some shops and town.
Pack a picnic. There are two recommended spots for a picnic in Sydney, Observation Hill or The Botanic Gardens, both offer sweeping views of the city.

Great views of the iconic harbour. The Botanic Gardens are really relaxing, beautifully presented and cared for. There is a stunning collection of tropical plants from across the world and some of the best views and photo opportunities of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge from various vantage points within the gardens.This free attraction is a great way to wind down and spend a morning in Sydney.Highly recommended.

Refeshing for the city slicker. Lots of different sections, but I particularly liked the food garden section. It struck me that many city dwellers may never have had a garden, and that it may be good for them to see how their food looks in he ground! And smells when fresh.

A Jewel in Sydney City. This is a beautiful jewel in Sydney. The royal botanic gardens are full of beautiful garden delights just on the edge of the hustle and bustle of the city and framed by the harbour. Walk to the Opera House via the Gardens and avoid the noise of the city streets. You will not regret it.

An oasis in the heart of the city. Right behind the Opera House are these wonderful gardens where you can happily spend half a day. If you turn up at the shop at 10.30 any morning you can join a free guided tour led by one of the volunteers. Not only are there some magnificent trees, shrubs and flowers but also many birds and all with picturesque views of the Sydney waterfront. The shop itself is well worth a visit if you are looking for gifts for friends who enjoy gardens and there is a cafe where you have something to eat.

Fantastic..... It took two visits to get round the gardens and I'm sure we still missed some of it. The gardens are fantastic and free to walk around. They can be accessed from just outside the opera house and you can continue to walk to the viewing point at Mrs Macquarie's Chair. Refreshments are available at the top of the hill where you can also get great views of the other side of the bay. You can also get the little land train around the gardens if you don't fancy walking it, this is guided but chargeable and leaves every 30 minuites from the gates near the opera house. Pick up one of the free maps available around the gardens to make sure you see everything they also include information about other guided walks which are free. We even did some celeb spotting whilst we were here, Def Leopard were doing a bit of sight seeing too!

A day with the family. I have been going to the Gardens since a small child. Am now 72. Good idea to visit every year to take in new and growing plants. Kids' love the Gardens. Drop in to the Art Gallery on the way out. A great day.

Nice way to kill a few hours or make a day of it. Nice walking paths all through the gardens. Really enjoyed the herb garden with the signs telling you what they are plus the uses of each one. Trees, flowers, herbs, bushes, large grassy areas to relax or picnic. Benches scattered around to take a short rest when it gets really hot out.

Beautiful Walk. The walk from the Sydney Harbour to the Botanical Gardens is only a short distance. There are several entrances and it is worth the walk. Not only are the gardens stunning,but the walk along the perimeter of the gardens follows Sydney harbour with fabulous views of watercraft and ships. Even if you are not a nature lover, it is well worth the extra effort to take a stroll or just relax on a bench. No need to take a guided tour unless you are an avid gardener. Also, this attraction is no fee.
Nice outdoor place . It's nice to go there for a walk between trees and nice scenery. It's good for long walks, probably it's gonna take you days to finish exploring this place.

Relaxed day out. Beautifully maintained gardens right next to the opera house with a beautiful view of the harbour. Within the gardens, you'll find a variety of different plants and trees in the heart of the city
Good for Gardeners!. We took the free 10.30 guided tour. Our guide was very knowledgeable especially on the indigenous plants in the gardens. We learnt so much and found it very interesting.

Great Garden. Huge expansive botanical garden to stroll for several hours, beautifully landscaped garden pleases the eyes as you walk through the endless pathways leading to the Mrs. Macquaries Point. Make sure you have a good pair of shoes for the walk can be very long due to many paths and the view towards the end is simply amazing.

Lovely, peaceful gardens. Very large and well maintained gardens in the very heart of Sydney with good views of the city skyline and also of the Harbour Bridge and Opera House.Lots of places to relax and have a picnic.The gardens are also very clean
Wonderful. Loved the area- benches, walks to get best city views, public conveniences, a Botanic garden restaurant..this place has it all!

An Oasis of calm in a city of delights. The Botanic Gardens snuggle around Farm Cove in the very heart of Sydney, right next to the Opera House and provide welcome respite from traipsing the streets. Lush corners of calm and tranquility abound, you can exercise, or sleep, cuddle or stroll to your heart's delight.
Lovely views. As a self confessed lover of Sydney, I am completely bias. The botanic gardens are such a lovely place for a walk and are always a hive of activity.

Amazing. Simply amazing, you must visit for walk or jog.The botanic gardens has unique variety of trees and plants. Well designed walks ways and places to sit or take some pictures. If you are nature lover and like fresh air breath then its a place to visit

Wonderfully maintained. Gardens are wonderfully maintained and provide a welcome retreat from the hustle ans bustle of a city centre. Bound by the Harbour, Opera House and City Centre, and just a few minutes from Circular Quay, the gardens are ideally located and easily accessible. Really enjoyed walking through them on more than one occasion.

Beautiful any time of the year. The Botanic Gardens in any city are always nice to visit, and the Sydney gardens are no exception. It's quite expansive and located near the beautiful Sydney Harbour. Lots of interesting plants and flowers and even a wishing tree. There's a lovely conservatory with lots of orchids, indoor plants and ferns.
Relaxation. Walking around the botanic garden is truly relaxing. The peace and quite so close to the city is a nice change of pace. The ponds were ekstra beautiful when we visited Sydney.

One of the best places, ever!. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a defining element of Sydney. Spectacular place to be - whether you are just hanging out, exploring the plantings and birds, or bringing your own picnic, the gardens are wonderful. Lots of terrific views and places to sit ...

Outstanding gardens centrally located. This is an extensive garden facing the water and easily accessed from the Opera house or Macquarie road. The setting, sloping down to the water from the tall buildings, is impressive. There are many sections of the gardens and hundreds different trees. There are ponds with great wildlife and a few artworks and restaurants. A few miles walking across is a priceless experience

A gem in the heart of the Sydney cbd. Bring your camera as there are some iconic shots of Sydney at every turn. On a beautiful day, the botanic gardens are a wonderful place to have lunch, view the unique Australian plants and take in the views. Be sure to walk to Mrs macquaries chair and read about its history.

Might be the best, sit down on the grass and relax.... This might probably be the best botanic garden in the world, I keep coming back to this place.... so many plants, so many beautiful (big trees), great views, fantastic location near opera house, birds, friendly people... and grass: please take a seat guys!
awesome. really nice place for picnic or just a walk or a run. there are free tours everyday at 10:30 am. totally worth it

Beautiful botanical gardens. I love these gardens. You can have a lovely walk in the gardens and see it's great variety of trees and plants. There is a little ponds with sea snakes that kids love to have a look. Nice coffee and beautiful view to the harbour. You can spend at least 2 hours in the gardens.

Great park. Beautiful park in the middle of the city, away from noise and stunning scenery. Great for any time of day and if you want to escape the city for a bit. Oh and of course there are great views!
Beautiful, and informative train ride around the park. Nice way to see the grounds, and learn a little about the surroundings and the history of the buildings and planting.

A nice stop if you have time. I did not have time to walk through the Botanic Gardens but I had a very good view from the hop on hop off bus stuck in traffic and they look beautiful to walk through and relax.

Serenity. A calm & beautiful setting in a bustling cosmopolitan city. It's a beautiful setting for a morning run, a walk back to your hotel or a leisurely stroll to take in the view of the gardens & surrounding harbour.

Not much plants. If you want to view plants and floral wonder, you will be disappointed. There isn't much to look at. Suppose it is a good place to view Sydney Opera House, but it closes at 8 and so there is no way to view sunset and night scene.

A beautiful oasis in the city. Very popular with runners in the morning. Gardeners grooming the beautiful city paradise in the early hours of the morning, and throughout the day. It has water fountains to quench your thirst during a run in strategic locations. With a toilet block located just before you hit Mrs. Macquarie chair on the western side of the loop road. Easy to access from circular quay by train or ferry, and right next door to the iconic Opera House.

Tranquil escape. I spent several hours wandering back and forward through the gardens on a showery day. There's lots to see for plant lovers and when the sun comes out it must be stunning. In my view if you are not in a hurry it is an obvious way to move between city centre locations. It may not always be on the way but it's worth the detour. If you are walking to the opera house make the effort.

Peaceful. I ate breakfast in these Gardens - what a peaceful way to start the morning! This was a weekday and not very busy at 7am when the gates opened. I brought a takeaway breakfast - a bit hard to find at that time of morning - found a convenient rock, and just sat, listening to the birds, watching the water, soothed by the greenery all around. I chose the end closest the Opera Center, a little ways off the usual paths.If you are in need of stillness, and don't mind getting up early for it, here's where to go.As a practical matter, the Gardens are also a lovely place to walk and look at plants. The plantings are well labelled, sometimes with interesting histories. There are open bathrooms (rather messy when I saw them but no stars off for that; they were *real* bathrooms and it was first thing in the morning - looked like animals had gotten in overnight).

Beautiful gardens with fabulous views. The gardens are a short walk from the Opera House and Circular Quay. There is no entrance fee. It is a lovely walk through the gardens to Mrs Macquarie's Point where you get an unrivaled view of the Opera House and harbour bridge. There is some interesting flora and fauna, a cafe in the centre and transport round the gardens if needed. There are plenty of benches in the shade to sit and watch the world go by on a warm sunny day. It's hard to realise that you are so close to the centre of a big city. Highly recommended.

Walk round the Royal Botanic Gardens and take in the views. Well worth a picnic, relax in the gorgeous park and watch the world go by. Have a walk by the sea, the variety of the park plants and features are great.

Just a stroll from Sydney Opera House. The botanic gardens are Just a stroll from Sydney Opera House and offer a excellent walk and views so take your camera. Good location for picnic or try the ice cream from the restaurant.
Big and beautiful . The gardens are lovely anytime of year but coming up to Xmas the gardens are vibrant and busy. Take the scenic train around to make most of your time. Next to the opera house.
Cooling afternoon stroll. We went on a cooling afternoon with slight drizzle. A wonderful garden to relax and lay on the grass. Lots of beautiful photo-taking moments as well!
Attractive, well maintained gardens by the sea. Very attractive and well maintained gardens by a sea wall and with great views throughout. Just a short walk from the Opera house.

Tranquil . Loved walking around and chilling in these beautiful gardens. Lots to see, lots of places to sit and just enjoy! You can take a train tour if you want but my advice is just to simply mooch about and enjoy the views especially down by the harbour.
beautiful day to walk these gardens. We spent an hour walking through these beautiful gardens. We had a delicious lunch at a near by restaurant on the grounds.

Great on a Sunny Day - Make sure you bring your camera. The botanic gardens are tucked away in the corner of the city and offer a excellent walk and great photography.
Brilliant views of opera house and bridge - great location for picnic

Beautiful sanctuary. What an amazing place. Loads of trails to follow even beautiful eels to look at in the ponds. Hundreds of plants ans beautiful flowers. Make sure to take a water bottle and wakking shoes!

Beautiful. It was really cool to find such a lovely green space in such a big city. It was a little jarring to find a freeway running through part of it, but it only took a moment to get lost in nature again.

On a clear day.... You can't see forever, but it feels like it. My favorite part is along the bay gazing across sparkling waters to other parts of Greater Sydney. Not only are the views great but there are plenty of exhibits in the park to keep one moving along. Take one of the free guided tours by one of their dedicated and knowledgeable volunteers.

Stunningly beautiful. Visiting the gardens is worth it for the gorgeous Jacaranda trees - with purple flowers they look nothing like any tree I've seen at home.But there's lot of beautiful plants and birds there, including wild parrots living in the trees.
Green Patch. This is a nice green Patch on the Sydney Harbour. Where you can relax, jogging, walk and have great exposure to the most magnificent views of the Sydney Opera House and Sydney Bridge.

Romantic, Arresting. This much is certain. You visit it once and it will never leave you. The spectacular, rolling, green expanse of the Botanical Gardens was so haunting it beckoned us back a second time during our 6 day stay in Sydney. I keep re-living that first day of our stay. We decided to explore the neighborhood on foot. With some helpful directions and a street map from the friendly reception guy at our Holiday Inn Potts Point abode we walked down Victoria Street and took the steps down to Woolomooloo Bay then walked on past the Finger Wharf to the steps leading up to the Botanical Gardens. The sheer open vastness of the Gardens, the immaculately laid out greens and the quietude relaxes, energises and romances you, more so if you are with your partner. Plenty of helpful signboards along the way to guide you along because the walk through the Garden also leads you on to the Sydney Opera House, the Sydney Harbour and Circular Quay. What a splendid day that was, absolutely amazing, romantic and memorable. There was even a marriage ceremony going on in the Gardens that day (November14) !! Hundreds of plant species around but you'd need a guided tour to comprehend those. On our second visit, the next day, we lost our way as we did the reverse direction, walking from the Harbour back to our hotel, through the Gardens. It was dark and we missed the signboards and came out on the wrong side of the road, looking for those flight of stairs down to the Woolomooloo Bay which we just couldn't locate. However, thanks to some splendid help from a group of passers-by one of whom whipped out his smart phone with google maps, we eventually made it to those steps !! Yea, we had several instances of getting lost during our wonderful Australia trip.

Sunday walk in the park. Spent a lovely day at the park with friends. So much to see and look at. Lovely displays and everything is signposted so it's easy to find. Well worth a visit for those visiting Sydney and even for Sydneysiders for a day out.

Good for flowers, bad for hay fever.... Such a lovely stroll through the park. Good for people who like taking long walks on the beach, flowers, trees, garden enthusiasts and walking in general. So bring your fit bit and some telfast and go for a stroll.

Beautiful Botanical Gardens. A great variety of plants and trees..it is a very historic Botanic gardens with many places to walk and is situated by the water offering wonderful views around the Harbour.There is an intersting gift shop with many books on Gardens and other Sydney places of interest....There is also a very nice restaurant to dine in.While walking you will see many native birds and even lizards , bats and other wild life.Many of the trees and plants are named with interesting details.Its i great family place to visit and makes for a very enjoyable day out.

Nice quiet place . If you have extra time do visit the garden. Right next to the Sydney Opera House, it is a nice place to sit or even work out. There are herbs and rose gardens of different varieties you can look at. A real nice tranquil place you should visit. It also offers a nice unobstructed view of the CBD buildings at various locations. You can read about the history of Australia along the way while enjoying the flora and fauna. If you are feeling a little adventurous, do walk a little further to Mrs MacQuarie's chair and you will see a gorgeous view of the Opera house and the harbour bridge. Just make sure you take note of the closing hours of the gate so you do not get locked in when night falls.

A really nice environment . You can enjoy the views of the opera house, see the nice plants and flowers, chill on the grass or feed the birds. I'd highly recommend enjoy a Sunday afternoon with a picnic.

Beautiful park right in the heart of the city. Amzing relaxing place so close to the city. It is a fantastic thorough-fare through to the opera house. It is peaceful, quiet and the plants and flowers on display are beautiful.

A huge garden and a good place to relax!. If you are visiting opera house, how can you miss this? The garden is very beautiful although there weren't many flowers when i visited. Still worth a walk! Make sure to carry a water bottle if visiting in summers. This is a huge garden!
Surely a royal garden. Walking through this historical garden is a pleasure where walking on the grass is not verboten where there are a host of lovely old trees and where the sea is next door
Morning Walk. Great morning heart starter , this walk took 40 min from Opera house to Mrs Macquaries Chair and back . Great views of the Bridge and Opera House , Photo Highlight for the tourist .
Really nice place to relax. As said above really nice place to relax and might even have a picnic, the views are spectacular with opera house on one side and the fort on the other.
Great place to have a picnic. My husband and I went here on our in between time we had. We packed sandwiches and snacks. It was a great place to sit and have lunch then roam around.

Near the Opera, so why not?. Although not as nice as several other botanical gardens I have visited such Yew Gardens outside London, one Wellington, New Zealand's, there is enough here to make it worth at least an hours or so; much more if you really enjoy such gardens or just want a leisurely place to stroll, jog or laze away an afternoon.
beautiful. worth the sightseeing, well within walking distance of everything and large amount of things to see, will recommend

An amazing morning or afternoon delight!. What follows is a short precis which I found very useful for this Visit.As keen plantsmen were really looked forward to seeingThe Royal Botanic Gardens.It's located in the heart of Sydney, Australia close to The Opera House and Cafe Sydney. It opened in 1816,and the garden is apparently the oldest scientific institution in Australia and one of the most important historic botanical institutions in the world. It is open every day of the year and access is free. Its stunning position on Sydney Harbour and immediately adjacent to the Sydney CBD, the Sydney Opera House and the large public parklands.The Gardens have much to offer from the rare and threatened plants of the world to the romantic rose garden, the themed garden areas show the diverse beauty of nature. Special features include: Cadi Jam Ora - first Encounters is a garden display that remembers and acknowledges the Cadigal - the original inhabitants of Sydney's city centre - and their relationship with this land. There are Free guided walks daily 10:30am - check this out first though.There's also a restaurant there with usual facilities and the obligatory Shop, which is where the guided walks start.Would highly recommend this just for views of The Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge alone!!
Very beautiful . This is a great place to walk around and relax. There are some good views and some interesting plants. The area was pretty well maintained.
Lovely gardens. We love gardens so were suitably impressed with the displays. Unfortunately we arrived too late to get a coffee so suggest you get there before 4pm.

Beautiful. At the Eoyal Botanic Garden in Sydney you can see everything, since people exercising, chilling out or even weddings! It's a perfect place to go in a sunny day and have a little picnic and relax on the grass! You can also see the bay, The Harbour Bridge and Opera House from there!

A good place to waste time. With 12 hours to waste between disembark in our cruise and our flight to Perth a stroll through the Botanic Gardens was a nice peaceful way to get away from the hustle and noise of the city..
Beautiful escape. Lovely and free. Plenty of space to wander around and escape the crowds and tourists. Lovely gardens and great views of the harbour and Government house, a must visit.

Great way to see the city. These gardens are truly wonderful - not only do have fabulous gardens to enjoy but also the setting right on the harbour add to a magical day out... There is a couple of food options and they are all pretty good in their own way... so feel safe to pop down for a nice lunch with a decent coffee and enjoy a lazy walk through the grounds!
Beautiful gardens is a busy city. The botanics are an oasis of calm from the city. Lovely place just to relax away from noise. Great views as well

What a beautiful place!. We spent several hours roaming around the gardens and were just mesmerized by the many different plants, flowers and trees. The views of the harbor were also very nice and added to the experience. Even though we got rained on a little, it was still a wonderful way to spend an afternoon. Be sure and add the gardens to your schedule if you have a few days in Sydney!
A lovely way to spend a day. Had an excellent day in the company of a very knowledgeable guide. Also saw a Great Grey Owl perched in a tree.There are also lovely views of Sydney Harbour.
Don't miss it!. An amazing and well kept garden. Great fun to have a picnic there overlooking the Sydney Opera House surrounded by plenty of cockatoos, wild birds and amazing plants

Lovely city escape. Beautiful oasis, it is an excellent place to escape from the city.You can either just stroll through the different sections of the garden, sit on one of the many benches and read a book or enjoy a coffee in the little coffee shop located in the centre of the Garden, there is also a Restaurant right above the coffee shop however haven't had the opportunity to eat there as yet but the menu looked delicious and the setting is lovely. It is also a Photographers heaven.If you are planing to go there on the weekend there is really cheap all day parking in Chifley Towers for only $10 which is just across the road from one of the Entrances.

Right in the centre. One of the things to do that does not cost money. Lovely walking through the gardens. We found a lot of flies in Sydney when we were there. We had a cream bought in kangaroo island and it keeps them at bay. There are plenty of seats where you can relax and enjoy the views and the sunshine
Just beautiful. Definitely recommend a visit to the botanical gardens while in Sydney. They are huge and so beautiful you could wander around for hours or just sit and take in the scenery.
Take the Little Train. We love wandering through the gardens and the kids just love the Little Train which gives you a great overview of the gardens

wonderful venue and location. This is a beautiful oasis to the hussle and bustle of Sydney, plenty of shade, walks and fantastic views. Within easy walking distance of martins place metro, and splendid views of bridge and harbour
So beautiful. I would have never planned to go through a garden on vaca, but we had extra time walking about and wandered through it. Just beautiful.

Gorgeous. Lovely gardens - large area - more park like than many botanic gardens - well tended - free - definitely worth it - spent about an hour - easy walking - well laid out - not as dramatic as some - if staying in the area a great way to spend a couple of relaxing hours

Beautiful . We loved our walk around and through the gardens to get to the opera house. The place was clean, tidy and with plenty to see.
We really enjoyed the walk from the Anzac memorial all the way through to the botanical gardens.
Well worth the visit.
It's a amazing a park. this is park just next to opera house so if you are tired you can relax there and watching boat and and great view from this park .Highly recommended it

Free to roam with beautiful wildlife flora and forna. Well we arrived in the early morning and our room was not ready until 2pm. So picked up a ferry in Darling harbour to take us to circular quay about 15 minute ride but boy what a spectacular view under the bridge and past the opera house not a bad start to the day. So we decided to walk through the botanic gardens and take in the sights on the way back to our hotel. Firstly the gardens are free to enter and are immaculately kept. You senses are awakens by the sound of birds calling and then you eyes are treated to the sight of a beautiful array of different coloured birds . We were then treated to the sight of a kookaburra bathing in the bird bath. There are lakes and beautiful coloured trees lining the gardens. The governors house is situated on the headland and overlooks the harbour. If you walk to the headland and follow the path round you come to Mrs Macquaries seat a huge stone seat carved out by the convicts so that she (the governors wife could sit and watch the tall sail ships arriving from England. Well worth a walk through.

Best way to start your day. My husband and I came here twice. First was in the afternoon after our visit from the Opera House, which was just a few steps. It was very relaxing, patches of gardens with lots of trees and birds. It was on our next visit, early morning like 730 to 830 or 9, that I enjoyed it more. During this time, there are less people, very serene, you only see some joggers. One will really see and feel the tranquility of the gardens, overlooking the harbour at this time. Try catching this lovely place early in the morning, an extraordinary way to start your day in Sydney.

Calm oasis. We walked through the gardens on route to Mrs Macquaries chair and found them a delight .. Well maintained peaceful and colourful .. Food in their cafe was good and inexpensive .. We had about 11/2 hours there but you could easily stay all day.

Great Location. I've been here a few times, but then again I love an afternoon walk, especially on a nice day, through a botanical gardens. Okay, the first time I came here it was drizzingly, but fortunately the second and third times I came here the weather was substantially better. The gardens a huge, and it is very easy to simply get lost in the wonder of the place. There are numerous habitats containing a variety of plants, as well as a fern house and another house containing a plant (or should I say flower) with one of the coolest names out there - a flame thrower.
Loved the gardens. Take a good 1/2 day just to look, see and relax in the sunshine. Nice cafe. plenty of birds of all kinds - nice gift shop

Wonderful gardens, easy to walk around. Plants, birds, fountains ... you could hardly ask for me. Oh yes, a fully sunny day would be nice (we didn't have one but loved the walk anyway). The biggest water lilies I've ever seen, growing artichokes (never seen these outside California), beautiful gardens. Take an hour an enjoy yourself - better yet, walk on up to the Opera House. Easy walking.

Very interesting. We strolled around the gardens for a short time on our arrival in Sydney. It was a beautiful introduction to a beautiful city. It was strange to see an ibis strolling casually around our feet, as you don't see many of those in England. There is a little train that does tours of the gardens, but we saved that for our next visit. Lovely place :-)

Lovely escape. We had only one day in Sydney due to a flight problem (thanks JetStar) and wanted to make the most of the time so we had an early start and walked through the gardens at 7am and it was just a lovely start to the day. The gardens are well tended and signage is informative and a lovely oasis in the city.

Amazing running trails!. I spent 2 days exploring the Royal Botanic Gardens, first walking through it with my husband, then running it the next day. I loved it so much, I couldn't stop running as there were always new trails to explore. Beautifully maintained and well worth the trip!

EHK. Most beautiful garden, overlooking the ocean near the famous opera house. The garden is celebrating 200 years in 2016. You need to spend one full day. Very relaxing views all over. Don't miss the smell train ride.

A GREAT PLACE FOR A WALKING. We walk into the Botanic Gardens from the Opera House. We cross all the beautiful differents gardens and arrived near the ANZAC Memorial. Was a beautiful morning in a beautiful place.

Majectic Botanical garden. I never seen trees as big as that. It is amazing. Birds singing and walking in the middle of the path. It wouldn't be a real work ti wok every in this fantastic garden, it's simply a gift ...but seriously it certainly need a lot of care to obtain a paysage as nice as this garden. The Royal botanical garden deserve entirely his name.

Amazing with different wildlife. The garden is beautiful and large. With it being beside the harbour, it made it amazing. Great pictures and I would tell everyone to visit. I would spend everyday there reading if I could.

.Beautiful downtown oasis!. Downtown and near the Sydney Performing Arts Centre, this is a beautiful place for a long morning walk (or jog). My wife and I marvelled at the flowers, trees, birds and many lovely areas to sit and take it all in. There is a cafe for a beverage or food and a gift shop with items sure to delight any gardener. I'm still sorting through the numerous photos I took along the way.

Moketastic Gardens!. I spent an hour walking around the gardens. They are beautifully kept and there are some amazing looking trees. When you walk down to the water you get a great view of the Opera House in front of the Harbour Bridge.And, the ground staff use a classic Mini Moke to transport tools and things around the gardens!Well worth a visit.

Great place to relax for lunch. When I worked in the CBD a place I would often go to just unwind and eat a sandwich and have a coffee in the middle of the working day but also a place to go for picnics on the weekend. Generally the gates close around dusk however in summer when the open air cinema is operating you can take in a film with the Sydney skyline as the backdrop and enjoy some light food and a drink. The gardens are situated in a beautiful north facing aspect and run from the eastern edge of the CBD to the Domain Lady Macquarie's Chair and the Art Gallery in the East. The gardens feature many lawns and established trees as well as greenhouses and specialised plantings - less emphasis on flowering exhibits than say Adelaide - the main gripe is that the fruit bats have taken up residence in plague proportions - while wildlife should be protected the fact that this is largely an exotic garden seems to fallen been forgotten this wasn't their natural habitat before the garden was created.

"Royal Botanic Gardens". Very nice gardens, lots of walking room. I did not see it personally but my wife did and very much enjoyed it. Easy access and a pleasant way to spend some time in good weather.

Lovely place. Enjoy walking around the Garderns as it has this peacefulness about it.Beautiful views of Sydney Harbour and the Opera House, just a relaxing walk out of the hustle and bustle of the city.Great to take family a visitors, also amazing to have wedding photo as there where a few being taken when we were there.Views of North Sydney, the ferries going by, passanger ships , pleasure crafts and many other things it's a must place to visit for all ages.k
Beautiful Gardens. Stunning gardens centrally located in Sydney. I enjoyed a walk through on route from my hostel to the harbour. Great place to enjoy the sun if you're not a fan on the beach.
It was a nice walk from the gardens to the Opera House. Great place for a walk or to visit for couple of hours on a nice day. Way better than the one in Melbourne!

Lovely Green space. Being surrounded on three sides by the Sydney CBD, the Botanical Gardens are an oasis of greenery. It was weekend and there were plenty of people having picnics amongst the trees. We took the little train around the gardens which has a very informative commentary. The shop and the café were doing a brisk trade.The wildlife was fun to watch whilst just strolling around in this little oasis.

A Stunning Example of how Cities can Breathe - and People enjoy Public Space. The Royal Botanic Gardens are stunning. Well maintained and safe walkways for families and friends and couples -- well anyone and everyone - to take a delightful walk in the green and the wonderful. There are signs with names of the gorgeous trees and plants but what was most striking was how large and quiet the place is - and it is adjacent to the Opera House. What a way to get away from eating and shopping (as a way to spend time) and to just do something wonderful for your mind and spirit. And oh how well the City maintains the space and astounding greenery and trees. (And did I mention the live music concerts?)
Pretty. Nice walk for an early morning. Mrs. Macquarie's Chair area was so crowded with Chinese tourists we couldn't even get near it.

I love the Royal Botanic Gardens . Most non-Sydneysiders say its our harbor that makes Sydney special. Thats only partly true. The RBG plays a vital role as the lungs of the city, links the harbor, the Rocks, domain and central business district. One can walk along or inside the RBG at any time of the day and of the year. A lot of office workers go for a run at lunch time and definitely veer through the popular gardens.
Well maintained oasis. We walked around the gardens after taking pictures of the Opera House. It's a huge, beautiful garden and worth the time to explore.
Well maintained and lovely scenery !. Definitely well worth a visit if in Sydney. Just on the outskirts of the CBD! Very well maintained and many seats to stop and take in the scenery!

Another amazing sight to see in Sydney and it is free. I love visiting gardens in every city I visit. I love seeing the kinds of plants and landscaping that differs from state to state, and even in different countries. A lovely place to visit for a casual stroll or to do some exercising through. Why would you be inside a gym on a treadmill when you can come here and enjoy the gorgeous views?
One of the prettiest botanic gardens. Strolling around this garden is wonderful. It has a great diversity of plants and flowers and a very natural look. It also has a great view over the water.

Peace in the heart of Sydney.. These gardens provide peace and tranquility in the heart of a busy city. The flowers were in full bloom, it was very colourful. Great veiws of the Opera House and bay. A great place to take time out.

Beautiful Gardens. The Sydney Botanic Gardens is a beautiful and accessible area of Sydney where you can take nice walks. There are lots of gardens, flowers, statues and fountains to explore and see. A great place to get away from the busy city and enjoy nature.
a little disappointed. I think I expected much more- the lawns were beautiful but the flowers left a lot to desire.The variety of flowers was very limited and the number of flower beds was very low.
Excellent view of the Sydney opera house and the Harbor. If you like to sit under the tree and have a quiet moment. This is a perfect place. Excellent view of the Harbor and the opera house.
Beautiful for Running!!. Running through the Garden early morning makes you incredibly refreshed!! The view of the opera house is also good.
Great Place for a Walk. Is a great place for a walk or running. The views from all around the park to the Sydney Harbor are wonderful.

Using the ferry service. We used Senior tickets at cost of $2.50 for whole day. After using buses to Bondi Beach and Watson Bay we used a ferry from Watson Bay, back to Circular Quay, then another ferry to Manly Beach and back which was a 'Cat.' The next day we used a ferry to Darling Harbour and then to Olympic Village and back. They were on time and quite comfortable. No problems.
Huge and Beautiful. Very nice park. Huge. The view is great. Too bad not so many toilet facility. Great place to have a picnic on a nice weather.
Beautiful. The setting is beautiful, the flowers were all in bloom, worthwhile taking this in while in Sydney. The Hop on bus is a great way to get around town.

Another pretty stop on the harbor. Beautiful "green" space in the heart of the city. Easy to walk trails, with many benches strategically placed for calm reflection on the flowery view of the harbor. You will have many opportunities for memorable photographs of both the harbor and the many specimens of plants from Australia and around the world. Great place for long or short hikes as your mood dictates. Wheelchair accessible. Refreshment available. Free admission. Free tours available.
Green haven in city centre. This is a free attraction right in the city centre, next to the Opera House. A lovely interesting place to walk through.

Amazing Music and Scenery. We recently went to the botanic Gardens and there was a Free music festival being held there, was absolutely amazing seeing all the boats docked in and around the quay watching and listening to the band, even though the bands where really loud you couldn't even hear them from inside the gardens themselves making it a relaxing walk back to hotel after sitting and watching the bands
Beautiful area in the middle of the city. Take time to walk around the gardens. Peaceful with many different plants, trees and small ponds to enjoy. A nice getaway from city congestion.

If you have a few hours spare.............. After visiting Manly Beach, we had some time to spare so decided to take a wander through the gardens before returning to our hotel. We entered near to the Opera House. From that entrance there is a little train you can travel on around the gardens for a small charge, but we decided to just walk at our own pace. The gardens are quite large and have views out onto the harbour waters, with the city skyline running along another side of it. There are different sections to see, with the occasional map or signpost for directions (though they could do with more). If you get a few hours to spare in Sydney, and want to get away from the hustle and bustle, this is an ideal place.
Nice walk. Nice walk but wear comfortable shoes. It's quite a hike. Very well maintained and beautiful. Good view of the Opera house and bridge.
Wonderful. Superb green space in the heart of Sydney which has lovely views of the Opera House and Harbour. Very tranquil & well maintained.
Lovely gardens! . Lovely just to sit and watch the world go by. We took a picnic here and was lovely to see the opera house and the Sydney harbour bridge.
A unique snapshot of botanical specimens. A world class Botanic Gardens with many interesting specimens...on a sunny day take a book or digital device and while the day away under a suitable spot

Beautiful Park!. Beautiful park to hang around or just for a walk. If you walk by the water all the way from the opera house to Margaret's Chair, you will get great views of the opera house and the bridge. Beautiful trees and flowers everywhere and a nice gift shop in the middle of the park. If you want some culture, pop into the Art Gallery, just at the entrance of the Park. Well worth the visit.
Beautiful!. The views are amazing! Lovely surroundings and set in a tranquil area, even in the middle of a bustling city! Well worth a visit!

As royal as it gets. Beautiful landscape garden right in the heart of Sydney CBD. A very nice place to enjoy day and evening to relax and many local actually jog there. The expansive garden is very relaxing and do take your time to stroll in the garden as there are many flora and fauna in every corner of the garden.

Stunning. A great place to sit in the shade and enjoy a picnic lunch while you explore Sydney. We hopped of the explorer bus and headed into the park. Easy to walk on paths meandering in all directions the park was simply stunning. We sat in the shade and ate our packed lunch and were soon joined by an over friendly Kookaburra who was very entertaining.

Relaxing. Right in the city this garden is a lovely haven from the hustle and bustle of the CBD. Lovely huge shady trees to rest under while watching activities on the harbour. The garden is now 200 years old and for the enthusiast there is quite a lot to look at too.

Sydney's Gem. During our weeks stay, we walked through the Gardens every day inevitably discovering something new. Peaceful, gorgeous, meticulously maintained- just a stunning icon of Sydney. Loved that mostly all the trees and plants were labled- such a treat to see so many things indigenous to this part of the world that we don't get to see at home. Wonderful!

Fantastic! . Beautiful gardens which are great for just chilling in the sun. There is such a variety of flowers and scenery, from the skyscrapers to the harbour. Fantastic way to escape the city without travelling for miles! Also good for a stroll if ypur on a budget!!
Suprised at how lovely. One of the nicest walks in Syndey. Beautiful walk along the ocean with views of the opera house and the govt building. Wish I had more time there I will definitely go back.

Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney, NSW. This is one of the places in Sydney that we liked the most. There is a great collection of plants arranged by type. It was a very relaxing walk (besides the omnipresent flies) and we stopped many times to take pictures and to look at the beautiful views around us. From one spot you can see the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge aligned. Keep your camera handy as you will use it often.
Excellent gardens just to stroll through. A large area of gardens with lots to see. Well worth a walk through if you have time! Particularly nice down by the water

Gutted about the bats. This is truly one of Sydney's most peaceful oasis,s. I love the cheeky birds nicking food in the cafe and the gigantic eels in the lake. However, I was gutted they moved the Fruit Bats out

Absolutely stunning. The Botanic Gardens were beautiful. I would recommend anyone alighting the Hop on Hop off Bus Tour at Harry's Café Du Wheels and walking from here through Mrs Macquaries point into the Botanic Gardens and through to Circular Key. This is not a short walk but definitely worth the time.

Gorgeous views. A perfect retreat in the middle of the city with stunning views of Sydney! A must-see place to enjoy nature, exercise and relax. The unstaffed information booths left something to be desired and when we asked in the gift shop about where to catch the little train that was taking people around, the man said something to the effect of, "If you don't see it, it's probably not running." We were too tired to take it all in on foot, but what we did see was well worth it.

Lovely park stroll close to the town centre. In easy reach, past the opera house from the main Sydneys quays, is this beatifully maintained, colourful park.There's not much information about the plants and trees but, if you're not used to the sight of eucalyptus trees and all the subtropical plants it's a lovely walk round. It's free, has a cafe, souvenir shop and toilets and is small enough to take in but large enough to feel you've escaped from the city, it's well worth a visit if you've an hour or two to spare.Mostly child- and wheelchair-friendly too.

Royal Botanic Gardens - Good Walk from Opera House. It is walkable from most areas in the CBD. You can also take the train to the Circular Quay train station/ferry docks and you are there! It is FREE.Walking East from CQ boat docks/train station:It is an easy 5 minute walk from CQ boat docks/train station to The Opera House .And a 15 minute walk from the Opera House along a paved path to Mrs. Macquarie's chair in the Royal Botanic Gardens.The best photo of both the Opera House and the SYD Harbor Bridge is from an area near Mrs. Macquaries Chair in the Gardens.Also from the paved walkway from the Opera House leading to the Gardens.
One of the greatest botanic gardens . Probably one of the greatest botanic gardens on Earth. Best place in Sydney to get a more quiet view on the city and relax...

Lovely gardens in the heart of Sydney. Bordered by the harbour, the opera house, circular quay, HMAS Kuttabul (naval base), and close to the central business district the gardens are part of the heart of Sydney. It caters to tourists and locals alike with an interesting mix of dawdling photographers, jogging office workers, organised fitness classes, pedestrians and families all making use of the facilities. On the northern edge it has a wonderful location for taking photographs of the opera house with the harbour bridge in the background and close by is a venue for summer evening open air concerts and film shows within quality restaurants. There is a more standard cafe in the centre of the garden with the usual gift shop and this can offer a respite from the sun and heat within its air-conditioned interior. As with most outdoor public spaces in Australia it has been well maintained and offers something for just about everyone.
Best Way to See the City. One of the best parks anywhere. You can see the harbor, bridge, opera house and old parts of town here. Good for photos!
Gorgeous Setting!. Spend as much time as you wish in this relaxing, inviting and scenic spot. I love Sydney!! So much to see, such friendly people! And that's just the city!

Beautiful Gardens. The Sydney Royal Botanical Gardens is large & beautiful.
There is a wide variety of plants, trees, flowers & herbs.
It is very pleasant to walk & relax.
Conveniently located near the harbor.

Essential part of harbour experience. Walk from quaysides and enjoy a classic imperial city experience with added world class view over harbour. Watch boats by day and movies by night (open air with bridge as backdrop). Fantastic.

Beautiful Gardens. We visited on a hot sunny day, the gardens are beautiful and well maintained. Lots of signs with interesting facts and the names of plants. Interesting story of the aboriginal people's history. Would go regularly if I lived in Sydney!

Not to be missed in downtown Sydney. Went in here numerous times on our week in Sydney. Great for jogging .... stop over at Mrs Maquaries chair. The views of the bridge and Opera House are probably the best of anywhere. ... well signed paths and an incredible diversity of plants all well marked. Early joggers / visitors can't get in until the gates open just before 7 AM every day. Like the rest of Sydney it's not bicycle friendly unless you are on one of the main roads. Many historical buildings, fountains and , of course, plants.

NYE here was fabulous!. Did Midnight at the Oasis for NYE 2014 & had the most wonderful time. When booking we were bowled over by the cost but it was worth it for the view, the private bar & private toilets (rather than queuing with hundreds for a portaloo!) The food wasn't amazing but drinks were reasonable & the entertainment was good too.

Beautiful, but Not Diuring Pesky Fly Season. The title says it all. Alas flies which will not go away swarmed upon us during our early November visit causing us to walk as fast as we could to get out of this very handsome garden. Go there, but only after determining when these critters are around... they really were a terrible nuisance.

A lovely restful place right next to a very busy city. A stroll here is always a relaxing pleasure. Sit on a seat in the shade and 'green out' as the world goes by. The trees are amazing especially the older ones - enormous.

Gardens are well kept and has no fees. Quite a few things make the Sydney botanic gardens stand out. It's right in the heart of the city, it has amazing views of the harbor and you can walk through it to just get to the harbor - or discover it as a serene spot with very well kept flora. The cactus garden is worth visiting, so is the small nursery that sells plants grown by the garden's staff. Be sure to check out the pond close to the edge right by the water - it contains some huge eel, known to feed on a duckling once in a while, which wander from the ocean to the pond on nights when moisture makes the grass wet.

Saturday casual walk and relaxing afternoon sitting in front of the bay. Was there last Saturday, sitting in front of the Opera house, Huge Jacaranda Trees In Bloom just next to our bench. We also see couple taking wedding photos on the lawn behind us. So peaceful and pretty. Soon it start to rain...

Well worth the visit. Great green space with a good array of plants and views across the harbour and Sydney. It was a bright sunny day when we walked around admiring the views and plants. We had brought a take-out lunch with us and sat in a bench overlooking the Opera House as we ate - spectacular. Definitely worth a visit for a gentle walk at a relaxed pace.

Stunning gardens. I recommend you start at the top and walk through all of the gardens as there are lots of different plants and trees as well as styles to see through out. A lovely walk through stunning scenery that takes you down to the water front where you can walk along it towards the opera house if you wish.

Sydney Royal Botanic Gardens. The gardens offer a wonderful display of natives as well as other display gardens using imported trees, shrubs & plants to create a colourful & spectacular environment which is complimented by the wonderful views of the opera house & our picturesque harbour. There are few if any locations which offer such a picturesque park to walk in all the year tound. Unlike most of the world this park area is comfotable & accessible all the year round other than the few days when rain makes it unpleasant. However even in winter the views & the access is generally very good & inviting.

Beautiful Park . It had perfect views of the whole harbor-- the opera house and Sydney harbor bridge. Great place for a run as well as a casual walk. Gorgeous flowers and some interesting trees as well.

A tranquil spot for reflection in a busy city centre. I work in the office a block away from the park. Whenever work load permits, I go for a 35 mins walk in the park at lunchtime. Every time without fail I marvel at how beautiful the harbour and the park are. I like walking in the middle of the park instead of just the walkway along the water. The latter is relatively busy with joggers. There are sections of the park in various themes - rose garden, Asian etc. some spots have nice views of the harbour, Opera House and the Bridge. Refreshing indeed

Royalistic. If you love nature, plants, flowers, trees this garden has it all. You need whole day to see it all. In this garden you can also visit the Governors house. The garden is huge. While you are in this garden you can see the view of Opera house and harbour bridge. Highly recommended.

Great place for a scenic stroll. This is a lovely place right off Macquarie Street where you can stroll around looking at plants and trees while getting views of Sydney Harbour. There is plenty of space to picnic or just sit on the grass enjoying the scenery. You can also stroll along the Harbour from the Opera House to Mrs Macquarie's Chair, a walk that will give you superb views of the Harbour and its traffic.

Beautiful. Such an awe inspiring gardens and huge! The gardens give access to many different view points of Sydney harbour so while admiring the different types of flora and fauna on display you can also gain some interesting views of the opera house and harbour bridge. There is also a good view of garden island and the Australian naval presence within Sydney harbour which can make for interesting watching.

A must for every visitor to Sydney. It has to be one of the best gardens and location in Sydney. Probably not many know about this place but it is for sure a hidden surprise. If you want peace and looking out to spend some quality time with your family or partner then this is a perfect place. It is very well located, cool and of course shady because of all the trees they have. You can easily access it via train.You can find trees and plants from all over the world here. Even if you are not a botanist I am sure the trees, plants and flowers will definitely attract your attention. You can see the Harbour bridge and the Opera house from one end while you can also walk along the sea shore from one end to the other but the real treasure is in the garden. It should take an entire day to explore the garden.Take an entire day out to visit this place.

Exotic trees, nice walk and cockatoo parrots!. Beautiful garden so close to the city!You can relax, walk around, admire the beautiful and exotic trees and also, get a visit from the famous cockatoo parrots always around! You can also continue to walk to the Opera House. From the city you can take a short walk there, and from other suburbs the train to Martin Place and then walk.Close to the botanical Garden you also have Miss Macquarie chair with nice views of the ocean.I have made a recommendation of the top 10 activities in Sydney ! Check them out on my page or youtube at /watch?v=7WTDvASldcYLet me know if you have any question !

A jewel in Sydney's crown. This is a wonderful part of Sydney to take a whole day and explore. Not only are there many different areas of the garden with different types of plants, but there is various Australian wildlife that call the gardens home. Be sure to be there in the afternoon when the fruit bats come home to roost for the night. It's spectacular!You can also see a variety of birds, get amazing views of Sydney Harbour, have lunch in one of the cafes or enjoy a picnic. All within easy walking distance to public transport or the city centre. A must do for visitors and locals alike.
Beautiful gardens. The gardens are well kept a beautiful place to spend a quite afternoon picnicking. Lots of gardens, flowers, statues and fountains to explore and see.

Beautiful place to visit. I took my boys to the botanical gardens recently and its just lovely there. Beautiful walkways, amazing fardens birdlife, the boys and I had fun petting the eels definitely a must visit when in Sydney

Lovely day enjoying spring!. We get to the Botanic Gardens at least every 3 months to fully take in what is newly in bloom! Its always exciting to see new growth and its always different. Ending up at the Quay for a lovely day! Highy recommend for a couple or a family!

If you love plants and wish to see the fruit bats and cockatoos this is a must!. I do love plants, and was so surprised that this park was free to visit, sit in, wonder at, went on a nice sunny day, lots of shade to sit under, very varied planting, and fruit bats - rather a lot of, I understand the Gardens staff were a bit nervous because there were so many. Very nice gift shop too, with good book among other things.

Sydney Botanic Gardens. The Sydney Botanic Gardens are a beautiful and accessible area of Sydney where you can take nice walks. The Opera House is very near the Botanic Gardens and by combining these two Sydney attractions it would be nice day. The trees, flowers, lakes and wildlife exhibited in the Botanic Gardens are a beautiful addition to this vey walkable park.
So restful. This garden has it all, stunning old trees, exotic plants, water views, bird life, lush grass, interesting species of plants. Everything one would want in a royal botanic garden.

One of the best in the world.. I've been to many botanical gardens and this was one of the best in the world. I didn't have time to walk it, so I took the train ride which is only $10. I wish I had the time to walk it. The amazing views and sights were just stunning. So colorful and so much to see.
A Stroll in the garden. Just an lovely place to walk with your partner and experience the beauty plants. Easy to get around and very relaxing.

Great place to visit. There are some very interesting plants here and beautiful trees. It is tranquil to walk around there are many bats sleeping during the day but which leave as dusk comes over the city.

Ideal for an introduction to NSW tree species.. On a sunny spring day this is a pleasing place to wander and admire tree species less common to the northern hemisphere. The grounds are spacious and well suited to picnics or painting or just lazing away a few hours. It is within walking distance of other interesting landmarks including the Library and Parliament House or Opera House.

Beautiful gardens!. We had a leisurely stroll from the Sydney Opera House to Mrs Macquaries Lookout. The Botanical Gardens are really beautiful,peaceful, and well maintained. It's hard to believe you are in the centre of a bustling city!
Peace in the City. Entry is free, as well as the gardens there are sometimes small exhibitions. It's just a lovely green oasis and it's got Ibis, White Cockatoo's and Parakeets to watch.
Absolutely stunning. The work that goes into making these gardens prestige all year round is phenomenal. The gardens are a truly outstanding accomplishment in the heart of the city.

Lovely garden. Well worth a look when in Sydney the botanical gardens are a refreshing break from the CBD. Plenty to see and do, there was a free concert on the day we were there. Close to many of the cities tourist attractions and a nice place to sit and relax.

A must to see in Sydney. A huge, beautiful park with amazing gardens! Sections of the gardens different species such as cactus, orchids etc. Tons of Lorikeets and Cockatoos in the trees. Peaceful and relaxing walk. Well marked.

Wonderful walk!. What a lovely place to walk through and visit. We walked from the Opera House, around Farm Cove and up to Mrs Macquaries Chair before coming back down through the Botanical Gardens. Great photo opportunities along the way. Lots of lovely gardens and the jacaranda trees all flowering purple was very pretty. This made for a very pleasant break in amongst the hustle and bustle of doing all the Sydney sights.
Fascinating. Incredibly beautifully kept and yet we never saw a single gardener, they must pop out at night like little gnomes. A really lovely oasis in a fabulous city.

Great coastal location. This is a pleasant botanical garden located on the Sydney harbor side. There are some pleasant specimens, nicely displayed, and the location is superb. Well worth a wander through.

Great Park near the Opera House. The Royal Botanic Gardens is relatively big and lies between the Woolloomooloo Wharf and the City Center of Sydney. On the North side of the Gardens is the Sydney Harbor and the Opera House. It is great to walk around alone or with the family. Also, it is a nice area to go jogging.
Beautiful views. Very peaceful place and lovely to while away the hours watching the harbour. Kept beautifully and great views of the bridge and opera house.

Royal Botanic Gardens has Free Entry!!! Opens at 7AM. Depends on the month, closing time changes. This place is huge! Walking, you can access it from the gate close to the Sydney Opera House. If you're taking the Sydney trains, the closest station is Martin Place. Bring water---even better, plan a picnic:) No pets allowed in this large park.

Quiet walk with my wife whilst enjoying Sidney.. Right next to the opera house we stumbled across these grounds.Beautiful. So well manicured and everything signposted and clearly described.There are great viewing points for the harbour too, although quite a few people used them, no issues to us though.With all we had to do at the harbour, this was a lovely addition we weren't expecting to find and it was fabulous!

Beautiful. We were only for a short time in Sydney but after a long flight wanted some exercise.Weather was wonderful and the gardens were immaculate.Could see the bridge and opera house from them .Very nice cafe in the gardens which sells the best banana loaf I have ever tasted and such a large piece kept the rest for the next day.Would love to go back to the gardens.

What a beautiful spot .... My dearly beloved wanted to go here while we were in Sydney , & what a great place it is . It is right in the heart of all the things you need to see , it is wonderfully peaceful ,& its free !!!! Sydney can be a bit chaotic ,so to have this haven of peace is wonderful , We thoroughly recommend it !!

Beautiful. If you want to stroll through some lush gardens whilst looking across an amazing harbour with views of Australian iconic bridge and opera house, then go to Botanic Gardens in Sydney. The pond near the water where eels inhabit is great for a view across the water and also interesting eel facts. You might even be lucky to see one swimming across the top of the pond. you can stop for a pit stop to visit the garden shop, visitor centre, food and restrooms. It's all in there. Walk down along and around the perimeter of the gardens to go from city to Wolloomarloo... for a coffee and view of the harbour from a different side. Enjoy all the variety of species even if you aren't a green thumb like myself... and if you just like walking or running... then it's a great spot for exercise also

Beautiful!. A great way to spend 2 to 3 hours relaxing and strolling through the gardens. The two times we visited while on our vacation in Sydney, the park was used by many locals and visitors alike. It was the end of a race, a jogging area, wedding venue, place to picnic, sleep and for kids to play. Ducks and eels inhabit the ponds while ibis, parrots, cormorants, cockatoos and many more species can be seen on the grassy areas and in the trees. Of course, the beauty of the trees, grassy areas and flowers with the Sydney Harbour area on one side make this a perfect morning or afternoon destination.
Peaceful. Beautiful peaceful area, plenty of shade and seated areas. lots of people us this area for jogging and exercising

The Best Way to Spend A Day!. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney, just a short walk along from the iconic Opera House, as well as offering you the chance to see up close some of the unique flora of Australia, also offers you one of the best places to spend a day leisurely strolling one of the most beautiful botanic gardens in the world ... at the edge of one of the best harbors in the world! Take time out of your busy schedule to relax and unwind ... you won't regret a minute!!

Best hang out spot. I was here one day with a book and some packed sandwiches and basically spent my whole day there reading and enjoying the cooling weather. Go to Macquarie's Chair spot for the sunset.
Morning in the Garden. To walk early in the morning in this beautiful place is a must to o in Sydney. A landscaping miracle in middle of the city.

Beautiful gardens!. A beautiful place to visit. Right on the edge of the water, just along from the Opera House. Beautiful native gardens with such a variety of trees and plants unique to Australia. Fantastic views and a great way to fill in a few hours and relax and unwind

Lovely. I loved wandering around these gardens, even during a rain storm! Offered beautiful views of the harbour.
The gardens are nicely laid out, with lots of benches - it's also a great place for a picnic.

What an amazing find!. A great find, strolling from the Opera House back to our hotel. This actually became our highlight. A great venue to stroll on your own, any time of day. Spectacular flora and fauna can be traversed through little paths that meander.

What a view !. Nice place to have walk and make beautiful pictures of the Opera !
You can discover birds and trees or make a picnic under the trees.

Amazing. Beautiful gardens to stroll through so peaceful you wouldn't think you were literally minutes away from the hustle and bustle of the town centre. Great place to take time out and watch the world go by.

Amazing views. It's an incredible place with Sydney harbour view. It's not only a botanic garden, but also a historic place. I visited Government House inside botanic garden with free guided tour. Highly recommended.
Beautiful garden. This large English style garden houses many flowers and trees as well as large lawns. It is really nice to walk along the trails on a beautiful sunny day.

Excellent way to spend Sunday in Sydney. Arrived at the gardens for brunch then saw there was a free tour at 1pm around the gardens. I was the only participant but that did not stop the tour. Philip Armstrong was my guide, a wealth of botanical and historical information. An excellent 2 hours. Park area offers great photo opportunities across the water of the opera house. Philip recommended I walk up to the new Barangaroo Reserve. So after a 30 minute walk past the opera house around the harbor I arrived at the reserve. Spectacular views from the Walugal walk along the foreshore.

Wonderful, eclectic gardens. Believe it or not, quite a few species of birds in addition to flowers, trees, and some interesting man-made displays. Peaceful with great views of the harbor in the background.
a beautiful place for a stroll. We spend an hour or so wandering through the gardens and really enjoyed ourselves. Even in a slight rain, it was still wonderful. And as a free attraction, a must-see!

Gardens. We had a blast in the rain on this day visiting the gardens, well at least we didnt melt in the rain. We walked and walked so far on this day enjoying all the historical sights and various trees and plants growing here. Great sights if you enjoy walking distances.
Stunning!. So relaxing. The train trip around the garden is worth the $10 as they give you a little bit of background on the garden and stop 4 times so you can get off if you like
Nice walk. Very nice park with beautiful flowers and palmtrees, divived in different themes. Exotic birds live there and the best of it is that it is for free, since it is a public park.

Lovely place to recharge your batteries. Beautiful views, cosy areas to observe the wild life and just let life pass you by. Café and restaurant on site if you need refreshments. Lots of information about the trees and plants growing there. Very popular with tourists and locals.
Beautiful, peaceful spot. This is a lovely place to spent a morning for a stroll before the day gets too hot. Sp beautiful, and peaceful.

Garden with a splendid view. The Royal Botanic Gardens are beautiful, picturesque and well maintained. It was a great experience to look around, read books and go for a jog/walk. It has a splendid view of the darling harbor. Perfect place to spend time on a sunny day.

Green spot in the city. It's a lovely park with many plants.
It's next to the Opera House and from the park you have good view on the Opera House
Be aware of the opening times.

These gardens are worth a couple of hours.. There are many botanical gardens around the world and many within Australia, but this one is one of the best. It is right next to the Opera House and overlooks the harbor, so the photo opportunities are second to none.They have such a great variety of plants and trees, laid out in a beautiful garden. They also have a large variety of birds, many of which we only see in cages in the US.The garden is easy to get to and very walkable, some stairs and steps, but nothing too strenuous. We visited on a cloudy day and thought it was great, so must be even better in the sun.

Beautiful gardens. It was a real pleasure to walk through these beautifully maintained gardens. They are quiet and peaceful and there are some fascinating plants and trees to be seen. Very helpful and frequent signs enable you to pass through the gardens and find exactly whatever, and wherever you need to go. The café is quite nice too.

Beautiful Garden with a great view. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a great place to visit when in Sydney. There is a wide variety of plans with beautiful flowers blooming. The area is well kept, the diversity is good, there are good places to sit and enjoy the environment: for enjoying the shade of a tree while laying underneath it, to sitting on a bench and looking at the harbour.After relaxing in the gardens, it is possible to visit the Sydney Opera House with just a few steps.

Well worth the time. Beautifully done with stunning views of the opera house and Sydney Harbor. We took the tram train around, but suggest skipping it. It is not worth the $10.00 fee for a quick 30 minute train ride.
always a pleasant walk. and the cafe was good too. The gardens are easy to get to and just good to walk through and around. Very relaxing and central to city.
Fabulous and beautifully kept. We had a lovely leisurely stroll around these beautiful gardens. So many different parts to explore. There's a great cafe in the centre for when you need refreshment.

Stunning!. Absolutely beautiful garden in the heart of Sydney, just off Sydney Harbour. During lunch, all of business Sydney empties out of the surrounding offices to walk and run through the park, and it's easy to see why.

Gardens with a view. I took the little trrain ride to get an idea of the layout of the Gardens. This was worthwhile as the driver explained the various parts of the gardens. Later I walked through the gardens which is lovely and gives you a great view over the harbour as well. A delightful few hours.

Stunning Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney.. Experience the hot summer sun while discovering unique flora and fauna that is both on display and lives in this majestic harbourside urban park. Well worth the time to relax and soak up the summer sun.

Gorgeous . Gorgeous gardens in the middle of the city. Can spot there not only all those beautiful plants and flowers but also many animals. The edge of the park has amazing view of the Opera and bridge

I just love the Sydney Royal Botanical Gardens. A+. I just love the Sydney Royal Botanical Gardens. I try to always go for a walk here when in Sydney. Definitely if I am staying in the city. There are so many different parts and I always walk a different route and find something new.

Garden Lovers. Visited during early spring and found many plants in bloom. A great Sunday morning stroll to visit the gardens is a nice way to spend the day. Walk the coastal path from the gardens towards Potts Point and explore waterfront areas of Sydney.

A short visit so we took the train. We were walking around Circular Quay and the Sydney Opera House and still had a little time to fill in but not enough time (or energy) to walk around the Royal Botanic Gardens so we took the little red train at the gates and had a guided 1/2 hour tour for $10 and the gardens were looking fresh and bright on this warm spring day. The guide's voice was a little hard to hear due to the noise of the train and other riders, but we were able to follow most of the talk.
Not to be missed. Site of the first European settlement in Australia, the gardens provide an oasis right in the heart of town next to the Opera House, Government House and the city.

Beautiful place to relax with great views. This is a wonderful, large piece of parkland with views of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House. The gardens are full of plants, open spaces, fountains, statues, and wildlife. You can spend hours wandering around the entire place and there is always something new to see. Its even good for a laugh with some of the fitness freaks doing some of the weirdest looking movements that if you did them in the street you'd get locked up - I'm talking Monty Python's funny walks! Get out in the sunshine and bring a picnic.A word of warning though - look out for Cockatoo #12 - he's a vicious little bugger! My other half was taking photos of a group of other cockatoos and #12 was running around chasing pigeons off. Next thing we know he runs right at my other half and bites one of her toes (she was wearing flip flops) - she tried to back off and run away, but the bird just kept chasing after her until I managed to wave it off.
A Good relax place. Very peaceful and lots of plants in Botanic Gardens. Good place to have free walk there. Fresh air provides much self energy for a daily busy work.

What a Garden!. The place is very tidy. The plants are well organised by type of environment they naturally growing in the wild. The collection is large and probably complete. A very nice place to walk through and free your mind of day to day worries.

Attractive gardens in a cental business area without much green. We entered the gardens up along the Macquarie Street gate and walked down toward the Opera House through the park.
