Wow! . My wife and I walked through the gardens on our first visit to Sydney. They are magnificent. The trees really are are gorgeous. Towards the water there are also great photo opportunities of the bay.

Beautiful & Peaceful. Good place to lounge and have a picnic -- if it's in the summer time. We went there in the winter time, and was pleasant...until the sun started going down. But all in all, a good place to visit.

Beautiful calm area in the middle of the city. We spent a morning wondering around this lovely gardens area in the middle of Sydney, the park is beautifully maintained and has so many different trees/flowers/birds and numerous other animals. Well worth a visit for the stunning park and great views of the city, harbour bridge and Opera House.

fresh air at edge of city. It's wonderful walking through the gates into another world, away from the city traffic and crowds. We recently walked into the Gardens from the Woolloomooloo side for the first time and strolled past large trees, complete with raucous cockatoos, and paid our respects to the wonderful statue of Henry Lawson and friends. We went on down past the Boy Charlton pool, along Mrs Macquarie's Bushwalk, down to the water's edge with its rocky overhang and little beach, much as it must have been for centuries. It was a delightful short walk.

For free, great views. Nice walkways and stairs with lots of good views from the skyline and harbour. Always nice and tidy.
Just remember no bikes allowed and the gates are closing in the night time.

beauitful. to many runners and bootcamps not taking walkers into consideration. beautiful place with lovely flowers plants and trees. we seen a wedding going on which was amazing. could have spent all day in there. there is a cafe in the middle of it all which was great to have a little rest and refreshment

Very well maintained, makes for amazing walks with splendid views. We visited the Royal Botanic garden on a weekend evening and had a lovely time walking the enormous park - it is well maintained with beautifully kept lawns and splendid views of the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. The much talked about Mrs Macqaurie's point also makes for a lovely walk with brilliant views of the blue seas.(P.S.: if you want to get the picture perfect postcards of the Opera house and the Bridge, visit the Park in the morning when the sun shines on these landmarks instead of evening)

Amazingly quiet and such fun to explore. right smack in Sydney! So green with so many shrubs and amazing trees. You also get great views of the harbour. Great way to unwind after a stressful day. A chance to see the winter blooms! There are cafes so hot drinks to warm oneself. Check times before esp if you want to spend a few hours lost in the gardens.

Sensational garden displays on Sydney Harbour. Beautifully tended and presented gardens, a total delight to walk through. Easy to understand why Mrs Macquarie sat where she did, gazing out over Sydney Harbour, watching the ships come and go.Great train ride on offer for kids (young and old) and a beautiful backdrop to run/jog past.

Nature and city life combined. Amazing to walk in the gardens with the skyscrapers and city life on the background. If you walk to the end (mrs Macquarie's Chair), you will have an amazing view on the harbour and the Opera house and you will find THE spot where people take the selfies with the opera house and harbour bridge on the background.

Beautiful with a big surprise. My wife and I did a walking tour of the gardens by ourselves after a morning tour of Sydney. We enjoyed the flowers, plants and tree that we saw, but the best part was the wild sulphur-crested cockatoos that we happened upon. I was taking a picture of my wife by a rock sculpture when a cockatoo landed on the rock. This was followed by another and another. One of them landed by my feet and I had a cracker in my bag that I gave it. Well, the next thing we knew, we were in the midst of a large flock of cockatoos. I've never seen them in the wild, so this was awesome. A few landed on my wife and myself and I even got one to mimic my talking. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Sydney.

A Great Place to Walk in an Oasis. Go to the botanic gardens and you can forget your are in the middle of the rat race of Sydney City. Green and lush with plenty of amazing trees and shrubs. There are also spectacular harbour views.

Nice Botanic Gardens. It's a nice Botanic Gardens to walk through with some pretty flowers. We were there in June and it was still green and pretty. There isn't a lot to see but it's worth taking a stroll through to see what it's all about and to hear the loud birds that aren't necessarily pleasant but certainly interesting. It's a good place just outside the city.
Beautiful. Guys, take your woman here and yiu will earn major brownie points!!!Great couple of hours, beautiful sights, tons of cool looking birds and a little bit of exercise...

My favourite place to relax in Sydney. My favourite place in Sydney. Nice stills, great views of the Sydney CBD skyline and the Opera House with Bay Bridge in the back. Some parts of the park have flocks of Kakadu's. There are many benches to sit and relax.
Worth the Visit. Worth walking through if you have the time, close to the Opera House and therefore the water. Go if you can.

Good place to visit in Sydney!. Nice place to visit where to see several different particular plants. Around the garden you can visit several other places and the surround is also great. A place where to go for relax.

Wonderful Plants and beautiful walking paths.. A fun and relaxing place to enjoy the plants and beautiful flowers of Australia. It is a great walk and it is a wonderful place of natural beauty and nature.

A must see. These gardens were beautiful. It was a testament to the gardeners kept it so fabulously green. Only recycled water used. My abidin memory is of fruit bats hanging off a tree. Why? Be warned if you don't like bats keep away from the section with bats. The matured bats can have 6 foot wing span. They occasionally go for a spin but they're pretty drowsy in the day. The views of Darling Harbour are one of the wonders of the world.
Gorgeous Trees. Spent a couple of afternoons walking through the gardens, lovely old trees in amongst some really well kept grounds, a very peaceful place.
Beautiful place. Always take friends and families who are visiting to watch the sunset. They all loved it. Lovely place to see the harbour bridge and opera house.

Fabulous! Excellent! Not enough words to describe!. This is my favourite place in Sydney. Each time I go to the city I try to fit in a visit to the gardens. Every time I am amazed by how well-maintained the gardens are, and I appreciate the people whose efforts go into keeping the gardens so pleasant and appealing to visitors.I have been there to read a book peacefully, I have been here with family to have picnics, I have come here to sit amidst familiar trees from back home when I get homesick... and I have enjoyed watching bridal parties who come here to get a few good photographs with the opera house in the background.

Relaxing place to wind down. Located near the famous opera house, it is recommended place to visit for the lush greenery and flower blooms. Joggers will enjoy the view of the Harbour side when running along the footpaths in the garden.

Fabulous Park. We had a great morning walk in this amazing park. The plants, trees and wildlife are well tended, stunningly beautiful and eager to help you out with your lunch (in that order!). There's a little red train that goes around and a some friendly ibis that love the crust off your sandwich.

Lush green. We were there in winters, so going to a garden was must. This Royal botanical gardens were too beautiful and tooooo green. Such big gardens and completely green.
We lie down on the grass, kids playing the sun, as really perfect.
They are indeed perfectly manicured gardens.
Walk about. Had a nice walk around the gardens saw some interesting and some rare plants very well laid out didn't get to see the large house but enjoyed the time spent there

Sydney's harbor side gardens. Beautiful and easy walk from the opera house steps through the botanical gardens into the city or turn down a path to the NSW art gallery. Views of the harbour. Lots of great photo opportunities. The gardens are a part of Sydney life with office workers playing a relaxed game of touch footie on a good day. Best of all unlike many other cities of the world th gardens are free!!

Pleasant stroll. Situated just by the opera house these gardens are large really well kept . But because you have great views ,you are left with the perplexing question of do you look at the view of the harbour or the local botany .My suggestion is look at both .Best to leave an hour , amenities are plentiful and clean
A Haven in the Middle of Sydney. Beautiful Gardens, on the harbor in the middle of the City. Take a picnic or just lay on the grass great for all ages.
Lovely walk with great views. This walk gives you the chance to see Sydney from a different perspective and is worth taking the time to explore.

Huge garden with animals and plants. The royal botanic garden is worth the trip. If you want to escape the busyness of the city, get on your way to the gardens, sit down on one of the benches or on the grass and enjoy the view of the plants and birds with the stunning harbour and opera house in the background.

Beautiful place to spend time with your loved ones. Very well maintained garden spread over a wide area, the best part is it is free for all to walk on the grass, and admire the beauty of plants and flowers, the pond in the middle has eels lovely environment in a natural setting.

Beautifully Maintained. Huge gardens that you can easily become lost in. If you enter the gardens from the Opera House side, you can hop on the Choo Choo express and go on a (novelty) scenic train ride throughout the park.Lovely for a quiet read, great for a morning jog, and excellent fun for Mermaid searching if your child is on a permanent search for Ariel.Plenty of variety in gardens (HSBC Chinese gardens, rose gardens, Apothecary gardens etc.) throughout the park.No obvious crime (except for plant theft), and a very secure feeling park, unlike Hyde Park in the city.

Lovely Gardens. This garden is huge. The lay-out and the concept reminds me of the formal gardens in Europe. Nice and quiet, great place to stroll and relax. It felt like a sanctuary from the hustle and bustle of the city-noise. Unlike Hyde Park, there was not much of the hurried feel There was just not a lot of tourists there. It is almost connected to the Sydney Opera House. You can access the Opera House area from the Royal Botanic Gardens and save you from crossing the busy McQuarie street.

flower!!!. a nice park with lots of flowers. Id recommend to walk there from circular Quey and then just walk around in the garden. there is also a red train wich you can go on. The park is great for a morning run.

must go. one of the best spots in Sydney that you shouldn't missed.
Was there weeks back, a beautiful winter, it was sunny and relaxing.so refreshing and perfect garden for jogging.
picture best angle taken from Mrs. Macquaries points
Relax. So many nice spots to enjoy here. Loved all the fountains and statues. Nice place to have a picnic and relax after all the walking in Sydney.

One of my favourite spots in Sydney . I consider myself to be very fortunate to have this haven on my doorstep. I work at the Macquarie Street end of Martin Place, just a few hundred meters from the RBG.
A serene and beautiful escape from the hustle and bustle of the CBD.
It remains an icon of this great city.

Boring Place. Not much you can do except lie down, sleep, rest, eat, etc.
fitness freaks can do jog, run, exercise
Pretty big garden with a stunning view of opera house & sydney harbour bridge

Beautiful Gardens with a view.. Many other World Gardens may surpass this for Botanical Quality but there are unique Australian plants, some as old as the colony almost, and the views as you wander around are great, lovely grassy areas where sun shine bathes the reclining figures of office workers lunching, families munching and walkers wandering. Right next to the Opera House and runs up toward the NSW Library and Art Galleries so well placed.

Highly recommend. This was one of our family highlights in Sydney! The spaciousness increased the beauty and our enjoyment not only did we see new flowers/trees/birds that we have never seen before in the States.

Royal Botanic Gardens. Excellent Gardens, this was Sydney's first farm 1788. Make it an inexpensive day by taking a picnic basket. There is no admission fee! The Art Gallery across from the park should also be included it's also free admission (except for some exhibitions) the cloak room will mind your picnic basket. Good coffee to be found in the Garden's and Art Gallery.
Beautiful. These gardens are quite extensive and very beautiful even if you aren't a gardener. I am not a gardener but really enjoyed the visit.

Tranquil and a Feast for the senses.. This is the most beautiful place, a must visit when you get to the Sydney area. There are so may specimens to see, some of which can only be seen in Australia. Very clean and not a lot of side attractions to spoil your time or pocket book. Enjoy the beauty that abounds, take as many pictures as you want and just relax in this most tranquil place in all of Sydney.

Beautiful place to get away from it in and lay on the grass. This is a great place to take in the views, lay in the grass, maybe visit one of the exibits on with in the gardens and if you can get tickets to be in they gardens on New Year's Eve you won't be disappointed!
Relaxing way to spend a couple of hours. Beautiful walk around the cove on Sydney Harbour. Great views of the Bridge and Opera House from Macquarie's point.
Garden. this garden is in the heart of the city and very highly rated world wide. plan to spend half a day here!

Beautiful gardens, great views. Loved the botanic gardens. The gardens themselves are so well kept and nice with the added bonus of fantastic views of the city, the harbour and the Opera house and Harbour Bridge. Plenty of lovely benches to sit and rest your legs for a while or it would be a great spot for a picnic too.

I love it. Absoulutely the place to be. "Please walk on the gras", there is no better way feel more invited to straight away fall in love with the Royal Botanic Garden. Bring your stress level down and enjoy the nature in the middle of the city. Don't miss the flying foxes!

The herb garden was a treat..... We had breakfast in the botanical gardens restaurant and it was disgusting to say the least. The service was, well there was no service they were to busy winning about work to serve and we had to wait on the lounge for about 10 minutes before being seated. Then we had to wait for another 15 minutes to be served and then the food came out half hour later, The only reason that we stayed is we were hungry and the trip to walk to go somewhere else was so far. Would not recommend this restaurant to anyone at all. Shame really as this is SYDNEYS BOTANICAL GARDENS and that is why we went there in the first place.

Take Your Time in the Gardens. Set aside some time to stroll through the Royal Botanical Gardens. The trails, gardens, public art and wildlife (even bats in trees!) are well worth not rushing.Read the descriptions of the flora and fauna along the way. The RBG is well-thought and well-planned.If you time your visit correctly, you can open a bottle of wine and sit in the grass to watch the sun set behind the Sydney Harbour Bridge.
Quality Time in the Gardens. Lovely. Relaxing. Good smells. Bats hanging from trees. A wonderful way to spent some quality SYD time! Uncrowded.

Beautiful Park but do reconsider before taking the choo choo rides. Went there for a short walk and decided to take the Choo Choo rides which last for about 25 minutes and going to 4 key stops. IF you're someone who wants to take nice photographs of the park, DO NOT TAKE THE RIDE. It's not that the ride is not good, but it does not stop at all and you have zero opportunity to take a nice photo. You will end up wanting to walk back to the location you past by to take nice photos. However, DO TAKE THE RIDE if you just want a quick overview of the garden, having some fun and not keen to take really nice photos of the view, the flowers, the fountain, the trees etc. For children it's 5 bucks and adult is 10 bucks. Even though my ride is at 4pm, I got to be seated as early as 3.30pm as the seats are "first come first serve" basis. Since I'm not into taking those really nice picture, I think the choo choo ride experience was fine.

Loved it!. We really loved strolling through these gardens especially from the Opera House to Macquarie Point. The views are stunning. The gardens are beautiful, and it is really quite a lovely walk. There is also a small train that runs through the gardens that you can take.

Beautiful Gardens. The gardens are definitely one of the most lovely places I visited in Australia, filled with trees, flowers, and birds, as well as peace and quiet. We did a walking tour with a guide (about 1.5 hours) which I would definitely recommend. We were on limited time, so I did not see as much as I would have liked. If I find myself in Sydney again, I will definitely go back to the gardens and allot myself more time to enjoy the beauty.

A truly grand botanical garden. We spent several days in Sydney during early April 2015. The Royal Botanic Gardens nestled above the Sydney Opera House and all the way around to Mrs. Macquarrie's Chair is truly a treasure to wander through and enjoy. It is a thoroughly relaxing place to sit and enjoy nature after a busy day exploring the CBD in Sydney.
Beautiful Gardens. When walking through the gardens you get a sense of the locals nak for enjoyment and relaxation. I love the Aussies positive attitude and joy in everything they do. Great!

I wish i was there everyday. i am a park person and this place was simple beautiful, I was there in summer so i had the opportunity to sit and relax a bit after a long day of walking around the CBD. a good book from the local library and an awesome cup of coffee was heavenly. Definitely going there again
Great day out. Spent a full day here loads to do and see watch out for the fruit bats hanging from the trees lovely to look at but can be messy
Easy to get round.. Caught the little train round the gardens due to my problematic hip!! This was a good way to get around with an interesting commentary.

Trip to Sydney. Amazing display of flowers considering the heat in Oz. Must be well watered!! Also some to enormous fruit bats that hang upside down in lots of the trees, flapping their wings to keep cool. Don't know how they stand the heat!

Beautiful, relaxing. Love these gardens. Such a beautiful place to visit, relax and enjoy the water view on one side and feel relaxed under the shade of the trees on the other side. Large areas to walk around or take the train for a small charge if unable to walk. A must place to visit when in Sydney

Pretty. It's so amazing that in a city the size of Sydney you can find somewhere are nice as the Botanical Gardens. So quite, tons of flowers and bushes to admire. And pond with ducks. Lots of benches to stop and sit to admire the surrounding beauty. As well as drinking fountains to refill water bottles on hot days.
Loved the Cockatoos!. So many birds and beautiful gardens. I visited the Government House and loved that also. I was lovely to walk along the water and admire the beautifully kept gardens.
So beautiful and peaceful. . Beautiful and idyllic, the botanical gardens is conveniently located near circular quay station and the opera house. Great for a picnic.

Good with Potential of becoming Great Botanical Garden in the City !. I'm not sure if I was expecting more from this place or this Botanical garden need a bit of face lift but I'm sure that it's got enough potential to be recognised as one of the Great botanical gardens if it can accommodate a wide and diversified portfolio of plants.

Great food with a fantastic vista. The restaurant has a very limited menu, maybe five or six mains, but the three we have had are all fantastic.Modern world cuisine, all fusion, perfectly balanced.Deserts are fantastic and the coffee is beautiful.The wine selection is quite limited and of moderate quality.The views over the Botanic Gardens are extensive, to the water, and the restaurant itself is beautifully presented in a slightly up market, smart casual sense. Prices are perhaps a bit steep, but consider that a view tax without loss of quality.
Lovely place tyo walk around. This is quite a big area and has plenty of various places within the park to either sit quietly and admire the view or to enter to view the plants

Walk in the Botanic Gardens. Any nice day take a walk around the Botanic Gardens, they are beautiful with so much to see. My fave walk is from the Opera House to Mrs. Macquarie's chair and then on to trendy Woolloomooloo for a mela or a coffee. Back via the NSW Art Gallery, and check out their reszstaurnt and gift shop. Back through the Gardens and be sure to stop at the Gift shop and restaurant. Delightfully located in a shady pretty part of the gardens near the ponds. SO much to buy in the shop and then walk back through the park to Macquarie Street and down Martin Place to catch your bus or train. So relaxing and so much to see for very little cost!

A escape from the city in the city. The first thing I visited when I arrived to Sydney was the Royal Botanic Gardens. I was fascinated: kids practising how to play the flute, enthusiastic runners everywhere, people having picnics plus the considerable variety of flora. Great way to spend the day out.

Calm and Serenity in the Middle of the City. The Royal Botanic Gardens, which semi-circles the magnificent Sydney Harbour, is a wonderful retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city. At lunch time, especially during the summer, many office workers will make the effort to come to the gardens with their sandwich lunch, sit under a tree, and just enjoy an hour of quiet and relaxation.Alternatively, it is a wonderful place to slowly walk around part of Sydney Harbour then meander through the various themed gardens.For those seriously interested in flora, the gardens have an astonishing array of native trees, shrubs, plants and flowers., including some glass houses for ferns, orchids and other plants that will not grow outside in Sydney's clime, benevolent as it is.In January, during the Sydney's Festival of Arts, there is a special treat for kids (or parents of kids who want to entertain them for the day during school holidays). The Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust stages an al fresco performance of "The Wind in the Willows".This hour long performance has the kids totally enthralled, although when I took my little granddaughter to the show a couple of years ago, she expressed instant dislike of Mr Fox. (NB: There is no fee for entrance to the Botanic Gardens, but tickets for the Wind in the Willows show are about $25 from memory).

Nature at its best - and it's all free. Amazing variety of flora and fauna, and hard to believe that it's in the city centre. Well worth a couple of hours' strolling, be it in a group or solo. Recommend packing a picnic just to enjoy the fresh air, birdsong and magnificent colours of the trees and flowers.

EXCELLENT LOCATION TO WATCH NEW YEAR EVE FIRE SHOW. The huge lush green garden right in the heart of the buzzing CBD area and in close proximity of the of the awesome Opera House, symbolises the true character of Sydney where culture and nature are considered precious pillars of contemporary life style.Immaculately maintained, a leisurely visit to the garden is very relaxing n refreshing.The northern tip of the garden offers stunning views of the Harbour bridge n Opera House and is probably one of the best location to watch the great New Year Eve Fire Show. Of course, this is a paid site, but certainly worth the money.
Pristine and simply stunning!. The gardens are simply beautiful, well cared for and just the most romantic place to be with that special someone you love.

Beautiful calm. The gardens are a beautiful calm spot alongside the lovely Sydney harbour. The gardens are lush, lawns are green, and the array of plants wonderful. A great spot to walk and enjoy the amazing views across the water towards the Opera House and Bridge. Many benches to rest at, lots of picnic spots and a café. What out for the Ibis birds that steal snacks at the café or from your picnic.
best place for a hangover!!!. absolutely beautiful!! and they have some great signage to explain things. You can get some great shots of the Opera house and the bridge while youre there
Beautiful. Didn't get much time to explore the botanical gardens but what i did see was beautiful a really nice area and walking distance to the opera house and harbour bridge

Haven in the city. This was one of my favorite parts of Melbourne. I loved how many birds live there and what a great variety of animals they had. I recommend taking the free tour that they offer to learn a bit about its history and about the plants.

Lovely even in the winter. We spent yesterday at the botanic gardens in Sydney. It was beautiful. So very lush and green. Hard to believe it is winter when you are Canadian. The walkways are very well maintained with alternate walkways if stairs are involved.There were a few flowers still in bloom and most were well signed with plaques. The birds were amazing, so different from the ones we normally see.The views of Sydney Harbour and the opera house were amazing.There was a cafe that had good food although very expensive. Also where was lots of bathrooms and the one near the gift shop was very clean. I didn't see any of the others. The gift shop had many lovely things and prices varied.The only problem we had was the website said that wheelchairs were available. We went early in the morning so we would be sure to get one and when we got there we were told they only had one and it was booked already. The website said nothing about pre-booking it. When I asked why they only had one I was told the others had been stolen. This is a simple problem to solve, ask people for a large deposit on their credit cards or have them leave a drivers licence that will be returned when the chair is returned.
Beautiful landscapes. Just a walk away from the Opera House. These beautiful gardens are well worth a visit, very pretty, picturesque and serene.

Beautiful wander . The garden is smaller than I thought, but has lovely open lawns, water features and ponds. There is a restaurant near the centre. The pond has eels that we could spot: exciting for my son. Large trees and many birds around.
Nice place to stay near centre. Lots of nice lawns to stay, lie and rest near by centre and Opera house. Places in shadows under the big trees with nice views.
Oasis near the heart of Sydney. Large and well looked after. The gardens are a calm oasis near the centre of the city. They are a delight to the eyes. A great place to just be for a few hours.

A brief visit. I didn't manage to stay and have a complete look, but we managed to go through it and it was so beautiful. There are just so many gems in Sydney and and local should be grateful for each and every one.
A good walk with great views. A great walk with awesome view of the harbour bridge and opera house, don't drive there as parking is not free and it is policed
A Walk through the Gardens. We visited the Gardens during winter just for a stroll after days of traveling around. Quite relaxing.
Sydney's Royal Botanic Gardens. What a great place to roam around and get creatively lost. Even in the winter months the gardens are spotlessly maintained and have representative plant life.

Great gardens and location. Extensive gardens with great views. Lots to see and the walking effort required is well worth it. We walked through the gardens towards the Opera House and then through the gardens / parks to the Domain towards Mrs Mcquaries seat
Loved it. A lovely botanic garden, I especially loved the ferns and the several peculiar looking trees, as well as the different species of birds all around.

Must come back. We were at circular quay with an hour to kill so we walked around past the Opera to the Botanic Gardens . By the gate there is the "Choochootrain" this service runs every half hour and does a tour of the Botanic Gardens , there are 4 stops in the Gardens and you can Hop off and walk around and then get the next train to the next stop . It is a great way to get around the Gardens without having to walk to far. There is also a commentary as you go around explaining some of the features and exhibits. As we were short of time we stayed on the train which takes around 25 minutes to complete a circuit but we will be spending a lot more time here on our next trip to Sydney. The cost is very reasonable at $10 - $5 for Seniors.
lovely strolls, look out for the bats. Excellent for a nice green seaside stroll - definitely look out for the flying foxes (fruit bats) when they leave their roosts in the evening!
Enjoyable Garden. There are several entrances and brochures available. Very relaxing site with fauna typical of Australia.

Must see. After your visit to the Opera House take time to stroll through the Royal Botanic Gardens. You will be glad you did. Don't expect a lot of exotic foliage, but do expect a beautiful relaxing stroll. My daughter made sandwichs and we had a picnic in the Gardens. Enjoyed the view which included a view of the harbor

Absolutely Gorgeous!. Originally, I planned just to use the gardens as a traffic free way to get to the famous Harry's Cafe du Wheels pie shop (known as Harry's to the locals as the latter part of the name is unused to the point that you will confuse the locals if you use it) and then to the Sydney Opera House which is directly adjacent. I just used Google Maps to plan out the route. However, the gardens are absolutely gorgeous. There are tropical plants that I was surprised to see thriving in an allegedly temperate environment. There are also gorgeous artsy sitting areas. Although I used the gardens as a quite and scenic alternative to the typical city streets which I spent most of my time in anyway, the Royal Gardens hosts plenty of free events throughout the year. It's easy to spend several minutes in or an afternoon in. I encourage everyone to grab a coffee and snack and just enjoy the views. I found a nice spot that I could watch the ocean and Sydney Opera House from.Have I mentioned that it's free to go in the gardens?

Trees!!. I love parks and gardens and this is one of the best! if you love weird and wonderful trees this is the place to go, I loved that everything was growing the way it is supposed to, not formed into a shape. When we went things were a little dead but still beautiful and definitely worth a look.

Very big and calm garden. I went on a morning so it was quite quiet. The garden is big and would take some time to walk around. I guess more recommendable in spring or summer time since there are less blossoms in June.

Beautiful Gardens. Gorgeous, well maintained gardens. My husband and I spent a nice afternoon walking around the gardens and taking pictures while recovering from our flight from the US. The sandwich shop and the gift shop were very nice. Loved the cockatoos!

Great little park. This was a great little park to hang out in or walk through. There are many interesting plants/flowers (and creepy huge spiders) and the park is full of folks hanging out, running, or just strolling through.

Great place to chill out. I have been here several times for quiet walks one my own and with my girlfriend. I have also been to a wedding here and it's a great place to go if that is your scene. There's a lot of pathways going to different places and once you reach the end you don't have to go back the same way you came. Good views of the bridge and skyline in areas too.
Lovely. The gardens are lovely, while many flowers were not in bloom, the path along the river is quite picturesque.
great views of the city. wonderful park, great gardens with lots of space for gardens, and amazing views of the city, the harbour bridge and the opera house.
Green and Local. I love how this botanical garden kept organized and taking good care of it's people. Plus you can visit here without a fee.

Visit to gardens. After first visiting opera house we walked over to close by Royal botanical gardens. Its beautiful and serene. Full of greenery with diversified species of trees,flowers,green lawns,marble statues,gazebos for sitting and a rose garden. Lots of small cafes and rest rooms at various locations and many gates. A must visit.

So much beauty for free. There is a lot to see at the Royal Botanic Gardens. Most people know of the Sydney Opera House, but walking the gardens should also be included in a visit. I've been to gardens that charge a fee, but this one does not. We walked through it during the fall/winter - beautiful colors.
Royal Botanic Gardens. The botanic gardens are very large, but everything is well laid out and easy to find. The Government House on the grounds is well worth a visit (free tours are offered).

Botanical Gardens Sydney. Wonderful and very varied gardens. Lovely views of the city, harbor and Opera House from many different angles. Small train runs thru part of the gardens if you are not able to walk, otherwise excellent paths and trails.

Don't Forget the Local Area. Loved the Gardens.. but also would love to spend more time next time exploring the historic buildings and exhibitions in the local area.. eg the library, and other nearby historic buildings.

Endless Precincts, Moods and Vistas. These Gardens can be approached from the Opera House and City side, or from the Art Gallery side. Here not only will you find yourself on a journey through an amazing range of environments, such as the hot house, the tropical jungle, the stands of local trees as well as exotics, but you can find a fantastic walled cactus garden and replica of the first farm gardens in Sydney's early European Settlement. There are ponds with ducks and water plants, there is a restaurant and a tea house. There are walkways with some elevation looking down onto the harbours, just behind the Conservatorium for Music, and there are harbour side walks where you may find busy city workers taking their lunch time run. For those with less orientation to the aerobic side of life, there are lawns for having picnic lunches where office workers and families with young children mingle. There are guided tours if you want to hear more in depth about the gardens, and if you don't there are quiet nooks and crannies where you may find lovers seeking privacy, or people contemplating the meaning of life, the universe and everything. Sometimes there are events, like Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Nights Dream" performed here at night in the summer. Some of the best ground level views of the harbour are from the Gardens. Tour buses often stop at Lady Macquarie's Chair to take photos of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House.There is parking along the road that runs between the Art Gallery and the Domain. There are clean toilets and easy access for everyone, including wheelchairs.
Botanic everything. great place did not want to leave the food was so great.Everything grown on site.Wine was wonderful before our pre cruise.wow.I wish I had one of these in my area.

Green and lush. A stroll through the gardens on your way to the harbour and Opera house is a great way to see some lush green grounds. Just outside the busy Sydney city and traffic it's a nice place to unwind. Also has some great viewing locations across the harbour
Beautiful Walk through the Gardens. Walking from our hotel the Daring Harbor we had to pass through this garden. It's beautiful and a good place to rest and take in the sights. We really enjoyed it.

Go There!. The Botanic Gardens are long-time faves. There are so many interesting sight; fruit bats in the trees and colourful parakeets will eat out of your hand. Don't forget the garden statuary and the sculpture of Pan.

Peaceful. Really lovely gardens (especially in the sun) to walk around and enjoy the views of the opera house, harbour bridge and all the flora. Very peaceful and relaxing - a break from the Sydney urban lifestyle!

Spent hours here completely enthralled.. We had a couple of hours to kill waiting to get on a cruise ship. We had already checked our bags at the pier so we headed around Circular Quay to the Gardens. We spent over 4 hours just mesmerized by the amazing variety of trees. plants, birds and the fabulous landscaping. Had a very fun chat with one of the docents and she walked us over to an area with 2 sleeping owls in a tree. We learned so much just walking and reading the information everywhere. Truly a fun time.

Old trees and cockatoos. Bring some almonds ffor the cockatoos and watch the ibis-birds clean out the waste-bins.
So much to see and do and learn.
Good walk. Weave through the gardens, see the art gallery, and appear at the opera house around the edge of the water.

Great way to see harbiur. Give yourself some time to explore the beauitful gardens
Cafes inside are great too
Walk around to wooloomoo from opera house via more macquaries chair

Still worth a visit even in winter. It was very pleasant and beautiful strolling through the Royal Botanic gardens. Only reason it didn't get an excellent rating was because it was winter time so you don't get to see it at its full bloom.

MOST BEAUTIFUL PLACE. The gardens are amazing. You can walk or take the ground tram. We did both and we saw it all. We had a wonderful lunch at the gardens. It is good to walk around and then take the tram to make sure you have seen it all. You won't be disappointed in this beautiful place. HAVE A GREAT TIME!

Very pretty. The train ride is $10 for an adult and $5 for a child and is well worth it. The driver was super friendly and she told us a lot about the gardens. The train also made 4 stops along the way where you could get out and get back on a later train. It was well worth the money on the train. It was very pretty and is pretty close to the opera house
Fun way to while away an afternoon. The ground are beautiful--its a great counterpoint to the hustle of Sydney--a great way to chill for an afternoon and take in some unique flora and fauna.
An escape in the city.. If you are tired of the fast pace of the city, get out for a brisk stroll through the gardens. A must if you spend most of your working hours trapped in the city centre.

Wedding in the rose gardens!. What a stunning spot for a small wedding! As with any outdoor setting the weather's a bit of a risk, but on this occasion it came up trumps! There is a covered area right there though, so that provides a contingency plan.There's space for a few white chairs with the ability to attach some flowers or bows, and also the possibility of larger urns of flowers on pedestals.And what a beautiful place to go for a relaxing stroll between the ceremony and reception - up the road at the Hyde Park Barracks! Lovely!

Beautiful walk!. I really enjoyed wandering through the gardens, and it's a nice, quiet place in the middle of the city! Take your time, as there is lots to see. The only thing I didn't like is the bats hanging upside down in the trees! They didn't do anything, but it creeped me out a bit! :)

Beauty at every turn. So many varieties of amazing trees, shrubs and plants it is hard to see it all. We saw it in fall and the blooms were still amazing. The biggest surprise was a flock of wild cockatoos - at least 30 of them were just sitting on the ground eating. The park closes early in fall/winter - 5 pm - do get there early.

Best sunset of the Opera House.. The garden is very beautiful and quiet. At least I was there during low season, so it was quiet. Also, the best view of the sunset is from the Royal Garden. It is quite amazing and very romantic for couples.
Excellent. I'm a big fan of gardens and these were ace, even in poor weather. Formal and informal areas and overlooking the harbour too.

Serene and beautiful. Visiting the Royal Botanic Gardens is a must do! Away from the busyness of the city, overlooking the ocean and Sydney Opera House, we were transported into lush, peaceful gardens. There is also a quaint little train to drive you through the grounds. Highly recommend!

Oasis in the City. I think it's hard to find a botanical gardens that isn't a lovely place of beauty and respite but the to find one in the middle of one of the most beautiful cities in the world is a rarer find. Enjoy the flora with a back drop of a stunning harbour and city skylines and be surprised by the fauna. There is aa colony of flying foxes that live in the trees, and an abundance of bird life, from cockatoos to ibis' as well as many other varieties that a green oasis like this must attract. There is a lovely cafe/restaurant at it's heart but you know, a picnic hamper and blanket is all you really need. Don't forget to check out the glass pyramid green house, the succulent garden as well as the pond down by harbour. This pond is a known breeding ground of eels (that periodically need clearing out as they would feed on the ducklings) that some how get back into the pond each year. There are some great walking tracks all through out the park but once you're done, exit the gardens via the Opera House. Always a lovely site to finish a wonderful treck.
Amazing grounds. Take an early morning stroll here and take in the beauty as the dew begins to evaporate. The ground are huge but every area is worth it.

Peaceful and very relaxing. We really enjoying spending a few hours walking around the gardens. Great views of the bridge and opera house. Many flowers were in bloom and best of all there is no admission fee.

Mother's Day Relaxing Picnic & Walk through the Royal Botanic Gardens. Inhale the oxygen of all the beautiful flora that our Royal Botanic Gardens offer. Stroll through the green park, stop for a picnic lunch and just enjoy the Harbour and Opera House view. Reflection, relaxation, a feeling of spiritual calmness.
Beautiful. I do love these gardens, with something to see whatever the season. The footpaths are easy to walk with so much to see.
A beautiful space in a spectacular location. The Royal Botanic Gardens are really beautiful and interesting and have the added bonus of providing a setting for your photos of the harbour

Oasis in the CBD. The gardens are very well-maintained. There's a great variety of flora, statues, fountains and interesting architecture. You can spend a whole day strolling, picnicking and enjoying the serenity. The view along the waterfront is gorgeous as well. Unfortunately, the gardens close around sunset, which is a bit early.
Place for relaxation. Peaceful place for relaxation. Beutiful garden, but not so nica than botanic gardens in Melbourne. There are a few steps that are difficult for wheelchair users.

From city bustle to calm oasis.. You can enjoy the Botanical Gardens any day and time of year. The whole gardens abound with amazing local and foreign flora, statuary, lovely old buildings and more modern structures featuring exotic tropical plants. It's an wonderfully peaceful place right in the centre of the hustle and bustle of the city, but the minute you cross the boundary into the gardens it's like the noise and activity of a big city melts away. I loved it.

Close to Nature. The Royal botanical garden is an absolute pleasure to visit. All those eager to have some respite from hush hush of city must visit and spend some hours close to nature here. During my trip I stayed few hours here and was refreshed for the day. Had a wonderful time here.

Peaceful respite from the city. The Royal Botanic gardens have something to offer at any time of year, though my favourite times are Spring and Autumn. The gardens contain native Australian plant gardens as well as rare exotic trees and other plants, including some which date back to the early settlement of Sydney. There are also tranquil duck ponds and seating areas to have a picnic. And the location is in The Domain, right on the harbour with views of the Opera House from the west side of the gardens. For fabulous harbour views, walk through the gardens along the harbour wall to Mrs Macquarie's chair, a promontory which juts out into the harbour. There is also a cafe and shop with lovely handicrafts. Avoid taking a car as the parking fees are exorbitant. Use public transport and walk. The nearest train stations are Martin Place and St James, which are on the city circle network. There are also free buses stopping outside the Art gallery of NSW which is located across Gallery Road nearby. There are free guided tours available most days of the week at lunchtime. To plan your visit to the gardens go to:http://www.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/welcome/royal_botanic_garden/planning_your_visitfrom this link you will also find another link to "What's on" for the current month. There are art courses and often an art or craft exhibition or two.
Enjoy the walk. My friend who lives in Sydney brought us here and we enjoy our walk and time here. Hopefully we can be back again.

Great (free) place to visit & explore flora heritage of Australia. The Royal Botanical Gardens are a great place to visit to escape from the hustle and bustle of Circular Quay and the Opera House. Set over a large foreshore area extending back, there are many areas to visit including some indoor buildings. These buildings house some little surprises - you should go and see!Of note are the large amounts of bats that roost in the trees during the daytime. At dusk and dawn, you can see their exodous which is quite spectacular. Furthermore, if you look carefully into the trees, you'll see some huge spiderwebs and spiders; certainly gets your hairs on end the first time you see them!Overall, the gardens are a great place to stroll, wind down a little and enjoy the often brilliant weather. Kids will love it too. You can use the gardens as a thoroughfare from Circular Quay to the domain and the Art Gallery of NSW (very good) or Woolloomooloo and the superb restaurants (for lunch or dinner) on Woolloomooloo wharf.Happy trails!

Great for Young and Old. Botanical gardens are beautiful. You can have a picnic, walk around and take in all the flora and views. Over the years I have had picnic , work functions attending weddings at the gardens. My daughter will be havin a wedding ceremony at the gardens it is such a stunning place and everyone locals and tourist should take the time to visit the Central Park of Sydney.

Spectacular harbour foreshore gardens. I have visited many Botanic Gardens around the world but I must say there is no garden that combines spectacular harbour views and gardens with established trees and flowers.
Tranquility on the water. Great place to chill and take in the atmosphere. Many tropical and sub tropical plants and trees to wander through at your leisure.

Absolutely gorgeous!. These gardens are a MUST view when in Sydney! The only things I am sad about is since our last visit they have removed the iconic bat colonies and the huge swarms of wild parrots and macaws are no longer there :( Otherwise it is still a beautiful and breathtaking place!
Lovely. Beautiful. We were there in May, so it was more fall/winter, but still lovely to look at and walk through.

Excellent gardens with enthusiastic and informative guides. I've been to a lot of botanic gardens in my time, from Kew in London to Kirstenbosch in South Africa and a lot in between. The Sydney version certainly lives up to it's reputation, but what really brought it alive was the volunteer guide who gave a lovely talk on some of the plants in the collection and a potted history of the area. These talks are run twice a day at 10.30am and 1pm and I can't recommend them highly enough.The rest of the garden is very relaxing with a lovely walk both to the opera house and Mrs Maquarie's chair - a seat carved into a rock at Mrs Macquarie's point. The views back to the opera house and the harbour bridge are well worth the walk.
Runner's Dream. My daughter and I ran this park one morning. Quiet pleasant as it goes around shoreline and around the park. A definite "do" to run if you're close by and probably a nice walk.

Beautiful place for a stroll or to relax!. Beautiful gardens in the city! Joggers, walkers, readers, relaxers will love this huge park. There are benches, pathways, great views of the harbor and it is adjacent to the opera house and the CBD.
Great place to be in Sydney.. No doubts. The Royal Botanic Garden is a great place to be in Sydney.The gardens are gorgeous and are perfectly placed next to the stunning harbour!

Large green space in the City. Having enjoyed beautiful botanic gardens in Adelaide and Melbourne, we had to rate this garden as just okay. The views from just above the Opera House give you a very different perspective of the bridge and Opera House, and we enjoyed seeing a noisy miner bird, and a walk through green space after being in the city.
Fantastic. Definitely worth a stroll around the gardens. Lady Macquarie's point is a fantastic spot to see the bridge and opera house together. Its perfect for sunset photos.
Gorgeous gardens. The gardens are splendid for strolling through and finding interesting areas.History to discover.A peaceful getaway in the heart of the city.
Beautiful!. Of course this is a very beautiful area of Sydney. While strolling through we were lucky enough to see Cockatoos flying around and take in the beauty of the royal rose garden.

Gorgeous!. This is a must on a trip to Sydney. The gardens are gorgeous and are perfectly placed next to the stunning harbour! A great place to have a picnic on a sunny day, which is absolutely free to do!

beautiful garden, beautiful view. It is probably one of the most special botanic garden that exist. Its plants are beautiful and interesting. And the view is exceptional with the Opera House, the Harbor Bridge, and the bay in front of the visitors eyes.

Beautiful Garden. Visit the Royal Botanic Gardens is a much do while in Sydney. The views from Macquarie's Point to the Harbour Bridge and Opera House are spectacular. The plants and flowers are well maintained and with plenty of sign post to various exits and facilities. Great café and friendly staffs.

Beauty of nature surrounded by the awesome Sydney Harbour. Nestled into the side of Sydney Harbour is the beautiful Botanical Gardens. Not only do they give peace and serenity as you wander around, but they provide a glimpse of the history of Sydney. When you imagine how it must have been back in the day when many of these trees, palms and plants were brought from various places of the world and planted you can close your eyes and be transported back in time.A worthwile place to stroll and enjoy the Harbour.

Lovely garden. It's a peaceful walk to avoid the noise from the city. Also a good start before visiting Sydney Opera House because the path from Royal Botanic Garden to the Opera House was so beautiful

Perfect to sit and enjoy in sun. This is a magical place, The gardens contain beautiful trees and flowers with lots of seats to enjoy the view. You can walk down to Harbour or lose yourself for hours in the park.

Relax in nature in the city. Where can you go in the heart of the city, next to one of the best harbours in the world, in front of the iconic Sydney Opera House and sit in a beautiful park and garden? The Royal Botanice Gardens covers all of this. Recently we spent a fun Mothers Day picnic lunch here with my adult children. Didn't stop us from playing like kids with a made up game of throw and catch the grape in a plastic cup. Much fun had by all in a relaxing and most beautiful setting.

Lovely Gardens. Sydney has several lovely parks. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a must when visiting. Very tranquil for gardens located in the heart of a big city with walkways leading to several major sites like the Sydney Opera House, Museum of Art and St. Mary's Cathedral. The plants and flowers are well marked and maintained.
Beautiful. Lovely to walk around or sit and people watch or have a picnic. Good views of Harbour bridge and opera house too.
Lovely protected area. Peninsula of sculpted gardens culminating in a gorgeous view of the opera house and harbour bridge. Definitely worth a visit, even just a morning run.

A relaxing walk . A beautiful oasis of green in the city. A leisurely walk around the gardens is tranquil and relaxing. The views from Macquarie's Point of the harbour, Bridge and Opera House are spectacular. The gardens are well maintained with plenty of toilet facilities and sign posts to the various exits.
Glorious gardens. These are fabulous gardens in the city with harbour and bridge views. Restful or a healthy walk. Great cafe. Good people watching. Drop in at the Art Gallery of NSW

Very nice. For a nice day, start with the 0900 Opera house tour and then walk the path to the Botanical Gardens. Check that out for a little bit and then head back to the harbor front path and go by Mrs. Macquaries Point on your way to the Art Gallery of NSW.Continue through The Domain past St. Mary's Cathedral to Hyde Park and end up at ANZAC Memorial.A wonderful walking day tour.

MUST SEE!. This is a must see spot for all things beautiful and botanical. If you are into a trip for the views this will definitely provide you with some AMAZING sites. Please be warned that sometimes bugs are at an all time high depending on the season and weather so dress accordingly!
Relaxing in the gardens. Most impressive and very enjoyable being able to wander and view the plants in such a lovely setting. Hard to believe that you are in the heart of a major city.
A place to relax in the city. The gardens are both spacious and well laid out. There is a wide variety of species for those interested and plenty of grass for those who want to relax or picnic

SYDNEY’S ROYAL BOTANIC GARDENS – THE EDEN OF THE CITY.. SYDNEY’S ROYAL BOTANIC GARDENS – THE EDEN OF THE CITY.Most cities across the world have their own botanical gardens showcasing a picturesque garden variety and lush lawns with an abundance of spots to stop and rest.However, none come close to Sydney’s Royal Botanic Gardens. Its watery boundary stretches from the brim of Circular Quay, following the harbour line right around past Andrew Boy Charlton pool and up to the Art Gallery of NSW and the Domain.Home to the Conservatory of Music, Government House, Herbarium Buildings and the famous landmark 'Mrs Macquarie’s Chair'. This historic sandstone chair was carved out of a rock ledge for Governor Macquarie's wife who loved to sit and admire the panoramic views of the harbour. Who can blame her? One lucky lady. During special events, the gardens come alive with people camping for days to secure their spot. Summer time offers movies under the stars, Wind in the Willows family production (at a fee), high tea at the café and a train which provides commentary of its flora and fauna within the gardens.Rose gardens and formal gardens are located at the top (up by Bridge Street and the Conservatory). With over 4000 trees in the Gardens, it provides plenty of shade to both the paths and steps down as you head to the foreshore enjoying the sea breeze and the views of the harbour around to Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. There is plenty of private nooks to picnic with your family and friends.It’s a great spot to people watch and have a bite to eat from the busy hustle and bustle of city life. It’s just another hot spot to add to your list of ‘free stuff’ to do with the family. Who said that everything costs money these days?
great gardens. The gardens are very beautiful and well kept , nice place for a quite afternoon stroll as it goes around the water front

A little bit of peace and beauty. Beautiful plants, well landscaped. A pleasure to walk through even if it was raining. Good to see people enjoying the hidden benches, small restaurant, or just strolling.
A beautiful walk and docent tour. Our docent also gave us a birding list which was very helpful. This was my favorite activity in Sydney!

A must do!!. This is an amazing place in the shadow of the opera house, magnificent!! It has lots of lovely plants and lots of green space and all free of charge. It is quite large so either allow enough time or plan a few visits. Open during the day but closes what looks like dusk which varies with the seasons so check if unsure. Cafe and toiler/gift shop also in the grounds.

One of the Few Free Things to Do in Sydney that is Worthwhile. I stumbled upon the botanic garden after getting lost walking in Sydney. It was a fortuitous mistake, since I enjoyed the peaceful walk in the garden, viewing interesting and exotic trees, ferns and other plants. But don't patronize the cafes or restaurants. They are overpriced and poor value for the money like most other restaurants in Australia.

green haven in busy city center. open, green, escape from the busy traffic. Great way to start exploration of the city. Many little roads but won't get lost. Was trying to get to north end to view Harbor bridge/opera house, but closed after dark and sidetracked by other points of interest. Not too sad. Like being sidetracked.

Beautiful Gardens and a Photographer's Dream. These beautifully designed gardens should definitely be on your list to visit. If you are a photographer then you will want to be sure to catch Mrs. Macquarie's point for breathtaking harbor views with the Opera House and Sydney Bridge. We didn't arrive until noon, and learned there was a free tour at 10 or 10:30 - check online for specific time. There is a cafe in the middle if you need refreshment, but I would not recommending having lunch there.

Free tour. We found out there was a free tour at 10.30 am so we joined. Caroline our guide was very informative and knew a lot about ferns. She showed us some of the highlights on our tour, trees, ferns, palms, flowers, also birds. She gave us a bit of history about the first European settlers and their struggles to grow food as the soil is so poor. She also engaged with the American children on the tour. We finished the 90 minute tour near Macquaries point and we then walked back along the harbour to Circular Quay - a good way to spend a morning in Sydney.

Roaming the Gardens. Never get tired of visitng the Botanic Gardens. Love to laze in the sun in spring and summer or walk for hours discovering new spots in the gardens during a cool winter day. Beautiful spot to sit down by the harbour. A must when visitng Sydney

Good walk even on a rainy day. Cafe in the centre of the gardens, but ibis birds are a bit of a nuisance! Not many seats though, for foot weary tourists.All the specimens are well marked.In May there was an exhibition of botanical art in the Friends House - very good.
OK.. Nothing more I can say apart from OK. Enjoyed it for what it is. Maybe another season when more colour is in bloom will be better.

A great place to walk away from the noise. Beautiful oasis in the heart of the city. Plenty of space for the kids to run around in all of the various sections of the gardens. Lots of seats to sit and observe life.

Lovely place to jog. There are plenty of paths to use to jog. Because its is located near the water the air seems to always be fresh, and therefore a good place to jog. Very expansive and well groomed gardens. You will enjoy it here.
Big walk. We did it completely and it wore us out , but we are 60 plus .Very nice place , beautiful vegetation for a North American to see .

Feast your senses!. It's a pleasure to just sit and watch the Cockatoos hop around, people training and exercising, the beautiful bay, trees and grass! Spent a lot of time just lying about on the grass and chilling! Good place to rest your achy feet after a long day of sight-seeing.

Beautiful Gardens on the Harbour. You are in the middle of the city but it feels like you are miles from nowhere. You can relax under a tree or in the sun. The gardens are spectacular as is the view. Take a picnic lunch and enjoy the day. Not many cities in the world where you can do this.

stunning beauty. my first time in Sydney, and I was impress for this beautiful tropical paradise. The gardens and areas of this very well kept place are beautiful. Other architectural gems plays together in order to create a very pleasant experience. The fountains, bridges, flowers and birds are also part of the perfect balance. THIS must be visited.

Best part about this place ? It's FREE. This is a beautiful Botanical Garden and it is completely free. It is right next to the Sydney Opera House. Don't miss it. There is a pond with ducks and a lovely walkway with beautiful plants and trees. It is very quiet and relaxing. It's nice and cool under the trees if you are tired and need to chill out for a bit. Loved it.

Great for a picnic . We had a great time at the royal botanic gardens we had a picnic where it was a great time to catch up we the family we haven't seen in while there's plenty to see I would say it's a must see

Peaceful place to take yor kids. Easy walking, plenty of space, a lot of native birds and animals to see. My kids loved the train ride, get off at the many stops and enjoy lunch just about anywhere. We took public transport from Manly and enjoyed the ferry trip across the harbour. The cost of the train is well worth it.
Beautiful Gardens. The Botanic Gardens are brilliant, always something new to discover. Well maintained and peaceful. Very nice Visitors Centre and coffee shop.

Watch out for the bats!. Breathtaking gardens, beautifully arranged with the bonus of harbour views. Just be aware this is where many of Sydney s bats sleep during the day! I found them fascinating. Have gone here many times.

Lovely stroll and tour. We took advantage of the free tours offered by volunteers. The tour enhanced our appreciation of this wonderful garden; highly recommend the free tour offered every day at 10:30 am.

A breath of freshair in the city. Lots of green, peaceful gardens and quiet moments under the trees. Oh!, and beautiful white parrots all over. Just a minute from the city, yet in another world!
The thematicgardens (such asthe rose garden) could be more impressive!

Gorgeous Grounds!. Absolutely stunning and well kept gardens.
Thousands of different species and animals.
The view of the bridge is an amazing photo opportunity too!

Beautiful Gardens and picturesque Views. Great at any time of the year, the gardens offer a place to stroll, picnic, fine dining, outdoor theatre, and so much more, while nestled amongst the Sydney landscape and right on the harbour of Sydney.

Great walking spot. Magic views of the harbour, very enjoyable & easy walking / running tracks, in a very relaxed setting. Definitely makes you want to get out of the hotel room & relax after flights.

free and serene. free and full of flowering plants and trees. nearby is darling harbour with beautiful night life and plenty of restuarants around though a bit expensive. also near to china town with great food all withing walking distance. should come and visit.

Magical place to be. Best place to relax and connect to those majestic trees....
Love this place and one of my favorite place on Earth :)

Must see and explore. Those gardens are containing an ancient trees and breathtaking sites and I recommend them to be explored. However due to the wide area of gardens you can use the small train which is operated on the weekends mostly from the entrance of gardens near Sydney Opera house to reach the rear of it, then take a walk through the lovely sites there, moreover if you want to eat in the gardens you have two options which are the fast food and a fancy restaurant in the heart of the gardens (book and reserve your place first because the places there are limited). If you like jogging, this is the perfect place especially along side the harbour.

Wonderful. Unlike other attractions like this you are actively encouraged to venture off the path and touch and smell the plants. Government house is also located in these grounds w high is an impressive sight
A real gem!. the great garden in a big city. every thing is perfect , clean and well mainteined. A paradise for sportsmen, the right place for jogging and relax.

Tranquility a few minutes from the City. Nice, peaceful, quiet, tranquil, green, cool and spectacular views of the city and the waterside. Just a minute away from the quayside, it is a great place to find some calm and space to yourself.

Great gardens. The gardens are wonderful to walk through with a great collection of plants, trees and flowers. It is so pretty being right on the harbour with sensational views and well worth a sit on one of the many benches or bring a rug and a picnic. Everything is well maintained and it is truly a joy to visit!
Beautiful and interesting. Stroll through the gardens from the opera house up to the art gallery. There is a good shop too. Very relaxed.

Smaller than you think. The gardens occupy a flat and relatively small area with good views to the North towards the Opera House.The Gardens are well-kept and contain a superb collection of palm (and many other) trees and provide a café and shop. There is a useful (and free) map available showing the main items (and trees) of interest (and giving interesting background), although it is not easy to work from the map to the reality on the ground - but this does not really matter. From the Gardens it is worth walking out to the Opera House and so onto the Circular Quays.

Must Do. A trip into Sydney was never complete without a stroll through the botanics. Ideal place to get great shots of the Opera house and harbour bridge, have a picnic in the shade during summer and check out the beautiful plants and birds. There is a lovely small gift shop too which sells great items for tourists and locals and a cafe.
Nice and relaxing. In a nice sunny day a place where you can have a walk while enjoying the harbour view and maybe a relaxing picnic on the grass.

A Must See in Sydney!. Being new to Sydney, I want to see everything the city has to offer and really experience the city's beauty. Many activities or experience in Sydney cost money, but the Botanic Gardens are one of the few free venues to visit. I was taken aback by the beauty of the gardens and the shear size of it. It is huge! I spent hours wandering around the beautiful grounds, exploring the different types of plants and scenery. The views are second to none. It is a perfect place to spend the day, perhaps for a picnic or just for some peace and quiet. A must see in Sydney!

Ideal location to spend a few hours. This is a great location to spend a few relaxing hours. Extensive walkways through mature gardens beautifully landscaped. An ideal place to get away from it all in a city centre. Walk through it and you are out in the harbour almost at the opera house. When I walked out of the gardens I experienced an opera, Aida, being performed on a stage set up on the waters edge in the open.

A real treat in the heart of the city!. Wonderful to be able to enjoy these lush verdant gardens in the heart of Sydney. Perfect place for jogging or a relaxing walk. I love the flora of Australia and these gardens have a great display of these.

Lovely place for a walk or take the scenic train.. We visited the Botanical Gardens, after visiting the Opera House. It is so close, you might as well visit while you are there. The gardens are lovely, and if you have tired and sore feet, you can take the scenic train, which has 4 stops, which you can hop on and off as you please.
An Oasis in the City. A great place to find some peace and quite from the city. Just to the east with wonderful views of the Harbour and some great examples of Sydney's native plants.

The flowers, the birds, the harbor, and more!. It is difficult to tell you what is the best part of these gardens since everything is so lovely. Pick a sunny day and spend a good part of the day wandering around this lovely park. Check out the gorgeous flowers, walk over to Mrs Macquarie's Chair for a great view of the Harbour Bridge and Opera House (awesome at sunset), stop in for lunch at the cafe, or picnic in any of the large grassy knolls.Take a beautiful walk from the Opera House to Mrs Macquarie's Chair (the end) for some splendid harbour views and great photo ops.

A great place to relax. this is a beautiful well maintained sanctuary. Take time to wander the gardens and visit the glasshouses and exhibitions. Book a visit to the governors house on the edge of the gardens. If you plan to visit the art gallery take the walk through the gardens rather than a bus or taxi.

Breathtaking. This is a wonderful spot to see the sights and take in beautiful trees, flowers, and rock formations. Go for a run, or a walk, the gardens offer the best view of the Sydney Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge in the same area.

Wrong time of year to visit. We arrived in Sydney in the Autumn during the worst rain period for 26 years, so perhaps this wasn't the best time to wander round the Gardens but we still enjoyed it. The highlight being an impromptu visit to the old Head Gardner's house (to get out of a downpour) where the Friends of the Botanic Gardens volunteers were holding a small art exhibition and selling teas, coffees and home-made cakes.They agreed that we were a few months too late to enjoy the Gardens at their best but it is no doubt a pleasant stroll at any time of year if the rain holds off.
Lovely walk on the City fringe. Nice walk through the Botanic Gardens which lead down to the Art Gallery, Hyde Park and then the Museum. Nice and close to the City.

Relaxed walk. I walk from the city center to St. Mary's church and then further to the Botanic Garden and then to the coast just by dawn. the whole trail is very quiet and relaxed.I can have a very good harbor view. enjoy the time and be healthy by doing more walk.

Beautiful place to stroll and view the harbor. You really must take the time to visit this place. The display of plants is amazing and we strolled for quite a while just enjoying the beautiful landscaping. We found a little cafe in the middle of the gardens surrounded by tall trees for some shade. Nice place to stop for a sip and enjoy the surroundings.

Beautiful gardens. Had a gentle stroll through the Botanical Gardens all the way down to Sydney Opera House and was very impressed. Well maintained with excellent views over Sydney. Would highly recommend.
A garden sanctuary. A wonderful haven (in a very vibrant, busy city) to wander around. Beautiful variety of trees and ferns and a lovely view from Mrs Macquarie's Chair. Well worth a visit.
Great place to relax and meditate!. This place is so nice! It feels like you are in another world but you are just outside the city! Come with a blanket and a picnic basket
A lovely walk. I always enjoy this walk and the spectacular views. You can also see some fun bird life. Very relaxing.

A walk in the best of parks. The botanical gardens is the green heart of the city. From which ever gate you choose to enter there is something different to admire. We visited at the beginning of the Australian Atumn but the flower colour was still spectacular. The restaurant served freshly cooked snacks, good coffee and great cakes and is situated beside a pond which attracts the colourful bird life. Ibis wander the gardens, the trees are full of the tropical colours of Rainbow lorrikeets. A vast range of Palm trees, Ferns and gum trees populate the estate. All this for free!!

Gorgeous. One of the most beautiful gardens I have ever seen. Beautifully maintained, not too big, full of information on plants and their habitat, it stretches from the city center towards the sea, the Sydney opera house, all around Farm Cove. It even features signs that encourage you to walk on the grass, breathe the fresh air and listen to the birds in the park. If you get to the far eastern end of the gardens, you can get to Mrs Macquarie ' chair, where you can enjoy a beautiful view of the bay with the Opera House and the Harbour bridge. Knowing the story of the chair is interesting, too.

Lovely... We were set to get to the historic Mrs Macquarie's chair and really wish we had more time to explore the gardens more fully. If you venture into the grounds of Government House, there are only two entry exit points as it's fenced all round, beware. Look out for surreal moments when the Opera House tops appear like mirages among the trees!

Tour of Botanic Gardens on the choo choo express. The Botanic Gardens overlooking the sea is a lovely place to meander...made even lovelier if u go aboard the choo choo express which is a 25 min ride with four stops, driven by the charming Anna. Even though the weather wasn't very good, she took us on a ride and pointed out all the peculiarities of the flora and fauna here...a lot of weddings are held here and we were fortunate to see one going on as we passed by. Totally worth the 10 bucks!
Worth a visit!. These gardens are so beautiful and serene. Plus you get to see the Opera House from another angle. Definitely worth a visit.

Train might be a good option, if you want to see the entire garden.. Easy to spend three to five hours. Garden establish in 1816 - 74 acres. Beautiful gardens but even better fanastic views of Sdyney, Harbour, Opera House & Bridge. Especially from Mrs. Macquaries point/Chair. Gardens are free.  The following information might help, if you want to cover all of the garden. We are active and healthy 68 year seniors who do a lot of walking. And the paved walkways are very nice. But a 74 acre Garden, with some inclines and some steps on a warm and hot day can be a little much. The Garden is divided into four parts, Lower Gardens, Middle Gardens, Palace Gardens and Bennelong precinct. And each of the gardens contains smaller individual gardens, rose, themed, etc. etc. with different features and large amounts of trees and lawn areas. Located in the middle of all the Gardens is Palm Grove Center which has a restaurant and a small cafe, garden shop, visitors center and restrooms. There are Free guided walks daily 10:30am starting from the Garden Shop and some other special interest tours as well. The cafe and restaurant at the Palm Grove Center Cafe serves sandwiches and the Restaurant serves more meals. TRAIN: - There is a small train “Choochoo\Express” runs 10:30 to 4:30, Which starts and finishes at Queen Elizabeth II Gate, which is close to the Opera house. Trains room every hour and half hour. If you just want to ride though the gardens, the complete circle tour takes about 30 minutes. And/or you can hop on and off if you have a train ticket and reboard as well at any of the following four stops. 1. Tropical centre/rose garden.2. The Woolloomoolo Gate/ Art Gallery.3. The restaurant Cafe/garden shop and information center.4. Mrs. Macquaries point/chair.  THE ONLY PLACE you can buy tickets for the train is at the QUEEN ELIZABETH II GATE, the entrance by the Opera House area. Tickets are not sold any other place in the park and you must have a ticket in hand. We entered the garden though the Art Gallery entrance. But If we had known about the train etc etc. We would have taken it. Not sure but think train ticket cost $10.00 per person.

Royal Botanic Gardens. It is a lovely walk around the Sydney Botanical Gardens on a nice day. I had a morning to fill before catching an afternoon plane.The rose gardens, oriental gardens and other gardens are very pleasing to the eye.The lakes and other water features are also very nice.Good view of Sydney harbour and Mrs Macquaries chair.Coffee shop had a good array of food and drink and was OK price wise.Don't sit outside and eat.The birds were very aggressive about stealing your food and very annoying.The ibises are nice to look at but not when they are on your table in your face.Sit in the cafe and just enjoy the view of the birds from inside.Apart from the dining "experience" this was a lovely walk and was very handy to where I was staying at the Medina Serviced Apartments just near Martin Place.
Pretty. Loved the gardens, fabulous birds and some of the trees are spectacular, only saw a part of it on this visit but still enjoyable
Peaceful and attractive. Walked through the gardens a number of times during our recent trip to Sydney. Very attractive and well worth a visit.

Loved it! . A fantastic botanic garden with so much to see and do. It is free entry which is an added bonus. It is a place that you keep coming back to and always have something new to see. I will definitely come back...again and again.

Great tour on the ( coho choo train ). On the day we visited it was over 30 degrees and it seemed sensible to tour the gardens on the train, at 10 dollars each it was money well spent. The driver guide gave an ex

The Gardens. Every time we visit the gardens we see something new. It is hard to believe that you are in the centre of a busy city. The Governor's house is alway s shut when we go, so next time we shall look up the opening hours so we can explore yet more of Sydney's history. This time we saw a huge banana spider...or so I was told.
smaller than I expected. I visited many botanic gardens in Australia and New Zealand, and this one was smaller than I expected. Still a pleasant way to spend time on a beautiful day
So well laid out and free. The Sydney botanical gardens are free to enter and have so much to see in the way of plant life as well as birds. Such a relaxing place.

Our visit to the Gardens. A visit to Sydney must include a visit to the gardens, a walk around sections of the harbour, see all the different plants and trees from all over the world. A must as well is a visit to Lady MacQuarie,s chair, which is located at a point onmthe harbour looking straight back at the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House, a graet place for photos.

A place you must visit. A lovely open space with interesting planting and a view of the sea.The hot houses were closed when we went which was a pity.Look out for the wild cockatoos,mynah birds and other indigenous Australian birds.

Inner city green space and our first farm. Originally called farm cove the royal botanic gardens can be accessed from the forecourt of the opera house or from an entry just off macquarie street not far from the state library. As Australia's first farm this is sn important historic site. But more importantly it is a sea of green tranquility right in the heart of Australia's largest city.Walk or cycle this is a place worth exploring.
Breathtaking & serene. Sydney has a lovely Botanical garden - great for sightseeing or a jog along the harbour or generally a good relaxing walk

Very peaceful. The locals obviously overlook this. We walked through the expansive area in the central city at 7.30 on a Sunday and hardly anyone was around only a few joggers. I was very surprised. The cafe does not open until 9 am very pretty and well maintained area

Great place to chill out and people watch. Long lazy summer days and what better way to spend than wandering aimlessly around the gardens.
