Unlike most places you go you are encouraged to "walk on the grass". You can watch the passing boats in the harbour or the array of bird life or my most interesting pastime - people watching. You can join the multitude of fitness nuts on their lunchtime jog or take a leisurely stroll. Of course in winter on a fine day, there's no better place to catch the sun. Enjoy!
Flower power. For people like us who like nature is a perfect place to see so different from our house plants instead . color and aroma is what most prevalent

Take A Break and Realx in the Middle of SYD. A short distance from the Opera House and Circular Quay this is a very relaxing environment with flower/plant displays and magnificent view of the harbour. You can bring your coffee and sandwich and take a break from the hustle and bustle of the CBD of Sydney. Do not rush but smell the roses-literally- at the rose garden and remember what a real rose should smell like. Definitely not like the ones at the flower shops!The only negative comment: There need to be more signs and the plan of the garden. One should be at the entrance close to the Opera House side as well.Highly Recommended. It was a nice break for us on this sunny noon hour (April 13, 2015) just before our Captain Cook Tea Cruise on the harbour. Expect to spend a leisurely one hour or even a little more.

The city all around - yet an oasis. Take a break from sightseeing and spend a few quiet moments here. I'm not a plant person, but some of these trees were curiosities. We had a nice tea at the tea house. Warmed us up. Nice respite.

Amazing bird life and plants. I have visited the Royal Botanic Gardens several times, and I just love walking around it and spotting the various flora and fauna. Bird watchers (or "twitchers" as the Aussies call it) will love the Sulpher Crested Cockatoos that squawk all day long from the big trees. A great free activity and way to spend your jet lagged day!

Calming and Relaxing. This was an easy walk through to Mrs MacQuaries Chair. With the water lapping at the wall to the harbour it made it very peaceful, with stunning views through the trees to the harbour, bridge, Opera House and city skyline.

Beautiful setting. Very pleasant gardens with spectacular setting. Not as complex and sophisticated as other botanic gardens (it is more like a park), but it is still great. Easy access from Circular Quay/Opera House area and also from Art Gallery NSW and Mrs Macquarie's Chair.

Oasis of Calm, and Tranquility. This is a really stunning Garden set right next to the Harbour and City Centre with an amazing display of flora and fauna. You can spend a few minutes relaxing here or spend half a day at least exploring all the paths and walkways. The views across the harbour are amazing especially looking towards the Opera House and Bridge. Take a picnic, sit on the grass and chill out !

Sample Sydney's outdoors at the Royal Botanic Gardens. I loved sampling Sydney's outdoors through walking through the Royal Botanic Gardens. With themed sections showcasing the diversity of the great Australian environment, the gardens are something everyone should put on their agenda. That the gardens are open plan with neat, easy to follow pathways also engendered a feeling of safety, peace and tranquility.
We loved it. Botanical gardens are well worth a visit, nice place to walk with places to sit and relax. Lots of unusual tree species and plants to see.
Beautiful with great views. Just simply beautiful with great views on the Sydney opera. Besides the great plants; you can also expect to see bats and cockatoos.
AMAZING SPOT. The green heart of the city, just next to Sydney harbour; perfect for a walk, pic-nic and amazing pictures!

Royal Botanic Gardens. A 4 out of 5 for Botanical Gardens, with beautiful trees, flowers and a really large hot house this is somewhere that all nature lovers should visit. There are many walks that take you in many different directions and much to choose from. Both indigenous and imported plants feature prominently and this makes for a great variety. A must to see. Combine with the NSW Art Gallery and Opera House as they are all within walking distance. A must do.

Sydney Botanic Gardens. Done this many times, any weather other than rain, take a camera for the many photo opportunities among flowers, statues and varying views. Take a picnic or snacks nearby at Circular Quay. The resident cafe is on par for city prices (pricey!)

Beautiful Gardens. Australia is expensive and the Royal Botanic Gardens is FREE, so we went. It is absolutely beautiful, you will see lots of cool birds (we saw a huge flock of cockatoos) and there is cool sights right next to it like Ms. Macquarie's Chair, Art Gallery of NSW, and the Government House. We spent hours there and took many photos of all the great views!

A much needed break from our city break!. Beautiful gardens - a wonderful change from the 'city break' race and crush of the other attractions. we went early, before they got busy (which meant we had the opera house steps to ourselves as well!). Shame the tropical house is being refurbished and is closed until to 2016, but loved the gardens and wish we had spent longer there - we rushed off to see other things having covered about half of them - in hindsight, we should have skipped the other things! Top few hours in Sydney. Got to tick off the opera house etc I know, but this was the most enjoyable bit for us!
Gardens by the sea. I liked a walk around from the Domain to the Opera House. I was impressed by the clean water of the Harbor and the beautiful flowers and trees in the surrounding area.

Beautiful gardens. For a free botanical gardens, this place was really impressive! The grounds are huge and very well maintained. We joined a free 10 a.m. tour, which I would strongly recommend. We had two tour guides, one of which was giving his first tour ever. They had tons of information, and were able to answer every question others on the tour answered, which was impressive. We spent about two hours in the gardens, but if you're a real plant lover you'll want more time.

A great place to stroll and stay awake after a long flight to Australia. We love this botanical garden. It is right next to the Intercontinental hotel where we stay, and it is surrounded by many attractions, most of which are free. You can spend a week in the area and see lots of wonderful things, from nature and wildlife to cultural exhibitions that focus on Aboriginal culture. The park has all sorts of vegetation, from rain forest walks to harbor view walks of the opera house and harbour bridge. It was the first place we went from our hotel after a long flight and arriving early in the morning. It helped keep us away, got some fresh air, and we were well on our way to dealing with our 14 hour time zone difference. Many of the local people enjoy the park, so it is a great place to immerse yourself in the local culture as well.

Picturesque Sydney. I loved the real beauty of the gardens, a wide arrangement of native plants and trees set in a calming environment next to the hustle and bustle of circular quay! A great spot to see the NYE fireworks.

Worth an hour of your trip. A vast and peaceful garden that stretches from the edge of the city to the water.
I was there today with my girlfriend for a walk and there are lots of nice spots to laze around. Lots of lovely little benches close to the greenhouses and restaurant too.

Pleasant gardens convenient to downtown. The Gardens are with a few hundred meters of the Opera House. It is pleasant to walk around the paths, look at the flora and watch a few birds seeking out food. The hustle and bustle of the city can be left behind.

A wonderful place to wander. Our hotel was right across from the Royal Botanic Gardens and we left it for our last day. It was blistering hot so we went out early and just wandered the paths, eventually getting down to the water, where we enjoyed the seawall path to the Opera House. Even on a hot day, there was lots of shade in the gardens, and there was good path signage and information about plants and history.We highly recommend doing this early in the day when you can enjoy the spaces without crowds.

So big it never felt crowded.. That part of the Royal Botanic Gardens (RBG) that we saw, were lovely. We took the Red Train ride (there is a fee for this) around and learned about the gardens and adjacent attractions. This took about 30 minutes. We then walked to those areas which were of greatest interest to us. The RBG is so large, one would have to spend the better part of a day to take it all in. There are great views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House from the RBG.

Very nice and relaxing park. So many cool plants and a lot of shade. We went in January and the trees were full of parrots. Some many good pictures and it was awesome to just sit under the tree and watch them.

Lovely Gardens. Walked through the gardens with my grandchildren, plenty of flowers and trees. Well laid out and informative. Nice to get away from the noise and hustle and bustle of the city. The whole family enjoyed their time in the gardens.

Peaceful break from the bustle of the City. A stroll through the Botanic gardens is a tonic after the bustle of the City. They cover a lot of ground and edge right onto the water, offering some great views. The gardens are well laid out and signposted with some fantastic specimen trees. Highly recommended, even if you just need some down time.

a Natural Oasis in the middle of the CBD. it is such a tranquil place to enjoy. You feel a million miles away for the City and the hustle and bustle of our busy lives. Wonderful to slow down and literally smell the roses and many other flowers, shrubs and herbs. Great to be able to then go into Government House and wonder around the gardens and take a tour (very responsible price) and or the Art Gallery of NSW. If you park in the Domain Car Park truly an easy hassle free day that is not expense.

Beautiful Garden ... Nice place for a quiet walk. It's a big park with lots of gardens, trees, birds, etc. The best part is the views of the harbour from the north end. It's a huge park and a great place to go for a quiet walk.

These gardens are just beautiful!. I usually include a trip to the gardens in virtually every town where I take a holiday. However this was the first time I had visited Sydney's gardens since I was a child. These gardens are so beautiful that I actually went twice in the week that we stayed in Sydney. I always find that there is a great sense of peace and tranquility in a garden and Sydney's is no exception. There is a path around the perimeter that leads to Mrs Macquarie's seat, where you can sit and have someone take the obligatory photograph! It's a lovely walk, and much more peaceful than the walk around Melbourne's gardens where you are likely to be mown down by joggers! There is a large variety of plants, many of which have information signs. There are statues here and there, Asian gardens in the middle: they are just gorgeous! There are lakes and ponds, places where you can get food and drinks (though we didn't). The rose garden is a particularly spectacular feature. There is a large gazebo set in the centre. It is surrounded by different beds of roses, all named. On one of our visits here, there was a wedding taking place. Truly a lovely setting for it, if you are that way inclined! I'd love to visit again in a different season to see the changes!

Tranquility amidst the hustle and bustle. One of the first places I and to when arriving in Australia and I loved it so much I returned many times. It's free to enter, has free tours of the gardens itself from behind the café, has a wide variety of animals and of awe-inspiring specimens of plants. A great place to sit down and relax or to cool down on a hot day.I will be returning every time I'm in Sydney as it is located in the CBD and a pleasant place to spend any amount of time.

Beautiful peaceful in the heart of a city. /what a fabulous place to go and sit with your own picnic, with a variety of lovely birds. There are great leaflets available at the information place, including one on birds of Sydney
A wonderful place. Perfect for a picknick or just a walk. Take enough time to see everything. Especially the huge old trees are amazing!
Lovely stroll through the park. The gardens are very tranquil and relaxing. Bring a rug and a picnic and snooze on the comfortable grass.
lush green sanctuary. These gardens are lovely - though popular, we don't feel crowded in here. They are well maintained and offer beautiful views. Such a contrast to the concrete of the city nearby.

What a nice garden. While visiting Australia for the first time, we decided to start our meeting with it by starting with botanical gardens as they are the places where first-timers (like us) can get to know better Australia's flora and some of the fauna (I mean, birds and etc.). The garden is fabulous, unfortunately we weren't able to spend as much time as we wanted here. So we saw just the small portion on the garden but it really impressed us. It's a great place for picnic, lunch or just meeting friends too, cause there are lots of grass areas where you can rest your foot and at the same time enjoy views to the water. All is totally free! We also walked to the Macquaeries chair and enjoyed views of the Opera and Harbour Bridge. Lots of people, but the place didn't feel owercrowded or to noisy. If you have more time, definitely pack your lunch bag and go here for a longer walk - so much to see!

Botanical bliss. Easily accessible beautifully created and maintained gardens in the centre of bustling sydney,a real escape in the centre of a busy city which always baffles me about Australia.i love that you can escape here for a few minutes or hours and then get back to life,tourism or all important shopping that sydney has to offer! All plants and shrubs are labelled and have very helpful useful information which keen gardeners would love,a great day!

Beautiful scenery. A great walk with the family and so beautiful. We packed a picnic lunch and it was good to sit and eat and then wander some more. A great way to burn energy in such a pretty setting.

A lovely walk. This is a must whilst in Sydney, and it's free! But you must start from the Wooloomooloo gates. We went via St Marys Cathederal. The walks are shaded and the planting is superb you walk past a cafe and ponds to views of Sydney harbour, do cross over to Mrs Macquaries point for stunning view across the harbour to the opera house and bridge. Then gentle walk around Farm Cove to the Opera House and the cafés.
Beautiful Gardens. Beautiful gardens which are perfect to get away from the hustle bustle of the city. A must see if staying in Sydney CBD.
Well worth a visit.. Beautifully maintained and a lovely palce to walk around. A small train if you cant do the walk takes you around to view the well manicured grounds.

Excellent!. The gardens were incredible. Completely worth a visit!Having spent over a month already in Australia it was lovely to see so much flourishing greenery. It's also quite unusual walking through such a lovely garden with the towering city of Sydney looming behind it all. The Royal Botanical Gardens are a wonderful break from the rat race of Sydney - you could easily lose a day there.

Peaceful and beautifully maintained. Had a great stroll through the gardens. The plant variety was good and all looked in mint condition. Came across a few workers who all gave a smile and a nice greeting. Location is brilliant and for a bush resident it was nice to swap the hussle and bussle for open air.
Nice but go when it's cool. Very nice gardens but if we weren't so hot we would have appreciated it a lot more. The cactus must love it.

Excellent Garden. Whether walking through as you make your way from Harbor to Museum or to spend more time, make sure to see the Gardens. It is rather extensive but is very well signed. Quite a few nice buildings with interesting architecture around the Gardens.
lots to see. lots to see in this huge royal botanic garden!relaxing evening to spend here and then walk to Hyde park as well which is pretty lovely as well!

Enjoy a Walk in the Park. There's nothing to dislike about the Botanic Gardens!! It's well laid out, has lots of walks, statutory and historic buildings galore. You'll also find historic points of interest, and a fabulous view across the harbour to the Opera House and Bridge.

Beautiful gardens in the summer city. A must see and an excellent way to spend an afternoon admiring the city from afar. A little slice of countryside in the middle of the city. Great views of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge!

Nice but I've seen nicer. I suspect April is not the best time to visit these gardens. The flowers are past and the vibrancy of the foliage is not at its peak. It's a lovely walk just the same, though.

Lovely park and views. We had a leisurely stroll around the park on the way for a swim (on the far side of the park - just out of it - go there, $6 per adult!).Some amazing trees (my faves were the ones with the roots growing on the top!) and just very relaxing. Great views of the city.Lots of city works on their lunch breaks running around.The cafe was quite pricey without much choice.

Great open space with variety of wildlife and plants. Were here for Opera House tour but arrived early to take advantage of the gardens. Walked out to the main pond during which we saw a variety of wildlife and a great many different trees and plants. Be careful as there seems to be a never ending supply of joggers

Always green. This Oasis on the CBD fringe is a must do when in Sydney. Always well kept with upgrades currently in progress. End of the Rose season but still a good display in April. An easy 5 minute walk from Circular Quay.

Green Haven. Amazing tall palms and trees, lovely clean place to relax, a variety of exotic birds, a pond where eels have made their home, lots of sitting areas on benches and also grass areas for relaxing.Close to the opera house and at least half a day required.

Good for a tranquil walk or rest. This is a really nice place to have a quiet stroll or some chill out time. It's one of those amazing park areas where the sounds of the city disappear as you enter it. Walking out to Mrs Macquaries chair makes for a good walk, either along the harbour side or through the park. And it does offer a nice new vantage of the opera house and bridge.

Breathtaking. Amazing gardens that are kept perfectly manicured and clean. There are many different sub-gardens within and much wildlife (birds, ducks, fresh-water eels in the pond, spiders). We spent two different days exploring this area and I still don't think that we saw it all!

An Oasis with a pungent kick... A very pleasant surpise to visit. It wasn't on my original list of things to do in Sydney but it is a very tranquil place to go. A large variety of plants and places to sit in peace. The Gardens lead to the harbour area with great views of the Opera House and Bridge. Warning, if using the Gents toilets take a deep breath before entering and hold for as long as possible..not pleasant at all.

An oasis in an already beautiful city. Sydney is a beautiful city as it is so there's hardly a need to get away from it all but if you do find the need, this place is your sanctuary. Visitor or local, the Royal Botanic Gardens are some of the best kept gardens that I've ever seen. The gardens have the city on one side and the harbor on the other. Get ready for amazing views and a sense of calm in your day. I'd start every morning here if I could. There is also a cafe in the center that looked nice but I did not visit.
Meandering. When I visit Sydney I love walking around the Royal Botanic Gardens and around to the Opera House, particularly first thing in the morning when the air is still and fresh.

Great place for strolling and escaping the crowds. The gardens are very large, beautiful, and varied. Their location ( right on the waterfront) makes getting there easy. From Circular Quay its walking distance. Lots of tour buses stop at the gardens as well including the hop on hop off bus. Plan for leisurely walking. There are stairs but wheelchairs are accommodated. If you are taking children be sure to plan for food and water. The restaurant and cafe are expensive.
beautiful walk. great escape from the busy tourist areas, plenty of shaded areas with benches. beautiful flowers and roses

Worth the walk!. As you walk around the harbor, keep walking until you reach these lovely gardens. The trees are spectacular, and it is a wonderful and quiet retreat from the hustle and bustle of the adjacent harbor. Grab your lunch and sit under one of these specatcular trees and contemplate how fortunate you are to be given the opportunity to experience such incredible surroundings.
Walk on the grass and smell the flowers. One of the nicest and accessible botanical gardens I have been to. Framed by beautiful Sydney harbor and the Opera House its a great place to visit.
Simply Beautiful!. When in Sydney do make sure you wander through these beautiful gardens & stop to smell the roses. This is a great place to just sit & watch the world go by
Not bad for kids. A forest infront of the sea with a view on the Opera House.A good variety of plants, beautiful fern.

Awesome Garden. After being on a plane for 15 hours, we spent most of our first day wondering through the many types of gardens they have, great views of the harbor, Opera House, Sydney Bridge, and the Sydney skyline.There are many different kinds of birds, and places to sit and enjoy the garden oasis in the city.
Wonderful walk.. Easy, non strenuous walk that is very accessible from downtown. Interesting to see the local flora and many local birds. Too bad the fruit bats are no longer there!

Relaxing, sports or walking. Great place to read a book, awesome flora and the animals, called flying foxes are a sight to see! must see in sydney! I used to live 5 min from the park and was a regular visitor, it is a mazing.

Excellent value for money!. The range of exotic trees and ferns was outstanding. The ibis and cockatoos that fly about freely are a joy.We were busy slapping on some sun lotion and a smart suited business man passed by and asked could he have some lotion for his bald head. If you don't ask, you don't get, we gave him the bottle and he helped himself. Apparently, it isn't unusual to get requests like that. There's no charge to get in and I enjoyed the view of the city from the park. You should go there!

Love it. I was pleasantly surprised to see these gardens. They provide you with information on all the differente species that are planted there. The spectacular manicured gardens are out of this world and just to be be there is wonderful. We did not want to leave and sat for a while on one of the many benches they have available and just enjoyed the wonderful weather and the faboulous views.

An oasis in the city. When the city bussle gets too much, come here and just chill out and wind down. It's easy to get lost, and you feel like alice in wonderland with all the different plants and signs pointing everywhere. There are apots with a 'fairy hunt', I believe there was a cafe, there was a bamboo garden which you can climb amongst. It's fun for the kids.Wilife is everywhere, on the grass and next to the water spots. Little dainty bridges and paths make it all very fun for kids. I would recommend taking a picnic and choosing a spot somewhere. There are hundreds of areas. Be sure to clean up after yourselves though because your litter would be noticed from a mile off, as the area is clearly maintained well.Just go and be at peace. Or enjoy the walk.

KEEP WALKING AND SEE LOTS OF THINGS!. The Royal Botanic Garden is the BEST GARDEN for me during my visit for 4 cities of Australia. It has lots of things to offer: beautiful and big flowering plants, trees and ferns; several entrances and accessibility, walking "connections" to the Rocks, Sydney Harbour and its attractions, and Opera House; lawns for picnics; benches to sit down to admire the views located inside and outside of the garden; fountains; statutes; rest rooms, etc. Best view ever - towards the end of my walk of the Garden, starting at the Mrs. McQuarie Street, I saw the best view ever - the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House. Excellent place for one's photo shoot!Tip: If you get tired walking, take the little train that goes around the Garden or just simply sit down at one of the benches.
Amazing trees. Would go back to spend more time here , exceptional display of trees and the birdlife was very attractive so clos to the City . Good cafe and other amenities

a wonderful garden for leisure time. It's peaceful and beautiful, a wonderful place foe leisure time. There is assorted plants in it, and the view to the bay is fabulous. Along the road to the Mrs. Macquarie's Point, you can enjoy the view of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. And the lookout in front of Mrs. Macquarie's Chair is doubtlessly the best spot to enjoy the fantastic sea view, including the

Tropical paradise in England. Oooh, I'll get blasted for that! But the gardens are a complete Must-see even for non gardeny types. Just a great place to walk and chill. And it's FREE!!!The whole area seems to retain that ex-colonial feel, help making Brits feel very at-home, very quickly.We took the train ride too from the Opera House end and benefitted from the guide's narrative. The oddest thing that struck me was the constantly changing fragrance on the air - it really was amazing!

Peaceful retreat in the city. Tranquil and beautiful. The palm trees were incredible. We live in Florida and I didn't expect to be amazed by Palm trees but the varieties were mind boggling. The trunks of the various trees were like works of art, so many intricate details in the trunks alone. I have never considered myself a tree lover but I may feel differently now,  We saw the most beautiful birds too. The lorikeets were among my favorites. We also spied some amazing spiders with enormous webs . Although we didn't ride the little red train that ran through the park, it did look like fun. The walk from the opera house through the botanical gardens was definitely worth doing and it's delightful to find something you enjoy so much that keeps you outdoors and is even free!

Beautiful. We loved walking through the Botanical Gardens. The gardens were gorgeous, the view of the coast was wonderful. It is so well maintained and the flower displays beautiful. It is a special place and a lovely way to spend a few hours.

Chill Out for a While,. The gardens are a very large park with interesting plants and trees.They're right by the water and Sydney Harbour.Agreat walk or take the hop on/off little train as it's on a hill.

A "Must Do" when visiting Sydney. This is an absolute memory of our visit to Sydney. Not only is it a wonderful place to relax in a busy city, but also has incredible views across the bay of the Opera Hous and the bridge.Great place to have lunch to in the cafe.

Worth a visit. Been there a few times, always maintained beautifully, and fantastic floral displays all year around. Older parts lovely too. Having visited Melb, Adelaide, Brissy and Sydney Gardens, I think Melb slightly has the edge, but Sydneys are superb too. Melb has a better lake area - Syd is small - more relies on the Harbour - which is fine too. Allow at least a couple of hours to enjoy them properly.

Wonderful day. The place is a really nice and large park for wandering. This park has beautiful gardens, walks, coastal views, historic sites. Everything you could want for a day off in the sun. See the opera house from the tip of the park.

Opera in the park. Went to the Opera Aida at Mrs Macquaries Chair
What a Great location to hold an outdoor concert
Great sets, costumes and atmosphere
Top Night

Excellent interesting gardens. One of the most unique gardens we have visited with heaps of different varieties of plants and trees.
Allow plenty of time and suggest packing a picnic lunch and really make a day of it.
Very well maintained and looked after.
Picnic. The space is unbelievable. Grab a picnic and a chilled bottle of SSB, a good book and a sun hat. A truly fabulous day.

Beautiful. We walked through here on several occasions whilst in sydney.
Beautiful gardens, beautiful scenery.
The cockatoo's are awfully noisy though :)
Relaxing, quiet place.. A great collection of superb old trees in the heart of a busy city. This is the place to go to walk barefoot on the lawns and admire the lovely view over Sydney harbour.

Stunning gardens with a million dollar view of the opera house and the bridge. On sunday I went to Hyde park and loved it but today the RBG kicked it up another notch , stunning gardens , crazy vibrant colours and at the far side next to the opera staging the perfect money shot .....opera house and bridge together .But the trees , plants & flowers are the stars of the park - well worth a visit when your in the city and it's free .......

Loved the gardens...not sure about the spiders!. The Sydney Botanic Gardens were a beautiful space for a long relaxing walk away from the hubbub of the city. Luscious green trees and grass, beautiful roses, but some intimidating looking spiders hanging between the bushes!

The Highlight of our Sydney Visit. The Royal Botanic Gardens were the highlight of our visit to Sydney. Compared to the Botanic Gardens in Dallas, these aren't to be missed and are free. The trees are fantastic and unlike those we have in the states. We were also visited by a myriad of curious birds, pookickers, I believe.

Beautiful city escape.... Get out of the hustle of metropolitan Sydney. I stumbled into the gardens accidentally after a visit to the Art Gallery of NSW. They're beautiful. Tranquil. Manicured to perfection. The only complaint I have is the spider webs everywhere LOL. There are beautiful birds to feed and a few eateries around the boarders of the gardens. Really nice find.
great gardens. lovely well maintained gardens great for a walk or jog and some fantastic photo opportunities overlooking the harbour bridge and opera house

Teresa. Wow, now this was well worth the walk. I was expecting flowers like the gardens in Canada. These were mostly trees, plants and wildlife. Not sure what it looks like at other times of the year. However it was gorgeous. Loved the different colors of green and so many different types too. Lovely, casual walk.

Delightful. Walked the Botanical Garden which has beautiful views of the harbor and opera house. Extremely relaxing....just sat under a tree for a while and enjoyed the sights which included sail boats and even some exotic birds. This would be an excellent place for a picnic on a lazy afternoon.
Beautiful Gardens. Liked everything. Great running space. Have lunch at the restaurant above the cafeteria. Very nice atmosphere overlooking the garden. Excellent food and service

A Wonderful walk and a surprise view.. We took the time on a recent city trip to walk around the garden and take in the peace and quiet. The flowers and garden are just wonderful as are the view of the harbour entrance as a back drop. As you walk ring the back you get a really picturesque view off the opera house with the bridge just behind it. This just brings the whole experience together. A wonderful walk in the afternoon, was had by both of us.

Great for a walk. The gardens are great if you like walking in a quiet place. There are signs everywhere, so you don’t really need a tourist guide to enjoy the gardens. There’s a nice area facing the water perfect for a picnic (you even see a lot of people sitting there eating a snack). I would recommend this attraction if the visitor wants to relax and get away from the city.

Stunning Views & Squawking Cockatoos . A gently stroll thorough the gardens will give you plenty of photo opportunities, though to me they can never replace Kew Botanical Gardens in London, there are some fascinating plants to behold along with eels in the ponds & Cockatoos squawking with the occasional dive bomb... The cafe makes an excellent Chai latte a first for me.

Take your camear or your running shoes. Either for a walk with your camera or your running shoes. There are many places in the park for good photo. Visit the government house in the morning. It is the best place to run around along the water. Also nice if you are just walking past sit on the grass during the warm seasons. This is a small park with many things, even better than Hyde Park in London! and I am from London.
Quick Trip. A quick trip though a part of this amazing park-like garden. Various entrances make for easy access. ENJOY.

Stunning!. I have been there during all seasons, and every time there is something to enjoy. A wonderful place for a peaceful walk after a busy day in the city. Although I have heard a lot about spiders I have never came across one, so laying on grass is safe. Great spot to bring kids to and let the climb some trees (with care of course). Little girls always get excited to see some wedding photo shoots happening there, it is a magic place indeed.

Beautiful and immaculate. Walked through it at dusk and last bit in the dark. The park. Guard closed the gate behind us. There were just a handful of people on the wide walkways. Signage was good. Huge trees, many beautiful ferns and flowers.

Royal Botanic Gardens. It's a nice way to spend an afternoon, have a picnic or get away from the crowds. I didn't see as many flowers as I would have liked to. However, there are a lot of beautiful trees and we saw some lovely birds in the trees. Also, it's a nice different view of the Opera House.

Purple palms, crazy cacti and tranquil fountains- and that's just outside the front gate!. I've been to many Botans, and I believe this is the best in the world. Subtropical splendor, rare Wollemi pines, and Moreton Bay figs apleny- not to mention insane birdlife and beautiful orb web spiders. Enjoy!!!
Wonderful. So peaceful to walk through these beautiful gardens. There is a magnificent selection of trees and plants, and a lot of written information. Don't miss this if you visit Sydney.

Tranquil and beautiful gardens close to city and on edge of Harbour and close to the Opera House. there could have been more flowers in bloom, but perhaps going in the Spring would have been more colourful.

Beautiful. A must if your visiting Sydney! Best on a nice sunny day.
Go to Mrs Macquaries chair for a great view of the bridge and opera house.

Perfectly positioned. Perfectly positioned gardens so close to the CBD and the Harbour. There is heaps to see in the gardens, or walk around thru the gardens or the esplanade following the harbour/gardens. Or find a nice spot and watch the world go by

Most beautiful garden. The gardens are just lovely, and the setting by the harbour perfect. So many varieties of trees and plants, wide stretches of well kept lawn where folk just sit in shade or sun, we ate in the restaurant which was cool and tasteful, in more ways than one. Choose a sunny day but wear comfy footwear, there are many paths to tread, but there is also a tram for the less able. Just another great Sydney attraction!

Must do if you love plants.. The Botanic gardens is an easy place to loose yourself in for hours. Something different around every corner. Take a picnic and make a day of it!! I wish I could see it through all the seasons.

Outstanding. Our son brought us here for a walk and a picnic with our 2 year old grandaughter.The layout of the gardens, the space, the flowers, trees and shrubs, not to mention the views of the water made this an outstanding trip. Thoroughly recommended.

Spectacular. The disappointment we had was our own bad planning. This was the first walk we took after arriving in Sydney. The gardens are spectacular but after traveling for 20+ hours, we couldn't throughly enjoy them as much as we wanted because we were so tired after about an hour! The pictures I have of what we saw are beautiful and would highly recommend spending at least a half a day there - it would be so worth it!

Quiet and Beautiful. A must visit if you go to Sydney. Gives you a different view of the opera house but also a beautiful walk. It allows you to forget that you are the biggest city in Australia. Try and find the area where the birds sit on your arms if you take some food!

Just love this place. I visit Sydney 4 times per year in business and would not miss out on a jog around the botanical gardens. Beautifully kept with views yo the harbour bridge and opera house. A nice cafe and shop are worth a visit.

What a great botanical garden!. Don't miss the garden of the indigenous people of Australia. Interesting history lesson. Also, incredible birds in the gardens. Walk along the water to xx chair. Great views!

Take your time to enjoy this wonderful part of the Sydney City and Harbour life. Start your trip by leaving the busy Macquarie Street traffic behind you, walk through the Sydney Hospital Grounds (a v quick walk through) and arrive on the other side at the beginning of the Botanical Gardens. What an enviable space these city and hospital workers have on their doorstep!! Walking through the initial open green space towards the NSW Art Gallery in the distance, you will see at the end of the path a signpost to the Botanical Gardens. Free entry. Take your time to walk through this lush and peaceful space. Wonderful for children to run ahead to see what delights await them. Awesome for all age groups to marvel at the history, planning and lay out of this incredible area. We locals are all too spoiled to have this heavenly plot of ground to enjoy at our leisure when we will. Every area is a delight, split according to plant species, one particular favourite of mine is the Cactus Garden, which I love taking my children to IN THE WINTER!! Something for everyone all year round. Suitable for Gardeners and non Gardeners. Just enjoy.

A great opportunity to see Austaralian and foreign plants. The gardens are large and lots to look at. A great selection of australian flora, foreign flora, plaques, sculptures, water plants, walks, buildings or just soak up the Sydney park life
Royal Botanic gardens. Pretty gardens with lovely places to see and explore. Very well kept and maintained with gardeners on site and happy to chat about their work

Really Diverse. So much to take in here. You could spend a day there is so much to do and look at. With the sun beating gently down we had a great few hours here looking at a huge diversity of flora and fauna, animals, birds, all sorts, well worth a visit. Great views to the Opera House and Harbour Bridge too.
Peaceful. Take a walk through the gardens and you will see people from all walks of life, chilling for a while in the peaceful surroundings

Amazing Gardens and views of the harbor!. I am not usually someone who visits gardens when on vacation. I am very happy we made the time for this one. It is located on the edge of Sydney harbor and has amazing views of the harbor, the opera house, and bridge.There are meandering trails that are easy to walk. The trees are everywhere. We cam across a lawn covered with a flock of wild cockatoos. They were not frightened by all the people stopping to photograph them. We spent about an hour in the park, but could have stayed for several hours!

Beautiful! . The gardens are a wonderful way to spend the afternoon. The venue is free and the paths are well marked so you don't get lost. The only thing that was a little disappointing was that there wasn't a lot of plants identified.

Large garden. This is right by the Sydney Opera House, so you can check 2 things off at once. This is a large botanical garden, so be prepared to do some walking. Both of these attractions are very close to bus stops and the train stop at the Circular Cay. We were there at the end of their summer, so flowers were not very showy. Nice way to get some exercise and pass a couple hours.

Beautiful and free!. Stunning gardens and dozens of new and interesting views of the opera house and harbour bridge. Open air cinema, Mrs McQuaries chair, tend these are all bonuses over and above the beautiful gardens.

Nice walk. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a must see. We came in through the Morshead Fountain gate and started our walk back towards the Opera house. We counted over 7 wedding going on while we were there and the roses were in bloom so we have lots of pictures. Very nice and huge park. You can either head towards the Opera or keep right and go to the Domain for more fun.
a great place in the city. Great to walk around and a real haven in the middle of Sydney and a nice cut through to Hyde Park. Very well laid out and beautifully presented

Neat plants, but bats aren't here!. Neat tours and information on lots of exotic plants, but the bats no longer live here. If you want to see the lovely fluffy fruit bats (flying foxes), go to Centennial Park and you'll find them roosting above Lachlan Swamp in the middle of the park. Go just before sunset to watch them fly out for the night! If you're heading to the Blue Mountains, go to Mount Tomah Botanic Gardens, it's gorgeous!

Lovely & peaceful. These gardens are a peaceful haven away from the hustle and bustle of the centre of Sydney. There is a nice coffee shop/restaurant where you can stop for refreshments and the views are excellent from most angles. There are some lovely plants and plenty of birds and wildlife all around. Take some time out and treat yourself to a gentle stroll through this oasis of calm.
Very Nice. Beautifull garden to discover behind the opera ! Nice place to have a break after lunch or at anytime during your working or bank day !

Great place to just take a break from the bustle. Great place to have a bit of peace & quiet - depending on how busy it is of course. I spent a very nice couple of hours here. You can take a stroll, sit down & rest a bit, find a bench to read a book or grab a bite to eat. A pity that there's construction on the way down to Macquarie Point as it really spoils everything down that side. The rest of the garden is really great through.
Pretty gardens in the CBD. Very nice place to relax and stroll around. Worth a visit (or two!). Especially like the bamboo areas and the different climate zones

My Favorite Part. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney are a MUST. If you are a walker, don't even think twice. It is so walkable and so beautiful…A large variety of trees, shrubs, flowers, birds, and breath taking views in every direction. Allow yourself at least a couple of hours to do this as it is HUGE!

Divine peace amidst the city. These extensive gardens offer a short break or a whole day adventure ... a few lovely little places to eat (or skip back into the city to do so) and so many different areas to explore.

Beautiful Garden. One of the interesting and beautiful places that are New South Wales, our family enjoyed it immensely and will return to this place for another year. The place is not far from the city, and tickets are not too expensive.

Stunning Gardens. Don't miss it - I've been to Sydney 9 times and this was the first time I made the time to actually spend a few hours in the Royal Botanic Gardens. Its well worth it, some lovely sculptures and very interesting trees. We sat on a bench under a hanging rock looking out towards the Sydney Opera House. Its tranquil and not that busy (even on a Sunday afternoon) - a lovely way to take in Sydney's most Iconic building.

Beautiful and calming. You couldn't find a place more serene in the middle of a big city. Both exotic plants and animals can be seen if you look hard enough. There are plenty of places to sit and relax, paint or have a picnic or alternatively there is a cafe and restaurant if you'd rather. With information everywhere, your visit can be as educational as you'd like it to be. One of the best afternoons I've had in Sydney so far! Beautiful.

Lovely spot close to the city. Starts at the Opera House and runs alongside a big chunk of the city centre, which makes it very accessible. Grab some food and a drink for an impromptu picnic under the shady trees. Big parkland spaces and more intimate areas with displays of native and foreign species. Good views of the Opera House and beyond to the Harbour Bridge.
a place to get away. this is always a great place to just forget the world, soak up the peacefulness, put down a blanket and read a book or have a picnic with friends.
Walk in the Park. Plant freaks or just sightseers love to walk jog or snooze here. Great views, birds and people watching. Quiet just 10 min. walk from Cir. Quay.

Beautiful walk in Sydney…worth the time! and it's Free!. We stayed in Hyde Park and the Royal Botanical Gardens are a pleasant walk away from our hotel. This is a fantastic place to walk, breathe in the scented air, observe beautiful and varied plants and all for free! What a deal. Truly, we could have spent all day here walking around and never repeated a single step. It rained while we were here so we had to cut short our visit. But then we got to see a rainbow that shined around Sydney, very cool!I really suggest this as a way to see the real Sydney, and you won't regret it!
Serentity in Sydney. A heavenly space to enjoy a sandwich while watching boats on Sydney harbour. Stroll towards Boy Charlton swimming pool, the Art Gallery or just enjoy the ambience of the park.

A calm and relaxing walk with so many things to see.. I visited the gardens on several occasions to explore different parts. Each time was different, and there is so much to see and take in. The variety of flowers and trees are breathe taking.

Garden of Delights. We wandered round for about 3 hours, including a bit of a respite snooze on the grass. It was so nice to see signs encouraging you to walk on the lawns and enjoy them, rather than the opposite as is the norm. There are fantastic photo opportunities, both within the gardens and of the harbour.Sadly we missed a cup of reviving tea in the cafe as it shut early for some reason, but another time a picnic would be a great idea. Around every corner was something interesting - a rain forest walk, a kookaburra, a rose arbour, a fern house, a cockatoo, a new view of the city. We managed the whole thing in an easy stroll without the need for the tourist train, but if you have trouble walking or get tired easily, that would be good too.Highly recommended.Take comfy shoes, refreshments and an empty memory card in your camera.

Don't miss it!. ok, so botanical gardens aren't necessarily my thing but this is stunning - acres of calm and tranquility, fantastic views out over the harbour, all manner of small wildlife... just an incredibly great place to spend a few hours wandering about.

Nice park. The park is well cared for. It would be a nice place to view the harbour and rest after touring around town. We saw a lot of nice trees and bushes. I think most of the flowers we last bloom.

Good stroll through some stunning scenery. Hadn't been to the gardens before, so we decided to go for a stroll through. It was a very warm day, do recommend taking water as I found out it was hot work walking around- not sure how the runners coped! Great views of the harbour.Lots of weddings happening, must be the place to be!

Just don't take the trackless train.... We've visited many botanical gardens in various countries...Greece, México, Australia and the U.S. These gardens in Sydney are among the best we've seen, with lots of plant variety and clear interpretation signs (some signs are badly weathered and should be replaced). Free admission is a very appealing enticement to visit these excellent grounds. Although not part of the floral displays, we found an amazing interpretive series there, dealing with the aboriginal people of the Sydney area. After taking a leisurely stroll through the different sections of the gardens for about 90 minutes, including a stop in the excellent gift shop, I decided to ride the $10 "Choo Choo Express" trackless train while my wife explored other sections. The loop trip lasted about 25 minutes. Despite the scripted live narration by a personable young driver, it was a complete waste of time and money. Hardly any interpretive information was given, and that was for just a few of the thousands of plant specimens in the expansive gardens.Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed our half-day visit to the Royal Botanical Gardens, and can recommend it as a good way to spend time away from the hustle and bustle of the city of Sydney. Just don't bother to ride the trackless train. You'll learn more by walking around and reading the interpretive signs.
Have a nice walk. In the center of Sydney you will find a very nice Botanical Garden. Nice walking. God info and signs.

Best Botanic Gardens Anywhere. OK we are botanic-garden-geeks, make a point to visit these everywhere we travel. The combination of magnificent gardens, incredible harbor views, and abundant actually-wild wildlife make this the best.
Beautiful Gardens to visit. Great place for a family day out, beautiful place for a wedding ceremony also. Check out the Herb garden Gazebo area .beautiful to hire.
relaxing. This is the perfect way to go towards the Opera building. It really gives you some time to relax from the buzz of Sydney City. Don't miss it.
Beautiful Greenery. I loved walking through the Botanical Gardens. It surprises me whenever there is so much greenery in the middle of the city.

The quiet Royal Botanic Gardens of downtown Sydney. If you want a break from the hustle and bustle of energetic Sydney, try the Royal Botanic Gardens in the center of town. Have your taxi drop you at the Art Gallery of New South Wales which is located right in the middle of the gardens. After dabbling in the Art Gallery for half an hour, stroll thru the gardens. It is a huge garden of 74 acres. There is a small lake in the middle of the garden and State Library of New South Wales is located in one corner of the garden. The Art Gallery and Botanic Garden were free of charge.
Just relax. The weather was absolutely beautiful, so we could have spent a whole day here. It is such a nice place to spend some time and relax.

Peaceful. The gardens are a beautiful oasis in the city. I had been told by many people how beautiful the gardens were but is not until you take a walk through that you realise what a hidden treasure these are. If you only have a short amount of time or an hour or two you will find there is something for everyone. Government House , with their beautiful gardens,sitting within the grounds is an added bonus

well kept gardens & great views. Definitely worth a leisurely walk around this area. There are plenty of seats on the way round for those less energetic! Very close to the Opera House so has a view of both the city behind and the harbour in front
So peaceful.. Sydney is all hustle and bustle, this is so quiet and serene and its virtually next door to the harbour
Down to earth. What's really great about this gorgeous garden is that it's very welcoming. Walk anywhere you want, smell anything, enjoy. Loved the lack of rules.

Not just plants. Lovely relaxing gardens for a walk or a seat, only minutes from the city centre. Plenty of birds to watch out for, especially around the lakes where little pied cormorants nest in the trees on the islands. Easily spotted are peewits, masked lapwings, currawongs, larger cormorants, and laughing kookaburras (they often sit on the signposts), as well as water fowl such as swamp hens. There's a spectacular bottle tree and a beautiful horse statue, and the grounds extend to Government House and along to Mrs. Macquarie's Chair, with wonderful views to the bridge.

Must see gardens. Beautiful gardens and great view of the water and bridge from some places. Best of all, it is free entrance! Completely recommend for a tranquil break from the busy pace of downtown Sydney.

Cool clam oasis in a busy city. Love the peace and quiet of the remote corners of the gardens but also the hussle and bussle of the busy parts with joggers, strollers, babies and tourists. Love the birds and wildlife and the lovely winding paths with new discoveries at every turn. Take your time and read about all the marvelous plants and animals.

Beautiful oasis on the edge of the city.... Escape into the gardens for a wander to see an infinite variety of plants from Australia and around the world. Just a few hundred metres in and you could be in another world. Beautifully maintained and sign-posted so you can easily find your way through the park or to a private picnic spot. Lots of quiet nooks to read a book or enjoy the ambiance.
Beautiful and interesting .. Beautiful gardens leading through from the Royal Opera House to Hyde Park . Several interesting and informative statues etc around as well .

Beautiful Park!. We decided to randomly walk through the park on our way to the city from the Harbor, and what a great decision it was! The gardens are absolutely beautiful and a great addition to an already beautiful city! The trees are unbelievable and you can really get some great pictures! If you are in Sydney and at the opera house, the gardens are right next door go take a look, you won't regret it!

Train tour round gardens very "dumbed-down". Having just done the tour at Melbourne's Botanic Gardens, I was keen for my husband to have a similar experience at the Sydney RBG and we were bitterly disappointed with the quality of the tour. The English girl doing the commentary was working from a script that didn't suggest any real knowledge of the trees. Indeed, after 5 minutes of hearing about buildings, my husband queried when we might hear anything about the gardens themselves! I know they have to appeal to a wide audience but a bit more content would have been good. The gardens themselves were nice but not as spectacular, in terms of wow-factor, as Melbourne.

Great free day out. The gardens, with more than a million specimens are just round the corner from The Opera House on the waters edge, giving stunning views. We only had limited time here so we took the train round, what great value, only 10 dollars, we sat back and listened to the driver pointing out all the different plants etc, he was so informative, it was a great way to learn about the gardens, plants etc. Anyone who has the time would be able to spend the day there and take advantage of the free guided walks. We got some stunning photos of the plants, opera house and harnour bridge.

Royal, serene walk. The thing that strikes you as you enter this garden, is the cleanliness. You can laze around in the greenery for hours and enjoy a relaxing day admist nature. Recommended for a visit when you visit the Opera house.
Free tour was amazing!. I was visiting Royal botanic gardens and I made a free your with Russell. It was really amazing and very interesting. Highly recommended!

dont miss goveners house. the governers house is a free tour and well worth the security check at the gate a small group shown round the ground floor of the state rooms with a guide who was very informative.
A real royal place. The botanic garden offers so many possibilities: a slow walk around, jogging, relaxing, sunbathing ... a place not to miss in Sydney.

Nice Walk in the Park. When you're at the Sydney Opera house and want to take a nice walk, just outside of it are gates to this garden. Not the best as botanical gardens go, but some spectacular views of the bay and surrounding areas. If you jog, this would be the place to test your skills with all the flat bellies that take off on their lunch breaks as the downtown area is only a few blocks away
soothing. the all green surrounding is so soothing that you can spend the whole afternoon - after the visit to the Opera House - snoozing with the cool breeze from the water front.
Birds. Plants were expected but not the ibis, lorakeets, cockatoos, and many other birds. It was a bit warm for us.
Always visit a city's botanics. Like any serious city Sydney has a cracking Botanical Gardens and well worth a visit and so perfectly sited.
Serene. Nice quiet walk with many trees and plants. Cockatoos noisy. Plenty of space and many entrances. Can be done in a half day, no entrance fee

Relaxing & beautiful views. Great views of the opera house and harbour bridge from Macquarie's point. Great for photos.
Lots of paths and places to sit and relax. Cafe good.

A Sanctuary in the middle of busy Sydney. Had a weekend in Sydney and just had enough of traffic and noise, the botanic gardens are the best antidote, green, quiet and peaceful with plenty of shade and views - stunning
Beautiful. So much to see, wonderful foliage and beautiful photo opportunities. Actually went back for a second visit. Very beautiful.

Peaceful Retreat. The Botanical Gardens are well worth a visit and only a short walk from the very bustling city. The trees therein are amazing and the Gardens are beautifully kept.there are good facilities too and entry is free,always a bonus! We had a nice lunch in the cafeteria on our first visit,but were disappointed on our second visit to arrive at the cafeteria gasping for a cup of tea at 3.50 pm only to find the place closes at 4pm. and we were unable to have even a glass of tap water!! It would be good I feel that the cafe should stay open until 5pm,and certainly during the long lovely summer days.
quiet spot in the choas. We spend a couple of hours wondering through the gardens, it was very relaxing and a nice detraction from the busyness of the city.

A delight in central Sydney. Our concierge recommended the Royal Botanic Gardens, and we wandered through them three times during our stay. There's a nice walk near Government House, and a number of walkways leading to various gates. A refuge near the bustling port. Tip: Go in the morning when the light is wonderful and it's less crowded.
Fantastic Gardens. It's a great botanical garden. But it is even better if you avail yourself of the FREE daily (10am) docent led guided tour. Don't miss it!

Clean well kept and interesting. We walked all the way around. Some of the more interesting enclosures were closed for refurbishment which was a real shame. There are a lot of toilets and eateries along the route. Watch out for the huge but harmless spiders above! The garden arrangements are pretty, there are a lovely selection of plants. W walked all the way to Lady Maquaries chair, fantastic views of the harbour from there without the hoards of tourists. I'd recommend a visit by all ages.

Wonderful Walk, Spectacular Views. The title says pretty much all there is to say. This is a beautiful garden located adjacent to the city park and with great views of the harbor. If the weather is good, this is a great place to be.

Sydney Royal Botanic Gardens. The Botanic Gardens are immense and well manicured. The flowers and trees are beautiful. There is no charge for visitors and one can easily spend several hours walking around.

A lovely place to unwind.. If you are in a hurry to see Sydney, I think you can give this place a skip. This park is best explored unhurried and with a tranquil mind. There are ample benches to sit and many points to drink water. The park is well marked with distances to various interesting points. If you love gardening, then this place can certainly pique your interest.

Great gardens, but the signage and maps are frustrating. We walked through the gardens several times in our six days in Sydney. The gardens, and the life within (birds especially), was wonderful. Lots of areas to explore and to experience. However, most frustrating is the signage used to provide direction. Many of the signs don't direct one to where they say one is going. As one of the gardeners said, most point as the crow flies, which isn't the direction taken by the paths. Anyway, the best thing to do is to wander through the garden and see where it takes you -- going with a plan is frustrating and disrupts the calm.

Worth the trip. The Gardens are a great place to have a picnic, walk the paths and enjoy the plants or find a cozy place and read. Take the trackless train to get an overview of the gardens without the walk.

Beatiful walk through well kept gardens. These gardens are located just next to the Sydney Opera House. You can go through them to the downtown area.The gardens are all well maintained and show off their plants well. Benches are strategically located, so you can see the garden and the bay, and the Opera House.
Nice Garden in Downtown. If you are looking for a superbly manicured formal garden in Sydney, this is it. You can take a peaceful walk along the lanes, and have wonderful views.

Wish this was on my doorstep. Very well maintained , true botanic garden with so many interesting species. You can spend a day exploring or just pop in or through it when you want, lots of seating and shade when required. Nothing to dislike except it had to close in the evening, just beautiful.
A nice walk.. We had a nice walk around the Royal botanical Gardens and stopped at their cafe for a drink and a bowl of fresh fruit.

Beautiful gardens to stroll and relax in. If you want to have a little break from the hustle and bustle of Sydney, just walk into the park and relax. Nice little coffee shop and restaurant, lots of places to sit or lay down. And breathtaking views of Sydney, the bridge and the Opera House.
Decent place to vist. Recommend checking it out if you have the time. Good place for a picnic. Just need to get a nice sunny day.

A beautiful place to go. A peaceful hideaway in the city. Well cared for, amazing views, wonderful plant life, and fantastic statues.
Highly Recommend

Stroll in the gardens. The gardens are great. So much room to roam, picnic, play, rest or just take in the sights.
There was so much going on out on the harbour it's easy to spend an afternoon there.

Beautiful. The botanic gardens are next to the opera house right on the harbour. It is huge and has a diverse range of plants and specialised areas. You can walk around but there are miniature trains that take you all around that you can hop on and off of.
So Beautiful. Spend a half day. Get a map. It's free and beautiful. Shady when hot and sunny. Governor's House is also free but book on arrival there and can be busy (tours every 30 mins)

Somewhere for peace and quiet. This is a large park on the edge of the harbour. Lovely to walk through with signposts giving walking times to various parts of the gardens. Well maintained and a lovely escape from the noise of the city.

Rose Garden Cocktail Party. I recently attended a cocktail party held in the Rose Garden at the Sydney Royal Botanic Gardens. Initially I thought it was a strange choice as a venue but it was. Great success, it was a lovely summers evening. The roses were at the best. It had an ambient is really conducive to getting to know the other guests

Spent some wonderful time in the gardens. The Royal Botanic Gardens are free - and if you love walking in beautiful and peaceful surroundings, this is a great place to spend some time. We especially enjoyed the begonia gardens, the lily pond, and the extensive collection of tropical palm trees. There are many birds in the gardens, including the Australian Ibis and some really large white Cockatoos (got dive bombed by one during our walk). The walk along the seawall between Mrs. Macquarie's Chair and the Opera House is very pleasant, with many joggers out at mid-day enjoying the sun. The grounds are very well maintained. We stopped in at the Café for a snack (they have sandwiches and drinks). All in all, a great place to spend time in downtown Sydney.

Outstanding. This is a must visit. Easy to get into from multiple directions and in a super location with views of the city, bay and suburbs.Very well maintained and with a superb selection of plants.Coffee shop and retail to keep you amused.Good land train for those that cannot walk too far.

An Oasis of Calm. Hard to believe that you are in the centre of one of the World's major cities - these gardens are wonderful. Beautiful walks, well laid out and sign posted and a magical variety of plants that bombard the senses. Add to this, no litter, vandalism, clean toilets, great shop and ever present friendly and well informed staff and you have, in my opinion, one of the finest urban parks to be found anywhere. A true asset to any City and a great way to get away from it all.

Good walk through the garden. If you like walking around greenery in serenity, this is a place for you. We walked through Hyde park and entered Botanic garden. Garden is well maintained and is a good picnic spot. It ends at Opera house near which you can find tonnes of restaurants.

Lovely Gardens. The gardens are free to enter. They are lovely to walk through and are really well kept. It is well signposted - telling you how far and how long in minutes to the Opera House. As we were walking I looked down and there were half a dozen little chicks underneath a tree. A lovely sight. We had a coffee and cake at the cafe which was really good value and an excellent moist Danish pastry.

Superb in every aspect. I'm not a particular lover of gardens but I had jogged through the gardens earlier in the day from our hotel, and went back with my wife for a walk later in the day.I was really impressed. The location is wonderful of course - by the Opera House, on the harbour, close to other nice areas that you'll be visiting in Sydney, and it is a model of how an attraction-for-all should be managed.I'll just mention a few positives:- great variety of spaces- beautifully maintained- the signage is absolutely excellent and links to the free map which itself is a real gem- the wholel place feels friendly and peaceful and indeed family friendly, and it also was not too crowded even on a lovely weekend day in summer ( admittedly late summer)Wonderful.
Plan on Spending Time. This is a very special place and one to spend at least a few hours. The plans, the birds and the people just hanging out make this a very special escape.
Breathtaking. Royal Botanic gardens are the best gift for the people of Sydney specially for those who are working in city. People working in city can go for jjag, walking,relaxation.

great walk about. a friend and i went here in November, early spring in Sydney.....an enjoyable break from the busy city....you can spend many hours here enjoying exotic flowers, amazing trees- at this time of year many in bloom- and glimpses of unique Australian birds etc. Anyone who enjoys gardening where ever their home may be, will enjoy these beautifully maintained gardens .....we wandered about for most of a day and still didn't cover every area on offer....and if you get tired many places to sit and relax and enjoy picture postcard views of the opera house and Sydney harbour bridge. Also enjoyed the coffee shop and gift shop as a diversion, and welcome chance to put up your feet for a while enjoy a coffee or buy a souvenir. Did I mention this is all free! We were impressed - would recommend this to anyone that wants to see some of the magnificence of Australian flora and fauna, and impressive views of Sydney and its gorgeous harbour setting.

Expansive gardens offering hours of entertainment. The enormity of the Royal Botanical Gardens in Sydney is nothing short of impressive. I found the property to be very well kept and the variety of both local and non-local flora was remarkable. The fact that the citizens of Sydney (and visitors) can enjoy this garden at no cost is notable and absolutely makes it worth a visit.
Gorgeous gardens. Absolutely beautiful . Views amazing and extremely well looked after gardens. Well worth visiting. Could spend ages just relaxing

Impressive but not a must-see. I am usually not a big fan of botanic gardens but this one was quite impressive. It is very well designed and matches the beautiful view. It's somehow more relaxed than botanic gardens elsewhere ("Please step on the grass!"). Definitively worth a visit.

Relaxing place to visit. The Gardens are spacious and relaxing and beautifully maintained. They are in a spectacular position, looking out on the Harbour but do not have a particularly good selection of plants. Go for the ambiance rather than to see plant specimens. It is a great place to be.
Gorgeous gardens. Well laid out with fantastic views of harbour.lovely and peaceful with stunning displays.we went twice as they are so relaxing.
Great place to walk on sunny day. Beautiful place. It makes you forget you are in a big city. All the gigantic trees, birds, flowers are all beautiful

A Sydney, Australia Crown Jewel. Whether you are a world class botanist or you flunked bonehead botany, this spacious, beautiful, relaxing park is one of the best on the planet. I love their signs, "Please Walk on the Grass" -there to twit their British brethren and to show the Aussie fry sense of humor.

Breathtakingly beautiful. Stop here at the cafe for breakfast to start the day. We saw more birds then anywhere else on our trip in Australia. The vistas are unendingly beautiful. Skip the guided tour unless you are really into horticulture and history. Just wander for an hour and see what turns up.
Beautiful public space. I rode a rented bicycle around the Opera House, through the Botanical Gardens. These are a must-see if you go to Sydney. Have a picnic there.

Nice garden. As far as I know, this garden provides free water for drink, so make sure you bring along your empty bottle and fill it up there. From I observed, this is a maintained garden, you can see "cho cho express car", they are good for kids and tourist who doesn't want to do a long walk, this also provides introduction service to the garden which is great for first visit. You may drop in the middle of garden and walk along the coast side, alternatively, you walk through the garden heading to NSW Art Gallery, they are all nearby, very handy.
Peace!. Beautiful, educational, relaxing, and a wonderful thing to do in Sydney. Also good for sitting on the grass and taking in the views or jogging!
Nice walk. Beautiful gardens. A really nice scenic walk. Great to walk through from the CBD on your way to Woolloomooloo.

Beautiful gardens with a incredible views. Botanic Gardens are the perfect place to walk, relax, enjoy and see incredible views of Sydney: the Opera, the city, the Harbour, the sea.Moreover, it is located near the sea. A excellent place to stop, when you have been visiting the city. You have to go, when you are in Sydney!But, I think that the less important thing is the Botanic Gardens!

Beautifully Exotic. With only 1 full day in Sydney I was so glad that we chose to walk all of the Botanical Gardens. This is an incredible place to see many types of exotic birds in their natural habitat and they are right there in the city. The Botanical Gardens are free and totally worth the visit. We walked the Harbour to the Opera House and at the bottom of the Opera house is the entrance to the Park. Also the Botanical Gardens Cafe at the park is excellent!

peacefull and beautiful gardens. lovey gardens lots of nice walks we went up to mrs marcquis chair which is nice to c the history and stunning views of the opera house and harbour bridge, port garrison and other bits of the city, nice cafe for a drink and food in the middle. lovely place to sit and chill and read a book/sunbathe for an hour. when we where there they where setting up an open air cinema looked amazing unfortunetly it was sold out so we couldnt go gutted

So close to city. Well worth a wander through, great views of bridge and opera house. Very tranquil as no bikes allowed but watch out for joggers. Staff brilliant . We left a bag there and they phoned last no. On mobile ( our nephew) and we were reunited with bag

Nice place for a picnic. Sydeny Botanic Gardens are great - plenty of green space and interesting plants. Take some food, a blanket and go for a nice picnic with a view of the harbour bridge and the opera house. Unfortunately I couldn't see the Government House because they closed it for the day - probably worth checking earlier.
Walk. Wonderful walk. Take a few dollars to enjoy a coffee along the way and take your time. To be in this location so close to the centre of a wonderful city is a blessing is discuise.

A Must!. You have to go for a walk in the Gardens when visiting Sydney. It is such a delight and is free! Pending on the time a vailable you can walk al the way back to the Rocks, past the opera house

So many varieties of plants. These gardens are amazing. Fantastic views of the harbor and Sydney Opera house. Governor's House open until 3pm with tours and 4pm to visit. Large grassy areas or benches to relax and soak up everything. Definitely one of the places you have to visit in Sydney. And they are free!

views walks art education this place has it all. gorgeous park with diverse plant life stretches down to the scenic harbour. Multiple paths and nooks and crannies to rest up in ones own peace & quiet or laze near the water and watch joggers go by. Don't miss the Indigenous garden v educational or the artistic succulent garden

What a way to spend a lunch break. We spent a couple of hours walking through here one lunch time, and the locals can't appreciate how fortunate they are to be able to spend their lunch break eating, reading or jogging in such beautiful surroundings. I know not every country in the world has the climate to accommodate this, but just wish we had somewhere like this at home to unwind at lunch time.

Exotic gardens with spectacular views. Always worth a visit, these botanical gardens are a fascinating glimpse into the flora of this part of the world. The Government House is also worth a look as is the nearby Art Gallery. But it is the views that make this simply a great place to get clicking
Quiet spot. The Botanic Gardens holds a variety of different ecosystems that are interesting to visit. We found Hyde Park to be more to our liking.

Beautiful gardens. This is a spectacular area in the harbor area, with beautiful views of the Opera House and Harbor Bridge. The walking paths take you to great views of harbor and artistic exhibits. There is a tram for those who would like to ride through the gardens,

Please walk on the grass. This is a garden with a good attitude - everything from BYO picnics, views, native and exotic plants (AND BATS in the Palm Grove), fantastic help at the Visitors' Booth, a very nice ($$ restaurant) - just a great place to be and its FREE. Access from Circular Quay, Macquarie Street and close to the Art Gallery of NSW. The herb and rose gardens are favorites and so are the Daily Guided Walks (google) and Aboriginal Culture Tours. This is the site of the one of the earliest gardens planted by European settlers, and an important site for the Aboriginal people of the SYD area. Don't miss out.
So tranquil and peaceful.... An oasis in the middle of the city. Take your time, take lunch - explore the foreshore and the Opera Hpuse. This will be an amazing outing - not to be missed.

Lovely Afternoon. Spent an afternoon wandering around the gardens. Visited Mrs Macquarie's Chair and admired the harbour view. Wandered across to the Art Gallery of NSW. Great way to spend an afternoon.

Make Time for This Attraction. This is an amazing botanical garden!! Sitting beside the Sydney Opera House, along the water, the gardens are park-like in feel and boast a beautiful array of flora and fauna.I went twice this week to be sure to capture all the photos I could. The gardens are full of Rainbow Lorikeets, cockatoos and a variety of water birds, ducks and even kookaburras. Multiple points of access allow you to visit and move to another part of the city easily for dining or shopping. And the gardens are free of charge, so there is no annoying long lines to wait in for ticket sales.
Very relaxing. The Royal Botanic Gardens are located next to the Sydney Opera House. It is a great way to escape the rat race of Sydney and relax.

IT'S NOT JUST BOTANICAL GARDENS!. Walking around from the Opera House continue up through the Botanical Gardens. There is always a board at each entrance of the Gardens telling what is on - exhibitions, Artisans in the Gardens in about August is especially good, The Palm House usually has some sort of art exhibition, etc. Continue up to the NSW Art Gallery if you are interested (free, except for special exhibitions). There is a bus from the Art Gallery to the Queen Victoria Building, central CBD, every 30 minutes. Taxis also available.

An incredible asset in the heart of Sydney. Spend half a day strolling from the Opera House to Lady Macquarie's Chair around the Harbour then head up hill past huge old trees, and areas decicated to particular types of plants, such as ferns or herbs. There is ample labelling and where work may be in progress and an area cordoned off, they tell you what they are doing. One of the great things about the gardens is that they are free, unlike Kew.

Early Settler Precinct. In the heart of a world class and size city, you can walk through botanic gardens, once the first farm site for early settlers, with the harbour , a clean, deep water, proximity , on one side and the gardens with many international botanic specimens , on the other. A good place to sit, sandwich, and watch the harbour, the passer by. And very close to the city centre.

Amazing, a place of peace and silence within Sydney!. If we should descripe Sydney in one word it will be "busy". All over it's just "business", "time is money", "lifestyle", "not enough place for so many people", "hectic", "fast" ....It's not really enjoyable if you are not the "city mainstream person" who loves metropolitan lifestyle! But, the Royal Botanic Gardens, is the heaven within the hell.With one step out of the city and one step in to the gardens you really feel the quietness and silence and the peaceful atmosphere. We didn't see that many different flowers and trees from all over the world at one place yet. You can come here to learn about the different species, you can come here to have a nice pic-nic, come here to do your yoga .. you can do everything in this wonderful area.All the detailed work by building the different areas like the roses, the orchid, the oriental area ...And everything without any entrance fee.If you reach the back of the gardens you can probably take the best photo of Sydney with Opera House and Harbour Bridge in one picture.

Beautiful Sydney. Got married here many moons ago, it was beautiful then and it is beautiful now.Public transport and walking would be my suggested mode of transport, parking is expensive.Peace in the heart of the city.

A Welcome Respite. A wonderful place to wander and take in the beautiful gardens, away from the city traffic and noise. Beautiful views of the harbour, and a swim in Boy Charlton Pool looking at a warship moored across the bay was surreal. The gardens are wonderful at any time of year, but autumn and winter are not as hot, and spring when so many plants are flowering is especially lovely.
Beautiful spo. Lovely place to take in Sydney. Peace and quiet, and great views of the harbour, plus nice shady spots to have a picnic.

Step out of the city bustle.. Recently had a big family gathering on a Sunday in the gardens. We spread picnic rugs & sheltered from the sun under a massive big tree near the duck ponds, with an magnificent view down to the harbour across a wide open lawn.
