The setting was just magic - so relaxing. We brought good food & drink, and leisurely picnicked until sunset. The wander through the gardens was more interesting than beautiful, & everyone you saw seemed to be very happy just enjoying the meander & time out. The gardens are a short walk to either the Art Gallery, or the Opera House - & if you keep going, to Circular Quay & the Rocks. The foreshore walk lets you take in the magnificent harbour views.
Nice. Very nice to just walk thru even sit for a while and just look at the harbour ,Gardens are Beautiful.

A visual and sensual delight. Living in Sydney my friends and I often go to the Botanic Gardens to enjoy the wonderful location, views, landscape and wonderful trees and plants. It is a haven in the middle of Sydney where one can relax and pretend to be many miles away from this busy metropolis. Access to the Opera House, foreshore and Circular Quay are all within walking distance and the day can be combined with a lunch in the Gardens restaurant or in one of the many eatieres surrounding the Quay. Don't miss it if you are visiting Sydney, it should be on the list for top 'must dos' whilst in Sydney.

Relaxing walk through Royal Botanic Gardens. Large span of Garden with a variety of flora, some ancient trees and overlooking the sea. A perfect mix for botanical gardens. A walk through the gardens is nice, refreshing and relaxing. A must for people who love nature.

A verdant lung in the city. A beautiful, well kept botanical garden with fantastic tree specimens, all laid out alongside Sydney Harbour and its hinterland. If you're fed up with trudging around the city, go here to be rejuvenated. Stay for an hour, longer or just walk through en route to somewhere else. Interesting and beautiful.

Nice break from busy Sydney. We walked through twice. Once when it was raining once in sunny weather. Both experiences were unique. Lovely gardens and all kinds of birds plus areas to sit and enjoy. Loved the architecture of the buildings on the grounds. Well worth a visit while you are in Sydney. You could spend hours here or just a short time while you are walking to somewhere else.

Gorgeous City Sanctuary . We completed a full circuit of the gardens including Lady Macquarie's Chair and the Andrew 'Boy' Charleton swimming pool. The gardens are extensive and filled with beautiful natives and European trees and shrubs. The views from every angle are exquisite. A welcome oasis from the excitement of this crazy city.

Beautiful Park. Very beautiful gardens with a backdrop of Sydney Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge.
What more can one say ?
Go and find out for oneself.
only negative is the cost of parking in Sydney if you go into the centre by car.
better to travel in by bus or to make the journey special use the ferry.

Lovely place for a walk but watch for the mad lunch time joggers. Go in the morning and it is peaceful walking about the lovely gardens but beware as lunch time approaches the fitness fanatics are out en masse so be careful you don't get mowed down.
Some lovely views of the opera house and bridge

Lawn with the view New Year's Eve Sydney. We spent Christmas 2014 with my daughter in Sydney. We wanted to find the ideal spot to watch the New Year's Eve fireworks and after lots of research we found just that!The Royal botanic Gardens have three areas to watch the fireworks from.Two are over 18 events and one,lawn with the view is a triangular area of grass on a slight hill.Tickets where £140 each (no consesions for children) and worth every penny. We registered our interest on the Botanical gardens web site in March last year and in doing so had access to tickets 2 days before they went on general sale. Thank goodness we did as it was an instant sell out. We qued for 40 mins at the enterance to the park before the gates opend and it was very orderly. You were provided with a hamper on entering the park which contained enough delicious food to feed two let alone one person and a bottle of water. You could pruchace alcohol from the tent inside.The views were amazing we overlooked the opera house and had a clear view of the bridge. It was so close you felt you could reach out and touch it. Because the area was sloped everybody stayed seated on their picnic blanket and everyone had an equally good view. As you can imagine the atmosphere was electric.Anybody that saw the 2015 fireworks on TV will know that they were spectacular. There was an added bonus that at 9 PM they have what they call the family fireworks which is another huge display lasting 20 minutes for people that do not want to stay until midnight.There were plenty of portaloos which were constantly cleaned and the stewards did a marvellous job of making sure everybody had a great time.After the event the way that the police and stewards guided the crowds to bus/trains etc was impressive. There was no charge on transport and as one bus was full another replaced it. By 1am you would never have guessed that there had been millions of people in the city.We all can't such a wonderful time. It was a night but none of us will ever forget

Awesome. The gardens were lovely and user friendly. I had brunch with an old friend in the restaurant in the middle of the gardens and then walked it off. It was a nice change from the gardens in Brisbane which, in comparison, seem lacklustre. I spent a lot of time there over my weekend away since it was within walking distance of my hotel.

Peace in the gardens. Don't miss out on the wonderful sanctuary of peace and tranquility that is the Botanical Gardens. Right next to the CBD, it has many different sections to explore and a great view of the harbour.

Nice place but to much like a park. This is a very pleasant place to have a quick wander. It is free so you can spend as little or much time as you like. There are masses of keep fit runners over the lunch period and finding a seat is not really possible. A couple of interesting areas like the Fernery for plant lovers but not much else

So Beautiful and Pleasant. We strolled through the garden on our way to the Art Museum. It was raining so everything seemed so green and beautiful. Fabulous twisted trees and open green lawns. Didn't spend much time but it was a very pleasant walk to get to our end point. I would like to spend more time there.

Historic Gardens. We spent our first day in Sydney exploring the Royal Botanic Gardens. The gardens are amazing. One discovers not only new flowering plants but also interesting birds. The cafe adjacent to the visitor center was delightful. There is history of early settlement of Sydney in the area. Two of the indoor display building were being renovated when we were there.

Fabulous Harbour Side Public Gardens.. The large open gardens right by Sydney Opera House have a blue ribbon spot right by Sydney Harbour. Vast lawns are interspersed with gigantic very old tree specimens, dedicated greenhouse displays, fliower and herb gardens, water features and statuary. Apart from the Opera House , excellent views of the Harbour Bridge, Fort Denison, Kirribilli House and Cockatoo Island are to be had.Extensive bitumen pathways took us past an oversized heart outlined on one lawn (it being Valentine's Day) with a raised platform at it's base for photographs. Ten Chinese brides were being married in a group ceremony. Runners were using the gorgeous old, wide sandstone steps to train. The Festival of Sydney had it's open air screen and seating all set for the evening's event. People were picnicking in the shade or lying in the sun. There was so much going on in the gardens, but it did not feel crowded at all. It was lovely to see this beautiful public space being enjoyed by so many, and treated with great respect by those making use of it. A National Treasure really.

Pleasant. My children and i spent the day here and had a very enjoyable time. We got the train here and if you are too then get off at Circular Quay. From there you can get a glass elevator up to the Gardens. I was honestly expecting a lot more flowers as other gardens i have been to were a lot more colorful. There was a delightful little herb garden and a spectacular cacti garden which was the highlight of the day for me. We also saw a butterly garden which was filled with white butterflies. I would appreciate more bathrooms as my son peed his pants due to the bathrooms being spread so far apart. There was a nice Japanese garden that the kids loved as they coukd rake in the zen garden. The walk took us right around to the Opera House. Finding the way we came in was hard so we couldn't go out the same way. We dropped in to Government House while we were there which was free. If you like gardens then this will be a lovely day out however there are nicer gardens elsewhere
worth a wander. A haven in Sydney (except for lunchtime when the joggers make the paths a contested space). Make sure you visit the palm house.

Such a delight!. Entering the gardens is such a delight as the amount of flora abounds. Definitely worth a stroll and then the view of the Opera house! Breathtaking! If one has time sit in the grass fields and just enjoy life's moments!

A beautiful setting for a wander through the gardens. For someone from Europe, the garden is full of fascinating tees and plants. We spent an afternoon wandering around in glorious sunny weather. The cafeteria in the middle of the gardens provided us with a nice refreshment break at a reasonable price and in total we spent about three hours enjoying a stroll.

Great run location. Beautiful place for a run--and it shows with all the others there. Great views of harbor, fun to see the night cinema crowd. Wish some of the paths opened a little earlier so I could have run through it all before work.

Relaxing getaway from the city. The botanic gardens are beautifully maintained and there are some really nice picnic spots that overlook the harbor and grassy spots for kids to run around. On the weekends if the weather is nice expect to see a wedding. A really good place to get away from all the traffic and take a breather.

Every city should have one.... A giant green space filled with eclectic gardens.Serenity and peace in Sydney. Quiet yet lots of people strolling around.Lots of folks interested and knowledgeable of botany but many people just reading, relaxing and hanging out in the sunshine.Nature is cool, take off the headphones, wander around, sit in the sun, sit in the shade, marvel at the plants, bushes and trees. Enjoy the RBG ( & check out the Chinese friendship garden too!)Every city should have one.

a must for everyone who loves flowers. If you love flowers and gardens this is a must when visiting Sydney. A wonderful range of flowers and plants and at its very best in January when I visited. Not to be missed, especially the agapanthus.

Get away from the bustle and smell the roses!. This is just a tremendous piece of property right in the heart of the city. Easily accessible and easy to walk around- no high hills or uneven paths. Suitable for strollers and wheelchairs. Tons of ducks for the little ones, sculptures to climb on, and fields to run around. Beautiful specimens for the nature lovers.

An oasis of green within downtown Sydney. Very relaxing well planned park that has something for everyone. The views are simply unbeatable, Opera House and Harbour Bridge form a great backdrop for joggers and everyone else.

Tranquility Now. A superb botanical garden. Well cared for, informative, and a tremendous walking with nature sanctuary within downtown Sydney. Plant signage abounds so that you will learn about the garden plants and flowers. Nice stopping point in the middle of the gardens of a small restaurant or self service drink place, restrooms. Plenty of benches around the gardens and some spactactular photo opportunities of one of the harbor bays or downtown buildings, and even a thru the trees shot of the Sydney Opera House. Free to all who wish to visit and tour.

Outstanding national treasure. The gardens are at the heart of Sydney and they are very large, beautifully maintained with some of the most unbelievable trees I have ever seen. Lake, rose gardens, good cafe. If you like gardens this is an absolute must. Simon Tarascon

Beautiful. This place is beautiful and relaxing, we had a lovely few hours walking around and seeing all the plants and wildlife. There are lots of signposts which made it very easy to navigate and find areas of interest.

Unusual & unknown plants. The fascinating thing and one of the enjoyments when you visit a botanical grden in a foreign land is the variety, of the unusual and unknown exhibits. You are often amazed at the size and colouring of the *tiny potted indoor plants' we have in our homes. In their natural habitat and with a kind climate, they never cease to surprise us and give enjoyment with their natural beauty.
Good for the soul. Beautiful gardens and a great range of plants to enjoy. Relax with a rug and a picnic on the lovely lawn. Great location so close to the Opera House.

Lovely peaceful place. This is a quiet haven in the city. Plenty of labelled plants & trees for those who are interested & lots of picnicking & playing spaces for families. Lovely place for nice strolls.PS The fruit bats have now been banished to Centennial Park

Lots of birds. This is a wonderful place to walk, sit or picnic. There are many species of birds and around the ponds they are nesting which is great to see. The gardens are well signed, have lots of different areas of interest and there is a train that takes you around if you don't want to walk the whole thing. There is a small areas selling drinks and ice creams too which was a welcome break. If you walk it at dusk you will see large fruit bats in the air which was amazing, loved this day and this garden.

Great picnic spot.... Pick up a picnic before you enter, a wonderful, free, half day out. We coupled it with a visit to the Opera House....perfect. Beautiful laid out grounds with many surprises...fabulous views of the Opera House and Bridge when you get to the headland. Look out for the open air cinema!

Spectacular for NYE. Our view point for NYE was here and wow what a view. The gardens we didn't really see as it was getting dark but looked very well maintained and well worth a visit. Would definitely recommend NYE tickets for here
the Gardens. Lovely walk around the Botanical Gardens, the rose gardens are beautiful & the smell & colour of all the roses are amazing

Nice gardens with epic views.. So nice to have a big sets of gardens in the centre of the city. This is where you go for new years eve,. This is where you go for lots of flowers. This is where you go to relax.
Great open space. Only a few minutes from the city, and close to the harbour and Opera House, Always enjoy a walk here when in Sydney.

Beautiful gardens. Lovely peaceful gardens in the midst of such a vibrant city. Spent a few hours wondering around the gardens and photographing all the beautiful exotic flowers. There is a lovely cafe and shop and the views across the harbour are stunning.

Go see Shakespere in the park at the gardens. Go to the gardens and see a production of Shakespere in the park. We loved the production of As you like it. Great evening fun. Pack a picnic and drinks and you can rent chairs as well.
Lovely. We really enjoyed our walk through the botanical gardens. We didn't see every part of it but the areas we went to visit offered great plant life and also great views of Sydney.

The quietest place 5 mins away from everything. What can I say I have been there almost everyday in my two week stay in Sydney. You can find plants and trees from various part of the world and the overall quietness is amazing considering yuo are just 5 mins away from busy CBD. Great, great place

Third Visit, it is so lovely. Absolutely stunning garden, with view of the Opera House and a little tram to take you about if the walking gets wearisome. It is our third time there and this time we missed the bats hanging from the tree (or maybe they were out terrorizing someone!) in one part of a deeply wooded area. Even grass is interesting at this place. Lovely shop and nice restaurant rounds out a wonderful stroll on a beautiful day.
Beautiful and peaceful walk.. These gardens are lovely, and varied. Learned quite a big about Australian horticulture, while enjoying the trails. The huge trees fascinated us.

Beautiful Spot In The City. Sydney is so lucky to have such a beautiful place right in the core of the city. Very peaceful and with lots of interesting plants and birds. We entered after visiting the opera house and were able to walk through to our hotel.
Impressive large Botanical Garden. Very big and impressive Botanical Garden close to Sydney City - Be sure also to visit the Mount Tomah part in Blue Mountain
Varied. Great for a stroll through , as the name suggests trees and plants from all over the world . Immaculately kept, also wildlife friendly especially the Ibis birds.
Wonderful gardens -best city park we have ever visited.. These gardens were massive, very well laid out and you are encouraged to sit on the grass! Good garden shop, cafe and harbour views.

What an amazing place!. The Royal Botanic Garden is a special place which is home to various and unique plants and flowers. It is set up in a nice and organized way. It's a big place - be ready to walk - but easy to navigate and explore. The views are incredible and it's a great place to wander, learn, and even rest for a few. The bats are cool to see and the rose garden is incredible! Definitely something fun and free (!) to do in the city- I would highly recommend it to anyone visiting!

Stroll the gardens in the midst of the city. We loved seeing the gardens, statues, fountains, etc. in the Royal Gardens. There were crazy birds trying to steal food as people picnicked, there's a cafe where we stopped for a snack, etc. The gardens are located right next to the opera house so you can easily go from one to the other. I absolutely loved some of the wild trees growing in the area. Take it slow and enjoy the area before heading back into the busy city.
Beautiful surrounding in the busy city. A beautiful green oasis in the concrete city . Nice for a walk or a picnic. To run or to relax. I found it very pleasant to be here during my visit.

Beautiful Gardens. Up the street from the Opera House the gardens are covered with easily accessible walking paths and beautiful flower garden areas. A walk across the gardens takes you to Mrs MacCrearys Chair where the view of the Opera House and Bridge are one of the best places for night photos of these two iconic places.

Ah the serenity!. Sydney is all so hustle and bustle! I just love coming to the botanic gardens for a chill out, to picnic with friends or to go for a run in it! It's right next to the harbour so the view is spectacular and the scenery is just divine to explore!

An Oasis in the city !. During a recent trip to Melbourne we spent several hours wandering through the Royal Botanic Gardens. Very beautiful and peaceful surroundings in the heart of Melbourne. We highly recommend a visit.

Spacious green corner. Spacious green with varieties of trees. The Botanic Garden also presents garden with special themes (Japanese garden, cactus, etc). Enjoyable place for a walk, roll around in the grass, or to read a book under a tree :)

A lovely afternoon. Exhausted from a 24h flight, I spent most of my first afternoon in Sydney here and I really enjoyed it: a beautiful garden in the heart of the city with ever-changing views to the CBD high-rises, the Westfield tower, the river, the Opera House, the bridge and most importantly the exotic trees and flowers.At the Mrs Macquaires chair, I saw two warships docked on the other side of the river. There are lots of yachts and boats, helicopters and old planes everywhere at this point, so if you enjoy watching other people enjoy, try this place. It also provides a number of great photo opportunities with the city and the Opera House.One thing that seems missing is introducing the flora and fauna to the visitors. Either no information is presented or it's not quite visible.

Visit the Botanical Gardens. Sydney is a fabulous city full of hustle and bustle and excitement. But if you need a break from all of that walk yourself over to the Botanic Gardens and enjoy the peace and quiet it has to offer. Stroll alone or with another. You will see couples,people young and old, people sitting on benches, bikers, joggers, babies in strollers. Everyone enjoys this beautiful place and once you visit you will know why. There is a lot to see and you can easily visit many times and not see the same thing twice! Bring your lunch, bring a book, bring a friend. It is an oasis so close to Circular Quay and yet miles away.(There may be a fee to go in some of the buildings - check the website given below).

Views to love. These gardens a worth a walk round. If for nothing else the amazing views over Sydney Harbour. The colors of the trees/flowers a wonderful.Note....take your own food and drinks as a very pricey if want to sit and gaze at the views.
A place to remember. With paths easily marked, the walked about the gardens was very calming and tranquil. We were able to photograph the Opera House and Bridge from the site near the water's edge.
Best Botanics gardens in the world. The location makes this unbeatable - the gardens are beautiful. Buy a picnic lunch and enjoy this great attraction for free.
Good Gardens. There are many flowers and trees that are from different countries in the world. It is a good way to tell visiters what they see using a note-pad.

One of the best chill out places!. The botanic gardens in Sydney is a unique mix of features. Lots of plants if that's your thing, and to be fair, it is a botanic gardens.Lots of interesting birds.Ponds full of fish and giant eels (1.5m).Nice restaurants.A shop.A cinema in summer.A great place to hang out.A nice walk.And much more...
Beautiful walk around here. This is a beautiful place to go visit and see for your own eyes. The Maintenance of the gardens are superb and well worth a visit. Colours are just wonderful !
Such a beautiful stroll. My husband and I spent hours here, walking throughout the gardens, then down to the harbor area. My only regret is that I didn't bring my running shoes.
Nice way to spend an hour or so. We had a couple of walks here when in Sydney. The gardens are very pleasant and are easy to walk to from the Circular Quay area.

RELAX AND APPRECIATE. Recently went there with my wife and we were pleasantly surprised at just how attractive the gardens were and the many varieties of plants on show. It was so nice to walk around relax, sit down and appreciate the beautiful setting and the amazing amount of colour. I am not a "green thumb" but I was in awe of the appeal and presentation of the gardens and the easy way we could get around. Certainly something that Sydney can be so proud of and the setting is so absolutely amazing and so beautiful. I had not been there since I was a child and it was so much better than I ever remembered. My advice, go and walk around, appreciate, relax and I am certain you will be mesmerised by the simple beauty of the gardens and the setting. It is a jewel in Sydney's crown.

Wonderful Greenspace By the Harbour. This verdant landscape is criss-crossed by many paths to a myriad of interesting spots for intimate quiet moments or open air adventure. It offers a great place to relax or to be as active as you like. All this set on the harbours edge in virtually the centre of the city. Oh ... by the way: it has a multitude of various landscape and garden environments with some interesting specimen plants.

Beautiful gardens. We had an hour to kill so went for a walk through the Gardens and around the Government House, which if you want to get into remember to have a photo ID on you. However, the grounds were immaculate with wonderful views of the harbor. We did not see a lot in bloom however what was in bloom was amazing. Definitely worth the trip.
very relaxed place. we spent one afternoo n to visit this garden,all people said me it is very great.this is true!!was very relaxed to walk around ,green and peaceful.

An oasis of calm and green. Surrounded by huge skyscrapers the gardens are beautifully kept and even better free to enter! The greenhouses are currently closed but it was great to just wander around and view the opera house and bridge from such a fantastic setting.

Great place, enjoyable day. What a treasure in downtown Sydney.We enjoyed several hours walking around these gardens which are only about 3 minute walk from the Opera House. Depending on your location you can enter via several routes. Our route was entering at first chance on Macquaries Road (entrance most away from Opera House), walking the gardens, ending at Mrs. Macquaries 'chair' and the 'outdoor theatre (in the water)' and then walking the waterfront back to the Opera House area and then Circle Quay. And it is free on top of that. Enjoy..............
Amazing. Very peaceful and serene, a good place to unwind after a crazy day in the city. Well worth your time
Beautiful and Peaceful. Peaceful area of tranquility amidst the hustle and bustle. There are lots of wide walking paths with excellent views of both the harbour and the city skyline.

In the garden in a CBD. There is no charge for this park. It has expansive lawns, and they encourage you to walk on the grass! Good for a get away from the city bussle, whether just to absorb nature or sit on this grass to eat a take away. Free walks are offerred at 10h30 and lunch times in summer. Imaccul;ately kept, supporting lots of bird life. If you ahve an hour or two to spare, a good venue to see the local plants.

Beautiful setting. The gardens are a special place and a different environment to the many great parks in Sydney. It's a visual paradise for sure. What I like most is the air, it's incredibly fresh and invigorating. Great cafe as well near a pleasant lake, and they serve cold beverages including beer and wine

my kinda sanctuary. if you love gardens, please please please visit The Botanical Garden!!!It is so beautiful with all the different species of plants, trees and flowers. I actually drooled at all the Hydrangeas!! ahhhhhh I love it so much!! I can imagine myself spending my day reading a book surrounding by its calming and beautiful surrounds. to breathe the scent of nature... ahhhhh i love it!!

Oasis. The Royal Botanical Gardens of Sydney offer an oasis in the middle of tourists (like ourselves, lol). We were there in late June and nearly had the entire place to ourselves. There are tours held daily and the history of the garden is easily researched online or at the garden with a guide. There are fantastic vistas of the harbor, nooks and crannies in which you can escape, and all sorts of bird life, in addition to the myriad of plant life. It is a wonderful place for lunch or just a quiet rest. It is free and is a great way to spend an afternoon.

Great place for a walk. Huge and vast, really a nice place to walk, jog, or even to sit down and relax. If you have more time you could just have a picnic there and read a book. Direct view to the harbor and opera house, you will never grow tired of this place.

This is huge.. The entire gardens are huge and cover two coves between Garden Island and the Opera House. There is lots to see plus very good views of the harbour. Is is not a crowded as the CBD, which makes for a nice change. Very well laid out.

Favourite place for a picnic!. The Sydney Botanic Gardens is awesome. Take a picnic and a rug, and take your mates. It's an awesome place to sit under a tree, and just enjoy Sydney and the harbour. I personally find the place inspiring. A good place to read a book too.

Very nice garden. A vey nice garden with a nice view on opera house and sydney ' bay. On other side you will see part of military harbour. Croos the garden and you will see so many birds and tall trees and well maintained as the park.

Excellent walk, Well labled. This was an easy walk from our hotel, the Marriott. We found plenty of shade, benches to rest and everything was labeled so one could tell what it was. Not very crowded and, it is free.We kept following the signs to the herb gardens and never did find them. We did exit for a bit and walked over the the Cathedral. We then walked back through the gardens to the opera house... we recommend this route, good photo ops.

Lovely escape from the hustle and bustle. Despite being in the middle of a big city, you feel like you can "get away from it all" at the gardens. We visited on a weekday, and it was relatively quiet. Had a lovely walk around, enjoying the trees, the themed gardens (especially the history of the site and original plantings) and the views.

Beautiful Respite in the Heart of the City. The Botanic Gardens are beautiful, right beside the Sydney Opera House, they offer great views of the harbour and are a lovely way to walk into the commerical and shopping heart of Sydney. I especially loved the tropical section. Don't miss them if you are in Sydney.

Beautiful Walks. So many walk ways to explore with brilliant views of the Harbour and the city a camera is a must. Lots of people and activities seem to be happening all the time while we were there. Disappointed that Parliament House was closed for a function at the time we arrived to do a tour.....walked down to find a closed sigh at the entry which could have been placed at the top of the drive and saved us time and effort but overall a lovely place to spend time.
An oasis in the heat of the city. Lovely areas to sit and for children to run.In the bustle of the city it is a magic place to sit and recharge the batteries

"Wind in the Willows" childrens play performed in the Botanic Gardens!. If you are looking for something to do with your children (from 5 to about 12 years of age) and you are in Sydney in January find out if "Wind in the Willows is on. This year it was held twice a day, 11am or 6pm) from 7-24th January. You meet at the main pond and once during the play the audience (who are designated rabbits!) all move with the actors to another part of the Gardens. You are encouraged to take a picnic with you for before or after. The actors are from the Shakespeare company and it was just captivating. The animals are wonderfully presented with amazing costumes. You can hear well and there are lots of jokes too.This year I took our 4 grandchildren and about 20 years or so ago I took my three children who still remember how good it was. You can book (www.shakespeareaustralia.com.au) and tickets are for sale at the pond. Cost this year was $25 or family of 4 $90. There also seemed to be a few adults there with no children!

Lovely and peaceful. We spent an hour or two in this beautiful park and had our picnic; I really enjoyed it. The view of the harbour was fantastic (although I'd prefer to not see some massive war ships!). The varity of plants are amazing; and the most importantly you do not see as many people as other places around inside the gardens, I really don't know why.

Relaxing. The gardens are just very beautiful! One can stay for a long time to relax and unwind with a good book. The place is quiet and tranquil, suitable for kind of soul searching. Very well maintained too.

So pretty!. Royal Botanic Gardens is a huge place filled with lots of plants. There are different themes to each section of the park, so it takes a while to walk through all of them. My personal favorite was the herb garden because it smelled really nice and fresh. Some potential highlights are the wollemi pine (previously believed to have been extinct) and the rose garden.

Lovely garden. The garden has a great view of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. So, I spent my NY with my husband in the garden. We had to arrive early (3 pm) to find our spot. During NYE, we had access to public toilets and food an beverages to buy. Besides, the garden itself is lovely, well-preserved and clean.

Magnificent open space.... A wonderful place to wander through and escape the city ....Some stunning trees and plantings....Beautifully kept and looked after...With some great views to other parts of the City....Lots of varied paths and routes....Stunning place to refresh the spirits.
Stunning gardens in the heart of the city. Green beyond green gardens, beautiful trees, two sculptures under construction. Shade or bright sunshine seating available. Beware the fruit bats.

Take the free guided tour. The Royal Botanic Gardens & Domian Trust volunteers are arranging free tours, starting daily from the information center in the middle of the gardens. Check website for specifics. We can highly recommend joining one if these tours. You'll get presented some of the remarkable plants in the garden. Most noticeably the Wollemi Pine - thought to be extinct for millions of years. But also other interesting things, like the Macadamian nut tree and information about some of the oldest structures in the garden. Most likely the guide will also be able to point out the residing Powerful Owl, sitting in a tree somewhere. Of course the gardens are wonderful to just walk around in, or use for a relaxing rest on one of the lawns.But getting a bit more information only heightens the experience.

Serene place in middle of Sydney. Wonderful range of plants, trees etc in a large parkland setting with harbour views and it is free. Government House is at the Brdige end but only open Firday-Sunday.

Right next door from the Intercontenal Hotel. This is a big park so give yourself a lot of time or do it in two sessions. The plants are amazing. Mrs. McQuiries chair is interesting. This park faces the harbor which includes the Opera House and the Harbour bridge so the pictures you can take are amazing. Wear comfortable shoes and take your time to see everything.

Location..... Its one of the most visited garden in Sydney because of its location on Sydney Harbour. A huge park in the heart of the city occupies Sydney’s most spectacular position.We couldn’t explore the most of the park as unfortunately had to rush some other place however whatever we could explore was beautiful.It has no entrance fee and is open round the year.
great escape. If you like to walk and escape the bustle of city life then a short walk into the gardens takes you to another world yet still in the city!fantastic surroundings and its free.

Royal Botanic Gardens. Beautifully kept gardens, lots of walk ways, well signed posted, a good walk way along the sea path, beware of the lunchtime joggers !, a good tea room and a very good shop. Clean toilets

Lovely Walk, beautiful Gardens.. Walked around the royal botanic gardens after visiting the Opera House. It is a beautiful serene place with some fantastic views. It doesn't cost anything either which makes it a must do for all!
nice views. We came in the fall hence there weren't much flowers. It was nice nonetheless to see greenery and view of the water.

Beautiful. A nice, calm, serene walk through the park in the middle of a city. Lots of beautiful gardens, trees and birds. Definitely a good place to explore a little and have a picnic. I definitely recommend stopping by the herb garden as well as the queens rose garden.

Great Place for Spend Your Time With Family, Friends, or Personally. This is one of my favourite spot in Sydney, its a really big garden and what i love about this garden is its really refreshing and it has a great view to harbour bridge and opera house. If you want to spent time with family or friends its a perfect place to visit, especially for couples. It also a perfect place for jogger! In here you also can learn about the type of the plants, etc. If you wanna get out from a crowded place like in the city or refresh your mind from work, you should visit this garden.

Bryan. Take your time and smell the bats along the way. Yes the distinctive odour of bats hanging about in trees is one of the wonderful things about this Botanical Garden. A wander around the gardens is a great way to introduce yourself to the plants of Australia. From desert plants to rainforest, this has it all, and some of the specimens are older than the visitors. The sad part of my latest visit was the notice that several very old trees were dying and they were to be removed soon. At least the notice beside the trees gave an opportunity to say goodbye. Meanwhile the colourful flowers throughout the gardens provided a happy scene and the birds, spiders and reptiles living amongst the vegetation added to the Australian experience. To top it off the shop has an excellent array of botanical books and gifts while the café with its friendly staff do a good coffee.

great views. We walked along the harbour side of the park great views and cool breeze,lots of open spaces and parkland.Did not see all of the gardens due to the heat and had our grandson with us. Well worth a stroll on a cool day.
lovely. all the gardens are interconnected so plan a good route and see all of them at once. Well maintained and lots of cafes to stop for a drink
Beautiful. This garden is simply beautiful. A perfect place to enjoy beautiful Sydney weather. A must visit place if you are in Sydney.

Relaxing. The gardens are quite large, we did it whilst walking to the opera house, some of the plants had already flowered so perhaps we didn't see the colourful displays but even so it was really lovely. Look out for the eels swimming in the lake,!!

A lovely garden and unlike Kew it is free!. As a former long term member of Kew in London I always visit here when in Sydney. It is restful and beautiful, but watch out for speeding joggers at lunch time. The volunteers are knowledgeable and so helpful and the cafes are pretty good. There are some great walks and many specimen trees etc. not just from Australia but all around the world. My favourite spot is Mrs Macquarie`s Seat. I always visit two or three times during my month long trip to Oz.
Restful place. It was lovely to walk through the gardens, so close to the harbour, city everthing.I was how ever disappointed that the Orchid house and another was closed.

NYE Under the Stars Dec 2014 at Botanic Gardens. Firstly, let me say that if you can afford a ticket to an exclusive viewing area for the fireworks, BUY ONE. Read as many reviews as possible about the different events offered at the Botanic Gardens (NYE Under the Stars, Midnight at the Oasis, Lawn With a View, The Point) and decide which one suites your needs best. I chose NYE under the stars and I'm very pleased with my selection. If you can not afford a ticket, and plan to get a great vantage point on the free viewing areas, be prepared to be in line/queue as early as 7 am even though the gates don't open until 10 am. This is if you want an unobstructed view free of trees. Prepare for hot weather during the day, possible rain, and very cool weather at night. Be prepared to use portable toilets that will get more and more filthy as the day wears on. Be prepared for extreme crowds that may get rather rowdy. Pack smartly for a LONG day outdoors in the elements. I researched my options thoroughly and finally decided on NYE Under the Stars because the tickets to all other venues were sold out. Search The Royal Botanic Gardens & Domain Trust and www.sydneynewyearseve.com for official events. My experience: I only queued for two hours. (This was by choice because I wanted to make sure I got a good spot on Tarpeian Precinct North to view the fireworks. The gates opened at 6:30 and my friend and I chose to wait at the gate for 2 hours. There were ~ 30 people ahead of us and about a hundred people behind us. Coming early paid off because we were front and center on the lawn once the gates opened). We very well could have arrived at 7 pm or later and still got a great spot for viewing. Honestly, no spot was a bad spot for VIEWING, but the farther back you are on the lawn, the more likely you'll be in the high traffic areas with people passing over you to get to the food/drink stands and toilets. Having people stepping over you all night has to be annoying!All inclusive food and drinks were included in our package. The food and drinks were good and plentiful, but lines were long earlier in the night and tapered off as the night went on. There were servers who circled the lawn delivering food/water, but they typically ran out of food before they reached patrons at the front of the lawn since they entered from the back.They were bathroom attendants who directed traffic which was extremely helpful! As the night went on, the bathroom line was longer than the food & drink line. The viewing area was SPECTACULAR and worth every penny!! It cost $395 AUD. The lawn could accommodate ~1500 patrons. The lawn is large and there is no bad area for VIEWING, but there is a large tree that can obscure views. I would suggest the following improvements for next year:1) there needs to be several CLEAR walking paths where sitting is PROHIBITED. Once the lawn got crowded, it was nearly impossible to walk around to get food/drinks or get to the bathroomIt would be great if these walking paths could be illuminated by outdoor bulbs2) there needs to be consistent rules as it relates to chairs being allowed. I enjoyed sitting on my beach towel, but a beach chair would have been more comfortable. I was envious of those who had small chairs. 3) the DJ may not be needed. There's so many parties in close proximity that it seems to be a distraction I loved that standing was not allowed during the fireworks. I hope this rule remains. Overall, I think this event and vantage point was worth EVERY dollar spent! If I'm ever in Sydney again, I wouldn't hesitate to attend again. But I would definitely arrive 2 hours early and wait for the gates to open.

Beautiful. The Royal Botanic Gardens is great. It's huge, pretty, and very relaxing. It's a good escape from the city. It's very diverse with lots of good scenic shots. We even saw some Cockatoos flying around. It's located on the water near the Opera House. I think it's a must see if visiting Sydney.

A must to visit when in Sydney. Lots of beautiful garden displays and shady spots to lie and relax in the sun. The view to the harbour is so pretty and it is a short walk to the wonderful Art gallery of NSW
Great for runners!. This was a perfect place for a run. The paved paths are safe and offer gorgeous views of the harbor, Opera House the bridge and city. The gardens are a great bonus ;)

Gorgeous!. Absolutely gorgeous gardens which has a mini train that runs through it and stops at different stops throughout the garden! Great toilet facilities which are easily sign posted. Beautiful and relaxing - just stunning!

Nice garden. I actually only ended up seeing only a small part of the gardens.I had read on their website that there was a free daily tour of the gardens at 10:30am and decided to do this. The tour was very informative and was actually very like a lesson. We looked at a few different trees and plants and learnt about their history and how they grow. It was very interesting but as I said we only saw a tiny bit of the garden. There was not a lot of walking around the garden so you didn't see as much of it.The tour was very good, just not what I had been expecting. For me I would have preferred to have walked around the garden more instead of examining a small area in such great detail.

A SYDNEY MUST !!. Such a brilliant setting - spoilt at time by the screaming bats etc - still worth the visit. Great food and service - reasonably priced -we have had Christmas Lunch there several times - excellent and also had lunch there together or with friends - particularly if from overseas or interstate - it is s Sydney Gem ! The food is "modern"Australian with a touch of the Continent and the East at times - nice servings and smiling service. Do visit - and then a nice walk to the Harbour !

Beautiful Well Kept Gardens. We spent an entertaining half-day wandering around Sydney's Botanic Gardens. Start at Mrs. McQuarrie's Chair then walk up through the gardens being sure to explore all that it has to offer. I found the walk giving the history of Sydney particularly interesting.

Incredible. Every time I go to Sydney I make a point of visiting the Botanic Gardens, even if it's just briefly.Probably the best Botanical gardens I've ever visited (kicks Melbourne's butt!). I'm not really a garden or flower person but it's really cool to walk around and where it opens up towards the edge of the water it's a great place to sit and relax with incredible views of both the opera house and the bridge.It's also usually quite quiet considering how great a spot it is. Must visit when in Sydney!

Botanic Gardens and Domain - Worth the Visit!. If you near the Circular Quay or visiting the Opera House, the Botanic Gardens and the domain is a great way to spend part of the day. Even if all you do is walk or jog the shore path from the Opera House to Mrs. Macqaurie's Chair it is worth it. The walk is about 3/4 mile each way with some of the best across the bay views of the Opera House and Bridge with Sydney as the background. On the opposite side is the Botanic gardens, an expanse of green lawns, huge variety of trees, plants and gardens throughout. I would recommend going to the "chair" either early in the day or late in the day, to avoid the "sea of tourist buses" getting there. You can take a bus or taxi there as well.We visited the gardens on the first day we arrived (noon), checked in, rested a bit and toured the gardens. Our hotel was right across the street so we started there, had coffee and a snack at the Garden restaurant, then to Mrs Macquarie's chair, took a lot of pictures and headed back along the shore path to the opera house, visited the opera house, had a light dinner at one of the cafes along the Quay and headed back to the hotel. You could go the opposite way and head into the city exiting the Government house or palace garden gates.For us it was great way to spend the first day, keeping us awake but not too demanding, just taking in the scenery. After spending 25+ hours on a plane, this was a great way to take our time, stretch the muscles and causally enjoy Sydney. It was a great start to a wonderful holiday.

Beautiful well kept grounds that everyone should see. Without a doubt, some of the best kept and scenic gardens that we’ve visited anywhere in the world. Its obvious the City takes a lot of pride and spends a lot of $ to maintain the gardens because they beautiful, immaculate and picturesque. Take at least an hour or two to walk the perimeter to see Mrs. Macquarie’s Chair, then to the east side of Farm Cove to take a picture of the Sydney Opera House.
Perfect spot for NYE. Spent NYE working here and the fireworks and atmosphere of the park was incredible! highly recommend if you plan on attending NYE. Great relaxed park throughout the day aswell

Lawn with the View, NYE. Each year the Botanic Gardens in Sydney close down in order to host a set of New Year's Eve events that facilitate the viewing of the incredible Fireworks display put on by the city of Sydney, Australia. As an American, I have only observed what is shown on national news clips which usually feature about 20 seconds of content (the 10 second countdown and about 10 seconds more of initial fireworks.) While this is exciting, it was nothing compared to the actual fireworks display that finishes up the midnight sequence. The last two minutes of the show are unlike anything I have ever experienced. It was phenomenal and worth every penny of the pricey tickets needed to get into this event. I will say you can experience the fireworks in a far less pleasurable, but much cheaper way on the public street, but after spending a great deal of money to travel thousands of miles, I wanted a more secure spot where I knew I would be able to savor this moment, and I have no regrets about doing so. The event we went to provided a substantial basket dinner which was innovative in concept although not as delicious in execution as I had hoped, and each patron must provide a "rug" (translation for Americans=blanket) to sit on the lawn, so if you find it difficult to sit on the ground for five hours, you might want to spring for the even more expensive tickets which offer a table and chairs. But overall, this was (by far) the best thing we did while in Sydney and will remain an amazing memory to hold on to for the rest of my years.
Beautiful!!. Beautiful, beautiful green lush gardens!! So relaxing to walk through and take in the gorgeous flowers and plants.

Beautiful - great scenery and top spot for kids. Well manicured and kept gardens. Lots of shade, and places to explore. Cafe was pretty good. Could not find any bins along the paths for rubbish - so we had to carry ours for some distance (evidently some others couldn't be bothered, though)
Beautiful and Free!. The gardens are absolutely beautiful and well maintained. I enjoyed reading about the history of the garden and viewing the thousands of plants from all over the world.

Beautiful spot in a lively place. It was a joy to stroll through the gardens. We had already taken the little train so we got the "lay of the land" and knew what to return to. Lots of good places to sit in the shade. Parrots in the trees. Interesting plantings all around. Just a lovely spot in a very busy city.

Great gardens. So big you can get lost. Loved the palm gardens with the lake, the rose garden and all the open parkland. The views across the harbour are excellent. IIt is centrally loacted so had no trouble finding it. So glad I spent a half day there.

Great Relaxing Place. Visiting the Gardens is definitely a must for any visitor of Sydney. More than a gorgeous view of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge, the garden itself is a great attraction. A lot of artworks, statues and different herbs and flowers to see. It's a great time to just hang around on a alazy afternoon and lie down.

Wild cockatoos ....amazing. New to AU so this was worth our time. Roses were exceptional. Views everywhere. and Seeing the wild birds just amazing. You can take as much time as you want or have to explore this lovely park!

Truly beautiful gardens a real delight. These gardens are right on the harbour and just along past the opera house. They are absolutely delightful I would go so far as to say they are the best I have seen in the world. A huge variety of native australian trees and plants are here and the view is to die for. A highly recommended free thing to do whilst staying in Sydney!

Everything is landscaped to perfection. The Royal Botanic Gardens is huge, everything is landscaped to perfection, and there are so many different areas to explore. I joined a free walking tour where the guide was very knowledgeable. It went for over an hour and showcased the main areas of the gardens. I definitely recommend seeing the gardens this way as you learn a lot, and get to see which areas you’d like to spend more time in once the tour has finished.

Serene gardens with city and harbour views. I seriously love the Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney and walk around them every evening when I'm on business travel in Sydney. The selection of flora is fantastic, with sections dedicated to certain world regions. There are ornamental lakes with some big eels in residence and bird life to look at as well. The views over the harbour and the Sydney Opera House are wonderful from the gardens. Definitely worth visiting next time you are in Sydney.

Best I've ever been to. The park is huge and beautiful. Good for a stroll, a picnic or jog. It is usually hard to convince my husband to go to gardens with me since he tends to not be impressed with flowers but he was easily sold within minutes. The best part of the park is that you are able to see the bridge and opera house at several different spots. Its perfect for some good pictures of the skyline.
Clean and Beautiful. It helps that it overlooks the iconic Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Prime spot for the NYE fireworks too.

Free tours of this magnificent garden. In planning our visit to Sydney, I knew that I wanted to see the Royal Botanic Garden. The hotel that I booked was right across the street from the garden, so we had easy access. The first day, my husband and I just walked around the park, exploring and trying to get our bearings for it is an extremely large area. It is close to the Sydney Opera House. I knew that I wanted to return the next day for a guided tour and I was trying to figure out the best way to get to the designated meeting area.The following day, I went by myself to the Garden Shop at Palm Grove Center. I met our guide, Glen. There were about 7 of us in the group. Glen was a volunteer who was very knowledgeable and passionate about the garden. He certainly knew his material. Not only did he talk about the plants, he also talked about the history of Sydney and Australia. He pointed out some of the brick work that had been done by convicts. When it was time for the hour and a half walk to be over, he asked if we would like to continue. All of us were eager to do so.Because their seasons are the opposite of ours in the U.S., we were there for the Spring Walk. It was absolutely magnificent! The Spring Walk is a tradition in Sydney that has been going on for many years.I would advise everyone who visits Sydney to visit the Royal Botanic Gardens and, if they have the time, to go on at least one of the guided tours.

Fireworks from Lawn with the View. Spent New Years Eve 2014 at the Botanic Gardens, on the lawn above the Opera House. The ticket price is steep ($270 including a large picnic and water; drinks extra), but the comfort and ease of the night made it well worth while. And the view really was magic! Saw everything, smelt the gunpowder, felt the explosions!Saving up now for next year!

Huge Trees. This is the best place to go and relax, have a picnic, walk, run, exercise, enjoy nature or simply watch the world go by. I saw this huge tree that takes 4-5 people to hug. We sat on this huge stone facing the harbour with the view of the opera house and end up talking to a local discussing about local politics. I think that is the best way to spend the afternoon. I truly enjoyed that.

Oldest Botanic Gardens in Australia. This is the oldest botanic gardens in Australia. Well laid out with lots of places for having a picnic. Very informative displays - especially the herbs garden. The Government House is located inside the gardens.

A free oasis. after the busyness of the harbour it is lovely to cross over to the botanical gardens. Sit under a tree and see the world go by. There are quite a number of coffee places. Be aware they close early, we could not get anything at 5 pm anymore.
More than flowers. A walk with flowers on all fronts .....just stop and smell the roses , a relaxing walk on nature ...the views are stunning ....

Beautiful. Spacious gardens, beautifully laid out, fabulous collection of plants and a variety of gardens in various styles. Went for a couple of vary pleasant walks. Coffee shop could do with some fresh decor but that's not the main reason for going I guess!

Historic and elegant. This is a beautiful place to gain some insights to Australian history. Grounds are impeccable and a delightful place to walk or find an open spot to simply enjoy the setting. A very popular place for people to walk and overlooks the harbor.

Little piece of heaven in a big city. So tranquil and beautiful in here. So many hidden areas to relax, have a picnic or read. It is right next to the harbour. They even have the Opera play in the botanic gardens on the water. Worth a visit.
Peaceful.. Nice place to find a shady spot with a sea breeze on a hot Summer day. Book out, shoes off and relax.

Wonderful Garden in a Busy City. Royal Botanic Gardens have a lot of beautiful plants and great view to offer. visitors can sit under some big old tress and relax or having a picnic. It is also very nice to walk from the garden to the Opera House. the view is amazing there!
BEAUTIFUL. Beautiful gardens... a must must do in Sydney. Take the long walks and explore the gardens. Beautiful views of the harbour from various points.
Not to be missed.... Great space to relax and take in views! Handy little train to take the strain especially helpful in the heat! Good cafe. Location ideal for Opera house.

Loads of space, fabulous views. OK, I'm not a fan of Sydney, but I love the Botanic Gardens. There is so much space, it's well laid out, and there are lots of interesting historical notes around. The view of Sydney Harbour is magnificent. Take a picnic and book, and enjoy the gardens.
Nice place. It was a very nice walk... several flora species, However it was not that good for learning purposes because of lack of signs in each specie. Anyway I totally recommend to visit it.
Beautiful place for a walk. We had a morning free from our children and had a beautiful walk around the gardens.They are a delight and a lovely way to spend an hour or two.

Take your time, have a nap. The gardens are very special and are especially green at the time of visiting. Take the time to read the plaques and visit the unique sculptures. Look closely and you will see some unique carvings. There some lush trees with great canopies. Stop for a picnic or a nap in the afternoon heat. There is a café in the gardens or outside nearby is a Subway sandwich outlet. Don't forget water/hat etc. It's a shame that the tropical display is under repair and wont be open until 2016. The breezes from the harbour and the lush grasses to walk on makes it very special. Don't rush.

Lovely gardens but both greenhouses are shut until 2016. We went here for a look around the 2 big greenhouses so were disappointed to find them shut and all overgrown or plants dead. The rest of the gardens were pretty though and it is a nice walk down to Mrs McQuarries chair.

Beautiful location. What a lovely place ...Rather than pay for an expensive restaurant, my wife and I had a special Christmas picnic for two in the Royal Botanic Gardens. It's a thoroughly lovely place, with, depending one where you go, views of the city, the Opera House or the Bridge, or indeed all three.On this occasion there were various other couples, families, groups of friends, and the occasional single just enjoying the ambience of this lovely setting in the middle of the otherwise busy city.The gardens themselves are very well laid out, and the tress and plants all labelled, so that a wander through the gardens is not just relaxing and peaceful but informative as well.

Great scenery in the middle of the city. Great hideaway right in the heart of the bussel ,cool breeze by the waters edge ,plenty of seating although a lot is out in the open not under the shade of the trees ,shame the glass houses were shut ,but it's still a great place to visit

Just beautiful. The botanical gardens are another aspect of the whole glorious experience that is Sydney Harbour.The gardens are very well kept and full of wonderful plants and trees making it such a lovely and tranquil place.There's also a nice like café where you can have some lunch and good little gift shop too.The gardens are perfect for a break from the hustle and bustle of Sydney - recommended.

Gorgeous grounds, scenic views. Gorgeous, huge gardens, lots of paths to explore the gardens and take in incredible views of the Sydney Harbour...don't miss it!
Best part is, it is free of charge.
If you want to visit the restaurant, be sure to book!

Oasis in the city. Beautiful part of Sydney with harbour views, historic trees, accessible next to the Opera House. Great place to visit, bring a picnic or jog through. Usually plenty of cockatoos and lorikeets at far end of park. You are not supposed to feed thembut people that do get climbed all over by the cockatoos

For nature lovers. This place may not be for everybody it is for one who is interested and likes visiting and knowing about the various foliage systems. There are a whole variety of species available around at the place that are well categorized and provided with in formations. I loved the whole visit to the place.
A big asset in a big city.. Close to both the CBD and the harbour. Plenty of open space to sit and ponder "what a lovely world"?

Midnight at the Oasis - 10/10 for the view, 1/10 for organisation. Note this is a review of the NYE Midnight at the Oasis event, not the Royal Botanical Gardens themselves.As we were coming to Australia, and to Sydney, for the first time and were here for NYE, we wanted to do something special and didn't want to have to queue all day. After much research we chose MatO as it had the best views. And we were right to do so. The views were amazing. We had a direct view of the opera house and the bridge from our table and were sat with some really nice people, so all in all we had a great evening. But...On the website it said because it was a ticketed event and doors didn't open until 7pm, there was no need for us to turn up early. We foolishly followed this advice and turned up just after 7pm to find an enormous queue. We then stood in this queue for 45 minutes before we were admitted. We were given our starter box, which we took to the table. We admired the fabulous view for a few seconds and I then left to get some drinks. Another queue. There was, it seemed, one bar for the entire event and approximately 10 people serving. I queued for another 45 mins to get to the front, and when I was finally there I was told by the bar staff I could only order 1 bottle of wine (as there was only me in the queue, my boyfriend had stayed at the table to look after our things). I just wanted a bottle of wine and a bottle of champagne for me and my other half to see us through until midnight. I nearly cried at this point. Fortunately people around me came to my aid and I was able to buy what I wanted. I got back to the table and my boyfriend had to immediately leave to join the queue for the main courses. This took him away for approx 1/2 an hour. The desserts queue was much better and only took 10 mins, but between us we queued for over 2 hours, during which time we couldn't enjoy either the view, or each other's company. On NYE. At an event that cost AUS$385 (approx £200) per person. This event has been going on for years. I am appalled at their lack of organisation not to say a little angry. I cannot overstate how amazing the view was, and of course the fireworks, and I refused to let it spoil our evening. However if we are ever lucky enough to be in Sydney for NYE again, we will certainly not be going to this event. All I can say if you do decide to go is don't believe the advice on the website, turn up early. And if you turn up on time, be prepared to queue.

N Y E visit for to Celebrate incoming year. Brilliant location, well organised. Some people are just stupid though or ignorant. In the paper work sent or given to you when paid you do not bring glass, tents, sharp objects, chairs that will spike the ground etc etc BUT they still did it. The organisers were so kind they even decanted the bottled wine into prepared bottle for these dumbo's, I would have kept it as compensation for dealing with ignorant morons. However the organisers still allowed the tents,chairs that had spike legs not curved , which was a shame, I would have loved a chair to be a bit more comfy over the 7 hrs, but silly me I followed the rules & requests. Even though it was self catered as stated in said paper work there was a coffee van which sold pies, sausage rolls, rolls with mixed fillings, chocolates. Would have been nice to not bring food if this was known. Everyone should experience this at least once a lifetime.

A must do in Sydney.. This is the first place we visited on our first trip to Sydney on a walk down to the Opera House. Great place to have a picnic. Great place to bring kids to see wildlife and different types of trees. Also has a quite a few monuments within it. Don't miss!

Beautiful, relaxing and well kept. This is a must see when in Sydney. So much time and effort is put into these gardens. Also I would suggest getting the little train around there as you learn so much about the garden and its history
Peace in a manic city. Loved the details around the gardens that make them special. Love the peace that can be found around these gardens.

It so increadibly beautiful!. It doesn't matter if you're a senior, a young backpacker or a business man. Everyone can enjoy this beautiful oasis from the rush and crowds of Sidney. Sit down for awhile and you will fell the tranquility and joy come. It sounds crazy but I love this place soo much!

Away from the city crowds....!!!!. Beautiful colourful flowers ,especially the multi coloured roses , grand big old trees , well trimmed sprawling grounds with birds and ducks set by a huge expense of sea water with famous Sydney icons,the Harbour Bridge and Opera House over yonder with ferries yachts and boats on the waters.... It was beautiful and picture perfect !!!Helpful directional signs indicate where one wants to go - it was Mrs. Macquarie Chair for me to view the Opera House and Harbour Bridge from another distance angle. There were many joggers and also many fishing by Mrs. MacQ's chair as I sat on the famous concrete chair to view my surroundings! Unfortunately, the weather was drizzly and cloudy and I did not get to see the famous sunset by the Sydney icons.... but the beauty of the garden and it's surroundings made up for the lack of sunset!Conveniently located on the fringe of the City, easily accessible by foot this garden is a relaxing place to be in away from the hustle & bustle of the city....!!!!

Charm, beauty, diversity in a gentle, unpretentious open garden near the harbour. You will need more than one visit to discover all the intimate joys of this beautiful botanic garden, Australia's oldest. The earliest bridge built in the colony through to a plant at has been taken to space, there is every sort of flower and plant to delight and surprise you - even a series of beds dedicated to lawn!! Sooo Australian.There is a train which takes you through the gardens which is great for getting your bearings and being a hop on, hop off you can use it during the same day. Only $10. There is a cafe and a restaurant to enjoy, with beautiful fountains and sculptures.The bird life is absolutely amazing as I is and various water birds have made this place home. But it is in the trees themselves where you wil find rainbowlorikeets, cockatoos, even the odd bar though they usually only come here to sleep.From the history of Australia to learning about plants from around the world, this is a truly joyful experience. There is also an art gallery, plus a fernery and other beautiful dedicated buildings.

Except for the fall. Breath taking views of the harbor from a beautifully maintained garden, birds and wildlife abound, made for morning runs I will never forget. Oops, landed uneven and fractured my collar bone, but still a beautiful memory.

Lovely Gardens. The gardens are so nice that we managed to visit twice during our brief time in Sydney. Beautifully laid out, the gardens encompass many, many plant varieties. I especially enjoyed the fairy garden.
Just OK. Not the Botanical Gardens that would make it an attraction, but a nice place for a walk, a picnic or a play area.
Lovely Gardens. Enjoyed several walks & a jog through the Royal Botanical Gardens. The gardens were simply beautiful, very well maintained & clean.
Royal Botanical Gardens. What a beautiful garden Sydney has created here. Take a nice walk through the gardens just a short walk from Circular Quay and the Opera House, no charge, a must see!
great gardens. We really enjoyed our time here. Please be sure to go here when you get a chance! It is a can't miss activity

Train journey around park added to attraction. Loved the variety of plants and foliage in this beautiful garden. The train journey was 10 Aus Dollars each was certainly worthwhile and the commentary enroute ideal if you simply didn't have time to explore the beautiful gardens.
beautiful views. Each section of the botanic gardens has its own charm and appeal, and a different perspective of the harbor. It is a tranquil setting in the city.

Lovely Gardens - Recommended. Beautiful gardens with an enormous variety of different Australian plants, trees and flowers etc to view. Great view of the Harbour and the Opera House from parts of the Gardens. I recommend adding this to your list of places to visit whilst in Sydney!

Beautiful Gardens - Highly Recommended. I would add this to your bucket list if you are traveling to Sydney along with the more famous sites like the bridge and opera house. This is a beautiful park with a huge diversity of native aussie trees and plants and shrubs etc and the best part is the Gardens overlook the opera house (they are on the next bay over). You can get some outstanding photos from here. Recommended to visit this place

Colourful and vibrant. Our extended family went to the Gardens in Dec 2013. The gardens were massive and spanned a very large area, thus it is recommended to spend half to a full day in the area alone. There were many areas to the Gardens, but I found the Begonia Gardens (I believe it to be, as I had to check the map since my memory is rusty) to be the best due to the excellent display of colour and charisma from the flowers. The central location of the Gardens make it a great place to go to, and I would highly recommend it to anyone visiting Sydney, even if they are not interested in horticulture or nature, simply for the tourist value of the area.

Gardens in need of attention. The Botanic Gardens are quite extensive, but we felt that they needed some attention. The succulents and herb gardens were good. Unfortunately the tropical centre was temporarily closed.The café sells quite tasty sandwiches.

Simply Beautiful. Set on the headland beyond the iconic Opera House the Royal Botanic Garden is a must when visiting Sydney. It can be accessed at various points: the gate behind the opera House and the lovely foreshore walk; the main entrance at the top of the hill and a couple of minor entrances in the perimeter fencing.The garden is beautifully set out with various garden zones. The planting is luxurious but with really helpful plant labels. Paths are mostly sealed and easy pushing for buggies or wheelchairs. Some of the minor routes have a bark covering. There is an enormous amount of space. Seats are sited around the gardens in abundance. Guided walks leave regularly. The shop and visitor centre have lots of information. The garden is very well signposted so finding your way around is not too much of a challenge. The café is well sited. There is a land train every half hour around the garden. The main stop for this is at the Opera House gate. The views from the garden over the Harbour and the opera House are stunning. Don't leave Sydney without enjoying this free attraction.
Beautiful. A lovely place to relax in the city. Take a picnic and soak up the sun or take a leisurely stroll around the gardens.

Disappointing. Too much waking and not enough plant life to see. My idea of a botanic garden might not be the same as Sydney's, but I was very disappointed. I visited the botanic gardens in Singapore, just a couple of weeks after this visit and I really enjoyed the Singapore Botanic Gardens.

Don't miss The Fernery. If you like nature, it can be fun to combine a beautiful spot with fantastic information. The person who designed the Fernery was truly inspired. The plants are amazing and the signs describe everything from the evolution of ferns to their lifecycle. Of all the many, many fantastic things we did in Sydney, I think the Fernery was my very favorite.

A perfect stroll !. Green .....the gardens are so incredibly green and in great health !!. That's what hit me most, how special, with someone special ! Having the Harbour so close by and Lady Macquarie's Point what a perfect midday activity. A Must.... stop at the Botanic Gardens café for a light meal, perfectly shaded and quiet!

Green and beautiful and the views.... The botanic gardens are a must visit in Sydney esp. on a sunny day. Apart from the greenery, they also give you an amazing view of the Harbour and the Opera House. Also a nice place to contemplate about the history of Sydney and Australia.

Great views, beautiful plantings. even if you are not someone who usually visits gardens, the sydney RBG is worth taking time for the incredible views of the harbour and the opera house. If you do like gardens, its a can't miss.

Very Relaxing! A oase in the busy city!. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a very relaxing and calming place in the middle of the busy and noisy city.
It is very nice to have a walk around the gardens and to forget about life for a while.

Very varied, and don't forget to look for birds. So much variety in a compact area. Particularly liked the Fernery with its jungle smells and nearby, an almost English Rose Garden.
Plenty of birds to watch as well, Mynas, Masked Lapwings & Cockatoos should all be obvious and you can't misss the White Ibises, they even jump on the empty cafe tables for crumbs.
Most uplifting. What more can you ask for? Surrounded by magnificent lawns and gardens with a magnificent harbour as a backdrop.
Beautiful gardens. Beautiful Gardens with amazing views over Sydney Harbour and the opera house. The gardens are alive with bird life and the occasional large lizard. A must on a visit to Sydney.

Free to visit, loads of plants and flowers. The garden is totally free and located next to the Opera. There is a train than goes around (I think it's 5 dollars/person) and leaves at H30. There are several areas in the gardens with explanations, a shop and a restaurant in the middle.

Majestic!. This place is amazing! It is a really peaceful place, with huge strong trees and people either tanning or having a picnic, it is ideal for couples, families or just some alone time with a great book. Do not expect to be entertained by a show or animals, this place is purely for relaxation and contemplation of nature's majestic landscapes!

pleasant green space right in town. this is actually quite a large green space with plenty of walks that afford you the opportunity to see plenty of the native flora as well as offering spectacular views of the harbor and its surrounds. take your time and enjoy a relaxing visit then head over to the museum of art on the edge of this garden. both the botanical gardens and the museum are free to enter.

Take time to enjoy. Escape from the hustle and bustle of Sydney's busy streets and take a walk through the Royal Botanic Gardens. If you have done a tour of the Opera House or a ferry cruise, take the entrance by the Opera House.The gardens are well laid out, well kept and provide a lovely space to walk in even if you are not interested in horticulture. The restaurant is a little disappointing if you leave it too late in the afternoon to visit however but it does provide the visitor with somewhere to get a meal and a drink.
Worth a walk!. The gardens were incredibly nice, with amazing views of the harbor and plenty of beautiful birds! Definitely worth a walk around for at least an hour!

Impressive. Very impressed with the gardens and their upkeep. Everywhere you walk and every turn you take provides something new and different to look at. Amazingly well maintained and a credit to all involved. One tip is don't buy water from the kiosk, $4 for a bottle of water. Bring your own.

Everywhere you turn unique and delightful. Amazingly peaceful and picturesque sprawling park is at the heart of Sydney sights. Everywhere you turn is some view, vegetation massive tree or relaxation spot inviting you to stay longer. Birds are bountiful and a delight. The Sydney harbour at the crown of the park. Every detail is done with care and love.

Large gardens. Great for wandering and exploring.. There is a lot to see in the gardens, but they are different from typical botanical gardens in my opinion. There are only a couple places on the grounds where the plants are labeled and arranged by theme (Palm and Asian garden, ect.). I would recommend making it to the lotus flower pond. It was absolutely beautiful! This is a great, free way to view some of Australia's natural flora with great views of Sydney Harbor wherever you look.

These are the best botanical gardens I have seen. I have seen plenty of gardens in my time but I honestly rate this one the best. Not only is it full of amazing native aussie plants and trees and flowers etc but it also overlooks the Opera House and Harbour Bridge in the distance! A must visit

Very nice. Really nice gardens. Quite expansive and maybe not as manicured as some other botanic gardens, but they are free to enter and roll all alongside the harbour beautifully. Well worth a look. Lots of wildlife and some exotic trees. Keep an eye out for the lavender trees.

Great for a Stroll. If you want to visit Government House in the Gardens you will need photo ID to get onto a tour otherwise you will be confined to the gardens as we were. The gardens are very pleasant and it was good to get away from the bustle of the streets of Sydney

Great for a simple outdoor activity.. Took my three young kids to the Royal Botanic Gardens last Saturday and we parked our car at the Domain carpark which is located at the edge of the garden and only cost $10 for the whole day.My kids enjoyed the garden which is located right on the Sydney Harbour and they were excited to see boats, wildlife and fish.We walked around to visit the Opera House and there is also an art gallery and swimming pool located in the garden.Great simple family outdoor fun at low costs.Nice place to visit.
Great spot for family picnic. Love this place, just beautiful to visit with the family. No better way to spend a sunday with the kids

Never disappointed. Seriously what a great day out, walk over the harbour bridge around the opera house and bang amongst the most beautiful gardens with a great big ice cream! such a great day out and so cheap. Its an incredible city and the Botanical Gardens never disappoint

A gardener's delight. A lovely afternoon spent walking around the various gardens. The variety of gardens provides an opportunity for gardener's, photographers and nature lovers. Allow a couple of hours to do the gardens justice. Beautiful vistas of the harbour from several vantage points.
Have a picnic or early morning walk. Nice, relaxing place to be. Not somewhere you'd go for views of anything, but it's a lovely landscape.
BEAUTIFUL AND HUGE. love to walk around this garden..it's huge but definitely worth a visit.there's cafe inside the garden for a light meal.
Calm and peacful. Great little red train ride around the gardens and learnt so much which made our walk through the gardens even better.

Must See in Sydney. Located a short distance from Circular Quay and the city center, you can walk to the Botanical gardens. The foliage and views are simply beautiful. Make sure to visit Mrs. Macquarie's chair while here -it is historically significant.

Vosit with my hubby. Such a nice place to sit and relax, peaceful, you can get peaceful and crowded both types.of environment at thos area, the garden walkimg throught is so peaceful and when you walk closed to the water side: you can see harber bridge and opera which is crowded.
