Beautiful and relaxing. If you are on your own, take a map. This is a large garden with many paths, each leading you to another area. There are many entrances and exits. My wife and I got lost, but were rescued by a friendly local. On our second visit, with a tour group, we saw other parts of the park. Give yourself several hours to just wander. Great views of the Bridge too.

Sydney's first market garden. when visiting Sydney, take time to breathe in the fresh air of Sydney's Royal Botanic Gardens situated on the edge of world famous Sydney Harbour. make sure to visit the offerings of the Botanic Garden Society where plants and information are on offer to all. A sheer delight and tranquil transportation in the middle of one of the world's busiest and most beautiful cities.
calm.. A nice place to stroll and picnic! Calm, beautiful and serene. Exotic plants, well laid out! Flying foxes are no more there.

A great walk away from the city. The Royal Botanical Gardens are beautiful. You get great views of the harbor and the city while beeing surounded by a great landscape. The colony of big bats that inhabit it are cool to see.Its a great way to get away from the city

A MUST EXPERIENCE!. Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney is the finest example of nature oasis within the Megalopolis. Beautiful at any time of the year and any season it offers you serenity, peace and beauty. Well designed, well looked after and well positioned. You can chose to spend your time there closer to the Harbour and water, or having picnic, or just lazing around on the manicured lawns in the shade of exotic trees. Do visit this place - you will be amazed and delighted!
Vast gardens with huge trees. The gardens were our first exposure to the beautiful nature in Australia. The huge ficus trees with the modern statues had us wondering for hours
Just beautiful. Grass and grounds so so beautiful relax, have lunch,or sit in awe at the real beauty of Sydney Harbour

a pretty good garden. these gardens are pretty good to look at. they are quite big and you would need a good amount of time to see all of it. there is a lovely seat which you can have a rest on and look at the beautifuil scenery.
Pleasant, well maintained. It's fantastic that you have such a great park with an even greater view of the opera house and the bridge.

Very Attractive and Centrally Located. The gardens are really very attractive with a great displays of plants and flowers and beautiful landscaping all located quite close to the city and adjacent to the harbor with very convenient and easy access.

Fabulous walking, plants and scenery. I covered this in a review on the opera house to the botanic gardens walk-it is all good, lots of beautiful scenery, pathways alongside the harbour and through the gardens, little bits of history sprinkled through botanical know how, and swallows flitting around us as we walked. Lots of fun and exercise for no cost.
Great time with the family!. We were surpised at how much our daughters enjoyed visiting the gardens. Free to enjoy the lush landscapes tucked away in the CBD.

A nice park in the middle of busy city. I am lucky to work near the Royal Botanic Gardens, and I spent a couple of lunch times a week with friends for exercising. It's free to enter, lots of native plantations to see and you will meet some fruit bats hanging down from tall trees.

Take your time and breath. This is an attraction that is mostly enjoyed if you have extra time. you toss and turn in each corner to find an exquisite native plant or flower. All this can be done over a cappuccino as well.

Beautiful!. And stunning views too. Clean and well-cared for.
I especially liked Mrs. Macquarie's Chair and the explanations.

Botanic Gardens. Spent a few hours here, just walking around and soaking up the sun and gardens. Worth a visit for a nice walk around with some scenic photos. Maybe go else where for a decent coffee and food. Worth the visit.
Worth a little time. The gardens were our route to the harbour and the opera house. By the scale of botanic gardens elsewhere, they are very extensive. Some very nice plants. Worth walking through.

WOW... amazing. This is a great green space in the middle of a busy city to allow you to rest, relax and unwind! You could walk around the grass, or look at the flowers, see the status, or watch the wildlife! we went there early one morning (only about 9 oclock or so) and walking through some of the grounds we saw some birds and went closer to get some better photos, but they were so comfortable around humans, my dad even put his hand out and they landed upon him (5 in total) one on his head, one of his shoulder and some along his arm. they were really colourful and beautiful to see :) I would highly highly recommend to go and see these gardens, you could go and see it for a\ short or long time its up to you, we went there a few times and its a great way to walk through inbetween placesas well as the viewpoint to see the opera houses! yes there were tourists but there was plenty of room to get a photo thats not crowed another wow point of sydney!!
Great city. Beautiful and peaceful. Don't forget to visit the Gouvernors House. It's free and gives an inside into history

Good Walk. We walked from our Hotel on Wentworth down Hyde Park to the Opera house.Great walk , historic buildings etc,Museum and Artgallery nearby.Gardens a little dry and needed more attention.Waterfront walk worthwhile.

fantastic place for a picnic. We took a picnic and sat on the lawn and admired the view. Our four year old loved the choo choo train and the wave sculpture that several kids played on. There are beautiful white cockatoos to admire flying from tree to tree.

The lungs of the City. After looping around the Opera House keep walking and at the waters edge the path leads through the gates of the Botanic Gardens. A wonderful green space in the heart of the city with everyone enjoying the lush planting clean walkways and fresh coastal breeze. Every city should have a park park this! Take a time out and stroll around here for a break from the big smoke.

Meandering. If your in Sydney definitely take a walk through the gardens. Tress as old as Sydney, flowers in bloom, water falls, stop for a coffee in the middle of the gardens. Plenty of photo opportunies. Very peaceful and rejuvenating considering its in the middle of Sydney.

A beautiful walk with wonderful Sydney views. We love walking around the gardens and sitting and enjoying the wonderful harbour views. It is a comfortable walk from the opera house. The gardens have done a great job of arranging spots to sit and details of the plant life.

Nice gardens, fantastic views. The botanic gardens are spread out over a a large area, and within the park it is very well signposted with lots of meandering walking paths. Walk along the sea wall path for fantastic views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge.

An island of relaxation. The Royal Botanic Garden is relaxed place just next to the hectic CBD. The great atmosphere is coming from the really different groups of people, the employees who are here for their lunch break, runners, sometimes a wedding party, tourists and a lot of playing kids. I love the variety of this place.

Fabulous, especially at sunrise, well worth it. I really enjoyed these Gardens, and took a ton of photos within them or of the Harbour/Opera House from these grounds. They are so peaceful, and beautiful. You really do not even go out of your way - these fabulous Gardens are literally in between the Opera House and the Fleet Steps / Mrs. Macquaries chair. One of my favorite Sydney photos is of the Ballerina statue at sunrise, if you take the photo looking towards the Harbour, the sun peaks through the trees with an orange glow and the ballerina looks like she is smiling towards it. Stunning. It's a garden of many interesting trees and plants (I visited in winter). Check out the Wishing Tree, make a wish, and learn where the phrase "touch wood" came from. See the tree blown on its side from the strong Harbour winds. Check out the terrific views of the Opera House with the Harbour bridge right behind it, from over near the Fleet Steps. It's just beautiful here, with benches all around for taking it in. A highlight for me in Sydney.

Enjoy the visual display of plants & trees. A great place to relax & sit in the sun & enjoy a diverse range of plants & trees. With the harbour in the background it is such a perfect place.The only downside would be the cafe ... Many choices on the menu board but not available. Burgers & chips seemed to be the only food available. Cakes/ muffins / sandwiches not available. At 2pm on a Sunday food should still be available.Staff not interested..take it or leave it... So we left & went to a cafe out of the gardens

Lovely in Every Season. We were here last during the Australian winter and didn't expect to see much. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The gardens are worth a visit in any season. It is a lovely place. One of the nicest botanical gardens anywhere.

Sydney's best kept secret!. Sydney's Royal Botanic Gardens is a must for all international and interstate visitors, and for Sydney residents as well.First, it is located near most of the most attractive icons of Sydney such as the Opera House, the Harbour Bridge, the Rocks, etc. Thus, it is convenient to walk to the Gardens when you are visiting Sydney's Opera House.Second, it is accessible by a variety of public transport such as buses and subways. If you get there by car, you can find metered parking at reasonably low costs.Third, the Gardens are very attractive in their own right. There are a variety of plants, trees, shrubs, and flowers from all over the world, including native ones. In fact, there is nothing more enjoyable than walking in the Gardens on a sunny afternoon, regardless of the season. Inside the Gardens, you can take photos with the beautiful Opera House in the background. This will serve as a nice reminder of your trip to Sydney.To us, the most enjoyable thing is the opportunity to feed birds including rainbow lorikeets and cockatoos. If you plan to do this, come with some mixed bird seeds although the cockatoos' favourite foo id sunflower seeds. You need to come to the right spot and If you are patient enough, the birds will come for sure.Importantly, there are no fees whatsoever to enter the Gardens.In short, if you are visiting Sydney, especially for the first time, please include its Royal Botanic Gardens in your itinerary.

Nice walk and views. The gardens are well cared for, and have nice walks. The views of sydney opera house are impressive. Would like to come back in a few years and see how the glass houses turn out. The succulents garden is very good too and best thing about it is that entry to the gardens is free.
Flower power in spring. Though we were there in July, there were already roses in bloom. Will be fantastic to stroll around in spring.

Beautiful place. Green and a lot of plant types to discover. I took photos of the plants and had to look up my botanical book to remind me of their names. The sculptures were amazing! From a corner of the Garden, I was very impressed by the beauty of the building where The British Medical Association NSW branch located in.

A world class venue with the beasutifully kept gardens bordering sydney's beautiful harbour.. Perfect for an afternoon stroll suitable for old and young alike, locals and tourists. Relaxing ambience among an exquisit selection of well kept flora some of which was plant possibly up to 200 years ago. Most plants are labelled. There are places to sit, lie down and relax or even a venue to jog and get fit.

AMAZING GARDENS!. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a mass of colour, even in winter when we visited. Each area is well explained and the signs leading to the various locations were excellent, as were the maps dotted around. It would be easy to spend a whole day here and I would like to come back in a different season to see the new planting.

So Very Beautiful. I LOVE this place. It was one of the highlights of our trip. Before coming to Sydney, we almost wanted to cross this place out from our list as we had so many things to look at. I am so glad we decided to come! The walk from Sydney Opera House to Mrs Macquerie's Chair is so beautiful and scenic, don't miss doing this! It takes only about 20 minutes at a slow pace.
Beautiful place. Very nice place, great scenery, very well kept, another must do in Sydney. Walk around and after through to the opera house, very scenic and great in the evening for the sun set.

Beautiful Gardens. We entered the gardens by Opera House and were amazed at the collection of flowers, shrubs and trees.It was wintertime yet still colourful flowers to be seen and each plant/tree was labelled and some information given so you were not thinking 'what was that?'. There are free maps of the gardens with clear routes around the main attractions but it is too easy to be distracted and amble elsewhere, as we did a lot! Even for those not keen on gardens it is hard to dislike this place as it has hidden statues, artwork and great views and photo opportunities of the Sydney skyline. It is also not far from Mrs Macquaries Chair which is worth a visit!A highlight was feeding wild lorikeets and cockatoos which make the gardens their home! Also look up high in the trees, you might see flying foxes sleeping!

So much to explore. We had a great time wandering around and exploring this beautiful garden. There is so much to see. I wish I could have seen more of it, but just didn't have the time. The Garden Shop was fun to look around in. Lots of unique items. Very nice shop. There is a cafe nearby too. Lots of interesting statues and many photo opportunities.

BEAUTIFUL!. We stayed in Sydney for 3 weeks and we found ourselves always heading to the same park almost every single day and spend at least 2 hours in this Beautiful park with our kids before heading to other places for lunch...Ohhh how we wish to have the same park back in our home :'(

A good flowery half a day. We took the walk from the Opera house to the botanic gardens. The garden entrance was very beautiful. This is a huge garden, so it is sort of impossible to walk the whole thing, so we took the train that takes you around the garden. You can get off and on when every you wish. They stop at all the main points. There are very few places to grab a drink or meal. There is very limited choice however. I would suggest you buy food before entering the gardens and you can have them while enjoying the views. The gardens provides probably the best view of Sydney harbour. We had a good half a day in the gardens. It is best to visit in the evening as it can get very hot and sunny during summer mornings.
A walk in the park. Beautifully kept gardens with walking paths throughout. Marvellous views of the Opera House and Harbour

Worth a visit. The Sydney RBG is one of the best botanic gardens to see. Nice selections of plants and brilliant views on the harbour, the opera house and the bridge. Bring some old bread to feed the Cockatoos and the Lorikeets!
very nice!. loved looking at the gardens and taking my time to enjoy the landscaping. Worth your time and take a nice stroll through the park.

Beautiful Place. A very beautiful place, it doesn't seem as big as it actually is. We had lots of fun there with my family. The only thing is the Gates close at sunset and it's hard to get out. Watch out for that. :)

Beautiful Gardens. On a beautiful Sydney winters day we took the ferry from Manly over to Circular Quay and walked up Moore Steps and over to the Botanic Gardens. Great for kids and adults alike it's must do walk to enjoy the sites and sounds of the harbor. Make sure you visit the cafe and or Resturant. There is also a fantastic sculpture by New Zealand artist Chris Booth - Wurrungwuri. Waves of rock cascade down the lawns - magical!

Beautiful! Simply stunning.. When in Sydney you must visit the gardens and surrounding parks. Very short stroll from circular quay. Nice easy walking paths and gorgeous gardens. You can visit govt house, (tours between 9 and 3 pm) or simply stroll around the outside. Magestic trees,gardens meticulously maintained, views to die for across the harbour and opera house. Must do when in town.

Wonderful way to while away some Sydney time. Crossing busy Macquarie St you can enter into a very different world from the busy one that is Sydney. The Royal Botanic Gardens are situated around Farm Cove, with free guided walks offered each day. Go with a guide or simply enjoy the walk on your own, it doesn't matter. The scenery will speak for itself as you go from the Sydney Opera House around to Mrs Macquaries Chair and beyond.

Wandering around. Spent a day wandering around the gardens when the weather wasn't that good. Gorgeous views and brilliant scenery. We spent a lot of time walking around, and I mean a lot. Well worth it though.
Lovely,with great views of the Harbour. Beautiful gardens and walks.Huge old trees,beautiful rose garden.Nice cafe in the gardens,but great for a picnic

An Oasis.. Beautifully manicured, easliy navigated, clearly signposted, and a majestic setting. Plenty of seating and also many grassed areas. Plenty of specialized gardens, such as herb, rose, succulents, etc. Had a great day here, and glorious weather.

Take the Choo Choo Express. After walking all around circular key and the opera house we fancied a look at the botanic gardens. It was bitterly cold so when we walked in the gates and saw the Choo Choo Express we hopped on. It is a 25 minute ride through the gardens with an interesting commentary pointing out the highlights. You can hop on and off at 4 stopping points and spend extra time at any point that interests you. We chose to stay on the train mainly due to the cold and blustery weather. Well worth it and meant we got to see most of the gardens and learned some interesting history along the way. Really good for people who don't want to walk or those like us with limited time to spend in the gardens.

Beautiful plants well labeled, beautiful views. Wonderful place for an afternoon. The gardens are well tended and beautiful. The views in the garden and across the harbor are wonderful. It is a lively place with many folks walking, jogging and exercising, and bird watching. The Fern garden and Succulent garden are must sees. Even in winter (late July) there were many northern hemisphere spring flowers, the tulips were blooming. The gift shop was pretty nice too.
No Flowers. The Botanic Gardens is just a big park; very little flowers, if any. The two buildings that would have house flowers were closed until 2015!

Excellent gardens. I hadn't known much about the botanic gardens and was very pleasantly surprised. Incredibly well maintained, ornate gardens - and just importantly - they encourage you to 'experience them' by walking on the grass, touching the plants, etc., which makes it a great place to hang out, have a picnic, or take a jog. Great views too.

Photographers Paradise. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney are a MUST visit for anyone who loves photography. Everywhere you turn you'll spot something beautiful that you want to treasure - from flowers to sculptures to birds and animals. The Royal Botanic Gardens has it all!Also - it should be noted that this place is big! I'd recommend planning to stay there for at least 3-4 hours (or even more!).
Great garden. Never gets disappointed by this place, always nice view and beautiful flowers. Very relaxing and cosy, favorite place to go while gets stressed.

Peace and green in the city centre. It is always fascinating to visit Botanical Gardens in cities around the world and to see the different plants which grow in different environments. It is also fascinating to see the different birds and animals often found in gardens. However Sydney Botanical Gardens has the added attraction of its superb location, right beside the harbour, THE bridge and THE Opera House. Definitely recommended, perhaps the first thing to do on your first visit to Sydney. The walk through the garden and emerging beside the harbour and those iconic sights is something special!

Beautiful, relaxing walk & Free!. The Royal Botanical Gardens are wonderful to walk through. There are several paths to wander through the gardens at your own pace. There is a Palm Garden, Fern Garden, Herb Garden, ponds and much more. You can see CBD on one side and the harbor on the other. You will see and hear many birds (all ones we have not seen before being from the States). There are guided tours and a train for the young ones. It is a great place for a picnic.
Beautiful walk. Really enjoyed our afternoon wandering around the gardens even the rain didnt dampen the spirits, have a sit down in the cafe too for a rest.

Relaxing. Went for a walk to the gardens , you can walk to the opera house from the gardens, I went in winter time so not much to see on the trees and flowers weren't in full bloom but it was nice all the same :)!

Just OK. If you like gardening, rain forests etc, then you will not be disappointed.
The hardens are beautifully laid out and presented.....just not my sort of thing, but had to visit.

Stunning. I loved walking along the water. The park was beautifully manicured and cared for, and very clean. It's also a great park for picnics, and to take children. It's also in a wonderful location - close to the harbour, if you then decide to take the ferry somewhere and make a day of it.

Fantastic!!. This has to be one of the most beautiful places in Sydney and it is free!!!You can just wander in off the street and take in the beautiful plants and flowers. The scenery is also fantastic and you can get great photos of the Harbour Bridge & Opera House from spots along the seawall. You can get a little train from the Opera House entrance but we didn't see it until too late so walked! Try to avoid going at lunchtime though as half of Sydney seems to be jogging then!! The café and shop are worth a visit as well and the staff in the shop were really helpful and nothing seemed too much trouble.Well worth a visit.

Beautiful gardens. Excellent walk through the gardens from our hotel making a roundabout route to the Opera House. Many beautiful trees, plants and exotic birds. Then along the edge of the sea/river to the Opera house.

Good for photography. There's a spot where you can snap the Harbour Bridge and Sydney Opera House together - it's called the Mrs Macquarie's Point. While walking there (I used the entrance near Opera House), it's possible to get nice shots of the sea. The stone wall is good for C curves.

Wonderful Place. From our hotel the RBC was on the route to so many sites, so we made a point to go through every day. It has areas for roses, and cactus, etc. Even in Fall it is beautiful. On Saturday there were at least 6 different wedding parties. In the evening, if you look close you can see Australian possums nestled in the tree branches.
Take A Camera. Spend a few hours walking around soaking up the various plants and trees indigenous to Australia. A really relaxing day- however watch out for rather large spiders.
An oasis in the City. Wonderful to wander around, beautifully tidy and clean. Highlight was to watch a wedding going on at the time. what a stunning setting to get married.
A gentle walk. Lovely walk on a cold spring day, great "rock" play ground for young children and little restrain for the oldies.

Peaceful Sydney. It is always a pleasure to walk through the gardens. We have done it many times, and there is always something different to see... flowers, shrubs and trees... no matter what time of the year. It was disappointing this time (middle of Winter) that the tropical display (pyramid) was closed for refurbishment!

Spectacular Gardens. A stroll through these gardens is a feast. They are huge and have views across the harbour. They contain Government House and the Art Gallery. A stroll takes you down to the Opera house. You could spend most of your day here. The variety of plants is wondrous and photo opportunities abound.

Family walk. I think this is my husband's favourite area of Sydney. He loves to walk through this garden. We walked from Martin Place down to the Opera House. The kids had a great romp. The rose garden is beautiful.

my favourite botanic gardens. I visited the botanic gardens while there and found it to be my favorite botanic gardens ever visited. Its huge and there's amazing trees around every corner. They have some huge trees which if your lucky you can climb :)

Incredible tropical gardens in the heart of Sydney. Simply incredible. To have such an expanse of green full of wildlife in the heart of a major city is quite a gift. The selection of tropical plants is quite extensive, and all sort of birds can be spotted quite close. Definitely a nice way to spend a few hours in the afternoon to get a break from the busy city or its shopping district.

Mid-morning walk. We walked from the gate near the State Library to the one leading to Mrs Macquarie’s Chair mid-morning recently. The roses are still blooming, the lawns and garden beds were in good order and the water was sparkling. This is an easy and beautiful walk which was being enjoyed by several groups, some apparently local, other tourists. The highlight was the abundant birdlife and the variety of birds which could be seen and heard. We often walk later in the day from near the Opera House to the gates near the Art Gallery which is pleasant, but the earlier time was special.
Stunning. Easy walking, Sydney's best views, free and easy. A must do when in Sydney. Take a picnic, pop in or explore in detail, the views are the best and the ambiance is unrivalled.
Nice park. Nice park for a walk around. Good place for children as well. Some interesting species of plants can be viewed.
Beautiful. We timed it so that we had a guided tour conducted by a volunteer. Really well done. A great walk along the boardwalk. Worth visiting.
Beautiful. Gorgeous gardens with plenty of wildlife and side trails to explore. Beautiful views and plenty of places to enjoy a picnic.
Wide garden. It is very wide garden. Grassfield, many kind of birds, very interesting. But I didn't feel speciality. I think it's just park which have nothing in particular.

Beautiful accessible gardens. We loved that we could so easily visit the gardens after walking around the Opera House. The gardens offer great views of different parts of the harbour, some interesting wild birdlife, good sculptures and plantings. Take the time to visit government house too, the gardens there are beautiful.

Wonderful place for a stroll. I spent a few hours strolling through the gardens on my last morning in Sydney. A great place for walking or a run. The gardens are beautiful and there are wonderful views if the Opera House and Sydney harbor. There's also a nice cafe for a snack.

Stunning. We spent a few hours roaming the truly gorgeous grounds with so many diverse plantings. Our favorite was the fern house and the cactus garden. Very unique huge trees, lovely old fountains, lots of birds and rare flowers. Be sure to check out the eel pond. We sat for 10 minutes and never saw one but when I went over to the edge they swam right up and poked their heads out. Most were about 3 feet long and establish themselves each time the pond is drained was kinda creepy but really cool.
A lovely place to wander through. Beautiful views and a wonderful way to spend a morning or afternoon walking along the harbour and taking in the most amazing views
The birds are the best. I heard so much birdsong and saw really unusual birds. There were tiny ones with expressive yellow eyes and large white and black - storks, I think - and so many more.

Peaceful walk away from city crowds. We always love walking through the Botanic Gardens. You get expansive lawns that the kids love running through, enormous trees that the kids love checking out and magnificent views of the bay. Watch out for the little train coming down the main path.
Great place. Brilliant place for picnics over looking the Harbour`,no dislikes.Can view Government House most days...saw a couple of weddings taking place.
A walk through Aussie History and story.. Glimpses of the harbour, green rolling lawns, delightful walled garden, aboriginal gardens, sculpture and a sense of history.

Batty for Botanics. A wonderful way to relax in Sydney is to stroll through the Royal Botanic Gardens and take in all the beautiful flora and fauna. My favourite? The bats -- rather, the grey-headed flying foxes, a large species of fruit bat. They are incredible creatures and there are thousands of them! The gardens are a truly magnificent jewel in a towering metropolis.
Best place in Sydney. This is honestly the best place to sit and ponder/picnic/relax with a book in the sun/walk in nature and just be at one with the moment.
Like the great city gardens of the world. The Botanic Gardens are to Sydney what Central Park is to New York and Hyde Park is to London. Its a great place to unwind and relax while enjoying nature.

Beautiful Day makes all the difference. This over-whelming botanical masterpiece, is for mine, one of Sydney's most incredible attractions. What a stunning counter-point to all those vertical concrete Phallic offerings.Bet you anything, you feel like a child again , after an hour or so drifting in this super-oxygenated playground ! If you want to get cerebral , you can study-up on the botanical names, of some of our most loved and iconic trees and aussie flora, via the well maintained signage all over the park.See the Opera House and the Harbour, from a totally different angle.Villa Borghese and Hyde Park are all very nice in their way, with a sense of history that is unmatched, but on a warm, summer day in the city , nothing can put you more in-touch, more quickly, with the notion of what it's like living in Australia, than an a few hours spent exploring this living gem.

Great place to chill, go for a run or picnic!. The gardens are well kept and has view of the harbour. Great place to go for a wander around, have a picnic or a run. Great green area in the middle of a big city.

A bit of relaxation in the Big City. Nice kept gardens with various walking tracks around the park, great views looking over different parts of Sydney make it a worth while visit for an hour or two and even better that you can grab a little bit of peace and quite before heading back to the hustle and bustle of the Oprah house or Darling harbor.Do try the cafe or restaurant in the park the food and coffee is wonderful

Great views over the Harbour. We spent a couple of hours walking around these beautiful gardens, still didn't see it all, the views over the Harbour are fantastic. We loved the beautiful Rose Garden, took heaps of photos. A little oasis in the middle of a very busy City.

A nice afternoon with my 2yr old.. This was a great afternoon spent relaxing and strolling around with my daughter. The food and drinks are priced as expected and the different paths around the gardens leading you to open grassed areas you could sit were pretty. It is a clean beautiful garden perfect for taking your time and relaxing.

what a sight. I found it a gorgeous arrangements of plants flowers and the way it has been set out, spectacular. There is many walkways it tells you what is there and how long it takes. There is spots to just sit for a bit and take in the beautiful site I would recommend you go and have a look.

Wonderful, free attraction. We enjoyed getting up early every morning to take a walk through this beautiful park. The park is very well maintained and extremely clean. It reminded us of Stanley Park in Vancouver. Great break from the congestion of the city!

Great even in winter!. We had a great walk through the botanical gardens. We didn't expect to see flowers and such in winter but the wide expanse of green and varieties of trees both local and imported were breathtaking. It seems like a great place for an afternoon run, or a picnic. There are plenty of places to sit down and rest your feet. We also rode the 'train' at my daughter's insistence. While the train driver is an informative guide, that part is skippable.

Outstanding Garden. We truly enjoyed the garden and plant and the flowers were blossomed and shining in the daylight. Truly amazing experience. The coffee shop and pastry were excellent during the break. Make sure plan a ahead and give plenty of time so you can enjoy the full expereince

Love the Cactus Garden. Sydney's Botanic Gardens has many precincts and any moods: It has its waterfront which buzzes with people perambulating, jogging and enjoying the views of the harbour. It has large open grassy areas with duck ponds and nearby kiosk where families love to picnic. There is a glass pyramid for plants requiring a specially humid environment. There is a jungle area to get lost in. I love the First Settlement Garden, complete with scarecrows, which has attempted to replicate the plants which were grown at that time. The Museum is worth a visit. Nearby you can purchase plants instead of surreptitiously taking cuttings from plants on your way around. It is from here that you can join tours of the gardens, also worth considering. Near to the Museum is the walled Succulent Garden, which is locked up at night. I love this precinct and over the years have watched it grow to maturity. The Succulent Garden was my destination on this day when I slipped into the gardens while I was on a visit to the nearby Art Gallery of NSW. Some sculptures have been added more recently which provide an interesting counterpoint to the myriad of cacti to be found there. In my mind succulents remind me of undersea plants which seem to have to solve the same challenges as cacti: how to retain moisture and withstand a high salt environment. I love the structure of succulents. In a way they look almost like alien creatures lost on a distant world. This part of the garden has now created its own ambiance, and when you enter this gated garden you feel as though you could be slipping into another dimension. It seems so far removed from anything else in this temperate zone in which Sydney sits. Photo opportunities here are surreal.

Free Garden Tour. We took the free garden tour which started about 10AM. Our guide was quite informative and did an excellent job keeping our small group involved, The weather was good although a bit overcast. Plan accordingly if you make the walk in the hotter Sydney summer months.
Pretty Walk in the City. A nice way to spend an afternoon breaking up the view of skyscrapers. There is also access to the government house, which looks like a small castle

Beautiful place to watch the sunset over the harbour. We went for a little walk from the back of the opera house around 3pm and the light was fantastic. The scenery is stunning as is the view back across to the bridge and the harbour. The walk to mrs Macquarie's chair is just a nice length. We even saw a pod of wild dolphins in the bay which was amazing.

was expecting more. been to a few parks and gardens in Australia and was quite disappointed by the royal botanic gardens. If i were to compare this with the one in Tasmania, its just too far in comparison. no flowers around to be seen, and towards the end, when we reach the rose garden, it was not taken care of either. it a nice huge park to chill but it wasn't the garden i was expecting.

Wonderful. The Botanic Gardens are terrific. I love to run around the gardens but, for others they are perfect for the views (Mrs Macquarie's chair to the Opera House and Bridge), picnics and walks. Not to be missed!
Birds!. I'm not a birder, but it was astounded by the flocks of cockatoo and other interesting birds. Plantings, of course, are beautiful, too. A relaxing walk.

Beautiful. The well-maintained and lush green (what else?) RBG was a sight to behold. We were taken there as a part of the City Tour of Sydney and in those minutes we spent there, the sights were breathtaking. The sights what one gets to see in / from Mrs. Macquarie's Chair were even more impressive and offered a nice closure to the quick tour of the RBG.

amazing. Good olace to have a romantic picnic or have a stroll and look at garden and amazing flowers. I would recimmend people to check it out if you have time or even if your in the area and want to get away from the main tourist places. This is a place where you would hardly see a lot of people or a place that doesnt get packed
A little bit of paradise. We strolled through the gardens on our way down to Mrs McQuires chair. Very beautiful. Very clean and very well kept glad we found time to pay a visit

Loved it!. That was one of my favourite parts of Sydney. It is very chilled, there are lots to see around the gardens and also a great view of the harbour. So if you need a day to relax and wanna feel like you are not in a "big" city, this is the place.

Finest botanical garden view out there. I try to make visiting botanic gardens a goal for most cities I visit. And really, this is the finest in 10+ years of travel thus far. Completely free, though locals can support with membership. They encourage you to walk on the grass. Botany buffs will love the inner path unique species (though the tropical house is closed for renovations). Walkers/runners will love the harbor views of the Opera House and bridge. Easily could spend a half-day here, as across the street is downtown for lunch and shopping. We didn't do a guided tour and with travel guides don't feel like anything was lost. Really an amazing Sydney treasure.

A must see in Sydney. Relaxing,educational and just a beautiful place to be in the midst of such a busy city.Great place to exercise, learn about the plants in the garden or just chill out with a good book or have lunch.
You forget you are in the city. A lovely sanctuary where you can escape city life and indulge in the manicured gardens. A 'must do' while in Sydney

Great place to run. Perfect place for a morning run. Away from the traffic and exhaust fumes of the Central Business District and beautiful scenery. You can run over to the Opera House and then up the harbour bridge for a great workout.

A Must see in Sydney. The gardens are a treat not to be missed. You will enjoy every moment and you can also eat at the cafe on the grounds. Spend at least a half a day walking these gardens and visit on a Friday, Saturday, or Sunday so you can visit the Government House which is on the grounds.

Royal Gardens Tour. This was a great tour after hiking the Opera House area. A free tour with lots of info on the dates and sequence of imported plant life that forms the Australian agricultural history. A very enjoyable ride in a miniature locomotive with informative and entertaining tour guides.

Do a Free Guided Tour!. The gardens are beautiful, but it's hard to really appreciate them fully unless you really know what you're looking at. Our tour guide was so knowledgeable and fun, we didn't want our tour to end!
Take a picnic and go near sunset. Such a tranquil place perfect late afternoon even in winter. Take a rug and a picnic very romantic but great place just to sit and watch the beautiful harbour

Beautiful, even in bad weather. It was raining and cold during our walk here, and still it was gorgeous. And compared to the Hunter Valley Garden that cost a lot to visit, this place was more pleasant and would have been considerably more pleasant in good weather. As a birder I found the bird life surprisingly diverse in the center of a major city.I'm sure had we been able to visit in spring or summer, I'd have rated it excellent. I Highly recommend it.

Lovely walks and so much to see.. We walked along the harbour edge and also cut in to see some of the other areas but really it is so vast and every season there will be something different so whatever the time of year do take some time to visit. Being so close to the city centre it is full of office workers out for a jog or lunchtime walk.
Beautiful!. Spent a day in the city wandering around the gardens, harbor, opera house, and the art museum. Had some great shops to eat at and was very easy to navigate.

Beautiful gardens, a must for tourists. The gardens are simply beautiful no matter what time of year. We recently attended a wedding in the gardens and what a back drop... The Sydney Harbour! If you are a tourist, the gardens are definitely worth visiting to enjoy the scenery. They are also close to many of the Sydney's finest hotels and restaurants.

A good walk around. We've been there each trip, and we still love the quite park with not too many people around. The trees are evergreen and the path leads to Lady Macquarie's Chair where you get the best view of the Skyline, Opera House and Bridge in a single glance!

A Quiet Haven in the City. We did not plan to visit the Botanic Gardens as it was raining that day. But what a gem! We drove into the gardens as the rain lifted -- the greenery was lush and the air was crisp. The views of the harbor, the Opera House, the Harbour bridge was spectacular. We visited in the late afternoon, with the golden rays of the sun shimmering on the water, you can imagine the beautiful sight -- not to be missed !

A great way to enjoy the City. This is an easy walk through the gardens and there is so much happening with gardeners managing the plants and birds floating around! It is a peaceful area of the city and one that allows you to walk with a family and enjoy the surroundings.
Lovely and peaceful. The gardens are gorgeos, there is plenty of plants to look at, a duck pond, statues, take a picnic and enjoy the serenity

Different experience. From a magneficent opera house, we walked to the royal botanic garden to relax. Although weve been to alot of gardens already the experience in royal botanic garden is different. We take a ride for a kiddie train for the tour in the garden. You can purchase the tickets right in the entrance gate. The tour was fun and very interesting.

Slotted in right next to the city. The Sydney Botanic Gardens are nicely places, being right near the CBD and easily reached from Hyde Park and the CBD area. In fact if you took in the ANZAC Memorial, Hyde Park, St Marys Cathedral, the NSW Art Gallery and the Botanic Gardens, thence proceeding along to the Opera House to view that world famous building you'd have filled a number of hours for free apart from food & drinks.As to the gardens themselves they are lush and green of course, there are a range of features and a café and a shop. The whole garden slopes away from the CBD down to the harbour and there is a plethora of walkways. Free guided walks are available - check the website for times - and punters are encouraged to loll about on the grass to their hearts content.Given it is free, easily accessible and can be used as a thoroughfare between different Sydney attractions this is a place you should find yourself in if you have the time.

Relaxing place to walk around. The gardens are serene and an nice place to while away an hour or two. We were a bit disappointed because we had gone in search of a colony of flying foxes which had been relocated.
Beautiful. The gardens are very beautiful, but personally I think some more attractions for children could be added.

Sydneys Royal Boyanic Gardens. What a fantastic way to walk away a few hours right on the cities doorstep. Also taking in the views across the harbour. From majestic trees to the fantastic succulent garden and everything in between. The gardens are signposted very well for easy navigation around. Take a camera as photo ops are everywhere. Highly recommended.

Beautiful peaceful botanic gardens. What can I say? Better than the average botanical gardens due to location location location. Reasonably peaceful [depending on your company at the time I guess] & beautiful gardens & momuments, bird life etc. And after a time you reach Circular Quay & the opera house, bridge, what's not to love. Even if you want a break from the noise & pace & smokers of Sydney, take a pit stop.

relaxing. The Royal Botanical Gardens would have to be the most relaxing place to just take a stroll and forget about everything else . Just wander down to Lady Macquaries Chair and just sit and watch the harbour and the bird life then wander back around to The Opera House and chill out over a coffee at one of the many establishments .
Hug the trees. Beautiful gardens. Most impressive was the warm welcome - signs encourage you to "please walk on the grass, hug the trees" and otherwise enjoy the gardens. Beautiful harbour views

Must Visit when In Sydney. Yes go here. The equivalent of Central Park of New York, but cleaner , more colorful , and fresher. It is the best huge parcel of fresh garden you will find at the Sydney CBD. You get a view of the bay, north and east of the garden. You get a view of the Harbour bridge at the west. Beautiful flowers, big trees, lush green grass, and manicured flower arrangements . Nice birds in the area. You may lounge and sit on the grass . If you have time , pass "Mrs Macquarie's chair" on the north-east side of the garden and see the Farm Cove. There are free tours of the garden which run at about 10:30 am and I believe 1pm. There is also a little train ride which goes around for $10 a head (starting from the Opera House). The garden is a good way to approach the Opera house from the south. And the best part of it is it's Free! Loved it!

Peaceful and Charming. I only had one day in Sydney before we boarded our cruise ship so our time was limited, but this was worth every bit of it. It was relaxing, clean, and absolutely stunning. This is great place for photo's of the opera house and sydney bridge. I usually never go to Botanic Gardens but this place was amazing. It is also located behind the opera house. This is a must see in Sydney.

It's a beautiful place to be. If you want to spend a day outside, Royal Botanic Gardens is a perfect place to be. We enjoy the plants, the scenery, the atmosphere and the views over the Sydney icons every time we visit this lovely place.

You Mustn't Miss It!. This place is an icon, and you really have to pay it a visit. It's a completely free and huge public park, complete with rose gardens, gazebos, an orchid greenhouse, as well as several additional greenhouses for specific plant genuses. The park is also home to giant flocks of cockatoos, and a couple thousand flying foxes. Look up into the treetops as you walk through the park and you'll see them hanging, waiting for dusk. If you are near the park at dusk, stick around for a few minutes and watch the bats depart, off to find food. Watching the swarm fly overhead is pretty amazing. I have to caution against feeding any of the birds, though. You'll think it's fun and endearing until a few hundred cockatoos surround you (several of which will land on you) demanding food for themselves. I saw many tourists get mobbed, and it wasn't pretty. You've been warned.

Fabulous place to get a nice walk in. Lovely views from the park. Not too much in the way of play stuff for little children but there are green hills to roll down if it's not damp underfoot. There is a little train that runs half hourly that is $10 for adults and $5 for kids. That was a lot of fun.

Botanical gardens peaceful and interesting. The gardens are quite extensive which means you can be here for as long as you like. There is sometimes events on which can be quite interesting to go to so watch out for these. Some signs on the trees to tell you what they are and lots of spider webs! But don't worry they don't get in your way! We went to government house which i would highly recommend with an included tour but take your passport with you!
good. nice open feel right in the middle of the city.walked around most too late to do the house but headed back to harbour as it started to rain

Beautiful locations with stunning views. These gardens are located in a fantastic location with stunning views of the Harbour bridge, opera house and the Sydney CBD. The gardens are world class and definitely worth a vist especially in spring.

Important part of Sydney. I have always lived in Sydney and have visited the gardens from time to time all my life. They are an iconic Sydney landmark. What a wonderful position with views of the harbour and Opera House! The gardens are beautifully maintained and full of interesting exotic and native plants, many with labels and information signs. It includes the site of the first farm in Australia made by the "First Fleet" in 1788. It's worth looking for the spot near a little bridge over the creek. The kiosk wasn't great (only place to buy food) but I think there are renovations taking place there and the pyramid grreenhouse for exotic tropical plants is being rebuilt. I recommend the Botanic gardens to visitors to our city and aso to residents looking for a pleasant walk or picnic.

The the largest lawn in a major city. Sydney botanical garden houses not just an amazing array of flora and fauna. In close proximity to Sydney's world famous harbour, Parliament house, the National Gallery of New South Wales, the Conservatorium of music, and the State library this is the place to lie back relax enjoy the sky in the middle of 5 million people.

Stroll through the Botanic Gardens. The weather was unusually warm and the pace a slow stroll to suit the young children. As usual, plenty to keep us all interested from plants, trees, landmarks, others walking/running and various birds.

Peaceful gardens. Lovely place to just wander about. Lots to see and thoroughly enjoyed the walk through. The birds were fascinating the spiders we spotted in the trees we gave a wide birth to but the place is lovely.
Peaceful. Great place to walk and see the most beautiful plants. Great location and make sure you enough time as this garden is very large and peaceful

Little Heaven in the City. The walks are well signed and there is a train if you get tired with plenty of explanations, tales and history :-) It was fun to spend time there. Beautiful trees and don't forget to see the Eels...

Some suggestions on how to see the Botanic Gardens. I've worked in the Sydney CBD for over 20 years and for the last 15 years located in building directly across from the main entrance to the Gardens. I visit the Gardens at least twice a week, all year round. Here are four suggestions on how to enjoy the Gardens: (A) Walk from the Opera House around to Lady Macquarie's Chair. For the return walk, choose a random side path up into the Gardens, checkout all of the unusual plants and try to find some random quiet spot. Nice!(B) Walk on the grass. There's lots of grass, an unlike parks in other countries, you can walk on it all. Or sunbake. All with a view of the harbour. Relax!(C) Have breaky or lunch at the Palace Gate Cafe. This little gem is located on Macquarie Street just outside the Palace Gate entrance near the rose garden. It's cash only, very inexpensive but good value, great owner (open daily weekdays 8 am-5 pm and Saturdays 9.30 am-4.30 pm, closed Sundays). You have to like 'rustic' to enjoy the cafe. Yum!(D) Go running. This is how most of the locals enjoy the Gardens. You can choose any path you like, and also try sections of the Domain (a park located East of the Gardens - just as scenic though!). Help to work off that yummy cafe meal!

Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney. A must see on your visit to Sydney.On the edge of Sydney Harbour and right next door to the Opera House.Catch the little train that departs at regular intervals to tour the gardens or wear a pair of comfortable shoes for walking.Fantastic number of trees, shrubs, plants and statues to see ( and ducks on the lake- no feeding please).Food available within the grounds or bring a picnic.A life time memory of your visit.Bill M

Tomatoes in the garden. I have visited the gardens. Many times in the past, but my last visit was to the Tomato Expo held by Diggers Seeds. Imagine this, beautiful sunny day, not too hot or humid, sun sparkling on the water, smiling faces everywhere. A friend and I went up to Sydney by train as the gardens are only a step away from the station at Martin Place. We went up for the Tomato Expo, and the highlight was Costas joining us when we had our lunch (home-made sandwiches) . My friend used to own a garden nursery, and when visitors to the gardens realised she knew the plants, our progress was slow but we met some great people. When we got tired we had a cup of excellent coffee at the cafe, we sat outside and watched birds playing in a little water run- off. Then home. A long day but memorable.

Great Garden. Just a wonderful garden! I went to the one in Melbourne and just adored it but this one brings it to a whole other level! Youll need a few hours to walk around the whole garden, but its well worth it! You can finish the whole thing with a drink at the harbour which is right next to the park!
Relaxing with a great backdrop. Beautiful established gardens that are good to get away from the city in. You can relax on the grassed areas and see the view of Sydney Harbour.

great gardens in the middle of sydney!. this is so amazing that such lush gardens are right in the heart of a huge city. very mature growth and beautiful peaceful setting, i love walking around here. there are bathrooms and food places or you can take a picnic..

Make Sure You Plan This into Your Sydney Trip. I LOVE Royal Botanic Gardens. It defines my Sydney trip!We spent hours in this garden, enjoying the rolling hills, paths, beautiful trees, the magnificent view of Sydney Harbour and city skyline. We had lunch at the cafe in the garden and we enjoyed the relaxing atmosphere. The garden is full with people, families enjoying quality time together, friends having great picnic, couples holding hands, tourists take tons of pictures...... Lively and peaceful at the same time. For tourists that wish to take the best picture of Sydney Opera House, do plan a trip to Mrs. Macquarie's Chair in the morning. I went in the afternoon and this beautiful building was a backlit subject. It was hard to take touristy "here-I-am" photos.

Some peace right next door to the main attraction... The Botanical Gardens are a great place to retreat to away from the bustling city and nearby Opera House and Circular Quay tourist attractions. The gardens house a wide variety of botanical delights but my special fave is a colony of small butterflies which have lived in a particular spot in the gardens since the 1800's!

Beautiful wedding venue for a wedding-Royal Botanical Gardens Restaurant. My daughter held her wedding reception here following her wedding in the gardens last October.From the first contact with their wedding planner to the last of the actual evening, the staff were considerate and helpful with all our needs.The food tasting was a definite highlight and enabled tasting of the whole range of courses available so that we could make our selection.The actual menu was a great success with our guests (including the vegetarian options that were needed).The service on the evening was excellent.I would definitely recommend the venue for a wedding reception. The view of the gardens through the open verandah was beautiful and relaxed and just the atmosphere that my dughter was looking for.Having the whole gardens to ourselves at night was magical. We were lucky enough to have booked on a night when there were fireworks in the harbour and the wedding party went down to the harbour's edge to see them with the best view in Sydney all to themselves-very special.A few things to think of though.Getting out of the gardens at night you must leave by only one gate near Mrs Macquarie's Chair end which can be quite a walk for elderly or disabled guests (the restaurant arranged for the security golf cart for those that needed it but depending on numbers can be a bit of a wait). There are few taxis availble late at night. Parking is limited at the exit area although you can purchase parking at a reduced price from the normal meter price from the restaurant in advance. The Domain parking is closest and you may want to send the driver on ahead to collect the car and drive back to the gate to pick the passengers up.Guests may need some refreshments after the ceremony if there is a gap between the actual ceremony and when the restaurant opens for the evening especially if the weather is warm. There are companies that service this for weddings in the gardens.I would certainly recommend this venue for those seeking a smaller (we had about 85) wedding reception, (but they can do larger numbers and also cocktail menus for large groups)-fine also if there are children- that still retains an intimate garden atmosphere in a modern setting with a beautiful, stunning environment as a major bonus.We also had a meal at the resturant during its normal opening hours as a trial prior to selecting it and we were equally impressed then.

A Beautiful Thing Do. The gardens are beautiful with many different flowers and greenery to loo at. There are different paths you can take- each one lovely. There are bridges and buildings to look at en route to. The best part for me is the view back to the harbour. For me this the best place to view the Opera House and bridge. The gardens are sign posted so you can't get lost. Defintely visit the gardens.
Gorgeous Gardens. When you've done all else in Sydney there is always a place to unwind in Australia's first garden. Stunning scenery, aged trees and a wonderful to relax. An oasis in a vibrant city.

Quiet and beautiful retreat in city centre. Just minutes from Sydney CBD you'll find the Royal Botanic Gardens. Enjoy the stunning harbour views and walking paths that bring you to the water's edge. Sit quietly and rest during a busy day of walking the city. Picnic on the expansive lawns, check out the duck pond with the children, marvel at the variety of beautiful plants of lunch in the garden cafe. There's something for everyone. Start at the Opera House and walk into the gardens- adjoining, or commence at the art gallery or walk across the domain from Macquarie Street. Easily accessible, suitable for prams,spend on hour or a day. I have visited many times; alone and with the family. It never disappoints.

Perfect for a picnic in beautiful gardens. Walking through the gardens is breathtaking. Pack a picnic basket and spend the day in this beautifully peaceful surrounding. Great little cafes to grab a coffee or something to eat if you don't feel like a picnic. A wonderful day out. Perfect for everyone.

Botanical Gardens Sydney. Beautiful gardens with lakes, ponds, most glorious species of all kinds of birds, ducks, benches to sit on and view the gardens. The walk is wonderful. One direction leads to the famous and awesome Opera House. You can walk right up to it. The other side goes via the city and one can see the ships in Woolloomooloo. There's a coffee shop, in the grounds where you can sit and enjoy yourself for a while. A train will take you round if you don't feel like the walk. Amazing plants and gardens. I love the trees, all so different. Always something happening in the gardens. Very peaceful and tranquil. Lots of joggers to be seen too.

A peaceful oasis in the city. The Botanic Gardens in the spring time are a real delight, with many colourful flower displays as well as the more formal ponds and gardens. There are plenty of grassy areas too, for picnics and for the children to run around and explore, with always the spectacular backdrop of the Harbour, with its many boats and ferries to watch.

Leisurely stroll around the garden. What an afternoon a leisurely stroll around these magnificent gardens. I can't believe how well maintained the gardens and buildings are it is a credit to the staff.

Beautiful throughout the year. Love walking through Sydney's Botanical Gardens. From the gorgeous statues placed throughout the lavish gardens to the magnificent view of Sydney Harbour there is always something wonderful to see. A short stroll, an leisurely picnic or some theatre. There's something for everyone.

So peaceful.... I took my mum for a walk through the gardens on her birthday, just for something different. We wandered along various paths, admiring the garden beds and beautiful trees. The rose garden was lovely, as was the herb garden nearby, but the star attraction - for me - was The Fernery. My late father's handy work is immortalised here, as he built the structure some 20+ years ago. It was very special for me to see, for the first time.You can easily spend a few hours walking around the many sections, enjoy a picnic or pop into the cafè for morning tea or lunch.So relaxing.

Green grass, rolling hills and views. The walk through the gardens took several hours, the rolling hills with sculptures, artwork, eel-filled ponds, and large variety of birds make this a magical place centered between the harbour and high-rise city buildings. A nice respite from the hustle and bustle of Sydney. Great for a picnic, the place to read a book, converse with friends -- all in the beauty of the Royal Botanic Garden.

Beautiful!. The gardens are kept in lovely condition and are free - why wouldn't you want to visit?
Great view of the Opera House and Bridge if you walk down to the end (definitely worth it!)

Outstanding garden. The Royal Botanic Gardens is a top-notch place to spend a couple of hours of your time. Beautiful trees, beautiful flowers, well laid out. The best botanic garden I've seen. And it's free.

A wonderful experience and it's free!. We thoroughly enjoyed our walk around the incredible botanic gardens. There was something to be marveled at around every corner. The views across Sydney are quite spectacular and a photographer's dream. The variety of trees and plants provide plenty of 'awe and wonder'! I would suggest not visiting on a really hot day as there is a fair amount of walking involved. A visit to the Governor's House is also to be recommended. We were pleased to find that refreshments are available at a pleasant cafe within the grounds. Don't miss these incredible gardens.
Sydney Botanic Gardens. Wonderful piece of greenery surrounded by blue water all around. Very close to the Opera house so an excellent way to reach the Opera house is via the Botanic gardens.

Stunning. What a beautiful oasis of colour in such a beautiful city. I visited three times in a week using it as a short cut into the Circular Quay and Rocks area of Sydney. Although it was Autumn the colours, trees, plants and bushes were stunning. A bit of humour on one visit was caused by an Ibis stealing a few chips from a plate outside the cafe, and the lady who was the vicitim grabbed the bird by both feet and was almost dragged off her feet!

Take a stroll. We walked out to the point, stopping along the way to admire the wild cockatoos and enjoy the view of the harbor and opera house. There was a crowd from a bus at Mrs. McQuairie's Chair, but a short wait made photos possible. A nice place to walk, starting with the Government House, down toward a really nice gift shop and restaurant and out to the point. There are lots of benches for resting, and plenty of plants and trees.

An oasis of peace and quiet. Urban parks and gardens have a "personality" of their own, and this one is no different. Tranquil and peaceful, while only a stone-throw away from the hustle and the bustle of the city. A sanctuary for all sorts of activities, from running to just admiring the views or having to packed lunch in a beautiful environment.
and it's free!. Enjoyed the lovely grounds filled with exotic plants and birds. Allow two hours to explore the gardens.

an impressive botanical garden in the middle of town. we had visited Sydney a couple of times before but never this garden and are so glad that we had a chance to spend many hours here. There is a lot to see and do. The views of the harbor are outstanding. You can stroll along the waterfront and admire the gigantic trees and amazing flower selections, walk around the Government House (which can be toured but we didn't do it), watch dozens of Kakadus on the ground and up in the tree nibbling on their favorite food, view the herb garden and many other sights of interest (statues, etc.).don't miss a visit to the 'Gardens Shop' across from the Palm Restaurant. It's a jewel.The signage is terrific and tells you how many minutes it will take you to get to a particular spot.Get a map before you explore the garden.

A morning spent at RBG. RBG is quite near from where i was staying and decided to go for a walk one weekend. It should be of no surprise that the place is spacious with lots greenery, it is a botanical garden after all. The place is well instructed, whether if you're looking for directions or reading its history. There's a museum inside RBG, some parts are free but if there's an exhibit you pay an entrance fee. When i went there, they had Afghanistan Hidden Treasures and it was quite educational. I always found historical artifacts to be interesting.
Always good value. We love visiting whenever we come up to Sydney. Always such good value and a wonderfully lovely day out.
Well kept and a pleasure to visit.. Excellent gardens that are well kept. A city Oasis away from the busy streets of Sydney. Bring a sandwhich and just relax!

must go. located next to the sydney opera house, you must pay a visit once you are there. Try to find a place where there are many wild cockatoo arround, you must be very happy there. Some times they move to the other location they used to stay. I will asked the ranger once i could not find them. all the trees, flowers - everything is excellent (You also can take anice pict with great view of Sydney Opera House and Sydey Harbour brideget from here.
expansive. Royal Botanic Gardens are situated by beautiful Sydney Harbour. They are large and provide a lovely atmosphere for strolling with people you love or whose company you enjoy.

Lush and green. A beautiful, relaxing space full of exotic, interesting plants and trees. After the buzz of the harbour and Opera House it is a place of calm - and so close! You are invited to " walk on the grass, hug the trees and even talk to the plants if you want to"!!

Wonderful selection of amazing plants. Wandered through here last week on a sunny day after seeing the Afghanistan exhibition at the Art Gallery and on my way to Circular Quay. A lush oasis on the edge of the city. Lots of stunning plants and colourful blooms as well as quiet grassy areas.

What a treat. Marvelous are so accessible to the downtown area of Sydney. Well marked paths, open areas, views of the bridge and opera house. Just a very relaxing way to spend some time away from the "must sees" of Sydney.

Beautiful walk. This was a great way to spend the afternoon in Sydney...I only wished we'd taken a picnic! Beautiful views of the bridge and the opera house and the different plants and trees are very interesting. Definitely worth a walk through! give yourself plenty of time so you don't have to rush!

Don't miss the excellent free guided walk. This was our second trip to Sydney. We had visited the Botanical Gardens on our previous trip and had been really impressed so, this time, we decided to take a free guided walk. These are provided by volunteers and start at the Information booth outside the Garden shop at the Palm Grove Centre at 10.30 am everyday or 1.00pm weekdays (The Palm Grove Centre is well signposted in the garden). You don't need to book. Just turn up before the start time. We did the morning walk, which was supposed to last 90 minutes. But our guide was so interesting and enthusiastic and had so much to tell us about the plants and trees and the role the site had played in the development of Sydney that we were with him for over 2 hours and had never ventured more than 200 yards from our starting point. This was a great introduction for a European to the flora of Australia and the problems which faced the earliest colonists and is a ideal for anyone who would like to understand the unique Australian landscape.

A quiet walk in a busy city. We thoroughly enjoyed our walk through the gardens and across Farm Cove to get the iconic shot of the Opera House and Bridge. Would recommend if you're looking for somewhere quiet to get away from the hustle and bustle of the busy city. We feel it would have been beneficial to have either had a labelled map of all the plants or all the plants labelled to enjoy all potentials of these lovely gardens.

A great way to spend a sunny day in Sydney. The Gardens are most attractive in Spring; however regardless of the season, it is easy to spend a few enjoyable hours wandering through these special gardens.,

One cannot have a better place to relax and walk off the stress of a day. What a marvel! Originally used by Governors Phillip and Macquarie as a private reserve, it was planted as a botanical garden beginning in 1817. By 1831 all of the roads and paths have been constructed to allow public access. This large space, comparable with New York Central Park, hosts a rose garden, rain forest walk and palm grove. I first traveled out to Macquaries Point to get some of the pictures of the Opera House and Bridge .I walked the entire length of this park, marveling at the details. There are vast open spaces that are used by families for picnics, etc. While walking the rain that threatened began to fall. I found a small bench in a grove of palms and trees – incredibly trees – and waited out the rain in the blissful sound of lightly falling rain. An incredibly relaxing area to stretch your legs (especially after a very long flight) and to see how nature and usefulness can be coordinated.

Attractive and well-kept attraction near the heart of a city. On entry to the gardens you will invariably have the chance to visit an In formation Point. If not, seek one out, as they are full of useful information as to what is especially worth seeing at the time of your visit, location of refreshments, toilets etc.The gardens are well laid-out in different themed areas, and you are encouraged to walk on the grass.The ponds, with their visiting large eels was well worth a look too.

A favourite walk. We really enjoy the botanic gardens and like the fact that you can take a small train ride around first to get bearings and then walk back to explore. Cafe in centre can be variable but the trees, birds and bats are amazing and we even saw a huge snake under one of the bushes. Lovely water side walk and views, too.

Such a good day. Walking into the Royal Botanic Gardens after the bustle of Circular Quay and the Opera House makes a lovely contrast. Even better on a sunny autumn day. Wandering around the gardens is a lovely way to see another side of Sydney. I always love the huge Moreton Bay Fig trees which look like they are perfect for cubbyhouses. We walked right through the Gardens, stopping at the café for a coffee, before heading out near the Art Gallery. There is a lot to see, and lots to enjoy.

Very relaxing. A very pleasant stroll around the gardens. Some interesting trees and plants and some amusingly noisy birds! Whether you are out for a stroll, looking to picnic or take in some views of sydney away from the hustke and bustle the gardens can offer that and more.

A glorious oasis in a bustling city. We stayed nearby and enjoyed many strolls through the gardens at several times of day. There are a good variety of plants and a fabulous view of the harbour from most places within. Its hard to believe such a sprawling city is out there as it such a place of peace and calm. Its a free activity and the spectacular views it affords you are priceless.
Wonderful gardens in the city. Beautiful, well-tended gardens with numerous birds, great ambience. Well-worth the time. It's a great way to meander to the Harbor and Opera House.

Very intersting variety of planting. For Europeans the variety of plants and birds make this a must see, even if the weather was a bit variable when we were there. Views across the harbour are great too.

So beautiful. The air smelled so fresh and clean...nice place to eat lunch, walk around, and enjoy a beautiful day outdoors. Plus it's free so you really can't go wrong with a simple walk through on your way to the opera house
Beautiful Gardens. The gardens are a nice way to escape from the city for a bit plus they offer great views across the harbour of the bridge and the opera house

A wonderful oasis in the city. The Gardens are so beautiful, lovely to walk through. There are many different plants to admire. I loved the succulents and cacti. Lots of places to sit and relax and take in the view. Very close to the harbour and the Opera House. Take a picnic and lie on the grass just magic!

Well worth a walk. So much to see from and in the Botanical gardens. Iconic views of the harbour, opera house, boats and city. Lovely walks with interesting attractions along the way. Had a very nice lunch in the cafe, visited the free art gallery (well worth a stop over) on our way to the shops. A 'must see' on a sunny afternoon in Sydney.

Relaxing relief from the hustle and bustle. This is a great spot to chill out from the busy hustle and bustle of Sydney. After spending a lot of time looking around the many attractions that Sydney has to offer, it's good to find a quiet spot to take time out and it has a wonderful view of the water.
Great way to spend some down time. Can stroll through the Gardens free of charge. Lots to see and very relaxing way to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. Beautifully maintained gardens.
Relaxing escape from the city. The gardens are spectacular and worth the walk from the Opera House to Woolloomooloo.The trails are well marked and maintained.

An oasis in the city. Where else can you absorb yourself in an abundance of plant life, and fabulous birds, in a close city environment. Together with the stunning views of the Opera House, the gardens themselves offer a very comprehensive display of plants from far and wide across the world. Beautifully maintained, these gardens are a must when visiting Sydney, especially if you are interested in horticulture.
Opera in the park. I attended the opera in the park which was amazing! The set up was really easy to navigate and no long waits to get out. A great night out.
Excellent. A beautiful walk in pristine gardens.Plenty of birds in the area also adding to the atmosphere and not too crowded.

Beautiful. What can I say: The gardens are beautiful, and a must see! They are free to enter. You can lay in the grass and read a book, go for a jog or simply stroll through it. It's like a respite in the otherwise busy city.

Beautiful walk through beautiful gardens. I was here on a Friday and saw lots of people sunbathing, relaxing on the grass, and walking through the gardens. It was a pleasant walk with lots to see. The Garden has a great layout that you could spend a good hour in just walking around. They promote you being on the grass, so this would be a perfect spot to camp out if you need a rest. Bring a packed lunch, or toys for the kids! I was lucky to have gone there on a day where they had a tent with local art for sale, and got a great painting of an Australian beach. If you walk all the way over to the far side of the Gardens, away from the harbour, you can get a good view of the Opera House and the Bridge together. I went when it was late afternoon, so I could not get a good picture due to the sun gleaming in my eyes and in the camera, but i you go before noon I'd suspect you'd get a great shot!
Wow. If you are from Canada, you got to see this, its just beautiful, especially if you are interested in plants and landscaping.

Wonderful scenic walk - or good jog trail.. If you're a jogger... head to the Opera House and take the full loop trail around the Botanical Garden. No cost, and its a beautiful trail which is somewhere around 5km around.

A relaxing walk. Even on a busy sunny Saturday a stroll through these extensive gardens is very pleasant and relaxing. Easily accessible from town, it is a lovely walk to enjoy the sights of the harbour, Opera House and Mrs Macquarie's chair.

Leisurely walk and great variety. Plenty of open space, shade, wide footpaths, some interesting plant and tree specimens and an opportunity to see some decent size spiders centred in their orb webs in amongst the leaves and branches.

Restful and stunning .... A Sydney visit won't be complete without a stroll through the Royal Botanic Gardens. Give yourself a good hour at least and try to get 'lost' among the paths ... you won't regret it!

Romance view best place in Sydney for a picnic.. This is my favourite place to picnic,weather. It be romance or family or with friends this place has it all. The view is amazing the cafe is great and the plants and sculptures are amazing.
All things bright and beautiful. Exceptionally well maintained and laid out gardens. Go to the NSW Art Gallery then walk across gardens to the Opera House back door.
Tropical Pyramid is still awaiting renovation ..... Broad gardens with rosebeds, statues on 2 levels. In the centre of town with sweeping views. Great for a stroll or a picnic.

Awesome Park. Its one of the best parks I've been at. What I liked most about this park was that I saw parrots and cockatoos flying around from tree to tree. The trees look like they've been there for decades. The park is clean. It was quite a treat to bike around the park when we joined a bike tour and we were brought here.

Great Garden and Place to Relax and its Free. My wife and I were recently on holiday in Sydney from the U.S. we spend an afternoon just soaking in the variety of vegetation at the gardens, which were very nicely manicured. It's a great place to just stroll and sit under a tree and visit with friends or love ones. The garden's are centrally located and very easy to access. Also there is no admission fees to entry the gardens.

great views. If you want a great view of the opera house and the harbour, the botanic gardens are a good place to start. Situated next to the Opera House, they are easily accessible from the City. We liked the views from its high location. The gardens are beautifully kept and there is an interesting herb garden to see as well.
Beautiful walk but watch out for the eels. The grounds are beautiful to walk through, but I can't get the scary baby duck eating eels that live in the ponds out of my mind.

So much green and so near the city. The Royal Botanic Gardens is a delight to your eyes, there is the spectacular harbour, Opera House, Government House and not fogetting, so many beautiful trees, plants and flowers
BEAUTIFUL!. THis is the place to visit if you enjoy the serenity of a well-kept park and enjoy the pure beauty of nature at its finest! LOVED it!!

Beautiful gardens on Sydney Harbour. I believe Sydney has one of the best harboursides in the world and having such a beautiful gardens overlooking with the beautiful flora mad sents is extraordinary and well worth the visit. I actually went for a walk after business day and it was lovely a pleasant and relaxing way to exercise and very safe. Highly recommend.

Royal Botanic Gardens Sydney. These gardens are the oldest in Australia. They are in the City and can be reached from the Opera House or Macquarie Street. They are near the Art Gallery and Library which are both worth a visit. Australia Museum nearby too.
