She took us around the gardens to points of interest explaining things along the way, she was very knowledgeably indeed. We started with around 18 people but had nearer 30 by the end! It was a good way of finding where you wanted to explore on your own afterwards. As a plantaholic I found it very good indeed.

A Peaceful Place. Plenty of lovely walks and seating and such a lovely ambience. A great place for a rest from "touristing" if you need it, and I imagine if you lived in Sydney it would be a lovely place for picnics and a romantic stroll.Like all the information about the trees, but would have liked to see the dates some of the huge trees were planted to get an idea of their age. Also love the sign that says please walk on the grass, smell the roses and hug the trees. Well done to the staff and the Friends of the Garden.Sadly missed the free guided walks, but we will be back.

Great way to connect with the city. What a superb space. Sits between the City towers and the harbour water. Beautiful green space teaming with willdlfe and local life (parties and weddings at the weekend)Wonderful arrray of plants. I loved the shop and cafe selectionWatch out for the cheeky birds!

A wonderful experience. Walking through the Gardens was the shortest route from our hotel to the Opera House and other attractions and we found this one of the highlights of our stay in Sydney. There was so much to see from the fantastic trees and plants, to the birds and other wildlife, to the sculptures, to the views of the harbour. Each of the many pathways revealed new treasures and it cost not a penny. The fruit bats are still there; they descend on the fig trees at dusk.

Pretty spacious and green. Personally I think it's just so-so, there are many patches of empty grassland, I think the buildings in the gardens are worth visiting, due to time constraint, we didn't really explore much of the place, do note that the gates close at 5.30pm, so might have to go there earlier if you're going for the buildings. There is a nice view of the Sydney Opera House from here though, you can take quite a number of nice pictures here too.

I LOVE PLANTS!. It should be noted, aside from flying, i love plants. I could have spent all day here. We wandered about for at least 90 minutes - walked the whole way around on amazing paths, viewed the harbour and the Opera house from the other side, sat in Mrs. MacQuaries chair and soaked up the southern hemisphere beauty. Lots of places to sit, eat, walk, and parking isn't half bad either. Free.

A Nice Walk-About. It was close to the Sydney Harbour ...so you can walk through going or coming from the Harbour. Some interesting & lovely local plants (which attract local birds) ...some of the water ways in the park were installed by the prisoners (about 100 yrs ago) ...worth the walk - they have a nice shop in the centre of the garden & some restaurants. The restaurants seem to keep "Banker's Hours or are always closed for "special events" ...bummer :(

Be sure to take the tour. The expansive land is most easily digested with a quick tour. The history of the horticulture is fascinating. It is a great place to go for a jog, grab lunch, take a nap, and get gorgeous photos. There is a café in the middle, if you get hungry. Its an affordable (FREE) way to spend an afternoon.

Friendly Police Officer. This is a great place to walk along the harbor and by the Opera House. There was a private function. I walked by, a police officer sopped me, but she was friendly and told me to wait while she literally RAN OVER and got me a map. They have some eateries too....and varied gardens. There are signs posted about. You can spend hours here. Bring a blanket, have a picnic.

Get away from the noise!. This is a lovely park, lots of well tended beds of flowers and shrubs, a few years back there were fruit bats hanging from the trees but these have gone now but there is still a lot of interesting places to visit within the park, best on a sunny day.

Nice for a picnic. Nice and well maintained though nothing exceptional. Convenient picnic spot near the Opera House though be warned that something about the location makes it considerably cooler than it's surroundings so in winter esp be prepared to freeze! Mrs. Macqueries chair is basically a bench in a birdcage with a view.
Beautiful, peaceful place. You are encouraged to walk on the grass, smell the roses and get up close to the plants. Fantastic trees - and the views to the harbour are the icing on the cake.

great place for a stroll. Its a great oasis of calm and beauty metres away from the city centre. It's a beautiful place and the fact that it exists at all is the biggest wonder. This is where a lot of those iconic shots of the opera and the harbour bridge were taken so of course, the views are amazing!

Beautiful gardens. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney are so beautiful and peaceful. The gardens are wonderful and the harbour views spectacular. Take a picnic lunch or walk to the Art Gallery of NSW for a meal in the restaurant for something special or the cafe if you want something less expensive.
fabulous. If you do nothing else, make time to savour this lush oasis in the middle of a busy city. You won't regret it!

A gem in the heart of Sydney. A short walk from the Opera House and just beauty everywhere. Historic old trees, mythical statues, the rose garden, the herb garden - all beautiful in bloom and kept. Spent several hours walking and exploring. A great way to pass time!

An extreme state of Gorgeousness. I so love this place, just a skip and a hop from busy downtown Sydney CBD, it is full of memories of happy days, falling in love, children growing up, birthday picnics, city celebrations, sunset performances of Shakespeare's Midsummer Nights Dream in the Park, ideas for gardens, short cuts across the city to the Art Gallery and Lady Macquarie's Chair, and so it goes. I love the replica of the first farm in European settlement. These days there are even scarecrows. I love the jungle area, I love the Cactus garden that looks like an undersea fantasy. I love the Museum. Here can be found wonderous collections of trees, shrubs, flowers. Right now the Spring display is just gorgeous! The flowers just capture you, overwhelm the senses and leave you smiling with in extreme state of pleasurance. Happy, happy place. Go, and take yourself, take your lover, take the kids, buy an ice cream, feed the ducks. And take your camera. Plenty of parking.

Bad time for our visit. We visited the Gardens at a bad time of year, when there were very few blooms on the plants. What blooms were there were pretty mangy. We were disappointed that the timing of our visit was poor, as we can appreciate how beautiful the gardens must be at peak bloom time.

Great way to spend an afternoon. We went there on our very first afternoon to Sydney and took one if the guided tours led by a horticulturist/ volunteer. Turned out to be a wonderful 3 hour excursion with a very knowledgeable gentleman who not only talked about the plants but wove in stories if the settlers, the native peoples and history of Sydney. Overall a great orientation to start our visit.

Green lung of the city. I visited twice, the first time jogging around the gardens on a torrential rain storm and the second early evening when the wildlife, which abounds, was out and about. A must see when in Sydney with great sea and harbour views.

An enjoyable break from the sounds of the city. I meandered my way along to royal botanic gardens Sydney A lovely place to while away an hour or so. Mangled old Yes with thick trunks exotic flowers. Big notice as you go in says please wall on the grass smell the Roses and hug the trees so it is an interactive garden. Plenty to see including the wishing tree, touch wood, and views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Plenty of others enjoying the space, Walkers joggers photographers sleepers dawdlers and sun bathers. Also the government building is open for tours from 10.30 to 15.00 but not every day. Worth at least one visit. Also a good place to see any fireworks over the water.

Lots to see, and its free. I walked through the Gardens twice on my visit to Sydney. I was surprised by the number of animals I saw while wandering about; cockatoos, parrots, kookaburra, lizards, and all sorts of spiders. You have to watch out so you don't get run over by the little tourist train driving around, but it is a very nice place to take a walk, and there is a lot of shade so even when it's horribly hot out, the Gardens are still pleasant. They also provide a great view of the Bridge and the Opera House.

A relaxing beautiful retreat from the city.. A must to visit when in Sydney. Lots of beautiful garden displays and shady spots to lie and relax in the sun. The view to the harbour is so pretty and it is a short walk to the wonderful Art gallery of NSW

Peace in the craziness of Sydney. If you need a little peace in the noise, traffic and busy-ness of Sydney, take a walk in the Royal Botanic Gardens. There is so much more to see than "just plants." Great views of Sydney Harbor and the Opera House. Or do the Australian thing and enjoy an excellent "cuppa" at a kiosk.
a garden how it should be. amazing plants and a invitation to discover nature with all senses -what more do you expect from a botanic garden

A Very Pleasant Walk . Once you're done with the Opera House leave (most of) the crowd behind and take a walk through the Botanical Gardens where there always seems to be something in season; my favorite was the Succulents Garden because these are plants that will never let you down regardless of the time of year. This walk can always be combined with a visit to one or more of the prominent historic buildings that border the gardens for a full days excursion.

Pleasant stroll. Easy to access - from either city end or harbour end. A lovely oasis in the middel of a bustling city. Season affected the display of flowers but still a peaceful way to spend a while wandering.

This Park is so faraway you really do think you are nowhere near the city.. The Gardens are right at edge of the harbour as far away as possible from the busy City to make you think that you are in the only oasis in the city. But to get there you need to walk quite a fair distance, but well worth the walk if you want escape the hustle and bustle of the city.

Free informative tour. Found ourselves in the gardens a number of times and saw something new every time. The free tours that leave at 10.30am and 1pm every day was definately worth going on. The volunteers were very friendly and informative and enthusiastic. Our guide had been doing the tours for 10 years. We took a heap of photos each time and it was amazing how when you compared between the days they plants change with the sun/rain etc. definately worth a visit....

Beautiful and relaxing. A must see in Sydney. Next to Circular Quay and the Opera, the Royal Botanic gardens are great for relaxing on the grass or taking a stroll, getting lost amongst its many gardens... It also offers a great view of grass esplanades and the city skyline behind.
Beautiful. One of the most breathtaking sights in the World, beautifully presented in the most amazing harbour, plenty of drinking and dining options in the area.

Great views of the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Definitely stop by here for a scenic park walk and to get another perspective of the picturesque Opera House and Bridge. Lovely scene.

Beautiful and great location. Beautiful gardens and neat to see some plants we have in the U.S. in a more natural setting (allowing them to grow much larger and impressive). Not overwhelmingly large garden so easy to take it all in with plenty of opportunities to stop and rest as needed. Grab a brochure at the visitor center that provides a guide to the numerous birds. Incredible views of the bridge, opera house and downtown. And take a few extra minutes at the pool with the eels...they jump out of the water occasionally..crazy! Also, we had the burgers at the cafe in the gardens (the one underneath the pricey restaurant)...surprisingly good. Be warned if you sit at the tables outside the cafe to eat (we didn't)...the ibis' get aggressive and jump on the tables to get the food.

Beautiful in spring!. I would definitely recommend visiting the Botanical Gardens in spring! All the different flowers and colors are beautiful. I love how it is so quiet and lovely, but just a few meters away from the bubbly city.
Utterly beautiful . Beautiful surrounding with stunning views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Cannot recommend highly enough. Watch out for the hue amount of joggers though!

Perfect for Jogging. I was surprised to find a spacious botanic garden like that in the middle of such a big city. You can get lost there and spend days strolling, looking at the harbour and bathing in the sun.
Lovely and worth the visit. Well worth the visit the gardens are lovely the plants well laid out and the different aromas given out was wonderful
Take Time to Smell the Roses and the Wisteria. Great place to while away a morning (or afternoon) Beautiful views. Variety of trees, plants and flowers.

amazing green space in the city. The fact the Royal Botanic Gardens is within walking distance from anywhere in the CBD is amazing. Sydney residents should consider themselves lucky to have such a beautiful natural space in the heart of their city. Definitely worth an hour or two to stroll through, maybe bring a lunch for a picnic.

Absolutely gorgeous - worth a detour. Even if you're not a botanist or a "plant person," the Gardens have an interesting and diverse collection of sculpture and historical artifacts. You can get an eyeful just using the Gardens for a short cut to the Opera House and city (depending on where your hotel is located), or wander around reading the sufficiently detailed signs at each of the featured stops. The herb garden is the largest and best maintained I've ever seen, with each of the featured plants well labeled. It's a visual and aromatic feast.
Beautiful, beautiful. impressive, free, huge, well worth a couple of hours or even longer if you want to picnic. Be sure to see the Govt House, and if it's a weekend,take the free tour.

A piece of Heaven on Earth!!!. Absolutely fantastic place to visit. We spent a week in Sydney and 3 of those days were spent here. Absolutely beautiful flora and fauna.
Fantasic views of both the Opera House and Bridge.
Highly recommended - take enough batteries for your camera, you'll need them
wonderful gardens. What a wonderful experience walking through the gardens, spent several hours enjoying it and it is free.
Most beautiful garden!. A beautiful oasis in the middle of the city with stunning view of bridge and opera house. Flora is amazing. Just a lovely place. A must see while in Sydney.

Be sure to plan for a picnic.. Fantastic gardens, extremely peaceful and quiet. You would never believe one of the world's busiest cities is just a few hundred yards away. "Please walk on the grass" as the signs say. So many beautiful trees and flowers, the air smells wonderful. Plan a picnic on a good weather day. The Governor's residence is beautiful. Great views of the Opera House and Harbor Bridge. A great escape from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Beautiful English style gardens. ...with the views of the harbour and the Opera House make this worth a visit. Lovely to realx under the beautiful shady trees on a hot afternoon. It is very central to all public transport and easy to reach. Take your time walking through and admiring the scenery.

Vast and a Nice Quiet Escape. The gardens are so vast and wonderfully situated on Sydney Harbor overlooking the Sydney Operat House. As a gardens enthusiast, I was surprised that they did not offer more. The had nice a nice rose garden planting, and assoted plantings of plants native to Australia. I missed not having a conservatory with specialty plants and aquatic gardens.

Free guided walk every day. Don't miss these beautiful and interesting gardens which have stunning views of Sydney harbour and the Opera House. If you want to really understand the gardens and the rare plants they contain catch the free guided walk that starts from outside the shop at 10.30am every day. It lasts about 1.5 to 2 hours and the guide will be a very knowledgeable volunteer. They also run shorter guided walks in at lunch time: 1pm from March to November. You can easily spend all day in these gardens. Nobody minds if you snooze on the grass for a while.The shop is an excellent source of gifts, and the staff are very helpful and friendly. The cafe does lovely sandwiches as well as hot food like posh burgers. There is also a restaurant above the cafe if you want a full meal with waitress service and table cloths.

Greenery and scenery. These gardens are a wondrous expanse along the water. Not sure how large the botanic gardens are but we spent HOURS covering it. The domain and botanic gardens melt into each other creating huge green spaces. It is located very close to the opera house and easy transit by ferry, bus or car. We esp. like Mrs Mrs Macquaries {the wife of the New South Wales Governor} seat. It was a seat carved out of the natural rock where she used to sit and watch for ships coming from England. There is an aboriginal tour offered that shows you how the original natives used all the botanical plants for food and medicine-that was awesome to see and hear. Lovely spot for a few minutes, hours or a full day. Some of the trees are full of fruit bats who just hang out {upside down from the branches} during the day and then go out at sunset-truly a site to behold.

Nice place to spend a sunny morning. There is a daily free guided tour which is worth the 90 minutes it takes you learn a lot more about the garden and plants. Our guide even told us where we could find 2 unusual birds

Relaxing place. I think that is my favorite place in Sydney!
Relax and silence in the middle of the city!
if you have free time during your trip, go there both you are a business man/woman... you'll enjoy this place!

Walk around, bring your camera and enjoy. For the flower lover, this is a must do. They have a rose garden, a cactus lover area, different varieties of all kinds of flowers. There are bathrooms and a cafe that makes great espresso and sandwiches. Grab one and head over to a bench and enjoy the relaxation. Make sure you wear good walking shoes.

A beautiful, serene place for an afternoon. We just loved the sign: "Do walk on the grass, hug a tree and smell the roses". Sets the tone for the type of place this is - friendly, open, and welcoming. Also enjoyed the great bodies tanning on the lawns.

A must.. We enjoyed taking a relaxing walk through the gardens. We were tired and jet lagged after arriving in Sydney, so taking a stroll through the gardens was a perfect way to stretch our legs and get some fresh air. And they are beautiful, lots of nice plants, and plenty of birds to check out. It has great views by the water!
Beautiful. It is very nice. It also gives you a great view of the opera house and harbour bridge and is also a great place to propose as I did.

Green space in heart of Sydney. The botanical gardens are huge and have lots of interesting plants. It is a nice place to walk around or get a picnic lunch. I especially liked the palms area. Several birds seem to call this area home. We also visited the botanical gardens in Hobart during our Australian vacation and I liked those better than the ones at Sydney - plants were better labelled with interesting information about them than in here.

Very peaceful. The gardens are beautiful and very well kept and maintained. They are vast and full of flowers, trees and wildlife. It also offers great views of both the city and the opera house and harbour bridge. It's a great place to relax and lay down on the grass with a drink and watch the world go by

Very scenic. Great place to walk and enjoy the day in Sydney. Lots of huge trees and plants to see. Great views of the city and the opera house. You can also see the first Government house at the gardens. Also the gardens are very big. We spent several hours and didn't see most of it.

Great Green Garden. The gardens are very well kept. Lush trees and flowers.unique in the diversity of species, both plans and birds.Great place for jogging, having a picnic, chilling or having some photos taken. You can hold events here as well.Has a great view of the water. Houses the Government House which looks like an old castle. Also has a lake and a greenhouse on the grounds.The Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbor Bridge are a stone's throw away.

A peaceful place.. After walking around the city it is nice to go to these gardens right next to the IOpera house. Everything is in cl;ose proximity. Good cafe in the gardens and great views of the city from here.

Heaven on the other side of the world. We have spent two weeks in Sydney and paid four visits to the Botanic Gardens! Really a fantastic place. What a variety of plants, a superb way to discover the flora of Australia. Very nice walk next to the bay with super views on the bay and the Opera house. A heaven on the other side of the world.

Varied and beautiful. The Botnaic Gardens are a place I make sure to visit every trip. They are large with such a great variety of things to see, and it is a a very popular hangout for tourists and locals alike.

a day on the green. attended a wedding here , the day before we walked through the gardens to orientate ourselves the herb garden is so fragrant this time of year along with the rose pavillion. as you stroll around the paths there is a new suprise around every corner, there is a motorised cart for those with walking and its free take a picnic lunch and enjoy the sunshine

Glorious Gardens with Superb Views.. Definitely worth a visit whether you are a visitor or local.A cool and welcoming environment with glorious Harbour vistas and views of the Opera House.The gardens are beautifully maintained and are a haven in the city for birds and humans alike!! One of my favourite areas is the cactus garden. The Garden's shop and visitor's centre is worth a visit too.One of the lovliest botanic gardens to visit.
Great escape from the city. These gardens are huge, and are a great place to escape if overwhelmed by the towering city.With so many lawns trees and flora and a little fauna. it is a special place
Beautiful day out. For a free park, these gardens are amazing. So beautiful , a real gem with amazing views, and a lovely place to chill away from all the hustle and bustle of the harbour

Amazing views and space. Where else can you stroll around such a wonderful waterfront and take in the city vistas so close to the city centre? Worth doing a guided tour through Government House if it is open. A delight to be strolling through the Government House grounds when the NSW Governor arrived. Anywhere else and the area would be full of security.
Out of this world gorgeous.. Acre after acre of foliage, fountains, statues, art from modern to Victorian, and views to die for. Don't miss it.
Spectacular gardens. We always enjoy the botanical gardens when visiting cities, a little tranquility among the bustling city and this one didn't fail to impress us. Definitely worth a wonder.

The gardens. Very enjoyable walk, good size park to walk in. I would do this walk again. Pleasant. The Gardens are not to far from other attraction in the area, Opera House, Darling Harbours, The Rocks, ajlso plenty of cafes, resturants if and when you get hungry for something to eat.
A must for plant and flower lovers. A lot of native Australian and foreign plants and flowers. Excellent collection of palms from the whole world.

Beautifully and interestingly laid out to relax and enjoy. Whether you are on the way from the city to the harbour or vice Versa, stop off in the cool serenity of the botanic gardens. With stunning views and lots of places to stop and sit and relax and drink in the tranquility.

Beautiful Park. We walked through the gardens, its a comfortable relaxing walk with lots of shade and plenty to look at. The many grass areas just call to you to sit or lie down and watch the day go by.

A beautiful walk along the coast. A long walk along the sea and through some beautiful gardens. It was perfect weather too. Warm but not too warm so you can lie down on the grass andcatch some sun or watch shirtless Aussie men doing so !
relaxing. Had a nice and relaxing walk in these garden, just walk through them and enjoy, the only down part will be the cactus part..but it s just a small area

Very pretty. We walked through the gardens en route to and from our hotel in Simpsons Point and the ferry terminal. It was a very picturesque and pleasant walk taking around 40mins if you didn't stop to look at the plant displays. Also you get good views of the Opera House and the harbour bridge.
great place to kill time. HUGE greenspace with lots to see, can walk around, have a picnic... take a nap! very well taken care of...

A very pleasant experience. A charming botanic experience especially situated by the harbour. Some fascinating specimins, some of which are very old. The Governor's residence is also very interesting.

Venue to be relaxed. It is not far for walking from the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. There is a observing point to view the Opera House with the Bridge at the background. You can get the best photo there. It is also a nice place to do excise including jogging along the water front. Spend your time at least for 2 hours at the Garden.

Lovely way to spend a couple of hours. I run through the gardens, down to the harbour, and up back past Mrs Macquarie's Chair at least a couple of times a week. It's a beautiful part of the city and something I recommend whenever out of town visitors come to stay. You can bring a blanket and have a picnic, you can have a leisurely stroll, you can stop and look and at the different flora and fauna. It's perfect.

Onward ho from Hyde Park!. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a short walk from Hyde Park, so it is a continuation of a beautiful, scenic natural trail so to speak. There is something for everyone here. The Mrs. Macquarie's chair promises a delightful view of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. There is the Art Gallery of New South Wales which I could not visit, but am sure will be a worthwhile detour for art lovers. And if you just want to sit and take in some lovely sights, this is the place to go.
Beautiful. Had a lovely walk through the gardens, kept imaculate and tidy, well sign posted if you get lost. Beautiful on a nice sunny day

Not to be missed. The Sydney Botanical Gardens are lush, expansive and back on to Sydney Harbour. Beautiful, tranquil and a great spot for a walk, picnic, celebration or just to glimpse a spectacular view of Sydney Harbour, the Bridge and the Opera House.

Beautiful view and flowers. I like to take pictures so this place is really good for me. I love the many types of plants and flowers, especially the roses. They're really pretty. The view of the Opera House and Harbor Bridge from Macquarie's Chair is stunning as well. Worth a visit.. or two. With the size, I doubt you can explore all of the garden in only a day.
very nice gardnes. brillant gardens and so pretty so peaceful they are so well look after and was so nice to just walk around and sit and look at all the pretty trees

Must visit!. One of the best botanic gardens in the world! The stroll by the water to the Sydney opera house is a photo opportunity not to be missed!It is amazing that it is free!Also visit the Friends of the garden nursery 12-2pm on weekdays. You would be tempted to buy all the rare and wonderful plants and really affordable prices! Then visit the cactus gardens next door, and inhale the perfume of the heliotropes and spring bulb flowers in spring.

A lovely trip for Sunday afternoon. Beautiful gardens, great lay out for a stroll. Good cafe and nice seating area. Interesting information about all of the plants and their history. Plenty to see and good spaces to relax in. Highly recommend this area.

Huge with a great variety of plants and trees. I enjoyed this garden very much. a lot to see, very scenic and well kept. A good variety of plants and trees. Lots of places for nice photography and to just sit and enjoy the scenery. Well worth a visit.
Free tour of gardens. We found out about the 10.30 am free tour and it lasted about 1.5 hrs and the host David was very knowledgeable

So peaceful in sydneys city. Loved it here.So pretty and peaceful and then you look up and see you are surranded by high rised buildings. The gardens are well maintained and nice to walk in with different sections to see such as the oriental section etc... You have go to visit:)

Great picnic place. Amazing spot to do a picnic, plus you are super close to the Harbour Bridge if you want to go after ! Try to walk a little along the gardens because the layout of everything in these garden were made to enjoy walking around them !!

Royal Botanic Gardens. If you like anything gardens you will feel right at home here. The view really speaks for its self, great views of Sydney Harbour and the city skyline makes this a popular choice for anyone traveling or a local wanting a little bit of time out. Well maintained and a number of "green" open spaces where you can have a picnic. if you walk to the end of the road you will then have great views of the Harbour Bridge and behind you to the east "Mrs Macquarie's Chair" it would be good to see some themed gardens here, in my opinion the view is the real "winner" here.

Well set out and maintained. Beautiful, cool setting on a very warm day. Many people used the gardens for exercise and relaxing during lunch. It is well signed as I used it to walk to get to the Art Gallery. You wouldn't think you were in the heart of Sydney

Mystical, magnificent and towering Moreton. Let your kids dress up as fairies and take a picnic lunch to share under the mystical, giant 150 year old Moreton Bay Fig trees. Truly amazing trees which have giant "buttress" roots protruding out of the ground. I believe the tree has been dubbed the "children's tree".
Spring fever!. Gorgeous! So colourful and lush and filled with sunshine. A tranquil place to sit and watch the world go by.
don't miss!. Fantastic walk, beautiful plants and birds. Loved the signage that you're encouraged to hug the trees. Amazing views to the opera. A quiet escape in the heart of the city.

The Perfect After Dinner Stroll. It’s been 28 years since I set foot in Sydney, or the Gardens. With so much change everywhere in the city – the same, yet different – you can imagine my delight at seeing old trees remembered, on a quiet evenings walk from our hotel in the city to dinner on Woolloomooloo wharf. The stillness, fresh air, adding to what remains a most enjoyable and romantic after dinner stroll available in any city, beautiful in the half-light. The boughs and branches of trees hundreds of years old, adding their still presence to the warm spring evening. Just lovely.With striking views of the harbour and the city, or the city against the setting sun, I would highly recommend this walk to anybody visiting Sydney for a peaceful, rejuvenating highlight amongst the hustle and bustle of holiday travel, day or night.

So relaxing to stroll and listen to the birds. We enjoyed a peaceful stroll around the gardens one Saturday morning. The trees were magnificent and provided much needed shade when the sun got a little hot. We enjoyed looking around the garden shop and had a cup of tea at the cafe. The gardens give you a chance to slow down if you've been walking around the busy city streets.

Beautiful gardens, easily accessible. The Botanical Gardens are close to the city, beside the harbour and very close the Opera House. There are numerous stunning walks through the gardens, along with it being suitable for lazing in the sun and enjoy the lovely Sydney skyline.There is a cafe and a less formal lunch/food bar area in the centre of the gardens. Fine.Good shop, close to the cafe for 'garden' related gifts.
Gorgeous. Countless beautiful flower beds and many truly spectacular trees. Right next to the opera house, no reason not to see them both.

Not your usual walk in the park. From the rare trees and plants, to the succulents, to the herb gardens, to the fernery, to the original settlers garden, there's more plant life that you can point a stick at. Well worth a visit or two. One of the best gems of Sydney.

Nice stroll amongst the greenery. There's a slanted tree that you ought to check out in the gardens. Generally the whole place will well kept and neat. plus there are quite a number of joggers during the evening time.

Beautiful Views!. I am not usually someone who enjoys visiting gardens when I tour a city. However, we visited the Royal Botanic Gardens, and it was a real treat. The gardens are beautiful, and the area offers some of the best views of Sydney Harbor and the Opera House (great photo spots!). I definitely suggest making time to visit this area. Also, visit Mrs. Macquarie's Chair, a sandstone lookout near the Botanic Gardens, offering a superb view of the harbor -- it is beautiful!
Just the right spot to escape from the city. Great place to just wind down and enjoy afternoonAlso a perfect spot if you decide to set up an event

convenient central location, disbility friendly. We climbed the stairs but then found lift access from Circular Quay, so accessible and disability friendly. The gardens are over a few acres so a slow stroll is the best way to see the gardens, there are clear signs and maps and a great variety of gardens.

Serene. The botanic gardens were very serene and peaceful. Also, overlooking the harbour is wonderful. I'd say the botanic gardens in Melbourne are prettier and more developed, but these were very nice.
Worth a visit. Would not have visited if not on my way to and from trips I had booked but definitely somewhere to at least walk through

Great for a picnic or a jog - or both!. I have walked and jogged around these gardens and enjoyed seeing the nature on offer. Take a camera and mind the parrots! Very family friendly, great for a jog or a slow leisurly walk. Picnic's are fun too, just make sure none of the animals poach your sandwiches !
Gateway to the Harbour. A transport hub for ferries, trains and buses. Expensive shopping to be had but its one place that met people will go to.

Walking with plants. Strange plants, odd birds and fantasdic views of the Bridge and Opera House, both of which seemed small when compared to the rest of the Sydney skyline. Very impressive and a great morning spent there

Calm in the City. Although this can be a busy place, especially over the lunch hour, it is equally a ver calming and tranquil oasis, in the heart of the city. Lots of Botany to see, of course, but also a few good quality rest stops to enjoy, as you go. Its a big area, so take your walking shoes.

Birds and Flying Foxes in the trees. The botanical gardens are a must see for any Sydney visitor. There is no cost to wander the trails throughout the gardens. I like to enter from the gate near the opera house. If you go first thing in the morning you will see sulfur crested cockatoos, lorikeets, flying foxes and a bunch of other active noisy birds including the odd kookaburra. Take a banana or two and you will have new friends. The flying foxes are amazing, they hang upside down in the trees and when they fly around the shadow they cast is huge. There is a wide variety of trees, flowers and other greenery. If you are there on a weekend visit the Government House, it is the office of the provincial governor. They offer a short tour of the building and offices for free and share the history of the state and federal governments in Australia. Sydney is a busy city and the gardens offer a chance to relax and enjoy some amazing views. I recommend spending 3 to 4 hours for a relaxed visit.
Lovely. Spent a sunny day in winter walking around these beautiful gardens its a must do if your visiting the opera house as its just next door!!

A delight for avid gardeners and visitors alike. My wife being an avid gardener always has this high on our list of places to visit when in Sydney. We make it a ritual to take the time to stroll around and see the various displays and how they have developed over the years - noticing on our last visit that the overload of bats seems to be diminshing and some of the trees that had been stripped starting to recover. The gardens provide an everchanging and interesting place to visit.

great train ride.. It was a very warm day. We went on a hop on hop off choo choo train. worth the $10 each it cost. lots of beautiful things to see. shame the tropical house was being fixed. fabulous view of opera house and bridge.

Peaceful spot in the city. Visited twice during our time in Sydney and enjoyed the peaceful walks and lovely views of the harbour. Beautifully kept, this is an oasis of tranquility, but we found the signage a bit lacking in clarity. We didn't use the coffee shop as prices were steep (even for Sydney). For fabulous views of the Opera House and Bridge, walk out to Mrs Maquarie's Chair.
great little train. We had a hot september day.Thank goodness for the choo choo trainwell worth the $10 fare.Lots of interesting stuff.Friendly staff.

Cool spots to grab flora/fauna photos & sit. One thing I noticed is the cooling nice weather with soft flowing wind & cool temperature. You can run/jog in the garden but won't sweat due to low humidity. There are many cool spots to grab flora/fauna photos & sit. One of these spots I went to was the gently sloping field where the small 'Stonehenge'-looking sculptures are. Here, you can take nice candid shots or casual group photos as well as have a short 5minute to sit & laze before continuing your walk. Other than that, there are also many animals scurrying or flying about. If you're lucky, you might get close-up shots of them as well. Best thing of all, it's free.Firstly, be sure to grab the photos of the white/yellow cockatoos in the garden. Secondly, be sure to find some great spots or sculptures where you can grab nice photos. Thirdly, go there at the end of winter/start of spring so that the temperature is cool & not warm, which may irritate you.Very good experience.
Impressive variety of plants and flowers. Plants and flowers in all shapes, forms and colours. Must see for nature lovers and all other people!
A decent stroll. Good open space with a variety of views and walks. Found the signage misleading. Can not find somewhere to have a coffee.
Great wee day out. Enjoyed our day out in the gardens.visited the hotspots,mrs macquaries point and chair.stunning views and would be a lovely day out for families or for a picnic

Wonderful, spectacular. Great early morning walk, around the quay, passed the Opera house and into a serene, peaceful beautiful garden, acres of garden bounded by the harbour, Opera house, Conservatary of Music. Today it was splashed with the Tulips in full bloom, the magnificent Moreton Bay Figs and a favourite Dragon Blood trees
In the heart of the city a true oasis
Beautifully maintained. The gardens have something for everyone - running tracks, walking tracks, lots of grassy sposts to sit and relax or just take in the beautiful surroundings.
Exellent walk. Lots of flowers in spring (cherry blossom - the best) and summer (roses - the best). Good to visit with kids, friends or couples. Great photo opportunities for visitors.

Not very well signposted, but pleasant. I had a chance to go for a longish walk through the botanic gardens and, frankly, got lost due to poor signposting. The gardens are pleasant and feature a good range of native flora. Good for a picnic or a stroll, just make sure you know where you're going before you enter!

Harbour bridge. Great to sail under the bridge and to drive over,the train also goes over the bridge.On a Sunday there are cheap rail tickets that also include your ferry ride and bus fare's ,these are excellent value and cover trips around Sydney.

Take the Choo Choo Express!. Sydney in the springtime -- fabulous weather and everything in bloom. Then what better place to really get to know the subtropical climate of Sydney than from the botanist's point of view? The Royal Botanical Gardens are -- simply -- HUGE. This paradise cum playground is smack up against downtown with harbor views everywhere you look. You could wander around this place for days on end and still now truly appreciate the depth and breadth that is captured here. For a great overview and to satiate the kid in you (or even better, if you have kids with you), take the Choo Choo Express. For $10 it stops in four key spots around the Gardens (we joined it at the Opera House stop); and, you can "hop on hop off" all you'd like for your ten bucks. What a deal! You'll get a good first look around and then you can decide how best to stroll the property. Don't miss the flower gardens in springtime -- so many beautiful tulips and flowering shrubs. Bring a frisbee (oops, a boomerang, perhaps!) and play on the many massive lawns. Pack a picnic lunch and blanket to enjoy the warm air and fresh green grass. Too hot? So many beautiful, gigantic shade trees you'll feel like you're on your own country estate.Great place for contemplation, a romantic walk, a serious talk or just fun with friends. How very marvelous that Sydney created this special property directly adjacent to its central business district. Not to be missed.

Beautiful. Very large beautiful manicured gardens and parkland alongside Sydney Harbour. Great for walking, strolling, jogging etc. Sights along the way include the Art Gallery of NSW, Opera House, Botanic Gardens Restaurant, Government House. Come to enjoy the sun and for a wonderful day out.
Amazing gardens. If you are a fan of gardens ( and I am) this is not be missed. Unique plants and trees, very well sign posted. Setting near the harbor and Opera House is unreal.

just beautiful!. This garden is an oasis of peace in the city. Really beautiful, with lots of various plants and trees and very well maintained, this garden is so big that you could easily spend a whole day walking through it. As we didn't stay long in Sydney we only spent an hour or two walking there, but we'll have a longer walk next time we'll go Down Under. We really enjoyed our time there!

Gorgeous views and totally free!!. The most lovely place to talk a chilled walk round, pictures were fab when we got home. Lovely kept gardens, very clean and tidy and best of all totally free to enjoy.

Nice walk. Went through the gardens several times as it was on the way between our hotel and the Opera House/ Sydney Harbour.
Nice place to sit or just walk around but closes quite early so no late night walks.

Place of Tranquility. The Royal Botanic Gardens is an expansive garden set aside in the Sydney CBD. Walking through it is as if you've been transported away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Absolutely beautiful, well maintained, you can spend many hours there without even fully scraping the surface. Also make sure to take that must-take panoramic photo of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney Opera House at Mrs Macquaries Point!

very impressive. The garden is massive. I entered the garden from the entrance at the front of State library at junction of Macquarie St. From there I did the walk to the Opera House through the garden. There are a lot of botanical collections inside. People seen doing their commuting through the garden too. Plenty of green grass fields for people to lay down, seat around, chit chat, enjoying the sun, or even having picnic. Wooden/metal benches also available almost every corner inside the garden. There is a cafe too in the middle of it. I think you could easily spend the whole day inside the garden if that is your thing. I did really enjoy my time with my two toddlers inside the garden.
Beautiful walk in Sydney CBD. Very well maintained gardens, lots of directional signage and free. Access to government house, make sure you get a chance to take a tour.
A great asset for the city......... Wander aimlessly or with purpose around these wonderful gardens. Fantastically set alongside the Harbour, they are a feast for the eyes, nose and heart !!
Excellent walk trail. Loved the fresh air from the ocean. Beware the aboriginals who shout at you. Some spit on you. Apart from that, it's really scenic!
Beautiful gardens with lots to see. I loved the different areas of the gardens and that there were lots of signs describing the trees and locations.

Signs tell you to hug the trees!. A lovely space providing some welcome shade; my favourite part was the signs telling you to walk on the grass and hug the trees. Obviously a well used and well loved park, which was so nice to see. Great views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge also.
A beatiful place to walk around. It is not a huge botanical garden, but its gardens and ways among the trees and grass, the flowers, bushes and plants will give you a sensation of peace and relax.

Beautiful walk through the gardens. We went for a stroll around the gardens on a sunny Saturday afternoon. The smells and flowers were beautiful.
The view of the Opera house and the Harbour bridge was terrific

Lovely place to chill !. Our first visit to Sydney and we decided to walk through the Botanic Gardens on our way to the Opera House. We spent more time than we expected in the Gardens as it was a lovely day. We grabbed some delicious baguettes at the Cafe and sat in the sun and watched the world go by. We checked out Mrs Macquaries chair where we got some great photos of the harbour. It is a lovely Garden and somewhere to relax from all the sightseeing !

Lovely well kept garden and fantastic view of Bridge and Opera House. Excellent well kept gardens. Mrs MaQuaries chair worth a quick sit down and photo. really good place for photo opportunities of Harbour. Also saw giant eels in lake, kookaburra and parrots.

Best gardens. Absolutely gorgeous. We had such a nice time strolling through here. If I lived in Sydney I would visit at least once a week! We started on Macquarie St and walked in a bit of a loop, around the Main Pond and then to the Opera House.
Exotic and perfect views. The gardens are beautiful and we were delighted to see such a variety of exotic birds and even to hear a cockatoo. What an oasis of calm.

An excellent place to spend the afternoon. The garden is very well kept, with excellent view over the Sydney opera house and Sydney bridge and lots of birds, including cockatoos. The tour to government house is a bit too long, but the garden around the house is just beautiful.
Beautiful. I liked the view of the Sydney CBD and high rises, variety of flora and trees. Also it is an excellent walk to the Maquaires Chair

Great Gardens!. I walked to the gardens from the Woolloomooloo pier. It was about 9 am when I entered the gardens, and I was impressed by the birds I saw: cockatoos, rainbow lorikeets, ibis, lapwings, and many, many more! The flowers and trees were interesting, too. Definitely go!

Lovely Place, wish I would have seen more. We spent nearly half a day at the beautiful gardens. But did not get to see much of it as I surprised my wife by having our vows renewed at this lovely location. Looking forward to coming back sometime in the future and seeing the whole thing.
A must see. To stroll and enjoy the scenery and the sunshine is delightful. Thoughtfully planted not long after the establishment of the colony

Beautiful way to start the day. The gardens are well looked after with little nooks and crannies to explore at every turn. The views are amazing over the harbour and there is a little restaurant at one end for those wanting to sit and ponder

Serene,peaceful Beautiful Garden by the harbor. This is where tranquility is found away from the hustle and bustle. An oasis,comprised of 74 acres wrapped around the harbor edge. The garden is a living museum with fountains,statues and monuments scattered throughout. Plant specimens collected on the original Captain James Cook's voyage are on display at the Herborium. Start at The Opera House end and stroll through the gardens of Government House,on route to Palm grove where there are fine examples of outdoor palms. Borders are planted with kaffir lilies which accent bright colos. Onto the herb garden for a looksie at at the multi purposes that essential plants serve culinary,medicinal to the aromatic.  Now you are primed for the tropical center where there are two glass houses that contain tropical ecosystems which house exotics and natives. Wonderful place to jog or cycle your lag away.
Awesome day. Wow how clean are our gardens!Thanks guys you do an amazing jobGorgeous place to relax,picnic,jogAwesome walk at night too

Outdoor exercise. Free outdoor exercise/activities. I enjoyed going for a run around the botanical gardens. I love keeping fit even when I 'm on holidays especially after some really yummy food at Zia Pina. You gotta burn off the calories :)

Beautiful Gardens. The gardens are right in the city centre alongside the Opera House and edged by the sea. They are beautifully kept and a walk around to Mrs Macquarie's chair gives great views of the Opera House and Bridge. There are some really interesting trees in the gardens not to mention the bightly coloured birds that freqent the trees there.

Great way to spend an afternoon. This is a huge garden with plants and trees from around the world. Its well worth a visit. We went in the winter, but it was still beautiful. If you take time to sit and listen there's a lot of interesting wildlife. We saw a large variety of birds, including many varieties of parrots and other birds. Some of them were quite friendly and looking for food. We also enjoyed looking at the eels in the freshwater pond, there are a number of large ones and they're really unique and can be fed as well. Some of the trees were truly amazing and on a nice day its a great place for a picnic.

A lovely place to visit. I suggest you take the free 10:30 guided walk to get a good overview of the history of the gardens and some of its more notable plants and trees. They have a fantastic gift shop.

Must Have Photos. A morning stroll east through the Gardens to Lady Macquarie's Chair. You'll get great photos of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, Opera House and city skyline. If silhouettes are more your style, late afternoon finds the sun behind the Bridge and Opera House but you'll need a flash for your partner. Lots of parking in Mrs Macquarie's Road. Public toilets close by, just ask at the coffee trailer at end of the road.

Free, easy and stunning views. Whether you're a tourist or a local, a visit to the Royal Botanic Gardens is a must. These beautiful parklands provide panoramic views of Sydney harbour and is an amazing picnic spot in the heart of the city. Many Sydneysiders escape to the Gardens in their lunch-hour for a run, a walk, or to enjoy there sandwich. In summer, why not book tickets to the Openair Cinema where you get to watch blockbuster movies outdoors with Sydney harbour as your backdrop.

Great place for a walk and jog. Took the family around the Gardens in July and had a lovely afternoon watching the wildlife while drinking tea. Returned the next day for a jog through the park and enjoyed the great views across the harbour.
A tranquil place for a stroll. Lovey gardens, right in the heart of the city. Great place to stretch your legs and go for a stroll.

Worth a visit, plenty to see. After a trip on the ferry we walked to the gardens, they were so close to the harbour. Beautiful gardens, lots of different paths to take. Great cafe and space to relax. Lots of birds to see. Great views.
Fantastic Royal Botanic Gardens. A must see, gorgeous gardens, very relaxing!! Lovely walks and lots of photo opportunities, you can get up close with the wildlife, even the Spiders!!!!!!

Royal Botanic Gardens. Good place to visit after dropping by NSW gallery, overally the garden has nothing much to see, but as we walk by towards the direction of the opera house, you will be able to see a nice view overlooking the opera house and a crystal clear water
Best place. Kids love it. Every time we have a daytrip to visit sydney we park near the gardens so we can walk through on way to CBD. Love this place and kids always have fun. Defiantly a must see

Underrate Must Do in Sydney. This is a beautiful garden, with many fascinating pockets of horticulture from around the world. They have a great and moving bit about the history of the aboriginals, the best history of them I've read to date.
The walk to Mrs. Macqueries Chair is fantastic, and the view when you get there is the best in the city.

They close early in winter. Lovely gardens, worth a visit, but remember they close at sunset. And when they say closed, they really mean it. We wanted to walk to Macquarie point and they had just closed the gate to leave the gardens. This meant walking around to the next gate and running, because they were closing that one too.

Great getaway in the city. The botanic garden is amazing with many different types of trees, plants, and landscapes. Since it is free makes it even more special. What fun to see wild cockatoos in the trees. Easy to get to and we went when it was raining and it was still spectacular. You also get a great view of the opera house and bridge. The gift shop is nice and they have boulder opal necklaces at good prices that are hard to find in Sydney. I passed them up and then wished I hadn't later when I tried to find similar ones. I ended up paying more somewhere else before I left. Would highly recommend coming here.

Oasis in the city. What a beautiful spot. Magnificent gardens amidst the heart of Sydney CBD. Photo opportunities with high rise in the background or Mrs Maquaries Chair or the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Or just admire the majestic flora.There's a great restaurant and a lovely little souvenir shop- don't miss that on your way out!!!

Very well done. The gardens are a terrific way to walk out of city, and the crowds and spend some time in a very nicely laid out and cared for botanic gardens. There are a number of garden theme areas to explore and are worth the time and effort if you like botany and gardens. Since it's free, its a bonus.
So worth a walk. Just lovely, high recommend a walk! Government House is stunning and it's a great view of the Harbour in lovely surroundings.

Find the cockatoos for some very close encounters!. What a lovely space, full of wildlife and very pretty areas to sit and take the world in. We enjoyed the Chinese gardens and spotting some very large spiders in the bushes! The cockatoos flock to one area by the waterfront and there were so many of them, lots of ibis too and other birds to see.

Cool and shady, peace and quiet. I have been visiting the gardens since I was a child and never tire of the beauty. They are extensive and full of plants and trees from all over the world. The governors residence backs on to the gardens and the harbour runs along one side. There is a cafe in the park but I would recommend you bring a picnic lunch, sit beside one of the ponds or under a tree and enjoy the peace and quiet.
Fantastic View !!. Was staying at Circular Quay and went for a walk in the morning. The place grows on you, is serene and scenic. Recommend for anyone staying in that area.

quite pleasant. a sunny day makes a walk in the royal botanic gardens a relaxing and amusing experience; walking in leisure and stoping at difference places in the gardens will take some time, well spent time.

walk among the flowers. colourful and lots of lovely monuments, government house, birds and can walk down to the waterviews. In the heart of the city but in a world of its own. great walking and for having a family picnic or a cuddle with your loved ones
Beautiful. Many different types of flora at this venue, very easy to reach from the opera house an easy walk.If you like gardening this place is for you

A must see when in Sydney. The gardens are lush and expansive. The views out over Sydney Harbour from the gardens are perfect. I've never found the Botanic Gardens crowded and in fact sometimes you will find yourself totally alone on a jungle track. Thousands of fruit bats have made part of the garden their home. The bats are damaging the trees and there have been plans hotly discussed about moving them on. The Royal Botanic Gardens is an oasis caught between a huge city and Sydney Harbour.

Relaxation plus. Enjoy the variety of plants and open space. On the Harbour foreshore a wonderful place to just relax or enjoy picnic time with family and friends Never crowded as there is plenty of room for everyone and their diverse requirements.

Magnificent Gardens. As mentioned in a previous review the Botanic Gardens are a beautiful area of Sydney to visit and relax in. Plenty of rest stations to either just rest or take in the beauty of the varied views within the 360 degree panorama. Suggest you continue through to Hyde Park to finish off the experience.

Beautiful Park with Spectacular views. The Botanic Gardens is a beautiful park with gorgeous flora everywhere. The park is open to the public and has the most spectular views of Sydney Harbour, Opera House and Harbour Bridge, not to mention that you can see the most of Sydney Harbour from the Gardens that is nestled on Sydney Harbour foreshore. You can walk around the park (Sydney Harbour foreshore) or through it, either way is easy, for all ages and all walking or no walking abilities. You can have a picnic or just enjoy the beautiful surroundings. In the park is the National Art Gallery and Government House, both can be visited. The park has convenience and a place to sit and buy food. A relaxing and free place to visit when in Sydney.

A really nice place for a walk or a picnic. A lovely old garden with lots of space for kids to run free and still not annoy everyone else. The gardens are always full of a variety of people, in business suits or completing their excercise regime during their lunch breaks, young families riding the little train around or feeding the ducks in the lakes, couples sitting under the huge figs and families having picnics. There is labels on plenty of the trees for people interested in the different species planted. During summer they have outdoor movies on a big screen overlooking the harbour and live performances of theatre such as A Midsummers Dream tyat moves around the garden. You can do an Aboriginal tour with a indigenous guide for a different view of the plants in the garden and learn a little bit about Sydney before white settlement. There is also a decent cafe and a restaurant.

Bat Heaven. Great park fantastic trees and seating areas,watch out for the thousands of fruit bats that call Sydney home.They live in the gardens in their thousands.You can walk around the waters edge to Mrs McQuarries chair.You can even hire a area of the park for a party or weddings

Well worth a visit. This is a well designed botanic garden that benefits enormously from is juxtaposition to the iconic Sydney Harbour. It's a very popular lunch time exercise spot for workers from Sydney's CBD so you may want to time your visit to avoid the conga lines of joggers. As Botanic Gardens go, it's collection has little to compete with the really great Botanic collections in UK and Europe BUT, it is one of the few places where you can come face to face with Wollemia nobilis. Wollemia is a genus of coniferous tree in the family Araucariaceae. Wollemia was only known through fossil records until this Australian species was discovered in 1994 in a still unrevealed area of Sydney's Blue Mountains.
Great place for those that like walking. It is a clean quiet spot in Sydney.It is free and peaceful. I like that there is no city noise. You can go for a walk and simply relax.

Peaceful. This is a really nice walk to undertake. Signpost tell you where to go and how long it will take and you are rewarded with some great views. This is a must do if you are in the City Centre and worth taking a picnic if you have time. The trees are flora are gorgeous.

A day with nature. Every major city has its botanical gardens and Sydney's Royal Botanic Gardens is a must. An idealic setting by the harbour.......a jewel in the crown of Sydney. Pathways lead you to cool and leafy escapes or sunny spots where you can enjoy a picnic or lay down on the many acres of beautiful grass and enjoy reading the paper or a good book. Exotic plants from all over the world and beautiful sculptures are not to be missed.

A jewel in the crown of Sydney. The gardens are a real gem, often overlooked by tourists or taken in too quickly to really appreciate the beauty of the gardens and the perfect setting on the harbour. They are an easy walk from the CBD or the opera house, and much of the garden is wheelchair accessible. Take a picnic lunch and plan to spend a few hours. There are also cafes and restaurants, but why dine inside when the outside is so gorgeous?The Royal Botanic Gardens adjoin the 'Domain', which is additional greenspace that is well used by the people of Sydney for sport, family activities or just lazing about. A good way to start a visit to the gardens is to walk along the water's edge from the opera house, around Farm Cove and on through the Domain to Mrs Macquaire's Chair for magnificant views back to the opera house and harbour bridge ... followed by an icecream. Then return via one or more of the many paths that meander through the botanic gardens. If time permits, do as we did and then visit the art gallery of NSW at the south-east corner of the gardens, in the Domain.

Harbour Views, Plants and Picnics. I never miss a visit to the Botanic Gardens when in Sydney, whether its a whole afternoon simply rambling around the collection, or a quick stroll through between the Gallery and Circular Quay, the Botanic Gardens is where you can escape the city, but not the Harbour.The Harbourside Walk is to be recommended. Ditto perusal of the succulent and fig collections. You can even see a Wollemi Pine, a plant indigenous to the Blue Mountains that was only discovered in the 1980s. It dates back to the days of Gondwanna Land, when Australia and and South America where yet to set adrift and is amongst the most ancient of tree forms on earth.Try not to miss Lady Macquarrie's Chair on the Opera House side, or the impressive Botanic Garden Gates on the Gallery side. And drink in the greenery as well as the scenery!
Freaking beautiful ... Walked to the garden in the morning up to Mrs. Macquaries point, beautiful view of the harbour, bridge and opera house.

even in winter worth a stroll. though less foliage in winter, still impressive to walk and view the harbor and opera house. My kids enjoyed searching for and finding the eels in one of the small pools.

I especially enjoyed the wild birds that were everywhere. We entered the gardens from the side of the opera house. This place is huge! Lots of walkways and benches. You can see everything here from ocean life at the sea wall to duck ponds and flowers.
Great Walk. This place is really nice, the parkland is very well looked after and there is allot of wildlife. Be sure to get the photo of both the Opera house and Harbour Bridge in.
An Excellent Free Tour. Even in the winter the gardens are full of life, whether plant or animal and the passionate tour guides will help you understand and appreciate the variety of life here.

Such huge trees and expansive park!. I could have spent all day there because I love plants and trees! We walked through to get to the recreation trail and on to the Opera House, but when you come off the city streets into the Gardens it is just so beautiful!They have it in sections by types of plants and trees and we just saw a bit of it walking through, but I would love to go back and spend more time there!Come to think of it, it started raining so we were a bit rushed...

Lovely Walk and Fantastic Views. When visitors come to town, I like to start with a stroll through the Botanic Gardens, to give them a taste of local flora and a view from Mrs Macquarie's toward the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House. We then walk along the water for a close-up view of the Opera House and Circular Quay. I just wish there were better cafes for lunch (without breaking the bank to pay the bill) along the Quay, to end a perfect introduction to Sydney.

Its a must when you visit Sydney. Its free, it has heaps to see and enjoy. It is great time out. A lot of thought has gone into the Royal Botanic Gardens. If I had more time in Sydney I would be back here again. So my tip, make sure you have plenty of time to take in this place to enjoy it, its worth it

From colony to city. This site is the place where the first farm of the new colony was established. It doesn't look like a farm any more as it is a very well thought out and cared for botanic garden. Some trees and plants here are as old as the colony itself and if you don't care about any of this history it is a beautiful place to visit, run, or just sit and watch the harbour or the world go by.

Great activity. Spent the morning walking the grounds of the Royal Botanic Gardens - incredible views, interesting plants, lots of walk ways. That Australian's devote prime retail land to beautiful parks says a lot about what they value!
Wonderful place to chill. If you want to relax on the grass and at the same time have a beautiful view of the harbour and the Sydney Opera House, that's the place to be.

Right in the heart of the city. The one thing the Australians are not short of is space, as demonstrated by this wonderful park adjacent to the Central Business District. Strolling round here for a couple of hours is simply a joy

A wonderful place to relax.. Views spectacular, gardens well kept and beautiful, plenty of areas to just sit and think about nothing. These gardens are a must for any overseas visitor and somewhere I always take friends coming to Sydney.

Lovely. Gardens were very nice and well maintained. We walked around for about an hour and a half in the Gardens. I think we only saw a small portion of what is actually there but what we did see was lovely. Recommend it to anyone visiting Sydney.
An oasis in the heart of bustling city. Special treats included the overall tranquility and awesome sight of pearl white butterfly colony on native pomegranate trees.
Beautiful!. The Royal Botanical Gardens were really enjoyable, well kept, beautiful flowers, we even got to see some exotic birds flying around free. Amazing!
Blissful. Beautifully kept, very tranquil in parts, stunning views of the harbour. Could definitely keep me occupied for the best part of the day.

Lovely way to spend an afternoon. Start up the top and walk down through the gardens. Take a picnic lunch as the cafes are expensive. If you start down the bottom near the Opera House you can catch the free train. Lots more info here but all in all a great cheap day looking over the most beautiful harbour in the world http://www.sydneyforall.com/RoyalBotanicGardens.html

So much to see and the views.. This is a great place to spend a few hours away from the main harbour area. It is only a few minutes walk from the opera house and you can walk all the way round in a circle. There is a cafe and shop in the gardens and as usual plenty of different plants etc.

Beautiful!. The views of the harbor, the various plants, especially those indigenous to Australia is very nice! It is quite a large area in the heart of Sydney, and a great place to relax or go for a jog, stroll, or picnic. I loved it!

Absolute must do. lovely, gorgeous, fun, interesting. Even if you don't go for the botannicals, go for the views. There are sometimes events on in the gardens so it's worth checking what's on before you go.
Stunning. Glad I took the time to walk through here, very children friendly and it's nice to see the various artistically sculptured gardens.

Beautiful Gardens. Really beautiful and well maintained. Lots of pretty flowers and birds, even in the winter. So many different walks and paths to take. Makes you forget you are in the middle of the city.

A great respite from downtwn Sydney - and it's all free!. No trip to Sydney is complete without having spent a considerable amount of one's time exploring the Botanical Gardens. The atmosphere is so calming. Photographers have much to see and capture with the many different plants, animals and fantastic views.
A great respite from the rush of downtown Sydney.

A must for all plant lovers and nature lovers. The herb garden was exceptional for us. The fountain in the herb is good time pass for children when adults get around the wonderful herb garden. The sundial is also highly recommended.

Great spot...lungs of the city. What a delight to walk through the Royal Botanic Gardens with spectacular views of the harbour and city as a backdrop. Beautiful gardens and absolutely loved the signs which stated "Please walk on the grass...we also invite you to smell the roses, hug the trees, talk to the trees and picnic on the lawns". Great message...great place, enjoy!

Lovely surroundings and views, very pleasant walk. Really pleasant area and I went back for a guided tour (free and take place every day at 10.30 am), that was when closer examination showed just how many some of the specimens actually are! But that does not take away from the glory of the setting. Views of the Opera House and bridge from a very different angle. make sure you visit Mrs Mcquaire's seat for a bit of history and to view the famous sites - and the industrial port on the other side of the headland.
Fantastic Garden/Park in a World Class Setting. Liked everything about it the variety of plants and trees, the Governors House, the views out to sea, over the Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge.

Oasis of calm in a busy city. The best thing about the Botanic gardens is the feeling of peacefulness and calm that comes about through walking through the many different trees and other species planted there. It's just a fantastic place to spend a couple of hours chilling before plunging into the maelstrom of Sydney. Make sure you walk on to Mrs. Macquarie's chair and enjoy the view of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge from there - and maybe a pie and coffee from the little shop there.

Nice, long stroll. This can be a very long walk, which is really nice, but you can also cut it a bit short. We went to the Opera House and then walked this direction, taking in all the beautiful scenery, and looking everything around. Taking a leisurely pace, it took about 4 hours to make a "full" trip, stopping a few times on a bench to appreciate water views.
Beautiful scenery. We walked through the entire gardens and had unbelievable views of the Opera House and harbour. Bring a camera and take lots of pictures.

Great in the winter..... A July visit is worth the price.
Very pleasant.
We are pleased with the attention to detail, the views, and the flora.

Beautiful grounds to walk or jog. If you are in Sydney, you have to go for a stroll through the Botanic Gardens. The amount of flora is astonishing, and everything is labeled so it is interesting and educational as well. Note that this is a tropic garden, not all native Australian species but it is gorgeous.There is also a lot of bird watching to do right here in the garden; if you don't get to go on an actual birding tour and are in the city, you can get some of it done here! Check in with one of the garden tourist shops, they will likely know what birds have been around and can give you a map to point out the most likely spots to find them!

Botanical Brilliance. Clearly, a huge amount of thought went into the design of the Gardens. There are many places of quiet and calm, even on a busy summer's day. Often, there are exhibitions such as Japanese tea drinking in the Japanese area. My favourite though, is the cactus display. I always get a feeling of a parched throat while walking around these.
Very peaceful and just next to city. Gardens are right next to Opera House so it is good to do gardens then you appear on right of Opera House and get amazing views of it and Harbour Bridge.

Just stunning!. A wonderful way to spend a few hours taking a leisurely stroll through the beautiful gardens. For those who don't like to walk there is a train :Choo Choo Express which takes you on a 30 min tour with commentary.

What a treasure!. Take the tour. Have a picnic. Go back several times. There is a lovely restaurant for a splurge, but a muffin and coffee at the outdoor tables while you watch birds making their nests is fun too.
Beautiful Walk. Really enjoyed these gardens - amazing views of Sydney Harbour and the Opera House. Also enjoyed seeing the parakeets and the ibis. Definite must-do while in Sydney.
A nice walk. Spend an afternoon in the gardens. Wine and cheese or a picnic. It is a great walk, and a relaxing day

Free! Time for some fresh air. The gardens are within an easy walking distance of the city centre and other attractions such as Sydney Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. I found out that there is a rainforest centre which simulates a rainforest environment, a rose garden, herb garden, desert area and more! worth a walk through.Lots of photogenic spots for llovely photoshoot, if possible i would want my pre wedding shoots to be done there. awesome! and its free!

The Louvre of Botanical Gardens. I've been to a few bontanical gardens in my day, but this one destroys them all--there are trees in this garden that are bigger than some whole botanical gardens. It's also old, I think it was founded in the late 1800s--so it has some huge old trees. There is so much variety--sometimes I had to stop and focus just trying to take in some of the individual species. My daughter did this really well. We came after a big rain storm so there was a fair amount of plant matter that had been knocked onto the ground. She collected pods and seeds and flowers that were fit for a fairy wedding. The gardens also attract a lot of birds--the air was filled w the flight (and screech) of cockatoos. We also saw what I think we're Ibis and some other waterfowl. At one point we looked over and saw a section of the garden swarmed by white butterflies. We walked over and read that this is the only known colony of this type of butterfly in NSW and it typically always lives within 20 meters of a certain pomegranate tree in the garden. The gardens flow down to the opera house. What more could you want in for an incredible day in Sydney.

lovely escape from the city. There is a lot to see in this park, and it has spectacular views. every time i go there i find more to see and explore. there is a rainforest centre which simulates a rainforest environment, a rose garden, herb garden, desert area and more! worth a walk through
Beautiful gardens. At the Royal Batanic Gardens so big and so good location to be relaxing. we can go theier for walk , run and looking for view. It so quiet and fantastic place to visit it.
Ditch the map and get lost!. Beautiful gardens, gorgeous views, great for a stroll around the fragrant herb garden or a jog to McQuarie's Point. Definitely a highlight not-to-be-missed.

Go hear the birds!. The gardens are free and very well manicured. The trees here seem very unique to the region and worth a visit. Even more intersting are the wild birds that make all sorts wild noises. Some sound like a lady screaming or yelling. It is quite large and tranquil to find your own space on a nice sunny day.

Simply Wonderful. Clean, well maintained and beautifully laid out. Picnic, evening walk, outing with the kids, or just to relax with a book, this is the place.
If you're with kids, not all parts are pram friendly (stairs) and the pools are not fenced, so keep an eye on them!

Very relaxing. There is alot to see in these gardens, unfortunately at the time I visited alot of flowers had died but it was still beautiful and so peaceful, so nice to bring a book and spend an hour just relaxing.
golf course. i only went for a stroll around here by accident but i thought it was lovely, well kept and i have been on worse golf courses !

Beautiful. When I visited there were building works going on just by the opera house which did not cause massive problems, but I believe this would be more beautiful without them! I'm not really one for trees and plants and things but these gardens were truly beautiful. Very clean and tidy, would definitely recommend.

Beautiful location within the city. The gardens are within an easy walking distance of the city centre and other attractions such as Sydney Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. They are well laid out with several different areas within a small space in a beautiful setting beside the harbour. The weather was not great when we visited but it was still a pleasant way to spend the morning.
Must to see. wonderful, quiet place, lovely trees, birds, lovely gardens. A place to find your harmony and to forget the noise of the town.

A jewel in the crown of Sydney. Just 5 mins walk from Martin Place this historic and beautiful tapestry of horticulture has something for everybody. Excellent tours, lush lawns to sit and relax, superb views and great dining options round out this superb asset in the heart of Sydney.

Nice walk, even in light rain.. I walked through the gardens in light rain and it was still a very pleasant and relaxing space. The gardens' layout gives plenty options to either walk along the water or more inland.

Beautiful gardens covering a lot of grounds. Beautiful gardens covering a lot of grounds. Lots of interesting birds to see as well as plants. Great free activity for tourists or for going on a date. You could also pack a lunch.
beautiful park. Perfect place for a picnic!! Stunning views and right next to the opera house on one end and the CBD. the walk along the harbour is highly recommended too

Beautiful. These gardens are lovely. We walked through them from the city to the Opera House and were impressed. Although this was middle of winter, they still looked great and had a very relaxing feel to it.
One of the best. One of the best Botanic Gardens with a great bay view. Highly recommended. Don't miss it during your Sydney trip.
So relaxing. I wish I had allocated more time to walk around these gardens. Incredibly tranquil and beautifully tended.

Excellent place to visit. Took some overseas friends down by the Harbour awesome sunny day
Very clean and well kept, great place to visit

Amazing!. I loved walking through the Botanic Gardens to get to the Opera House. There is lots of diversity in plantlife, and the gardens make a relaxing break only a short distance way from the city. The ibis birds also provide great entertainment!

Nature next to the city!. Beautiful semi-tropical gardens almost in the city, full of plants, birds and great views. The birds are so tame it is like being in walk in avery - after the bussle of the city this is a complete contrast!

Amazing Gardens and Bird Life - and Free. The Gardens border the Sydney CBD and plan to spend some time here. Bird life is also amazing - but as a tip wear some good walking shoes as also can be a bit hilly - depending on the path you take.
