Just relax and enjoy the views. Great chance to get away from the city - but still close enough to be back within a few minutes - well set out and well stocked with mature plants - take a trip to the governors house too
Nice half day walk. Had a nice walk around the botanic gardens. Some nice areas to picnic on a sunny day! Worth a visit.
Beautiful and quiet. A really nice walk!. Only walking distance from the city and Opera House but quiet and serene! Can get great photos here!
A great English park in the sub-tropics.. See above--but there is, in addition, the views of the harbour and the city, the lovely palm grove, and the extraordinary ficus trees.

Eventful. We were enjoying a stroll through the beautiful gardens when my wife badly twisted her ankle. The staff at the gardens responded quickly and applied first aid and then took us to Sydney Hosiptal to have the damage assessed and treated. We will have to come back to complete out walk through the gardens!! Thank you to the staff at the gardens!!
Great way to relax. Spent hours walking, sitting, smelling, taking photos & mainly just relaxing. Such a perfect location on the harbour & has been wonderfully taken advantage of.

Fantastic Day out. One of the best Botanic Gardens I've been too! Really well designed, a lot of plant variety and mini-gardens within the garden - great place for families or couples or solo travelers! Highly recommend.

Nice long walk. Next to the opera house, there are numerous paths through the beautiful gardens which wraps around Sydney Harbour. Plenty of areas to picnic or just meditate on the beauty of the plants and the bay.

Beautiful open space on the Harbor. A lovely garden right on the water. Lots of open space for the kids to run around and burn off energy. there is a cafe on the grounds which is reasonable for a picnic lunch.

BEAUTIFUL. The Botanical Gardens are a great place to have tea. The Botanical Gardens have beautiful flowers and insects. Nothing would hurt a fly at the Botanical Gardens. The Botanical Gardens are a great place to relax and just enjoy yourself and your surroundings.

Just too Beautiful. THe Royal Botanic Gardens, stroll along and see the most amazingly beautiful plants exotic and local walk around it in the mornings or run around it and breath in the freshest of air...the Opera House is at one end of it and the NSW Art Gallery at the other end...where else can you park your car and run down some steps do your 2.5km walk and be in the middle of total beauty?

A nice, free attraction. This is a free attraction and a nice way to spend a morning or afternoon. There are many paths and routes to take. My favourite is one leading from the Gates in Macquarie Street, next to the Conservatorium of Music and ending up on the Finger Wharf in Wooloomooloo. If walking back, make sure you do it before 7pm as this is when the gates close.

Any time of year you can come here. This garden, the first one in the colony, has a long history and is carefully maintained by a dedicated team of gardeners. The trees are so old that sometimes they lie down with their crowns in their arms. There are landscaped gardens with new plants and older areas with plants that predate the colony. This is a magical place for any time of the year. There are statues in the grounds and there are ducks on the pond. Come and see for youself why people love it.

You can’t go wrong. The Royal Botanic Gardens are extensive and beautiful. You can just walk in through a gate and explore the pathways, seeing all sorts of plants and views. The maintenance is immaculate and the lawns and garden beds are stunning. You’ll also get some great views of the Sydney skyline from inside the gardens. Worth a few hours at least to explore.

Visiting in Winter. We visited during the winter, so unfortunately it wasn't a great time to see all the flowers - but the views of the harbor was wonderful and their were plenty of great walking paths to stroll.
Amazing harbourside gardens. well established botanic garden with wonderful harbour views. Plants are labelled and you can sit on the grass!

One of the Best Experiences I had while in Sydney. I loved the botanical gardens in Sydney. What's not to love?! The view is fantastic, take your pick either of the water or the opera house or the garden itself. Perfect. They are free to enter which I thought was amazing and great. We ate al fresco at the restaurant there, the food was good. Many photo opportunities. Interesting to see the the huge bats hanging on the trees and then all of a sudden we hear this caos up in the trees, we were there at the right time when the white wild cockatoos come to feed & rest and get on the same trees as the bats and kind of start shrieking and fighting for space on the trees. The bats leave to feed on insects while the cockatoos mingle with the people on the grounds. Amazing. Be careful & watch out as these lovely birds like to bite! Wear a hat that covers your ears as they will get on your head & might want to take a nibble. Loved and cherish this memory. Great experience.
Stroll and relax. My friend had her wedding ceremony here - could not have had a better backdrop (to the Opera House) and photo opportunities. It's great for a walk and a picnic too.

Fun way to get out of the city and still be in it!. Tucked behind the Opera House, this is a great tailed to touring the exterior of the Opera House. You can either walk or take a mini-train around. We had a picnic under the trees. The cafe is actually pretty good and reasonable, for Sydney standards. Great views of the city too. Great for kids!
Serene atmosphere and lovely views. Absolutely worth it. A nice walk in tranquil greenery away from the busy streets and concrete of the city. I enjoyed approching Opera house from this angle.

I went back several times.. Beautiful designed and maintained - only a short walk from the opera house - a wonderful place to learn about native trees, visit the greenhouses, more great views. The jacaranda was flowering which made it even more special. . After the long walks through the city it was great to walk barefoot in the grass.

Beautiful Gardens. If you like botanical gardens you'll love the Royal Botanical Gardens, they are expansive, varied and very well maintained. They warn you about Flying Foxes (very large bats) but we didn't see any, perhaps because it was winter. As beautiful as it was, Ivan imagine its even better in the spring.

Beautiful. Amazing gardens, variety of different plants and a gorgeous mass tulip display. Only thing is that entry gates are a bit hard to find. a must in any season to escape the city hustle and bustle!

Nothing beats this scenic and leisurely stroll by the sea. Nothing beats this scenic and leisurely stroll by the sea. I would recommend that you start from Circular Quay, heading towards the Sydney Opera House, where you can spend an hour or so touring it. Just five minutes' walk along the shore, you will reach the Royal Botanic Gardens, a lush and vast park where they invite you to walk on the grass. It is filled with many species of plants and herbs. Stop by the central lake where you can see birdlife as well as eels swimming along. Better yet, bring some food and wine and have a picnic. A lovely way to spend a spring morning.

Perfect place to unwind.. After walking around for hours, it was an excellent choice to sit back and relax on the grass or the garden chairs which were everywhere for free! Beautiful garden, very well maintained. Love it!

Royal Botanic Gardens. The Gardens are breathtaking and very well kept. There is much to explore and plenty of exercise. Lots of beautiful bird life from Rainbow Lorakeets to the ibis to black ducks, cockatoos and more. I was profoundly disappointed this year to see that the Gardens staff had finally successfully run off the Flying Fox Bats - a sight to see in themselves and one of the many reasons I have been returning to the Gardens year after year. It's hard for many who take them for granted to understand the uniqueness and specialness of this species. Very disappointing.

Get away from the city hustle and bustle. Winter in the gardens is obviously a time for maintenance but it is still a beautiful place to have a wander around. We also enjoyed lunch in the restaurant where it was a bit noisy due to some large family groups however the staff were very attentive and food was very nice.

Beautiful gardens, a haven in downtown Sydney. A condensed version of Australia flora and nostalgia for Europe. Beautiful nature right in the middle of Sydney, a complement to the splendor of the harbor and the city bustle.
Huge and Well Maintained. Huge and very well maintained. I spent many days picnic or went for a run here. It is one of the parks that I spent many days on. Totally recommended.

Give yourself time. I didn't allow enough time to do the Gardens justice, just walked through them on the way to the opera house. What we did see made us want to spend longer on our next visit - lots of exploring to do. Will probably allow between a half to a full day.
Spend the day wandering. With many different areas and gardens you will not get bored!! There's lots to see and brilliant areas to relax.
Plants. It is so peaceful to walk around and look at the gardens they are kept so nice its a good day out for the family.
Quiet and beautiful. Big garden. You will need a map. Very nice view to the Opera house and the town. Go visiting the government house for free.
Nice. a good place for all age group. The surroundings is very peaceful. The natural environment is great. The plush green trees and plans, the garden, the walk. Its very soothing.
The lungs of Sydney.. hadn't been for a walk through the gardens for years. was pleasantly surprised by the beauty of the place, even on a winters day.

Really Nice gardnes. If you like nature and green areas, this is the place.
Lots of pathways to walk through, nice places to sit down and relax.
Look for the Kakadoos (white parrot with yellow "spike" head feathers)

Very pretty & sweet smelling. Loved the gardens.
They were neat and tidy and smelt beautiful.
Got to see most flowers in full bloom and enjoyed walking around seeing the many different trees, plants, flowers and gadren exhibits.
Gorgeous. Wonderful different sections and an amazing sample of trees, plants and bushes. Lovely cafe in the centre and all this in the middle of the city

Very pretty. The Royal Botanic Gardens are very pretty. There are trees, plants, and flowers from all over the world. If you are not from the area, it is worth checking out for some trees in particular that were different from anything I've ever seen. There is a lot of ground to cover. You don't necessarily need to do it all. Worth a stroll or perhaps back a lunch and people-watch!

Lovely,Peaceful. The gardens are an oasis in the heart of Sydney. A great place to relax away from the hustle and bustle of city life. Take time to appreciate the many beautiful gardens and amazing bird life within the gardens. There are amazing statues at various places within the park.There are also a couple of water features to enjoy.There is a great view of the city skyline and views of Sydney Harbor at places in the gardens.A great place to take some amazing photos. Its a place I would highly recommend for people living in or visiting Sydney.

Nice break form the city. Well maintained garden worth exploring. Lots of birds to take in up close. A wide variety of plants and flowers to see as well. In the mist of the garden is the Governor's House which is free to the public to tour.
Views of the harbour are magic. Botanical display varies and not at its peak in July. But lovely walks with water vistas and if you get tired try to find Mrs McQuarie's chair and have a rest.
Lovely place. Good place to have a picnic or hang out with kids. Take the mini train ride to see all of the gardens
A leafy paradise... During a heatwave in December, what better way to relax & admire the beautiful surroundings of Sydney than in the Royal Botanic Gardens!

Visit more than one Sydney landmark here. After a year of not seeing each other, I visited my significant other,who was then based in Sydney, last year. The RBG was a good choice to spend a lazy afternoon as it is quiet and huge with a number of themed gardens showcasing their respective plant collections. Even though some of the outdoor plants were covered in nets (it was winter), it didn't ruin the experience one bit. Before you start your stroll in the park, pay a visit to the Art Gallery of NSW then walk your way into the gardens. Explore each seemingly wrong turn only to discover something beautiful. When you reach the other end, get a stunning view of the Sydney Opera House and the harbor. We chose one of the benches on the elevated ground and nicknamed it "our spot." It was one of the best (and cheapest) dates we've ever had.

A lovely place for lunch. After seeing art at the NSW State Gallery we almost always walk into the Botanic Gardens to have a lovely lunch. The walk itself is fascinating surrounded by beautiful and interesting plants. The restaurant is located near the garden shop on the upper floor with balcony behind grape vines. The food is beautifully cooked but a warning for those who like hearty meals: portions are small. I wish we could have a restaurant like this in Canberra Botanic Gardens or Australian National Gallery.

Relax in beauty. How wonderful is it? I was the last person who was kick out of the garden by closing the place security guard. Just put comfortable shoes an enjoy the garden, bats, and the views on Sydney, opera, bridge and sunset and .... watch your clock.

Grassy retreat. The Royal Botanic Gardens offer tourists and office workers a green space in which to recharge. They are attractively laid out with plenty of lawned areas and big trees. For those not wishing to walk there is a "train" that chugs around , At about 10 AuD its probably fun for kids. There are a couple of interesting artworks like a Corinthian column and life size statue of a mare and foal( the mare's expression is particularly good) along with some large rock objects.I had lunch at the Botanic Cafe near the duck ponds , but would not recommend it my ciabatta had been around a while and although I requested toasted it was cold, the service was not memorable either.For anyone with kids or looking for a place to sit awhile the gardens offer great views and plenty of space, though be aware of joggers at lunchtime.

Location and upkeep, one of the World's great City centre gardens. Located right alongside Sydney downtown these botanic gardens contain a range of native specimens as well as a small hothouse and cacti garden. More than this however the location running down from the neoclassical splendours of public buildings to the harbour and Opera House make these gardens a great strolling venue for whenever you have the time! Some interesting statues and great views .... Twenty minute ramble to much more if you are checking the flora and fauna!
Restful Gardens. Gardens are a very pretty and restful place to to have some 'time out' in the city. We visited th gardens in the winter,i'm sure that we will be having a return visit in the summer.

Look out for the bats. Nice position, short walk from the Opera House. If you are a keen gardener plenty of indigenous flora and fauna to see. Colony od fruit bats there too. Noisy and messy so you cannot miss them. If you don't care for the walk, a small train will take you around the grounds - not expensive.
Lovely. Wondferful walk through nature tucked away into the city. Gardens are well maintained and the sculptures interesting. Good variety of bird life as well.

Beautiful even in winter. We loved our afternoon in the Royal Botanic Gardens. We spent much longer than planned there as it was so peaceful and beautifully laid out. We saw the most amazing birds - even lorikeets. Enjoy!
Very nice. Well worth a visit and so pleasant in the midst of such a large city!
Amazing flora and fauna. The varieties of flora and fauna on display are amazing, and some of the trees are ancient!

Nice day out with the kids. Beautiful gardens to spend the day walking around with the kids being able to run around and enjoying nature and the great views of Sydney Harbour, has a varity of different gardens to walk through, Animals to see including Birds, lizzards and fruit bats. A few options to eat at include cafes, kiosks. At one end of the gardens is the opera house and the other is the Art gallery. Fantastic place for photos. We got married here in the gardens in 2007 right by the water. I also remember as a kid myself being brought here by my parents for family days out. So will continue to visit this place for the memories we have shared
Nice and interesting. We joined the free walk in the morning and it was really nice. The fruitbats in the gardens are so big!

Far from spectacular. My dad is a forester, so he loves trees and plants. However, the garden got very repetitive. Most of the trees were the same (gum/eucalyptus trees). We did go when it was raining, which put a damper on it, but rain aside, I didn't think it was anything special.

Best Gardens in Sydney. Beautifully laid out and you should walk from the Opera House to Mrs Macquaries Chair and back to the CBD via Mrs Macquaries Road and the Art Gallery of NSW. You could easily spend a whole day here.
Beautiful and peaceful. My favourite place for a picnic in the whole world, even in the rain

Pack a picnic and just relax. A great place to sit and do nothing, or spend and hour or a day to just wander and enjoy the beautiful plants, ponds and garden fauna and the views of the harbour, Opera House and bridge.
A little slice of heaven. They actually ask you to waslk on the grass. Immerse yourself in a magnificent greenspace beside a beautiful and safe city.
Beautiful.. I very much liked the variety of plants and animals. Do not miss the flying foxes!
Went on Sunday. Lovely sunshine. Lovely gardens. Shame its winter and the roses aren't out.

Beautiful Botanical Gardens. A fantastic place for a peaceful walk or to stop for a picnic. There is plenty to look at, from flowers to cacti. There are water features, themed areas, places to sit, and well-manicured lawns. There's usually a lot of bats up in the trees which is quite cool. A good place to visit when making a trip to the Opera House/ Art Gallery or just down the Circular Quay end of town.

The Sunniest Side of the Street. Few places on earth as beguiling and enchanting as the Sydney Royal Botanic Gardens. A first-time stroll through this magnificent garden on a sunny day will not easily be forgotten.
worth a look for quiet reflection. nice and lovely peaceful to walk thru and think of the heritage

Sydney Royal Botanic Gardens. A great place for a relaxing walk or to spend several hours relaxing. Very interesting flora and unlike many other gardens, the public is invited to walk on the lawns. A huge flying fox colony has been roosting in the central part of the gardens for years and has destroyed many heritage trees. As a result, a noise eviction programme was undertaken in June 2012 to disturb the flying foxes so they roost elsewhere. This eviction programme has proven successful to date. The Gardens are next to the Sydney Opera House and Mrs Macquaries Chair.

Lovely.. We've walked through the Royal Botanic Gardens multiple times on our visit to Sydney. We think they are just fantastic. Beautiful flowers and trees, well kept lawns, and easily navigable paths. A real treasure in Sydney.

Beautiful place to visit. We live in Sydney, so try to visit regularly. You can simply walk through it or spend some time exploring all the different areas and have a picnic lunch or eat at the cafes. There is plenty of room for children to run around and explore. You can combine a visit with a visit to the Art Gallery or the Opera House. Remember the gates are closed in the evening , check the times as I got caught once in my youth and had to scale the wall....not fun.
A wide range of plants. A wide range of ploant especially Australian ones. Not much in flower in mid winter except in the heated glasshouses

Gardens great, but don't forget the Governor's Mansion. Even though it was mid winter a stroll the gardens was very worthwhile. One can only imagine how beautiful they would be in the spring and summer. However, the big surprise was a guided tour of the governor's mansion on the garden grounds. Not only is the the tour very well done, it is FREE, thanks to an order by the governor. To get a ticket go to the gatehouse and ask when the next available tour is taking place . They go every half hour.

beautiful, especially on a warm day. I took a walk through these gardens. I loved that there was a sign as you go in, stating that you can walk on the grass and hug the trees! I loved hearing the wind through the bambo, it was like a wind-chime. the gardens are well maintained and lovely, and you can see loads of gardeners busy working. I also liked seeing lots of people enjoying themselves; people jogging, family picnics, kids playing etc. Well worth a wonder through. I will return for a second visit.
A visual experience. Well laid out and maintained. A wonderfully planned and organized Botanic Garden. A place to sit and relax amidst the busyness of city life.
Strolling through Paradise. An amazing place, beautiful orchids, flowers, trees and wildlife. Walk through here at sunset and it is an experience that will never leave you.

A wonderful haven, close to the Sydney Central Business District. Set on Sydney Harbour, amidst the peaceful Farm Cove. The Gardens sprawl up to the Domain and the city. Nice restaurant towards the centre of the Gardens. Good for joggers and locals/tourists looking for a break from the city.

Peaceful. These gardens were beautiful, full of lovely birds and great views of the Opera House. These are also the home of Mrs McQuarries chair which is worth a look. There is also an outdoor swimming pool.
Stunning. These garden are beautiful, so a great day in Spring is the time to go and its not too hot either

Tranquility in Sydney, what a wonderful spot. A wonderfully tranquil spot in a modern city, my favourite part of the city. Beautiful flora and fauna, and the roosting fruitbats are quite an experience indeed. An essential spot to chill out in Sydney. Highly recommended.
Beautiful. Great food in the gorgeous botanical gardens great or birthdays and celebrations they staff are also fantastic

Oasis of peace. Fantastic flora, as you would expect, little train to take you around which brings back memories of childhood, amazing location on the harbour with fantastic views of the opera house, a great place for a picnic, and check out those huge bats!
Beautiful. Right in the heart of the city. A must visit when your there. Lovely laid out gardens and lawns and a peaceful retreat from city life. A good place to see the local bird life.

An oasis in Sydney. Every Sydney visitor should visit this beautiful botanical garden, the view of the bay and the Opera House are magnificent.
My wife and I walked throught it and ended at Sydney Opera House.
Simply Stunning. Wonderful walking & exploring on a sunny winters day

please step on the green. in many western countries you might find a sign on a green in a paar: plase do not walk on the green.
In Sydney you are invited do do so... :-) great area, very interesting trees, plants, animals

My Fav Place in Sydney. Need a reprieve from the hustle and bustle? The Botanic Gardens have it. Need to learn about Australia's floral and fauna? Botanic Gardens. Want an outstanding place for an intimate wedding or vow renewal? Yep, Botanic Gardens... This is THE place I go to in Sydney EVERY TIME I go home to get some balance. It's my place for peace and tranquility and it can be busy as ever and it's still beautiful and peaceful.
Beautiful place. One of the most beautiful gardens I have ever seen... Superb views, plants and animals especially parrots..

A nice place to walk and admire the views. Easy to access, and a delight to walk in, with a wonderful mix of flowers, trees and vistas. When we visited there were several trees full of hanging bats, lots of different birds, some with their young.It was easy to find quiet places to sit and reflect, and the land based views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge were good too.All in all a most enjoyable experience.
Nice Gardens. Nice gardens...hard to fault any garden when beautiful flowers are involved :)I have seen much better, though.

Tranquility in the city. The flowering aloes in the succulent garden, near the conservatorium of music and throughout the gardens are an absolute feast for the eyes. We noticed them in many parts of he gardens and they added brights colour throughout. What amazing plants. The coffee in the gardens cafe is strong and hot- delicious!
Not so awesome in the winter. Went in June - not much was in bloom. However a lot of the herbs were thriving. Very quaint "English" style gardens.
Fairly average. The garden is fairly ordinary, I would leave this to last if you have other things to do.
Taking time out. Take a quiet walk around the gardens and reflect how far from home you are when watching the parrots flying around, a place away from the hustle.

Excellent gardens and smack in the middle of the city. Great cities have great gardens within the city and Sydney is no different. It was beautful and peaceful at the gardens seeing very different flora from where I come from. To top it off, there a museum in the middle, the Art Gallery of NSW!

Beautiful gardens and views. The RBG are beautiful. There is a myriad of wonderful, native and non-native species displayed. It is extremely well kept and some of the views are really pretty. One of the most interesting things we saw were several large trees completely covered in bats. Lots of trails for walking, picture taking and jogging.

A lovely afternoon. Hmm there isnt much to dislike. The lay of the gardens tends to make you want to search what may be around the corner yet at the same time you just want to laze around and have a lush picnic. Although there are many people walking around you have a sense that it is all yours and feel no rush to move along at any point. I wish I would have spent more time here. I loved the gift shop which had many pictures and post cards of parts of the gardens which you could mail right there. Amazing.

What you imagine Australian life to be. This is a fabulous place. The exotic and strange plants the cockatoo's flying free. Take the little road train around so see more than you may wish to walk. One point of advise be aware that the massive fruit bats are way up in the trees ( you will see them flying as it get closer to dusk) the issue here is that the forget their manners and are very liable to use you as a target for thier droppings!! You have been warned.
Beautiful. One of the worlds most beautiful gardens...how can you compete when it it right on the waterfront of Sydney HArbour!
A place to relax. After a days sightseeing we found refuge here and enjoyed the little cafe. What an idyllic place right on the harbour foreshores.
Great views. Really fantastic views of the harbour bridge and opera house. Nice walk with interesting plants and trees, lots of walking/jogging trails.
Take one of the free guided tours. Free guided tours, 2 daily, we had a very knowledgable guide and learned a lot about domestic flora.
It's even good in the rain. The setting is beautiful, right on the harbour. Plenty of recreation, walking paths, etc

Pleasant experience. This was a very infortmative afternoon. We had a stroll and met up with a gentleman whose knowledge was fantastic. The bats and background to the Australian birds was great. The gardens were just perfect in colour and just nice to have this just a stones throw away from the central location of the Harbour. Really enjoyed the experience.
Must Do. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney are huge. Strolling through the garden is very calming and enjoyable.
Empty. Sorry but simply nothing much to see for a group of six of us it was money down the drain. When approached, even the lady taking the money apologised for the lack of everything.

A must see for budding botanists. These gardens are most impressive and well worth a visit if you like beautiful trees, well manicured lawns and magnificent harbour glimpses. Allow plenty of time to see the exhibits and to just stroll around soaking up the atmosphere.
So natural. First of all it's a beautiful park -- but loved a sign that basically said, walk on the grass, fly a kite, enjoy. That's the best kind of garden!

A beautiful respite from the city. Stayed in the Marriott went for a short run every morning in the park. It was lovely relaxing and beautiful, with amazing birds and a jog down to Sydney harbour and the opera house. Can you imagine a better start to the day? A real respite from the city. Ok the bad news is the opera house needs and is getting a refit.

Amazing Gardens. One of the best botanical gardens I have been in. The upkeep is amazing, many great trees, plants and flowers to see along with sculptures, and the gardens are quite expansive. A nice slice of tranquility in the middle of such a large, busy city. The approach up to the Opera House with the Harbour Bridge in the background is very nice.

Unbelievable. The flora and fauna in Australia are amazing the the Botanic Gardens (both the one in Sydney and the Mount Tomah gardens in the Blue Mountains) offer a great overview of what's truly special about Australia.

Best Tour in Sydney. A wonderful place to visit, just to lie on the grass! The free guided tours are the best! It differs from day-to-day, and from guide-to-guide (all volunteers) - no 2 tours are ever the same, because of the weather and season changes. The guides have their own favourite routes, and little snippets of information to share. The tour is a mix of nature walk, historical gossip, botany lesson and good ol' fresh air.The tour runs daily at 10.30am, for 1 1/2 hours and there are tours at 1pm on weekdays as well.
Stunning!. The gardens are stunning! There is also a small gift shop and cafe here and wonderful walks right down to the harbour and a rather famous view to look at!

will be visiting again when we are in Sydney. An amazing place for walks at your leisure. A huge array of fauna, flowers, birds and flying foxes.Plenty of places to take a rest. Directions are very clearly marked to parts of the botanical garden, cafes, restaurants and restrooms.One thing I was not too keen at one of the cafés was the Florentine. It was the most strange Florentine I have ever tasted and also it was not fresh. Public toilet was very clean.The gardens lead to the Sydney Opera House. Going backwards from there to get to the other side, is Mrs Macquarie’s Chair from where you can see the most spectacular views of the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge.A must if you are visiting Sydney. Highly recommended.

Watch out for Wild Cockatoos!. Loved walking through the Botanic Gardens! It was a bit chilly as we were there in June but none the less the gardens were beautiful and full of wild life. Keep your eyes peeled for the Cockatoos near the water! So cool! :)

Perfect little botanical gardens. Somehow on all of my recent journeys I have ended up in the botanical gardens and on our recent trip to Sydney, it happened again. The gardens are very pretty and easy to walk through - we were impressed with the flowers and layouts and it was a great little respite from the city life.We saw lots of birds and also a tree full of fruit bats which were quite a surprise - I know they are vermin but they did look very interesting.We only had a short time there but I'd like to go back and walk around again and enjoy the tranquility.

Sublime Relaxing post .. So BIG so many different Gardens and quite area,s nooks and Crannies. Good spot to rest on the Lady MacQuarie to Opera House walk , Food outlets average Toilets need more , The Bats are being relocated theres 1000,s Beautiful, If you get a Chance go for a FREE Tour at the Old Government HOuse within the Gardens.
stunning. I love this park. Lots of lovely plants, trees and flowers. Lots of people watching to be done. Brilliant view of harbour bridge and sydney opera house infront of it.

the ocean and the gardens - a beautiful combo. Loved the Gardens - of course, the vegetation, giant fig trees, the layout, the ponds, sculptures, the birds (fed them from the palm and could pet the feathers!). Shot a movie with fruit bats - caught them in the flight quite close - an amazing experience and not for the faint of heart. There were free volunteer-guided walks in the gardens - many thanks! Food in the cafeteria was good - choice of hot stuff and sandwiches, cakes and fruit salads, and not too pricey. My only peeve - they close the gates too early - it is still too light to take pictures, and one can't cut through the Gardens. The views of the ocean and the Harbour from the Gardens are lovely, the walk on the other side was winding and interesting.
Tranquil. The Royal Botanic Gardens is a beautiful place to stroll through or just sit and realx in its tranquil environment. A good way to spend a few hours on a sunny day.
Beautiful. Beautiful gardens with well-manicured displays, unique sculptures, and lively wildlife.

Variety of wildlife and views are amazing. The gardens are beautiful and relaxing with an abundance of wildlife, particularly flying foxes and tropical birds. Walk around to Mrs Macquaries Point for stunning views of the Opera House with the Harbour Bridge behind - particularly at sunset.
Treasure!. From picnics to a solitude getaway, it has every patch to suit, delight and challenge all. Must see.
Quiet, Beautiful, Inspiring. I always talk a walk throughout the gardens each time I visit Sydney, I love the quiet in the the middle of a huge city
Spectacular. I took the kids for a fun day at the Gardens - we enjoyed the many different places to see - Hide and Seek has never been more fun. Picnic in the park anyone!!

Beautiful. Take a few hours and wander through the gardens. Or take along a blanket and lay in the grass. Great views of the harbor, the Opera house and the unique vegetation and plant life of Australia.

Beautiful Beautiful Beautiful. The most amazing trees among many other plants.
Its one of my favorite places to walk. There are bats sleeping in the trees, I love that they dont get rid of them! The gardens are natural and well groomed. Immaculate. you can spend hours jsut sitting in the grass or on a bench

A wonderfully serene oasis in the busy city. The Royal Botanic Gardens are at the northern end of Sydney CBD's green space & gardens, which begin with Hyde Park, run through the Domain and end at the harbour, beside the Opera House.It's an interesting area; the Cadigal people held initiation ceremonies near Mrs Macquarie's Chair, and there are many Aboriginal exhibits and displays in the Gardens today.Governor Phillilp wanted to farm the area to feed the fledgling colony in 1788, but the infertile soils couldn't support the fruits & vegetables, and in 1816 Governor Macquarie founded the Royal Botanic Gardens on the site. For 21 years from 1862, it housed our first Zoo. Today, it's a serene green oasis, home to native and imported species from all around the world. And the oldest scientific institution in Australia. Flowers in season provide colours, ducks & kids love the ponds and locals & visitors can be found walking, running & jogging along the paths in the early mornings & evenings. Or taking a more leisurely approach & lounging on the grass, picnicing or enjoying food from the cafe or amongst the tree tops in the restaurant.Few views can better watching boats on the harbour or the sun set behind the Opera House & Bridge from the gardens.

BEAUTIFUL GARDENS. Lovely gardens at the harbourside - favourite haunt for tourists, gardeners, office-worker lunches and joggers (especially lunchtime). It's just good to wander throughout the gardens which stretch from the shore by the Opera House.Most memorable were the views over the harbour, the fruit bats chattering and a very good shop which probably has more original giftware at a a better price then anywhere else in the area.You're certainly encouraged to experience it rather than having signs everywhere saying "keep off" or "don't touch".

Stunning views, and a peaceful spot in the city...and it is all free!. The botanic gardens are the perfect place to take a leisurely walk while in Sydney. They are near the heart of the city, but once inside you feel like you could be miles away! The gardens are beautiful and people are encouraged to smell the flowers, sit on the grass, and generally just enjoy the space. The views from the gardens are stunning, with views across the water to the opera house and the bridge. You should not miss a walk in the gardens when visiting the city!
The nature in sydney!. Amazing plants, and relaxing walk in the reign of the nature.
Nice free attraction.. We were walking in the area and got turned around while map reading and stumbled upon the gardens. It's a good past time and nice scenery if you're already in the area.

nature in the city. when sick of traditional city - type excursions this was awonderful place to unwind , watching the antics of flocks of cockatoos , admiring the amazing old trees, (& the bats asleep in them !) & fuelling up on delicious food at the restaurant.

Awesome views of the Harbour. What a terrific walk! The landscaping is fantastic, well kept, with signs along the way that identify the plants. The view of the Harbour from Mrs. MacQuarie's Chair is beautiful.
A tropical oasis in the middle of the city. Lush, established plantings and trees, with a huge native bird population in the center of the city of Sydney. Exotic and beautiful. Well cared for space.

A walk through serene beauty. The Sydney Botanical Garden is located very close to the Sydney Opera House. A walk through the garden is a must. There are four sculptures representing four seasons which overlook the garden. The fragrance of flowers & leaves leave lilting memories.

Amazing!. The things which captivate in relation to Sydney are its green belt which encompasses the Botanic Gardens, the undulating landscape and the water. A truly beautiful city. The Botanic Gardens is part of a green belt which snakes its way from the Harbour right through to the centre of the city. It gives this city a vibrant and living heart.

Do the free 11AM walking tour. Arrive a few minutes early at the garden shop/information center.That is where the tour leaves from; just outside the front doors of the garden shop.Rest rooms are there and they have interestinggifts/books in the Garden shop. The Botanical gardens are very large so leave time to walkto the Garden shop before 11 AM. There are signs and just ask people where it is.It is a 11/2-2 hour walking tour..the docents are very knowledgeable about the plants and it is no issue if you drop off early to do other touring.

Beautiful gardens with great city and harbour views. We enjoyed the gardens towards the end of the day in May, the lengthening shadows and the sunset behind the harbour bridge made this a wonderful place to while away an hour or so.
Lovely urban green space. Near the opera house,it's a great spot for walk . We enjoyed the herb gardens and all the exotic urban birdlife

Absolutely love it. Beautiful green area close to the city centre. Great photo opportunities, birds, spiders... We have been there three times already, but planning of going back, because there is so much to see. Excellent!

Beautiful, Beautiful. This was my third trip to Sydney and had not been through these incredible gardens. We mostly walked through to go to the water, but the gardens were lovely, incredible and very family oriented with many fields of people playing soccer and rugby.
A nice 2 hoursWe. We had lunch here and enjoyed the stroll around with superb viws of the harbour.

A beautiful garden near the Opera House. We lived in Woollomooloo for a week in December 2011, and went through the Royal Botanic Gardens every day with our children aged 3 and 4. We really enjoyed seeing the beautiful flowers and gardens, the birds and animals that live here, and all other surprises we got when we strolled through the gardens. The harbour view is one of a kind, and also the walk to the Opera House. It really makes you relax and feel well, and jogging here gave us a lot of energy :-)It is a "must see" for anyone who visits Sydney, the true heart of a beautiful city. Take your time and explore!
not bad. only problem is finding the carpark. it's good for nature photography

Beautiful and informative. We initially made an enforced visit to the Gardens after the taxi dropped us of at the wrong place. I had a very sore toe and as a result was extremely grumpy and deep into victim mode. We had to walk to the garden in order to get to our original destination - the Art Museum. It was not too long before I conceded that my toe was bearing up OK - not THAT OK, but OK. (I might need to play the old soldier later.) We therefore decided upon a serpentine route to reach the gallery, through each of the Gardens exemplar sections. Not only a beautiful garden(s) but setting out to educate with clarity and in an entertaining way.So impressed were we that we gave over a day of our time in the Blue Mountains to visiting the annexe handling the cool and higher altitude plants at (sorry, I forget).

Take Your Time. It's big, and takes time to explore. Not a place to visit if you don't have long in Sydney. Excellent for people with an interest in plants, and it makes a curious contrast with the city high-rise that's so close.
Beautiful gardens and wildlife. Even though it was fall, our walk through the gardens was fantastic. We say a variety of birds, flying foxes, and a possum, all in the heart of a large city.

Great location for running. I'm a new local, and I love the Royal Botanic Gardens for the great running setting they provide. They're beautifully maintained, gardeners are friendly and it provides a very surreal and beautiful setting in the middle of Sydney to take a break and go for a quick run. Just be aware that unless you're doing loops, max kilometers is about 5-6km, maybe more if you expand outside to Potts Point or head towards Darling Harbour. Happy running!

Difficult for mobility impaired. Some interesting areas, but VERY hilly!! Not all entrances are accessible, and you have to go up or down hill to get to the next one. Hop-on/off bus stop is at the top. We enjoyed what we could get to, but only because the Opera House stop from the bus was closed the day we were there. Difficult proceeding down the hill in the drizzle to the Opera House. When the prime minister is in residence you can't visit the Government House and there are no other bathrooms near by.

Calm amidst the crowds!. Defintely worth taking the time to explore. The park is an oasis of calm and we spent a couple of hours exploring the beautiful surroundings. It's worth visiting just to see the bats!!!!!Beautiful plants and scuplute with the background of the Opera House and the harbour.

Nice in summer and in winter. Taking a stroll in the Royal Botanic Garden is always a pleasure. Immerse yourself in a quiet corner of Sydney, swim in the pool in Woolloomooloo dwarf, chillout under the shade of a tree. It is always a great time!

These gardens are beautiful!. Loved learning about the interesting trees. Also enjoyed seeing the unusual birds in the trees and walking around the grounds. This is worth doing for sure. But allow enough time to walk and enjoy yourself - you need 2-3 hours from the Circular Quay to walk past the Opera House, through the Botanical Gardens and back to Circular Quay.

Country in the city. Well maintained and documented gardens. Great place to see relax and enjoy some clean fresh air in the city. Place is huge and will take a good day to see everything and enjoy or just pop in for a few hours of relief from the city.
Great Walk through Gardens. Gardens are beautiful; great walk through gardens and visit to Governor's House.
Nice to walk around on an Autumn Day. What a beautiful place this is to walk around, lovely gardens, beautiful harbour. Lay down on the grass and enjoy the sunshine.
Lovely gardens. Large park with lots of easy walks. Not as many flowers in April (beginning of Fall there) as we would like.
Gorgeous. We walked from the city, right through the gardens down to the water and the opera house...gorgeous esp on a sunny day!

A lovely & tranquil space .... .. in the middle of the city. Great views on part of the skyline, lots of birds, fruitbats, spots for reading & lying on the grass. I have been there lots of times & never get sick of it. A great setting w phantastic views of the bay!

Great place to spend a half day. Clean and tidy, pleasant green space and fantastic variety of flora, even fruit bats hanging in the trees.
I'm not a gardener but enjoyed this place.

Enjoy your exercise. A unique setting with stunning views of the harbour as well as incredible gardens, trees and shrubberies. Oh then there is the birdlife! So many different paths, walks, even down to the water. Great way to get your exercise, feel like a local, can even do a loop and go round the Opera House. Spectacular scenery.

Quiet morning alone. I found the Gardens while exploring Sydney on foot. I figured I had my Kindle in my bad and would find a nice tree to sit under to do some reading but I was so enthralled by the Gardens I didn't STOP WANDERING!!! There really is a lot to see and to soak in the beautiful surrounds. Easy to get to and easy to navigate. I visited their gift store and a little gallery that some artwork was being shown in. I was BY far the youngest person in the room but I enjoyed seeing all the different styles. So I was looking UP and thought I saw pods....until my eyes focused and realized they were BATS! creepy but cool. On my way out I was checking out the herb garden and saw something scary staring back at me....I came home to google it and turns out it was a blue tongued lizard! again...pretty creepy but cool. :) Take some time to wander the park. Take a picnic lunch and enjoy the harbor view, learn about the plants and the history of this beautiful park! It's amazing...and better yet...FREE!

bats!. Gorgeous picturesque gardens with city on one side and harbor on the other. We were told there would be bats in the trees but it did not prepare us for the sheer numbers we saw hanging on the branches. Interesting in a creepy way. But the rest of the gardens are wonderful and wholesome!!
Beautiful. So serene. A little getaway from the reality of city life!!! Great place to have a picnic or eat lunch!!!

A wonderful oasis of peace and beauty !. The gardens are a wonderful oasis of greenery and calm in a amazing location. They are easy to explore and would be a wonderful place for a picnic or just to sit and relax for a while by yourself or with kids.

Amazing and not to be missed! Also, you won't regret visiting the cafe in the garden. I cannot recommend a visit to these Gardens highly enough. They have it all: amazing plants, wonderful theme-garden areas (for example the cacti section and Chinese gardens) and uniquely the most amazing views of Sydney. Budget at least half a day to walk through them and take it all in. The only specific pieces of advice I would give to anyone visiting are: allow enough time; if you're eating there, visit Botanic Garden Cafe in the centre of the garden and NOT Pavilion on the Park near the NSW Art Gallery, which we found overpriced and very sub-par; and if you're afraid of bats then be sure to find out in advance where the flying foxes live, as there are hundreds of them in certain sections. Finally, we really enjoyed the information sign for the Wattle - it demonstrates the Australian sense of humour.

Amazing gardens and extraordinary location. This is one of the best things about Sydney without a doubt.We have just been to the Singapore Botannical Gardnes and ours in Sydney is so much better because it is perched on the foreshore of the harbour and from so many parts of the garden you can see the sparkling harbour. With a tropical section and many extremely old and large tree species, ponds and the cafe for a rest stop we can easily spend a lovely sfternoon relaxing here.tThe Art gallery of NSW is a hop away. How good is that!
Must Do. These gardens are wonderful. They have a train ride you can take to learn more about the history of the gardens that was nice. Wonderful place to spend a stress free couple of hours.

Serene, calming and beautiful. Our hotel was in the Potts point area of Sydney so the walk through the botanical gardens was the best way for us to get to the harbour - i'll never forget my first view of the bridge and opera house from the gardens - it took my breath away.The gardens themselves are the perfect size and there are some lovely plants and trees which are being lovingly tended to. We were also impressed by the amount of wildlife and how quiet the place was - all in all, i think this was our very favourite spot in Sydney.

Botanica Gardens. Most cities have one of these, but I love the one in Sydney especially. It is a peaceful meditation to walk through this and then on the harbour, the colours are always vibrant and inviting. A must for every visitor
Great established gardens. Wonderful to wander through, so many different sections with grand old trees and plants. Views across the harbour, close to the CBD. A great day out.
Beautiful. Great on a sunny day, one of the most fantastic inner city Garden retreats in the world. The best place for a morning run.

A lovely place to relax. It's nice to be able to walk around a park & enjoy nature, have a coffee or lunch and feed the cockatoo's & rainbow lorikeets (my favourite part).The settlers garden is interesting as is the herb gardens.

Very "friendly" gardens!. A must do, even for non-nature lovers. Very beautiful gardens to walk around. I say "friendly" gardens because the signs posted encourage you to hug the trees and walk on the grass. The general admission is free of charge. The tour on foot can take about 2 hours. They have free volunteer guided tours that run 1-2 times a day or maps for self-guided tours. For those who want an alternative, the Choo Choo express is a train that brings you all around the gardens, takes about 30 minutes and the driver gives commentary.Lots of beautiful plant life and interesting wildlife, mostly birds. We saw a family of ducks and cockatoos flying free. A word to the wise: be aware of the runners! They share the same paths but if you stick to one side, everyone will be happy. Great place for a family day or even a romantic walk. Photo ops are fantastic in the garden itself and there are nice views of the bridge and the Opera house from Mrs. Macquaries Chair, not too far away.

Nice way to spend and hour or tour. I visited the Botanical Gardens in early April 2012 on a beautiful sunny day. The gardens are beautiful and well-maintained - perfect for a leisurely stroll, a picnic, or just a break from the hustle and bustle of the harbor. The colony of fox bats was cool albeit a bit creepy if you don't care for bats lol!!!
Beautiful. Beautiful, peaceful and relaxing. An oasis in the heart of the city.

A must for garden lovers. Really nice place to visit, no matter who you are. Near the harbour, you can sit in the sun and just enjoy the surroundings... and its FREE!!! :-) I dont know much about plants etc, but its a nice place to just walk through and relax. Some nice signs and historic information scattered around too.
Worth a visit. Large with a great variety of plants and such. Must check out the trees with all the huge bats in them. A walk to Macquerie's chair is worth it as well as to the opera house

An oasis. The Botanical Gardens are an oasis in the hustle of the city. The location is magnificent,(right on the harbour) the gardens are beautifully maintained and has a great diversity of plants. It's got some lovely out of the way places to discover and enjoy, to veg and watch the view, eat some lunch or lay on the plush grass and dream! Amazing views!! Another must do for all!

Amazing wildlife. Great to see a number of native Australian plants so close to the city centre. In amongst the different plants, there were loads of animals and birds to se as well. The gardens are well laid out so that you are never aware where you are and are constantly being surprised by what comes next.
Beautiful. Well-maintained and offering some of the best views of the harbour you'll find in Sydney. Unlike many gardens, admission is free.
Beautiful. - Being from Scandinavia this garden is very different and stunning. Loved my walks there.

Bats in the garden. The Royal Botanic gardens are a pleasure to be in and during my visit to Sydney visited/crossed through the gardens around 5 times. Amazing - the HUGE bats hanging in the trees and making some considerable noise. The gardens themselves are wonderful, mature trees, loads of space, invitation to walk on the grass, hug the trees! Really good for a picnic, morning walk or run, and wonderful views of the harbour

Beautiful gardens. Last day in Sydney, and we take a walk around the garden since it was just beside the hotel we were staying at. Coupled with the wonderfully pleasant weather, the walk was really lovely. We got to see the flying foxes, the various pavilions, the sea breeze sweeping against our faces, and a nice light lunch to boot. Not to be missed!

A really incredible place. One of the many nice things about Sydney are all the parks, and the RBG is one of the finest. A great place to spend the day whether your a botany fan or not. You don't have to know or care about the local flora or fauna to appreciate the park, but if that's your thing, you won't be disappointed.But if fitness is your gig, that's another good reason to visit and you won't be alone. The Aussie are a fit group and the park is always full of people running, kick boxing and doing yoga. Still not enough? Bring a ball or a Frisbee, or bring lunch and have a picnic. The RBG offers some of the best views of Sydney Harbour, you can even tour the Government house for a bit of history and it's all free.

Much more than a drive by. Don't even begin to think you have seen this beautiful garden from the road outside. There is much more to see. Enjoy all the areas that are easily mapped. There are steps inside so wheelchair access is limited but there are plenty of other areas to see.
LOVE IT. Perfect place to lay down and read a book in the sun, or go for a run if you prefer.
Sydney Botanical Gardens. Restful except for the chattering of grey-headed flying foxes in the defoliated trees. Chatty lady in the "Friends of the Gardens" information booth at the Domain entrance.

The best place. We always stay at a hotel near Hyde Park so we can walk down to the Botanic Gardens to start our day. You can never tire of it as there are so many paths to take and things to see. Take one of the guided walks to add to the delight. With all the plant and bird life to observe there is never a dull moment.

That's a knowledgeable gardener!. The gardens are beautiful, well maintained, and a great free way to enjoy your time in Sydney. When the weather is good, it's a fantastic spot to be. We even came upon a plant we didn't know and when we asked the gardener about it, we received a whole biology lesson about the evolution of that plant in the region. It was really impressive and shows how much care and thought is put into what goes on at the Gardens. Plus, no trip would be complete without taking a picture of the Opera House and the Harbor Bridge from Mrs. McQuarrie's chair.
Pleasant walk and lots to see. My wife and I enjoyed our walk through the gardens on our way to see the Opera House. The were plenty of places to take some lovely photos across to the Opera House.
Superb!. How wonderful to go into a public garden and be greeted by an invitiation to walk on the grass and hug the trees!
Botanical Gardens Sydney. Stunning!Everything about the Botanical Gardens is Excellent.Do not visit Sydney without a visit.
cool and tranquil. We just spent 30 mins walking through here from the Opera House, and it was just beautiful and tranquil on a sunny day.
Tranquility right in the city. Pleasant contrast to the bustle of the nearby Harbour front.
Botantic Gardens. Nice gardens, nothing too special. Nice walk from the Opera House.

what a treat! but watch out for runners!. Spectacular trees, glorious gardens but watch out for runners! It seems as if everyone in Sydney runs especially on their lunch break! We wanted to see flying foxes and kept looking up to find one... In searching the trees we saw beautiful white cockatoos, tawny frogmouth owls and colourful parakees...but no flying foxes UNTIL we heard a terrible frackus - there were literally hundreds of these most fascinating creatures hanging from virtually stripped bare branches. We discovered that they are becoming a nuisance - their constant coming and going strips the leaves and buds off the trees and in fact is killing them, including magnificent 100 yr + trees. The Gardens are now using methods to discourage them and to get them to move elsewhere. We had hoped to tour the Governor's place but it wasn't open on the day we went so check for days and times ahead of your arrival.
Birds and Flowers. This was nice as we saw many birds and nice flower displays.

Breathtaking!. After you go to the Opera House, head to the Gardens. There is a "train" that will take you all through the Garden from the Queen Elizabeth II gate. Best way to see the whole thing and rest your weary feet at the same time!!

An oasis in the city. Fantastic gardens spread over a wide area near the Opera House. There are some intersting pieces of sculpture as well as the wide variety of trees and plants. Amazing noise from the flying foxes!

Flying Foxes!. Our hotel was right across the street from the gardens. When we arrived our room wasn't ready yet so we took a walk through the gardens. The first wildlife we met in Australia were the Flying Foxes that live in the gardens. They are so crazy and cute! We went back before we left Sydney to get some good pictures of them.There are so many beautiful plans and birds to watch. It's a must see!

Sydney Botanic Gardens. The Gardens cover a large expanse of area and are full of beautiful sculptures along with a plethora of plants and trees.The music conservatorium near the garden entrance is constructed in a beautiful Fort type architecture.
Sydney Botanic Gardens. Near to the city for beautiful gardens, birds, views of the harbour and bats. Peace and quiet -choose a spot away from the bat colony.

Surprisingly entertaining. Chris Isaak (the country singer) Suggested to me that I check out the Royal Botanical Gardens when I ran into him in San Francisco. He was right. The COOLEST part was the flying Foxes all nested overhead. Eerie!

absolutely beautiful and it was free!. Was on a holiday with sister and we got to walk about the park which felt more like a zoo! We saw exotic animals and plants and a breath taking view of the Opera House from the park.
Beautiful way to spend an afternoon. Picturesque gardens, incredible wildlife, a lovely way to spend a few hours

beautiful Gardens right in the middle of the city. we took the free guided tour in the gardens and learned all about the history of Sydney and the gardens and plants. Our docent was very enthusiastic about plants and actually talked much longer than we expected. We were able to see up close lots of birds that we had never seen before...kookaburras, ibis, mocking birds and lots and lots of white cockatoos.These gardens are free to all, excellently maintained, and a beautiful spot for a picnic with the family. Don't miss it on your next trip to Sydney.

Just beautiful. I am a local but every time I go for a walk or a run around the Botanical Gardens it feels like the first time. Amazing views, clean, people exercising.... and oasis in the middle of the city.
Worth a walk around. Really rather pleasant and amazing bats in the trees

Sitting middle of Sydney CBD - Fantastic. It is a large botanical garden and it is around the bay. Don't miss to take a ride in the train. There are huge number of bats on the garden. It is better place to take rest during the day time in Sydney. The gardens are well maintained.
Loved the walk. In the centre of Sydney and yet so quiet. Loved the walks
Fun family day in the city. Unbeatable location, great views and plenty for the kids to discover.
sightseeing. We had a trip round on the train whilst waiting for our allocated timed visit to the opera house. The guide was excelent, beautifully laid out gardens.
Oasis of peace. smack in the center of the city this wonderful oasis of peace with exotic plants and birds, perfect for a pic-nic!

Beautiful for everyone. Beautiful gardens to enjoyed by everyone. Great view of harbour and just a great place to spend time or just to detour through instead of walking through the city for a change.

The Location Is Perfect. You would be hard pressed to find another botanic garden so well located and well designed. It's a joy to stroll from the Opera House through the gardens and on to many of Sydney's other cultural attractions. The specialist gardens are well-tended and provide much to absorb the keen gardener.
Feed the birds/see the bats. A wonderful day in the park. Bring birdseed to feed the birds and look out for all the bats. A great place to stroll around and take in the beauty of Sydney.

Bring some bird seed. One of the most wonderful things about Australia is it's spectacular wildlife and beautiful birds. Some of my most memorable moments include the times when I got to feed birdseed to some of Australia's birds and it doesn't cost much either. Buy a bag of birdseed at any grocery store and head out to the Royal Botanic Gardens next to the Sydney Opera House. Bring a friend and a camera and you'll have lots of opportunities to hand feed some of their white sulfur crested cockatoos. But beware, the one animal Steve Irwin feared was birds because they are unpredictable and can sometimes bite or poo on you.

Lovely Place to Chill Out. We love the beautiful plants and flowers that we saw as we walked to the Domain. There is a beautiful pond that people can sit around. Would love to go back to the gardens again in our next trip to Sydney.
A glimpse of Australia. Well laid out and really interesting gardens very informative with amazing views

Where the gardens and the Harbour meet. Not too many places in the world have a Botanical Garden that sits alongside one of the prettiest harbours in the world. Whether its a gentle stroll or a picnic, it's worth a visit. The walk from Circular Quay around the foreshore to Wooloomooloo is lovely. You also take in Lady Macquarie's Chair if that's of interest.

Peaceful Nature. Bats in the tall trees, birds singing, flowers blooming, surrounded by the water on one side, the glass city backdrop on another side. The air was light with little droplets of water..rain and then sun, and then rain again.

Loved the gardens and the lovely gift shop. Particularly loved the little train which you could hop on and off at a number of stops. The heat was too much for a lot of walking, but this meant we could see all the things we wanted to and be taken back to the Opera House at the end.

Pretty location. We walked from our hotel in Darlinghurst, through Potts Point and Woolloomooloo to the Botanic Gardens. Lovely view across the water to the Opera House. Good place to sit and relax in the shade. Pleasant walk to the city from Darlinghurst. Watch out for the flying foxes..!
Cockatoos that are all over you. It is a wonderful park and the views great too. The birds, bats and trees kept us there for much longer than we expected.

Definitely worth a walk-through. I walked through here as a shortcut on the way to a restaurant in Wolloomooloo with my family. I'm definitely glad I took this detour. The gardens are so magical and beautiful, mysterious and romantic. Plus its free, so great value for money. I'd prefer to spend more time walking through the whole area or perhaps having a picnic, so if you are in Sydney and are short of time, I'd save this beautiful place for a time where you can actually sit, enjoy and soak up the atmosphere.

Great place to walk and unwind. First off, wear your walking shoes. Though not the largest botanic garden I've been to, it had more hills than many.Lots of gardens, each with some sort of theme, whether type of flora or regions. I went in the Aussie winter/early spring, but there was still plenty blooming and a number of birds and insects poking around.Great views of the Sydney Harbour, plus you can sit on the wall and dangle your feet in. Mrs. Macquaries chair is interesting, but seems to be often swamped with bus tours. On my visit, there were about a hundred people up there and maybe fifty scattered through the rest of the Gardens.Good to make this part of a day worth of walking, as it's right next to the Opera House. I made it part of a loop from Hyde Park, up through the east side of the downtown area, through the Gardens, Opera House, down to the Circular Quay. From the Quay, you can hit anywhere in the Sydney area.Anyways, worth seeing for fans of flowers, bugs, birds, taking pictures and relaxing.
True natural beauty. What's not to love; the trees especially the purple ones, the guided tours, tourist train, pathways, views, fresh air, openness, scents. its a great place to feel alive
Lovely Gardens, great cafe. The botanic gardens are free, and very peaceful even though they are so close to the hussle and bustle of Syndey Centre

Attractive spot. Grab a map & follow the signs posted throughout. Brilliant array of various gardens. Hive of activity from people playing football to lazing around reading a book to having a picnic in the park.
Lovely garden!. The garden is very nice, especially when you like to see some special birds. The birds are extremely social eating from your hand. Great for children!

Lovely Park-like Setting. Loved the overall feel of this botanic garden as much giant park with labeled specimens as rigid, structured gardens; I came here 3 times in a 7 day stay. I was 10-15 minutes from my hotel and so pleasurable I just kept going back. You may be disappointed if looking for one of those gardens with overly structured spaces and labels. While I found most of the areas I visited well labeled, there was a fair amount of plants left unlabeled. If you freak out easily, beware the fruit bat colony that likes to roost in the trees near the gift shop. For the uninitiated, they are a bit much - albeit completely harmless.
Perfect place to relax in Sydney. We did a picnic there with some friends and it was amazing! If you can, go during the sunset. The view is fantastic!
lovely and free. You could spend hours wandering around these gardens. well worth a visit

The Best Garden I've Been To. The garden is wonderful. There was one tree that was full of colorful Loriketts. The Bats were facinating to watch in the trees near the Cafe. I had a great lunch at the Cafe and a wonderful walk around the Garden.
Oasis in the city. Walked here, jogged through a few times, grabbed a coffee and flopped on a shade spattered lawn for a few lovely hours, looking out at the Harbour. A gorgeous place to enjoy,

Beautiful!. It is a great way to spend a nice afternoon because the view of the city and harbour is splendid, and the plants and flowers are beautiful. You will see many different types of wildlife including the large, loud bats and white cockatoos flying from tree to tree. It's a lovely place to visit. Must do!!
Outstanding.. Excellent gardens of native and non-native species, plus just a tremendous place to explore--a little paradise in the heart of a major city.

A gorgeous place to visit. What a great FREE attraction!The Gardens are an easy walk from the Rocks hotel where we were staying. What a lovely, peaceful garden with a path that follows the harbour edge so the views of the Opera House and Bridge together are seen from Mrs. Macquaries Point. Also we got a peek at the outdoor stage the Opera is building.The trees, vegetation, birds and bats (flying foxes) were amazing. The trees were identified by placards. And there are many beautiful and interesting trees.There are multiple paths that can be taken. I would suggest going to their excellent website and printing out a map or two before you go so it is easier to find your way around, particularly if you come into the park from the north side near the Opera House. They offered guided walks which are free, that I wish we had had the time to take.

The best garden I have been too and the most fun I,ve had on my own. This is such a wonderful place. I went here on my own. Usually I don't like going off to places without someone to share them with but I spent 4 hours here and it still wasn't enough time to enjoy the beauty of the place. Walk around, get lost and enjoy the beauty because every cornf you turn there is something new to surprise you. I have been to botanical gardens around the world and this is by far the best one. It has the most variety and it,s the most entertaining, make sure you get a map. And yes, totally pay the fee for the tropical gardens, it's completely worth it. You,ll need about 6 hours if you want to see the whole thing leisurely.

They do a good job of this garden. Lots of australian and other species. Beautiful setting looking onto the harbour. Cockatoos, kookaburras, lorikeets, Ibises, possums and flying foxes are common here. There are times when there is a trail of flying foxes from turramurra (north shore suburb) to the botanical gardens at sunset, to feast.
The lungs of Sydney. Beautiful, historic gardens close to the CBD and harbour. Great spot for a picnic or a stroll. Watch out for the possums early or late in the day.
Really peacful. A beatiful place to visit and walk around, Ideal for a picnic or just to hang out

Birds, scary bats haniging from above and tropical fauna..... Parrots, lizards, scary bats hanging from above and tropical fauna....where else but in Sydney can you get this steps away from the bustling city?! Beautiful walk, but beware of the stong sun (even if you do not feel it, it will burn !!)
Beautiful. I walked around Sydney CBD for 5 days. This was a lovely area. The train was well worth the $10AU after walking for 2 hours.
Very Clean and Historical. We love this place and when ever we visit Sydney we always spend some time here looking at Opera House and Sydney Harbor.

Great views and lovely gardens - pity about the fruit bats.. Spent several hours wondering around the Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney. Some really wonderful displays and some great old trees. They are also situated on the shores of the beautiful Sydney Harbour. Lots of great photo opportunities. The fruit bats are a novelty but you can really see the damage they are causing to some of the older trees - in fact several seemed trees seems to be almost dead.
Don't miss a morning walk through the Royal Botanic Gardens.. Take your time and bring your camera! Don't forget to look UP, because sometimes you'll see large flying foxes (bats) hanging about.
great gardens. Lovely walks and scenic views of gardens government house and opera house.
Beautiful!. Very scenic and relaxing-great place to lounge on a quiet,sunny day:)

Great for relaxing away from the city and excellent views of the harbor. This park is central to the CBD and is great for running, walking and relaxing. It has views of the city, Sydney Harbour Bridge, Opera House, the Sydney Harbour and the Woolloomooloo inlet. It even has a swimming pool on the Woolloomoloo side. It is quite a large park, so you can spend a good hour or two exploring and taking in the natural beauty of Sydney. Best on a fine day.

Peaceful relaxing.. A wonderful place to visit in Sydney to get away from the rush of the city. In a beautiful setting near the Harbour. There are many themed gardens which are just stunning. Lovely for a picnic or try the cafes in the Gardens. Just lie in the sun and relax!

Beautiful!. We took a tour of the gardens and are glad we did. We had walked around on our own before taking the tour. We learned so much about the entire area. Make sure you have an ice cream up by Mrs. McQuarrie's Chair!

Oasis in the city. You can get lost in the gardens which is amazing in a big city. An oasis of green. Walk from the barracks museum, all the way down to the opera house. The most stunning bit is when you arrive at the harbor, are surrounded by green, have water, the opera house, the bridge....perfect day
Give the cafe a miss. Lovely gardens but go elsewhere for lunch, or bring a picnic!
Nice bit of Exotic in a city centre. As the title says- it's nice to walk through an exotic, australian garden with fruit bats, cockatoos, and other birds, yet be in the centre of a city!
Wonderful Garden of Delights in the Heart of Sydney. Great space for a walk and to take in the fauna as well as the flora. And, it's free!

Beautiful Gardens. Are ANY botanical gardens rubbish to look at?? I don't think so. Some are more beautiful than others but that's mostly subjective.
I love these gardens - best view of the harbour and city from here too.

Amazing natural beauty.. The Botanic Gardens are surely worth a stroll if you are in Sydney. There are many wonderful species of plants and trees to see and lots of art sculptures to check out. There are many areas where folks can bring a picnic lunch and relax and enjoy the wonderful nature in the area.
More than a stroll in the park. For those who like parks this is a must see. Cactus garden never ceases to amaze me.

So much to see spend a day in the gardens.. The gardens are beautiful we took the free tour but I would do more exploring on your own as well. They have eels swimming in the pond that came in from the oceans. Trees that were around with the dinosaurs.

BEAUTIFUL GARDENS, GREAT VIEWS OF SYDNEY HARBOUR. The Royal Botanic Gardens, situated on about 75 acres, is comprised of over 15 separate garden themes and terraces, including the Begonia Garden, Palace Rose Garden, Herb garden, the Rainforest Walk. If you have a nice day, plan to spend at least 3 hours here.If you start from the Bridge Street side entrance, you will eventually make your way to the Sydney Harbour and striking views of The Sydney Opera House, The Sydney Harbour Bridge, and The Rocks. If you go in the opposite direction of the Opera House, you will see tons of joggers, an outdoor movie theater, and eventually Mrs Macquaries' Bench. You have to have your picture taken on the bench!In addition to numerous birds, including Ibis, you will be wondering about those big things hanging from so many of the trees. These are fruit bats that can have a wingspan of one meter. Specifically, the bats are Grey Headed Flying Foxes. If the day is a hot one, these critters will flap their wings and you will see how really big they are. If you are lucky, as we were, you will see the "foxes" fly from one tree to another. They are big!Plan to end your time here by walking toward the OPERA HOUSE. As I said, this is a beautiful view and it gets better the closer you get to the Circular Quay (the area at the end of Sydney Harbour that is bordered by the The Rocks, Opera House, and Sydney Harbour terminal).

Another jewel in Sydney's crown. A perfect way to spend some time wandering around these beautiful gardens. So close to the city...yet they seem so far away. Fantastic views of the harbour and Opera House.I visit the gardens every time I go to Sydney. They are also a brilliant space for jogging.For other things to do while in Sydney check out my blog www.sydney-jono.blogspot.com

Green, quiet and informative. For a quiet picnic or a wedding, the gardens on Sydney's beautiful harbour is truly wonderful. The absolutely wonderful trees, bird life and greenery is a minutes walk from the busy CBD of Sydney.

Easy walk with ocean breezes and lush flora. This is a lovely walk where you get to view the harbour, governers house, Lady Macquaries chair, and different flora from all over the world and some of our oldest trees. Downside is the bats in the trees that are killing them off!

Diverse area with lots of interesting plants and birds. Fruit bats, great gardens, wonderful views. Public rest areas, can get a bottle of water, or use public drinking fountains. Staff are happy to answer questions.

Magical place in the centre of Sydney. This place is magical. It's is a great place right in the centre of Sydney, but feels a million miles away. Take a picnic or a book or just wonder in amazement at the view. My favourite is Mrs Macquires Chair

Stunning. I was completely surprised how exquisite the Gardens are and how much I enjoyed them. I live next to King's Park in Perth which is stunning so thought I had little to experience at another park. It's completely different and just amazing. Thick with special trees and a cacophony of birds. An oasis in the city.

Take time out to smell the flowers. What a way to relax right in the middle of Sydney City. Take the time to wander through the Gardens, enjoy the entertainment in the Park or have something to eat. Great for all the family
MUST SEE. This is a must see when in Sydney. The views are great with amazing wild life and there are thousands of flying foxes hanging in the middle gardens!

Superb - and it is free. Beautiful setting adjacent to the Opera House; well cared for and carefully set out - wonderful to walk through, look at the different and varied species and enjoy the magnificent setting. Best of all it will not cost you a cent.

A beauitful spot in a big city. On entering the Royal Botanic Gardens one is amazed at the beautiful display of garden beds. The trees are magnificent. As you wander through the gardens there are surprises around every corner. You can take so much time as you investigate the names of the different varieties of each the species.The cafe has good food and the restrooms good. The view of the harbour is amaziing as you walk doen the gardens.

One of my favourite places in the world. Taking a walk from the CBD through Hyde Park, past the Cathedral, down Art Gallery Road to Mrs Macquarie's Chair and then through the Botanic Gardens to the Opera House is a must for all tourists to Sydney (and all Sydney-siders alike). The gardens are an oasis in the CBD and a haven for wildlife, including the famous fruit bats and many birds. The cockatoos are particularly friendly! Perfect spot for a big family picnic or a romantic alfresco supper.The views from Mrs Macquarie's Chair provide the classic Sydney Harbour Bridge and Opera House photo op. On a sparkling Sydney day, it's heaven.

Absolutely Beautiful. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney has to be one of the most beautiful parks in the world. Hike, jog, walk, stroll, picnic, explore, exercise, meditate, swim, dine, shop: this park has it all. Admission is free and the park is breathtakingly beautiful. Lots of picture opportunities and many venues to learn about native flora and fauna. One can spends days in the park and not see it all. A must visit while in Sydney.
