An area of calm and beauty. We also went to the old Government Building and had a very good free tour!

A must do!. We spent part of a day walking all throughout. The plants are outstanding, the bats a must see. Enjoyed walking through the gardens for my daily exercise later in the trip as well. So close to the downtown, easily accessed from may points/gates.

This amazing place should not be missed. One of the best locations in Sydney. All visitors should not miss this beautiful spot in Sydney. Its a leisurely stroll from the Opera House, or from Macquaries st.tAs a botanical garden there is a vast array of plants, trees, flowers, and nature, but it is also the way the garden has been designed that makes it so beautiful. Themed areas can be enjoyed or just laze under huge majestic trees. A pleasureable place to escape the bustle of the city. you must go.

Great Place for Nature Aficionados and Not.... The Royal Botanic Garden is a great place to discover the beauty of the flora of this hemisphere of the world as well an amazing place for a quiet walk.Free admission.

Watch out for the big bats!. What a lovely place! It's HUGE, and nicely maintained. We had read about the big Fox Bats, and saw them hanging in the trees, but, fortunately, we were not there when they flew away. There were many runners on the path, and I expect they dislike us tourists holding them up. We walked to Mrs. Macquarie's Chair, which we hardly recognized since it isn't a chair at all, but a bench carved into the rock. The views of the bridge and the Opera House are wonderful from that area of the Garden, though, and well worth the walk.
Beautiful place for a walk.. These gardens are beautiful and very well maintained.
peaceful and close to Opera House. very pleasant relaxing place with a great variety of plants. Located next to the Opera House.

Worth a visit. Great gardens overlooking the harbour and if you dont feel like walking they have a tourist train which winds its way through the gardens. Look up in the trees and see the flying foxes hanging from the branches.While in the gardens visit the goveners house where they have guided tours.
A calming oasis in Sydney. The Botanic Gardens are a real gem and it's a wonderful place to explore for an hour or so. The Cacti Garden has really become a key "must see" - it's fabulous.
*. A lovely pretty area. Amazing that it's in the middle of a city!
A pleaseant interlude to the city. make certain you are there at Dusk to see the Bats take flight.
Large, well kept gardens. Themed gardens, wide range of well-labelled plants, near to city, stunnig views - what's not to love?
quiet retreat. well maintained and superb location. Look out for the roosting fruit bats, birds and fish in the pond
Botanic Gdns. Very relaxing and one of the biggest spiders outside the shop doorway

Beautiful gardens.. A must to visit when you are in Sydney. We loved walking through the garden looking at the beautiful plants, trees and the fruit bats hanging from the trees. You can just sit on the grass and watch the world go by and forget you are in a busy city for a while.
I forgot about this gem. A great place to walk and take in the views of the harbour along with the many stands of plants and interesting information on signs dotted throughout the gardens.
Love it. Tons of variety, trees filled with sleeping bats and an awesome gift shop. Bring your camera!
Pretty. A very pretty place to visit and a nice stroll down the park and water front.
What a park. Excellent location in the city centre. Beautiful plants and walks, harbour views and many picnic places. It also abuts the NSW Art Gallery if you want to combine both visits.

A Deceiving Little Gem. You don't realise how much there is to see in the Botanical Gardens. It is beautifully laid out and tended, and if you're interested in plants and trees, you can easily spend three hours here. If the weather's great, chill out with a lie down on the grass.

Beautiful accessible gardens!. The sign "please walk on our grass" says it all! Beautiful gardens, lots of plant labels for those who want to know, amazing sight of flying foxes hanging in the trees, cockatoos, watching the locals play various sports. Lovely way to spend a few hours walking.
Brilliant and its free. A real gem in the middle of such a busy city. So much to see and all the trees and plants are labelled. And what are those huge bats in the trees near the restaurant?

What lovely gardens and FREE to go in. We spent 2.5 hours walking around (all the time we had) looking at the Fruit Bats hanging from the trees, tree carvings and the wonderful exotic plants, the views of the bridge and harbour, it was a warm sunny day and we could have easily stayed longer, lots of maps along the way to direct you, and water fountains dotted around to, and the place was empty!!! you can take a picnic there, and of course there are a few places to eat, the toilets were a bit dire, so maybe use the cafe ones instead, make sure you find time to do this, you wont be dissappointed.

Peace and tranquility in the middle of Sydney. Wander from the Opera House through the Botanic Gardens and let the stress slip away. The gardens are lovely and tranquil, a great spot for a stroll, or to sit and eat lunch if you need to escape from your office. We're so lucky to have these gardens right in the middle of our city!

One Fine Day Strolling the Gardens. My friends and I went to visit the Sydney opera house and afterwards was just walking around the area and ended up in the Royal Botanical gardens! IT was a nice walk along the edge of SYdney harbor. Sat on the grass to picnic, and just bask in the early summer sun of Sydney! What a fun way to spend one lazy day in Sydney. We walked all the way to Mrs Macquarry's Chair, saw the flying foxes and some amazing birds along the way. Don't forget to get one of those free maps and guides located in all entrances.

Must visit when in Sydney - great place to chillax.. Even if you are not a gardener, a visit to the botanic garden is a must. Start from the opera house and take the time to walk along the water and explore the various themed gardens. The Rose garden is my favourite especially in summer when all of the roses are in bloom. There's a big old tree there that's perfect for a picnic rug and a good book. If you love people watching then go there around lunch time when it is the busiest.

Heaven on Earth. Sublime - go lie on the grass and breathe. The Moreton Bay Figs are inspirational, the succulent garden a must and make sure you walk to Mrs Macqurie's chair and finally make it to the Andrew Boy Charleton for a swim.

A refreshing walk with various green life and good views of the Opera House. Yes the bridge has good views of the harbor but so does the Botanical Gardens. This is a lush oasis in Sydney. Sydney has a large collection of green parks but this one is dedicated to horticulture. This is one of Sydney's free attractions.Time required - Leisurely walks with picture talking can be finished in an hour. Guided tours are free and available. Check the Botanical Garden website for current times. Terrain - Mostly there are gradual slopes on paved walkways. There are some steps near the harbor but no more than two storey. During a hot day there is comfortable shade to be found. There are plenty of places for a picnic. On sunny warm days you may see a wedding or two in progress on the green lawns.On some occasions in the summer there are movies by the harbor side. Services - Bathrooms are available. There is a restaurant for good dining with views of the garden. There also is a souvenir/Botanical Garden shop located in the center next to the restaurant. At the edges of the park are vendors with drinks, ice cream, and sandwiches.Do not discount a visit here in the winter as the green house is a great place to be during the colder days.

Don't miss the Gray Faced Flying Foxes. As this is the oldest part of Sidney there are many very large old trees making up the structure of the gardens. All very well discribed but you'll need a map to keep from missing anything.

Just Brilliant. Lovely gardens & lots of areas for picnics with great views. This is a must visit & should should include a free visit to government house & their gardens. Wander up to the cafe area to see the fruit bats hanging from the trees, very impressive

Feed Cockatoo's. This was a highlight, I saw a kid with his arms out wide and a cracker in each hand, the Cockatoo's would come down and perch on his arms whilst nibbling on the cracker! I did the same amazing!

Peaceful oasis in the heart of the city. Walking through this peaceful park you can easily forget you are in the heart of the city. Like most botanical gardens, the space is beautifully maintained and they positively encourage you to walk on the grass and hug the trees !! At lunchtime the walkway to Mrs McQuarrie's chair becomes the running ground for all the office workers who have changed into their running gear and escaping their desks for an hour. All the green spaces in Sydney remind me what Australians do best - enjoying the outdoors with a relaxed approach to life.Even if you are not a gardener you would not be disappointed with a walk around the Botanics.

Just go. Great gardens, amazing landscaping and free! Wild cockatoos all over, wild Ibis you can walk right up to, and hundreds of wild flying foxes- huge furry bats the size of cats. Exotic plants everywhere. One of the best attractions in Sydney
Royal Botanic Gardens. A must for any garden enthusiast, while in Sydney. The roses were impressive and birds all new to us and fascinating.

Beautiful and relaxing place with great views. I spent a few hours walking around the Royal Botanical Gardens in Sydney. It's a beautiful place to go and relax away from the noise and speed of the city. There is a great variety of plants and the place is much larger than it appears on a map. You can either sit down and relax, perhaps read, or if you want to go for a run this is a great place for it.Pick up a leaflet to help navigate yourself around the park. They should be available on your way in, or at least they were the way I went in. Be sure to check out the Flying Foxes (bats), Government House, and Mrs Macquarie's Point for some great views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge.

Nice stroll through the garden and on to Mrs Macquairie's Chair. I like the rose garden, the birds( ducks, seagulls), the manicured flower beds, the lotus pond,the proximity to Mrs Macquairie's Chair and the stunning Harbour and Sydney opera house views, even the joggers who jog despite the rain. even in the rain, it is possible to enjoy the garden like I did.
Gardens. Great place to be on a nice day and they even have a Restaurant. Some Homeless people call this home as well as it's locked at night.Don't forget the camera. Love the Rose Garden.
Pristine. Peaceful and pristine, friendly birds, bats!, more trees than you can shake a stick at.

if you like flower gardens. well i jut don't rate flower beds and gardens with a couple of lizards when the place is so obviously a construct and not a natural native tree in it...sorry but again over cooked for a botanical garden...nice but not my thing i guess with out the fauna
Relax and enjoy whilst in Sydney. A great place to wonder and relax in Sydney and very close to the centre
Supersize garden at the middle of Sydney CBD. Supersize and pleasant garden at the middle of Sydney CBD. Lots to see, like Ms Macquaire chair and etc... ^^ definitely a must and also its FREE...^^
Lovely park and location. Close to opera house and varied areas. The tropical house wasnt worth the cost of entry.
Lovely. Great place for a picnic or a walk. Very well maintained and plenty to see.

Keep fit and enjoy the plants. We took a picnic lunch and enjoyed a sunny and warm January day! There are many lovely walks and plant-related experiences to be had here and even the roosting fruit bats (Flying Foxes) had a certain attraction although the damage they do is huge and in the evening, you need to keep well clear as the smell is palpable and droppings can be well aimed! The Botanic Gardens include Government House, the Sydney Conservatorium of Music, the Boy Charlton Pool and on the fringes, the Art Gallery of New South Wales. As well, the views of the harbour and surrounding city points and suburbs, are stunning.
Gorgeous. We didn't have much time there so our walk was pretty short. What we did see was simply beautiful. We wish we had more time there. What an approach to the Opera House.

Beautiful and Serene. Love walking through here. So many plants and flowers to see. The flying foxes aka fruit bats are plentiful. Would love to grab a blanket and a book and spend all day here. Great place to visit, wonderful example of the beauty of Sydney
Litter !!. Litter.... in a royal garden. I was shocked. The toilets were dirty as well. I mved on quickly.
Worth it.. Nice place to walk and picnic with beautiful surroundings.
beautiful asset. relaxing, quiet, free- wander here for a few hours or stay and have a coffee in the cafe and browse the bookshop
Well kept and easy to walk around in.. We walked the gardens early in the morning while the joggers were out and found it wonderful.
The wide open space. the wide open spaces after the city is fantastic. The jogging office workers made me feel really motivated. watching the ferries, the liners comimg and going.

Stunning. What a beautiful and tranquil place in the middle of the city. Really fell in love with these gardens - you just can't believe you're in the middle of a city. There were loads of bats and some funky looking spiders plus a particular spot where you can see the bridge and opera house framed by tropical looking trees. Blissful.

Great Place for peace and quiet. Fantastic place to stroll, relax and unwind!
Was staying in a locall hotel, wonderful place to just stroll around and watch the world go by..
Strolled all the way to the end then back around to the Opera House, stunning!!

Don't walk the dog. What an idyllic area for walking and enjoying the gorgeous trees and plants. The views around every corner are spectacular. BUT we're very naughty as pooch did come along. Purely innocent on our part but a big no no.

Well kept Gardens!. The gardens are beautiful! They are great for a quick walk or a picnic, or apparently a wedding (we saw a couple weddings held there over the weekend) and for bird/bat watching! My boyfriend and I were visiting from the US and were amazed at how many wild flying foxes, cockatoos and lorikeets call the park home.
Gorgeous. Diversity vs history right on the harbour. Amazing plant life, fruit bats, historic stories, nice places to picnic.

A quiet escape within the city.. The Botanic gardens provide a lovely escape form the hustle and bustle of the city. the cool of the trees, the expanses of green grass, the hint of the Harbour through the trees, are a great attraction in Sydney.

Beautiful and interesting!. The Botanic Gardens are so interesting not to mention beautiful.
We saw trees and plants like we never see in the United States.
Also interesting were the huge bats. Wow!
Should have spent more time wandering around there. Next time.
Just Beautiful. Definitely worth a walk in the gardens and if you walk right to the point, it is the best view of the Opera House and Bridge.
Utterly gorgeous. 'Twas the week before Mardi Gras, and the hotties were out running in their lunch break in jaw-dropping numbers. I recall some of the plants were nice too ;-)

Highly recommend Botanic Gardens. Recommend going on the ride around the gardens and hearing what they have to say.
The gardens are very relaxing and lovely ambience.
You can have afternoon tea and morning tea and lunch.
A must see in Sydney
Trees with a View. What's not to love about a garden, filled with trees and that view.....

Very Relaxing Gardens. I really love these gardens and try to spend some time in them whenever I go to Sydney. They are a beautiful respite from the traffic of the city and once you are lying on the grass looking up from under a massive canoply of trees, you could be miles from the city, when in fact you are just minutes from the CBD. Great place to take photos of plants too! Plust there is a nice cafe and excellent little shop selling garden related items. Nice place to chill out that's for sure.

Wonderful!. A great place for a superb walk! Great views! Great for running with kids. Great for picnic! A fantastic view in the evening of how the bats (flying foxes) colony is managing itself on the trees! A definate must-go in Sydney!
Worth a visit if you have the time. It would take a long time to see all the gardens. Very interesting plaques giving info about the flora and fauna.
worth a wander.... they invite you to sit on the grass- wonderful plants and views of the opera house. also a kids train tour.

Great place for a long walk. Walked through the gardens this morning and had a fantastic time. One of the best places in Sydney for a relaxing stroll. While it seems the flying foxes are a bit of a problem for the trees, etc. it's cool to see thousands of giant bats hanging from the trees. The best part of the gardens is that admission is free. I highly recommend going here.

A few hours in the Royal Botanic Gardens. While only expecting to take a quick visit to this area, we ended up spending almost four hours walking around and through the Gardens. Definitely take the walk around the waterfront area...there's great views of the city/Opera House/Harbour Bridge from the part that sticks out into the Harbor near Mrs Macquarie's Chair.

Fountains, Trees, Birds and City Views. Yes walk on the grass! Incredibly maintained flower gardens, ponds, chattering birds, trees identifed by name tags all to assist the common person enjoy and learn about natual beaty. Views of the Opera House and Bays.

Absolutely don't miss. Without a doubt the most stunningly located botanical gardens I have visited, with views over Sydney Harbour, including the Opera House, Harbour Bridge, Government House and city. Botanically I'm no judge but watch out for the wollemi pine, not exciting to look at but thought extinct till someone discovered a stand in the early 1990s. Also to watch for, the fruit bats, sacred ibis and all the other bird life of Sydney.

Serenity amidst urbanity. Such a beautiful place, great walks around great scenery, peace within the city and fantastic views of opera house, harbour bridge and the harbour itself as well as the city high rises.
Great. Great place to relax and unwind. Also has great views for photos
nice walk. walk to ms maquaries chair. this has to be one of the best views in sydney if not the world. you have the sydney opera house superimposed over the harbour bridge.

Most amazing gardens. Next to the opera house, these gardens are huge, with a fabulous display of very diverse plants, trees, birds and bats. Nice place to walk or just lay on the grass and enjoy it all.

Peaceful haven. The information staff were very helpful, giving us directions through the garden. If you have a minute in your schedule try to take a minute to visit the peaceful haven in the middle of the a big city.
Beautiful!!. Its been a while since I have visited here but the last time tthe gardens were just beautiful.
Beautiful. Relaxing place. Beautiful follage. Fun (and a little creepy) to see the bats flying at night.
Special, unique, join an art class. If you like plants and flowers, this is for you, there are even workshops you can join in on and paint or draw.
Gorgeous plant paradise of the South Seas.. Lots of good level walking, iconic views. So Sydney.

A fantastic space and place. We strolled for hours around these lovely gardens. The view of the Opera House and the Bay enhanced the beauty of the gardens. A very friendly, warden shared his knowledge with us, which further enhanced our visit. The Flora and Fauna is fantastic. The Flying Foxes are fascinating. The complex dilema related to the damage they do to trees is offset to some extent by the fact that they are great pollinators.

Beautiful Gardens. We walked through the gardens each day we were in Sydney and found it very interesting. It is well laid out and beautifully maintained. Apart from the multitude of birds and butterflies the most interesting for me were the flying foxes. They are very scary hanging upside down in the trees and the largest bats I have ever seen flapping around as they fly. They are in fact considered pests because they are destroying the trees

A pleasant escape form the city. Travelling with two children we found the gardens a great retreat from the heat and bustle of the city. We got a bit lost without a map as the paths weave around the park in some areas. We wished we had more time here.
Lovely gardens. Well worth a visit! Lovely gardens close the Opera House. Look out for the fruit bats hanging from the trees!

Our favourite Botanic Gardens in Australia. We spent a whole day just walking around the gardens and were more than happy. A great range of trees, plants, birds etc...
Great views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge.
Highly recommend spending a day or two here.

Local. I'm a local so I don't see the Gardens as a new visitor would. I definitely remember how beautiful they used to be with the magnificent Azalea displays and many more flowers and a lot less paving than the Gardens have now. The current ethos is to concentrate on a more drab display with a leaning towards spiky unfriendly bushes and palms. Still worth a visit to just lay on the grass and watch The Harbour. It's not quiet, though. Leaf-blowers and petrol carts are part of The Gardens' new ethos. It can be crowded, especially on weekends, but just sitting-back and observing the people is fun in itself.
Nice for a walk, good views. This is a pleasant area with many different plants and trees. It's a great place to walk around for free and it's nearby the Opera House.
No dogs :(. Pitty cant take dogs!
Loved walking through. Took a 90-minute walk through the gardens. BEAUTIFUL. Would go back in a minute. See it all.

A must - do when in sydney. Beautiful well-tended gardens with fantastic views to city and harbour. A great place to have an afternoon stroll, don't forget to take your camera to capture amazing views over to the iconic Opera House and Harbour Bridge, not to mention the many floral displays.Great gift shop with good quality Australiana.
Bats in the daytime!. Flying Foxes in their thousands - flying around - amazingTrees and exotic plants - fabulous
beautiful. we had a lovely afternoon here strolling around the gardens. we especially liked the herb garden (we took a couple of different ones home to use in our cooking ;) )plus its free :)
great day out. A great way to spend a lazy sunday just walking around looking at all the native australian plants and flowers

Good to withdraw to after the noisy city. I've been living in Sydney for over 9 years now, and would call myself a Sydney-sider. As with every person going native, after a while you take certain things for granted and don't appreciate them as much as you should. That's how I always feel about the Royal Botanic Gardens, whenever my Mum comes over for a visit from Germany. She absolutely loves them, and usually goes several times, just to wander around between the beautiful trees and wide open spaces. As a tourist, Sydney can be a little stressful at times, so she takes a book with her, and when she's had enough of the city, she just sits herself under a tree and reads for a little while.And the gardens are gorgeous in their lazy display of everything that makes Sydney so special. They have a huge part of the waterfront, with gorgeous views of the Opera House and the Bridge (the last 5 minutes of the 3rd Matrix instalment was filmed there). You can see LOTS of flying foxes, HUGE native trees, some art and statues, but mainly lots of nice open space to kick back. I would definitely recommend to every tourist to take a couple of hours to explore!
Outstanding. Must see if if you arent interested in gardens, a natural beauty!

Always nice to visit. Adjacent to Sydney Harbour, a stroll from the Opera House and you end up a nice cafe. There are bats in the trees, ibis and lovely old trees. Always a pleasure to see under a tree. I have seen Shakespeare in the Park there and it was brillant with the view of huge ocean liners, strawberries and champers and possums in the roof of the public conveniences.

Green Thumbs unite!. What's not to like. If you have the chance, take the Aboriginal Heritage tour (at a very small fee but so worth it) or a tour guided by one of the many very knowledgeable volunteers. Learn about plants and horticulture or just lie back and enjoy the beautiful surroundings. We've been on both types of tours a few times and we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves each time. And our visitors were very impressed.
Botanic Gardens by the Sea. They're nice gardens and their location by the harbour is very appealing, but compared with other gardens I've seen in other countries they're nothing to write home about.

Magical Setting. Wander the acres of greenery and don't forget the glass house for those unique species. Take a picnic lunch, a bottle of wine and time. These gardens are set on the Sydney Harbour and if you want a distraction from the plant life just turn and look at the prettiest harbour in the world.
Beautiful. We loved the gardens and popped into them most days whilst in Sydney
Beautiful. The gardens are easy to get around, there are excellent plantings and beautiful green spaces, its great
Yeah. Very nice and prettty but gets boring after a while
a lovely escape from the hustle of the city. It was raining when we visited but the escape from the noise and hustle and bustle of the harbour was fabulous
Relaxing. Very well maintained. Well labled, could have spent much longer. However with the sun the views and the atmosphere we just sat and enjoyed the gardens.
Good selection. Pleasant gardens, nice selection of plants, very good for a lazy afternoon. Nice vieuws over the water.
Excellent photo oppotunities. Some great vantage points for photos of the Opera House & Harbour Bridge. Wonderful parkland for a stroll- huge colony of Flying Foxes nest here hanging from the trees!
Don't miss this garden!. All right, I am a palm expert so this place is paradise but one could spend an entire day wandering around. View of the bridge is awesome.
Superb gardens. Huge gardens. Great wildlife including big bats. Beautifully laid out and they want you to walk on the grass! Goes around the harbour.Great for runners, walkers, botanists.

Interesting, but don't expect a lot of flowers. We had a combined tour with the gardens and a presentation on Aboriginal History. While I enjoyed the gardens, I am a flower enthusiast, and was just a tiny bit disappointed with the lack variety among the plants. Now, the fruit bats that live in the gardens are amazing and worth the trip alone. For me, by far the most interesting was the historical presentation.

Beautiful Gardens. Even with the recent torrential rains in Sydney, the Gardens have fared well, which must be attributed to the gardeners who look after it. Beautiful grounds with much variety, a lovely way to spend a Sunday afternoon. Staff are friendly and helpful.

One of our favorite Sydney attractions. We thoroughly enjoyed walking through the Royal Botanic Gardens. It was massive and full of beautifully landscaped mature plantings. I have never seen so many different plant varieties in bloom at the same time.
Great Gardens. Totally worth the visit. Check out the huge fruit bats in the palm grove. Who knew!
Beautiful makes for great photos!!!. A lot of different areas to take wonderful photos of the Bridge and the city!! Beautiful birds all around the park! Love It
Worth walking around. Even on a grey day it was worth walking around. Well looked after. Mind the joggers.
Beauty. The plan of the gardens, the beautiful flowers, the fragrance of the flowers and the peaceful surroundings.
Excellent gardens. Having see a few of these around Australia and the world, the RBGs are right up there with the best
Bigger than expected!. The gardens were beautiful and seemed to go on forever. Got a really nice photo of the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House from the gardens, near the water.
Tranquil Haven. Peace, tranquility and "pretty" in the very heart of a busy, noisy city.
Go for a stroll. Great for photographers of nature. Lots of open space for sports too. Bring water and snacks with you. Try and find the bats in the trees!
Pretty as a picture. Easy walking, beautiful plants and view, be as busy as you want or just pull up a piece of grass and enjoy.
Best thing in Sydney and it's free!. Walk, walk, walk...touch everything. Wonderful place for kids to run around and the harbor views are priceless.

Oasis in the city. Lovely Victorian era botanic gardens. This was the site of the first farming attempts in Australia, hence the bay is known as Farm Cove. Lovely views across to the North Shore and also the back of the Opera House

English Garden on Sydney Harbour. Old Government House open 3 times a week and fountains, ponds in European style. Garden first established by first Governors Wife (I believe). Cafe, shop and beautiful views over harbour. Small trolley to take you around if you wish.
A Beautiful space in the heart of the city. I love the gardens, they are a beautiful haven in the city and the wild bats are an added bonus!

Brilliant interlude. The Botanic Gardens are just lovely. Make sure you allow some time to wander around and check out the bits that interest you. We loved the extensive herb gardens in particular, but also enjoyed the oriental gardens, the rose gardens and the area down by the pond where the bats hang during the day. Good for a picnic, wedding spotting on a Saturday and giving your city experience a breath of fresh air. Lots of birds to watch as well.We didn't go everywhere and will definitely visit again on our next trip.

A must if you are interested in flora. It's a pity that such a wonderful Botanic Garden is not more popular.The advantage is that you may visit it in peace.It is extremely well kept and the species are abundant.

Absolutely beautiful and very well maintained. A huge area hugging the city CBD area on one side and the harbor on the other, this is one of my favorite places in Sydney to wander. Start at the Opera House and walk along the path up to Mrs Macquaries chair and perhaps back along to the NSW Art Gallery and then out along Art Gallery Road and exiting near Hyde Park. A gorgeous place to meander for a few hours on a sunny afternoon in Sydney.

Something for everyone. Whether you are an office worker on a break, a child interesting in the fruit bats or interesting in indigenous uses for plants - the botanic gardens has something for everyone.
Go see the bats. Lovely place to walk through and there is a nice little restaurant in the centre, ideal for coffee / cake / salad.Make sure you look up in the trees for a view of the massive bats!
Give it a day.. Amazing space in downtown Sydney, one moment your looking at rose gardens and the next modern skyscrapers.

See bats up close. We spent a pleasant morning in these huge gardens that are immaculately maintained. This is a good space to walk in Sydney. The grounds range from the oceanside promenade, views of Circular Quay and the Sydney Opera House and go around ponds and various trees and flowers. The most interesting aspect was the presence of many huge fruit bats. Unfortunately these are killing many of the trees and steps are being taken to discourage their tendency to sleep in the trees. For those people who do not want to walk, we noticed and little train/trolley that tours the garden on its pathways.

New Bird Friends. Suanne with Real Sydney Tours showed us this gorgeous park in the heart of Sydney. She knew right where to take us to meet the friendly & nearly tame cockatoos and lorakeets, feed them and interact for awesome photos

Welcome to the gardens- Please Walk on the Grass!!. Don't miss these- great views of the Harbour too. walk round to Mrs McQuarries chair, or get the little train. Nice restaurant/cafe and shop- don't forget to look up for those fruit bats- huge!

Originally named Farm Cove as it was the first area set aside to grow crops after ther First Fleet arived in 1788.. Walk leisurly through the gardens relaxing and enjoying the views of the harbour and the many varities of plants that were transported from England by the First Fleet to feed those who were transported from England.

Gardens are beautiful and extensive.. The botanic gardens cover a huge area. Much to see and just fun to wander through. Being from the US, the plant, shrub and tree species that differ from our country were amazing. See this on your trip.

Gorgeous green space in the middle of the city. A must place to visit, in fact worthy of several visits at different times of day.
Really interesting areas with plants from when the first settlers arrived, aboriginal area, lawns and amazing colonies of fruit bats - watch them all take off at dusk for a vision
of almost vampire like eeriness.

Beautiful and well maintained. A gardeners paradise. I am no gardener but appreciated the hard work that has been put into it, a perfect place to relax and enjoy lunch or just wonder round. It makes a great walk from Kings cross to the harbour.

Pleasant walk in the park. The Gardens are a nice green space close to the city. They are a well organized and have all the goodies of most BGs, without being particularly spectacular or unique. The slight downer is the people pressure, which is inevitable and expected. Enjoy early as much as you can. Watch out fot the bat haven .. You will hear them, just don't walk underneath them.
A peaceful haven. If you are a garden lover the walk round is lovely, also try the small train good commentary
Royal Botanic Gardens. For people who have a keen interest in plants, Sydney's Royal Botanic Gardens is worth a visit. It's close to the city centre and the Art Gallery.,
Opulence. Nice, quaint, peaceful, opulent. Excellent views, good flora, beautiful gardens with benches lined along pathways.

Oasis in the city. The Botanic gardens is a large green oasis right next to the city. It is great for a stroll and is right next to the opera house. There are different types of Gardens including a greenhouse (which requires a fee for admission). Walk to Mrs Mqcquaries chair for picture perfect shots of the Opera house and harbour bridge.
Beautiful. Beautiful rambling gardens, tame cockatoos and beautiful views over the harbour. Wish we had longer there

Fantastic. A must see when visiting Sydney. Beautiful gardens with abundant birdlife and resident bats. There are many smaller gardens such as the oriental garden or the fernery which adds interest, and the backdrop of the sea and opera house adds to the charm. Make sure you check opening times, as the garden gates close about 8 pm but many of the smaller gardens close their gates as early as 4.30. There is also nowhere to get coffee, at least late in the afternoon when we went.

Royal indeed!. Plush, beautiful rolling gardens with some of the most beautiful tropical plants ever. The grass is so soft and the gardens are expansive with a ridiculous view of the Sydney Harbour Bridge & the Opera House. Its easy to understand why many Sydneysiders spend their lunch or afternoons chilling, jogging, playing and/or reading in the awesomeness of the Royal Botanic Gardens. Best I've seen so far.
What a quiet and colourfull place. Paradise on earth with so large gardens with authentic lanscapes. Very suitable for families.

So peaceful and beautiful. These beautiful old gardens are framed so beautifully by their Harbour backdrop. Go for a stroll, read a book, take a shortcut to the Art Gallery but make sure you include these lovely gardens in a trip to Sydney.

Stunning sydney views. This is the place to see Sydney in all its glory. Fantastic views in a beautiful location with lovely walks through such a variety horticulture. Gardens from all around the world are on display here. There are lots of places in the gardens to sit quietly and admire the view. Can't come to Sydney without a walk around the Royal Botanic Gardens.
Beautiful!. Great location, and beautiful. Big. Look out for dramatic performances being held in the open!

Beautiful. A must for anyone visiting Sydney Harbour Area, we didn't intend to visit the Botanic Gardens but it looked so beautiful as we were looking around the opera house.A must is to look at all the fruit bats living in the trees near the cafe

BEAUTIFUL!. It really is beautiful. It's romantic, it's a great place to spend with either family, friends, colleagues or lovers. There's a great attitude and by that I mean there's no loud teenagers screaming and getting munted, the children are absorbing the view and are generally not ruining it with their loud screaming for ice cream.It's got great views of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House and the walk around the park is absolutely beautiful!
Lovely gardens. Watch out for the flying foxes in the equatorial rain forests. We thought it was birds chattering!

Beautiful urban oasis - and great for runners!. The Royal Botanical Gardens were near my hotel and recommended by fellow travelers, but I've been to city parks before and was not overly excited. The Royal Botanical Gardens far exceeded my expectations and was among my favorite places in all of Sydney. The paths that weave through the garden are gorgeous and relatively quiet, making them ideal for a morning or afternoon jog or walk. Allow yourself some time and enjoy your day at the gardens - you will not regret it!
beautiful and so uneke. this is a very old and uneke botanic Gardens the peace and sense of history here is lovely.
Check out the trees near the Gift Shop!. During the day you can find hundreds of sleeping fruit bats in the trees near the Gift Shop. Around sunset they take off in flight.
Stunning Gardens. Beautiful part of Sydney that makes a nice respite from the hustle and bustle of the city.Hosts the St. George OpenAir Cinema during the December/January months
A natural treasure.. This is one of the lungs of Sydney city.A must see . Take your time to walk through the gardens ,have a picnic,sit down under a tree and enjoy the nature.

Beautiful and Relaxing. We spent an afternoon wandering through the gardens and then Mrs. Macquaries Chair. Great views, beatiful flowers, some interesting wildlife as well. Perfect for a sunny afternoon.
Beautiful Gardens. Beautiful gardens by the harbour well worth a casual stroll.
a must see in Sydney. Free entry and fantastic views of the harbour and opera house from the gardens
Beautiful place for a stroll. It's always refreshing to walk through this little piece of paradise, nestled up against the skyscrapers. I find something new every time I go.
a beautifull oasis of green. i was amazed at how well RB Gardens are kept. People relaxing , socializing or taking lunch breaks there in a shade of trees. Gardens will relax your senses
Beautiful Walk. This was certainly a beautiful place. The gardens were astounding and it offered some wonderful views of the Harbour

Can I live here?. Unbelievably beautiful, expansive garden. The perfect place for a picnic, a nap or a game of kick with your toddler. Or all three! Love that they encourage you to "get on the grass and smell the roses." (They don't do that here in Shanghai!)

Bats and opera house views!. So much more than a botanic garden, this is a lovely place to walk, run, or bike. The views towards the Opera House and bridge are priceless, and the bats are an extra plus.

Tranquil and well laid out gardens. This is a jewel in Sydney's crown. There is helpful information displayed that identifies what plant or tree you are looking at. Whether you are relaxing under a shady tree or actively walking around the extensive gardens this place is great. Mrs Maquaries chair provides great photo opportunities of the harbour and surrounds.
Wonderful gardens. Beautiful well kept gardens, lovely to walk around and even better just to sit on the grass and take in the view of bridge and Opera House.
Nice gardens for a walk. Nice gardens, excellent for walks or runs. Many species of native plants and trees to see for the botanically inclined

Magnificent gardens. These gardens are among our favourite place, not just in Sydney but anywhere in the world.Walk through Hyde Park and the Domain, past the cathedral and the art gallery and enjoy these beautiful gardens and Sydney's wonderful harbour. At the other end of the gardens you have the Opera House, Government House, Circular Quay and the Rocks. A wonderful walk early in the monring, on your way to catch a ferry or to unwind later in the day.
Great walk thru gardens. Lots of flowers, trees, great harbor views. right next to Opera House.
Great place for a couple of hours. Lovely setting so close to city centre. Lots of plants, birds and flying foxes and a good harbour view

Great place to roam around. How can you not love the place that promotes you to walk on the grass, hug the trees and speak with the animals. The Botanic Gardens is perfect for a leisurely walk around or to lay out on the grass and enjoy a book. There are different sections with plants from various regions and they have a pretty rose garden. Great free attraction, don't miss it!
Our best experience in Sydney. A lovely place to spend a couple of hours. Beautiful borders, unique trees and dont miss the flying foxes.

Beautiful gardens. the most beautiful gardens in sydney.
lovely herb and rose gardens.

Beautiful Gardens. The Botanic garden is HUGE. We spent several hours wandering around and exploring all the gardens. Don't miss Miss Macquaries Chair. Great Photo opportunity. A great, free attraction for all.
Great Walk. Great walk from the Opera House, through the Gardens and then onto the NSW Art Gallery.

Peaceful & quiet, right in the heart of the city!. What a wonderful place to go to get away from it all, right in the heart of the city! Beautiful themed areas, paths to wander around & the hugest shady trees to sit underneath. Highly recommended!
take time to breath. wonder this wonderful paradise in the city ,enjoy and relax
Pleasant walk away from hussle and bustle. Cool, shafy walk in verdant gardens, all trees and shrubs well-labelled. A very pleasant interlude.
Gardens are magic. Plenty so see all year round. Always peaceful and beautiful with wonderful harbor views

~Gorgeous but no bats!. ~My son wanted to go as we had read there are lots of bats in this park, unfortunately we didn't see any. We went in the afternoon. The park is GORGEOUS, so relaxing and all sorts of beautiful flower and statues around!

A Very Happy Afternoon. We spent a very enjoyable afternoon amongst the flowers, trees and plants in this fantastic part of the city. There's lots to see and do with lots of information for visitors.Following a lot of walking, we grabbed a quick snack in the cafe and then relaxed on the green with stunning views of the bridge and the opera house.Well worth a visit - a real oasis of calm amongst the hustle and bustle of the city.

Wait for the flying foxes to come out at dusk. The gardens are really beautiful, and a great way to spend an afternoon. As the sun sets, the colony of thousands of flying foxes (enormous fruit bats) awakes from the trees and takes flight. It's amazing to watch.

Haven within walking distance of the bustling city. These gardens are a gem - a peaceful and tranquil walk giving not only verdant vistas but spectacular views of the harbour bridge and opera house. Best place to start is the entrance next to the opera house and wend your way from there following the well signposted paths. Visit the rose garden, see the first explorers garden, cactus garden and many other features. Be awed by the ancient fig trees with there wonderful spreading trunks. There is a coffee shop serving light meals and a gift shop near the waterlily pond. Different birdlife populate this oasis and early morning brings the parrots and cockatoos. Close by and within easy walking are the Fleet Steps and Mrs. Macquarie's Chair giving further harbour and city views.
Treated like royalty. One of Australia's best attractions.Well worth the time spent.
Beautiful. Clean green beautiful views and very peaceful. Well worth a visit. Fab location for those iconic photos!
Neat place. We went during Australia's winter so not much was blooming. Seeing the flying foxex (large bats) was impressive.
lovely well ordered pathways. well laid outbeautifull groundseasy to get around
Beautiful. An oasis of calm tranquility with harbour views, close to the CBD.

Nice place to relax.. Beautiful gardens, if you like gardens. The gardens are well maintained and manicured, with several different sections with depending on plant type. It is an excellent place to have a picnic, or just sit and relax in the grass, under a tree, and/or sit one of the many benches in the gardens and people watch.
Lovely ambience. Service pretty good, food very good, location excellent.

Beautiful, well-kept gardens. Right by the harbour, the Botanic gardens are extensive and provide a serene area right in the city. There are often wonderful botanic art displays and some artwork on sale. The flying foxes spoil it a bit in the area they have taken over, but there is an excellent restaurant and gift shop and it;s a haven from the hustle of the business area.

Great PARK!. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a very nicely done, well landscaped, and great location for what I would term a park, not a botanical garden (i.e. comparing to what we typically determine as a botanical garden in the USA). It is free, next to the Opera House, and easy to get to from all of Sydney city. I had higher expectations, and was really expecting a botanical garden rather than a park....but it was still a great place and a must see when in Sydney.

A great place in the CBD to get away from the noise. A nice park right in the CBD where one can have a break from all the city noise and stress. Lots of trees and plants to see and a choice vegetation from different climatic zones from the tropics to the temperate.
Great gardens. Very expanse area with summer plants and good displays.
An oasis in the middle of the city but with a harbour view.. One of the best spots in Sydney! Its big but easy to walk around. The grounds are first class. It doesn;t get any better than this.
So beautiful. Just breathtaking to walk around, so much to see. Very nice cafe too. Watch out for the flying foxes.
Great place for lunch. The Royal Botanic Gardens make for a stunning backdrop for a picnic lunch. Very pretty, and popular for people exercising on their lunch breaks!
Sydney. This would be a personal view as I can appreciate the work involved, but not my favourite pastime.

Beautiful Botanic Gardens, inculding bats!. We visited the gardens 3 times, the 3rd time going back just to see the bats (or flying foxes) which we had missed before! It was well sign posted and lovely to walk around, with many of the diverse plants and trees being well cared for.
So close to the city. The Botanic Gardens are just a great place to escape the bustle of the city. They are so close to the city and beautiful. Love the fig trees.

a lovely stroll amongst exotic flowers. this season with so much rain - the Botanic Gardens is the greenest and most prolific flowers in years - gorgeous !stroll around late afternoon when the heat is out of the sun, and enjoy the various themes - original aboriginal/early settlement plantings, and flowers from all over the world - very strange and interesting exotic creations - bring your camera !If you want a classic sunset photo - perhaps stroll around to Mrs.Macquaries Chair (the eastern point from Farm Cove) to enjoy the city skyscrapers, Opera House and Harbour Bridge in one panorama.It's a kilometre walk from Circular Quay - so plan to relax your feet regularly - bring a sandwich/fruit - there's plenty of nice lawn to sit on and have a picnic.One option might be to stroll in from the south/city/Hyde Park - (fairly long walk) past the Art Gallery (not free?), pool and Navy base, and return by walking the waterside path back around the cove to the Opera House and Circular Quay bus/train station - or vice versa.ground level beside the Opera House facing the bridge had a nice waterside wine/jazz bar where I liked to linger - it may be worth buying a drink in the dusk just to enjoy it longer.
what a place to spend the day. we spent two days in the garden . if you like gardens then well worth a visit , keep an eye out for the flying foxes and the lovely birds. 10 out 10

Amazing city green space. A little tropical paradise in the center of the city. Great for walks, reading and relaxing in the outdoors! Check out the fruit bats, they're HUGE, and there are so many of them.

Great place to get scenic photos of Sydney Habour Bridge and Sydney Opera House!. As above.
We went to find Mrs Macquarie's Chair and found the perfect spot to take beautiful photos that capture both the Sydney Habour Bridge and Sydney Opera House.

Great place for peace and a midday sleep. i was so relaxed looking over the harbour i fell asleep where I was. Woke up with sunburn but pretty rested - Summer heat and the Sydney Botanic Gardens - not to forget
lovely. this are just amazing so vast so beautiful, one of the most outstanding places i have been to right next to the opera house

Situated right on Sydney Harbour with views of the SH Bridge, Opera House. Situated right on Sydney Harbour, the Royal Botanic Gardens have stunning views of Sydney Harbour, Sydney Harbour Bridge, the Opera House etc. The gardens have large established shady trees and lovely landscaping. If you love gardens, you'll enjoy the Royal Botanic Gardens.

There all right but not exceptional. Theres many parks and gardens in the world to visit and this is not one of the exceptional ones so if your time poor don't waste it here. There are some good trees but I've seen allot nicer gardens and better set out.

Beautiful, even in winter. We planned to spend only a few hours at the Gardens but spent the better part of a day. Even in winter the sites and sounds of the RBG were spectacular. From tropical plants, to desert succulents the horticultural displays were amazing. For animal lovers, there is plenty to see: ibis; cockatiels, flying foxes were spotted. Geological sites to see include Mrs. Macquarries' point (as well as her chair). Fishing along the walkway along Farm Cove was fun to watch and made me want to buy a fishing rod.All of this is available for no charge minutes from Sydney's CBD. A true gem.
Immaculate. Beautiful, clean and great place to have a romantic picnic, away from the city centreA must for a walk or a relaxing read with your favourite book
Beautiful. We spent almost a full day walking around the gardens. Plants are well marked. And the gardeners were quite approachable when we had questions.

Stunning views!. This is where I proposed to my wife. Right beside the opera house, you can walk right through the gardens with some of the best views of the harbour, as well as the stunning gardens. The Governor's house is also here, as is the college of contemporary music (worth a photo from the outside).Given it's location, it is very much on and near the the normal tourist path.

Love the Bats. Walked through on our way to the Opera House & Circular Quay - beautiful grounds, lots of lawns where you are allowed to sit and picnic and don't miss the fruit bats hanging from the trees - if you are around the gardens (or Circular Quay) at dusk you can see the bats flying off to get their dinner (reminded me of Gotham City!).Don't miss viewing Government House up close and personal either. We couldn't get inside the building itself, but you can walk around the outside and admire the gardens (you have to walk uphill from the main path to get in via the formal entry gate but well worth it).

Town centre treat. After a minute or 2 of walking into the Botanic Gardens you wouldn't know you were in the city. Brilliantly maintained gardens and pools. There was a wedding on the day we were there, what a stunning place to have it.

Fabulous Gardens. Amazing views!. These beautiful Gardens were straight across the street from our Cirqular Quay hotel. We walked down through the Gardens to be confronted with the Opera House, front on, at eye level. Not the usual view you get looking up at it from the forecourt. Then walked down to Farm Cove, up towards Mrs Macquaries Road and back up to Macquarie Street.It was a lovely evening, the Gardens looked beautifully maintained, I didn't see any litter or rubbish anywhere, there were lots of people out strolling/jogging/walking and the plants/features were very well sign posted and explained.All for the cost of the energy we used up walking around ourselves. FABULOUS!

A great setting and free. Free to get in the Botanic Gardens are located next to the Opera House the gardens overlook the Harbour, they are large, well kept and have some spectacular plants and trees. A great place for a picnic or to take a pleasant walk away from the noise and crowds of the City.
Gardens not to miss. Beautiful, vast gardens. Not to miss if you like incredible views, peaceful walks, romantic parks, and interesting plants, trees, birds, and bats.
Beautiful, peaceful and great views. Must see if you are in Sydney. The views from the extended Botanical gardens are amazing and it is great to walk through the peaceful greenery!

Refreshing, great for a picnic and view photos of the city. Lush gardens, unique birds, and amazing views of the city, including the opera house and bridge. Families and couples alike will find beautiful spots to spread a blanket and picnic.
Oasis of calm. Stunning location with terrific plants and layout - and watch out for the Flying Foxes
green oasis. Beautiful place to spent some hours to walk around in. Great views too. I recommend walking from Mrs. Macquaries Chair through the Gardens and to the opera house.
A haven in the city. What an amazing place, so glad it is still there. Shame about the bats.
Calming effect. Beautiful to walk, or ride. Have a picnic or whatever takes your fancy whilst looking at all around you to see.

Beautiful manicured Gardens.. We spent four hours on a lovely summers day just wondering around these extensive manicured gardens.
Well woth the visit, just take your time and relax, the veiws over the harbour are a great bonus

Fantastic gardens. We enjoyed very much the beautiful Botanic Gardens and we have even watched the New Years Eve fireworks there. Before and after the 31.12, one can relax walking or lying in this great (and free) gardens!

Take 30 minutes and walk through the RBG. After arriving in Sydney our first day after the plane ride and walked around the city for a while, we caught the tour train which was a nice overview of the park with guided commentary on some of the plants and animals at the Royal Botanic Garnens.

Take time to smell the flowers. Close to the city heart, make sure you leave ample time for a stroll through the gardens, the nearby art gallery, museum and state library. In summer you may be lucky enough to stumble on a free concert at the domain, or open air movies near Mrs Macqaurie's chair.

Green Oasis close to Opera House with river views. Great place to sunbathe or just relax in the shade of a tree. There is road train that takes you around the full gardens and stops near the Opera House if you cannot face walking in the hot weather of Sydney.

Strolling through the Gardens affords some nice city views. You can stroll through the gardens for free and it will afford you some different views of the city skyline, as well as the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. If you walk all the way around to the Mrs Macqaurie's Chair (the next point along after the Opera House), you can get some great photos of the Opera House in the foreground and the Harbour Bridge in the background. Lovely for a picnic and soaking up the glorious harbour city.

Best Botanic Gardens site in world. I used to visit the gardens as a small child and have not been back for over 25 years. They are as good as I remembered. I dont think there could be a more beautiful Botanic Gardens site in world!
If you have the time. So many wonderful thngs to see this is not on the list of must dos unless ou are mad for gardens there are other cities who do it better.
Welcome heat relief. A welcome escape from the heat and a short walk from the ferry terminal

Fantastic park to escape the city. I worked next to these gardens for a while and would go there to have much lunch every day. There are so many places to walk and it's beautiful to get some greenery in when you've been in the city a while. Great place for a daily run too, the plants have plaques to give you information about them if you are into that and there are great little sections with seats all over the place. A great place for a picnic or some relaxation and thinking time.

An ideal location to celebrate new year. My husband and I choose the Royal Botanic Gardens to watch the new year celebrations called "Picnic on the lawn". Yes, it is expensive but well worth it. The area does not open until 7pm and comes with a fantastic picnic. The quality of the food which is carefully sourced from organic local produce is amazing. It is very plentiful and comes in a picnic box with water. There is a bar area servicing drinks. I would certainly recommend these gardens to view and celebrate the new year.

Beautiful Area of Sydney. We spent a few hours walking through these gardens and it was time well spent. The various specimens of trees and plants are spectacular and the park is clean and manicured. Look for the "flying foxes" hanging from the trees and flying from tree to tree.

Great way to fight Jet Lag if flying to Sydney from UK. The Gardens are of course beautiful and offer stunning views of the Opera House/harbour Bridge & City for pictures etc.... most amazing part was seeing all the BATS! Yes BATS hanging from the trees and making a right racket!!! We visited the Gardens the morning we landed in Sydney and took the train tour of the park with a guide, it really woke us all up and allowed us to fight the Jet Lag to stay up the entire day so we could sleep as late as possible to fight the lag!

Well laid out, stunning flowers near Government House. A really relaxing spot and well maintained. We liked the Flying Fox bats hanging upside down in the trees. One down side, there's no cafe for a coffee or an icecream - only a fancy restaurant that serves lunch and closes around 3.30pm. Why isn't there a cafe here?
very pretty place. walked here for hours so pretty. there was so much to ee and th view of the opera house from here was the best!
Beautiful Public Garden. I couldn't believe how beautiful this garden was and the fact that it was free and open to the public.

And don't forget Government House .... The Botanic Gardens are a beautiful place to spend some time while you're in Sydney. The price (free) is also very friendly. While you're there don't forget to visit the old Government House building. This is great to see, and again is free. The Government House gardens are open every day and are lovely, and you can have a good look at the magnificent old building itself while you're there. Views back to Sydney from this location are brilliant. I think there are guided tours inside the House on some days (weekends mainly) which would be good. I did one of these tours many years ago and it was very interesting, and again very reasonably priced, if not free as well. From the gardens you can walk out along the Harbour down to the Opera House for some absolutely spectacular views, with the Harbour Bridge as a backdrop to the Opera House. An easy way to spend a wonderful half-day to a day in Sydney without having to open your wallet once.
Great for a stroll. A great spot for an afternoon stroll and free too so all good
Beautiful. Not much is cheap or free in Sydney so enjoy the very few things that are. Walking shoes and a picnic is the shot here.

Tranquility in the middle of Sydney.... So peaceful and serene. Some historic sights in the Gardens as well as little plant shop and those Bat's in the tree's. Combine the gardens with a stroll to Mrs Macquaries chair.
Peaceful place. This is a lovely walk from the Domain through to Opera House. I did not like the bats
Beautiful Gardens in the middle of town. This is a terrific place to spend a morning or afternoon. The flowers and trees are fantastic. Very easy to walk to it from Sydney Harbor, then just amble.
a lovely stroll. A walk in the Botanic Gardens is always a pleasure and enhanced by the variety of plants and the waterside position.
Wonderful place to relax. No matter what time of year it's a lovely to spend your lunch hour when working or when on holiday.
Beautiful. The Gardens are a perfect walk toward the Opera House and Mrs. Macquarie's Chair. The trees are amazing, and look up to notice all of the bats hanging around during the day.

A nice was to spend an afternoon in the middle of the city. The gardens are a lovely escape from city life & very well maintained. I recommend walking from here to the opera house, you will get some great views.
Walk it, love it.. Peace, quiet and beauty right in the heart of the city.

Sydney's Botanical Bounty. Tall bamboo, multi-trunked trees, flocks of Ibis, sleeping wombats, stone statues and fountains, rainbow lorikeets close enough to photograph, great views across Sydney Harbour to Opera House, wide open space. Easy cut through from Woolloomooloo Apartments (first hotel) in Kings Cross district to Circular Quay.

So impressive. After all the spring rainfall, the gardens were lush and green at Christmas time. I entered at the top of the gardens (cnr Macquarie and Bent Streets) and then walked all the way down to the foreshore and to the Opera House. Along the way there is so much to see. Each little patch is beautifully maintained and the towering Morton Bay fig trees leave every visitor astounded. Perfect for a stroll, a picnic or a bit of yoga or exercise!
Different Trees. unfortunalty we only had a little time here too, but what we did see whas good.Wish we had more time in Sydney.
lovely afternoon. It's free; it's beautiful; it's great for people-watching.
Terrific. Don't miss this attraction. We were there when lots of plants and trees were in bloom

Peaceful and refreshing. Great for picnics. Still haven't picnic'd there but from walking around and going back there for a couple of times now I know it is great. Also the views of the opera house with a backdrop of the Harbour bridge is spectacular! Great little escape from the busy cbd!
Just walk it!. A great walk through the park to get refreshed and view the beauty of greeness.

Heaven of tranquility. This is one of my favorite spots in Sydney. Walk around watching the flying foxes and cockatoos, or sit under the shade of a tree watching boats cruise past in the harbour. A true gem!

Animals and flowers in the wild. Vampire bats recovering an entire tree, beautiful trees and plants around the sea shore, a magical place to hang around. Located just in the City, this is a lung of green, just few minutes from the hotels, circular quays...Sydney is a pedestrian place so everything is a walk distance. A lovely restaurant and a handy cafeteria are also available for those who dont want to pic nic and get their food taken away by the seagulls.
Love the gardens... so much to see. There is so much to see in the gardens, I love spending time here! Jan-Feb is especially brilliant with the St George open air cinema overlooking the harbour
Not our first visit. We love this area of Sydney and visit everytime we are there.
Worth the walk. A great walk through a magnificent park in the centre of the city and with harbour views.

Beautiful Gardens, fabulous location. The Royal Botanic Gardens are really beautiful, easy to get around and there is much to see. You can get refreshments in the cafes in the middle of the gardens, so you can spend quite a bit of time there to really relax. There is parkland adjoining where you can lay down on soft grass in the shade and enjoy the surrounds. The harbour is very close which is another benefit. The gardens are an easy walk from inner city hotels, of from the Cross and Darlinghurst and train stations. The Opera House is nearby as well as are department stores, Hyde Park, The Rocks.

Wonderful reprieve from the hustle and bustle. The Royal Botanic Gardens offers a wonderful reprieve from the hustle and bustle of the city. It is located right in the city but once you are inside the garden, it is easy to feel like you are miles away. I was impressed by the rich variety of trees, plants, and floral in the park. Clearly they reflect how well maintained this huge park is. Definitely a must visit.Tip: To get a view of the most photographed spot in Sydney, walk towards Mrs Macquarie's Chair and you will have the view of both the Opera House and Harbour Bridge together in front of you. Picture perfect.

Nature Wonderland in the middle of concrete jungle. Whether you have 30 mins or couple of hours this is a great place to unwind instantly.Also to gain some inspiration to make your own place somewhat more 'natural' than it is now. Variety of plants is just so amazing.If you are there around dusk, beware of bats. it will not attack you but will transport you to a pre-historic ambiance ..... Spooky but truly astounded at how nature and city-life can co-exist. Better to get there by public transport or taxi as parking will put you way back or you will end up rushing to avoid the parking nazies on patrol.
great spot. very woth the look to see lots of different plants gives a great view of the opera house framed by the bridge

Excellent Garden - Nice retreat from the City. The Botanic Gardens are a great retreat from the main city of Sydney. Enter via the gates next to the Opera House for a pleasant walk through the gardens with many native plants.
Beautiful gardens. Lovely ,serene place in busy Sydney. Lots of flowers in bloom and a pleasant way to spend a few hours.
Relaxing environment. Walking through here takes you away from the hustle and bustle of Sydney. An ever changing panorama.

Love these Gardens. It is not that difficult to park to view these gardens living in Sydney myself and a visitor often to the gardens we find it best to drive to the art gallery park down the street it is easy to find a gate leading into these beautiful gardens it is meter parkingThe city underground parking nearby is to far to walk to reach the gardens would not advise thisThere are 2 gift shops inside within these gardens 1 selling lovely works of art sculptures and mainly handy crafts the other books and souvenirsplaques through out the gardens have details on trees and flowers grown this time we were a little disappointed that there were not more flowers aroundDifferent events are held on Sydney artists and sculptures as well tours of the gardens can be arranged The main restaurant is lovely they also hold special eventsThere is not a charge to enter the gardens and it is a lovely day out wandering around this beautiful place

One of most amazing places. Botanical Gardens were amazing. Full of bats, different types of birds and of course vegetation. I have seen zoos with less animal life. Highly recommended. Location new the Sydney Opera makes it for a great walk through the gardens to the Sydney Opera. One thing to keep in mind is that it closes for the evening and night
Beautiful Walk thru Gardens. Take the docent tour...very informative...didn't even realize there were flying foxes in trees until our guide pointed them out!

Beautiul Gardens in Downtown Sydney.. In some cities the Botanical Gardens are on the outskirts. The Sydney Botanical Gardens are right in the middle of the Central Business District. There are lovely paths, part of which brings you along the water, and you can either begin or end at the Opera House. On a sunny day there is almost nothing better to do in the city.
as a park amazing but lacking toilet and cafe facilities. you can not get a cafe there easy and the only cafeteria was shut on Friday from 4pm!!! ridiculous!
Beautiful gardens - wonderful animal life. Free. Beautiful. Summer. What more is there to like? Such great and informative signs, and lots of volunteers to help you. Tons of terrific bird life too!

Bats galore...... Great place for a picnic and a view of the harbour. Pity the bats in the trees make so much noise around the cafe area. You need to watch for the bat droppings (an umbrella is handy for this!)
It's free. Its free to walk round, glorious on a sunny day and don't forget to check out the fruit bats in the trees
Beautiful Garden on the Water. Just a hop, skip, and a jump away from the Opera House, the Botanical Gardens provide a beautiful garden of flowers and plants to see right on the side of the water!

Look for huge bat population.. We were surprised to see the large bat population there. The bat is huge - 1.5m wing span! The garden is free, you can spend a day there...it is so beautiful! The Governor's Mansion is only open on the weekends.

Please walk on the grass!. I liked walking in the beautiful garden, with large bats (flying foxes) hanging from the trees, strange and interesting birds walking and flying around, and then there's the incredible vista of the opera house and harbor.
the best view in Sydney. lovely photo op with the opera house and harbor bridge in the background. don't miss the flying foxes
beautiful oasis in the heart of the city. A great place to stroll. A quiet, green place in the heart of the city.
great park. loved all the plants and the info provided under each tree. great relaxing way to spend time and appreciate quiet time. Is right in the middle of the city too. Easily accessible

Tranquility in the heart of the city.. The Royal Botanical Gardens is a wonderful way to escape the hustle of the city - and entry is free, although you will have to pay for street parking if you drive there. There are many different gardens within it to explore. Unfortunately, there are more foreign species of plants than Australian plants within it but the lush lawns are still a great place to spread a picnic blanket.
Excellent gardens, dreadful cafe prices. The gardens are fantastic however i would advise anyone to by pass the cafes, absolute rip off prices.
Lovely and Educational. Just take a stroll through the gardens for relaxation, and/or take the time to read the wealth of information on display. Time well spent, whatever you do there!

So much to see!. The Botanical Gardens were beautiful. Different themes allow you to see different flowers, trees and shrubs. And also a surprise are where there are huge bats (someone referred to them as flying foxes) hanging upside down in the trees. I think it would be a bit scary at night. But it was very interesting seeing that in the day time.
Unbelievable!. Take the time to walk about these amazing gardens. If you are lucky you will see some glorious parrots and "flying foxes" also known as large bats!

Lovely walk to the Harbour!. Great range of plants. Very picturesque. A good walk. Make sure you walk to the Mitchell Library as well and around the Cathedral into Hyde Park for a good view of the city as well.
Feedback on the Gardens. Great, very well kept see the size of the BATS !! Check out the Governors House

Lovéd being hère!. One of the mots astonishing view of Sydney.If you love nature, you should visit this place and spend Time in.if you Like to Walk also or jog this is for you.There is accès for wheelchair too.I saw a lot of parrots and man y orner birds flying
Avid gardener. As I am an avid gardener thought it would be interesting to compare the botanic gardens in my home town to the Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney, was gobsmacked

a host of golden daffodils.... Is not what you'll find here, but what you will see has to be one of the best laid-out and cared-for gardens in the world. The plant descriptions are excellent, the landscaping complements the planting and vice versa, and the flowers are beautiful. Just walk, look and smell. It doesn't come much better than this.Oh, and the people in the shop are lovely. So helpful.

Reconnoitering a paradise. A sunny Sunday morning encouraged us to take a small cycling trip around the Royal Botanic Gardens. The first thing I remember was a huge amount of colours and a pleasant scent of some beautiful tropical flowers. After a short visit at Greenway Terrace with a panoramic view of the Gardens and the bay we went around Mrs Macquaries Bushland Walk route. There was a beautiful viewpoint on the way with the Sydney Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. At Mrs Macquaries Point we could admire strange coastal (sand?)stone formations. And we got extremely tired on the way back as the path went up and down numerous times. I would recommend visiting the Sydney Tropical Centre with a glass Pyramid - it looks like the Louvre Pyramid filled with palm trees.To sum up, this trip encouraged us to visit the Royal Botanic Gardens again - in order to see the feature gardens in more detail!PS. Allergics should take their medicines with them - they may be useful. Also, when we were leaving the Gardes, we saw "Bicycles not allowed" sign (there was plenty of cyclists though)...
An excellent place to start a sydney trip.. Beautiful gardens, good for people watching and seeing different views of the harbor and citiscape. Great for photos.
The best sited botanical gardens I have seen. Framed between the city, the harbor and at the foot of the Sydney Opera House the invite you to walk on the grass and smell the flowers. Don't miss it.

Love plants or sit on the harbour or just lie down the whole day. Its the best place to be in Sydney , terrific views of Opera house, the harbour , the air from the beach and variety of plants and wildlife, we saw white parrots and bats , birdlife is everywhere and plants are amzing and dont forget to visit the carnivores plants enclosed section for a nominal fee and rose gardens the bloom is in spring to summer and its fantastic , most of all a free entry and a great place to pass whole day , lie down , read a book or have a snooze, learn about plants or just click photos with amazing views.

Disappointing - not as large as I expected but near museum. I had expected more from this botanic garden. We were there in November (spring) so some but not all things were in bloom. The garden is adjacent to the Sydney museum,so you could combine them.

Lovely gardens and a great shortcut. . .. A lovely place to go and just chill out on a bench with a takeaway coffee and just watch everyone run their errands. Also doubles up as a nice cut through to the opera house if coming in from Kings cross. The park shuts its gates quite early though (6 o clock I think)

Beautiful gardens, world-class views.. Gorgeous gardens with some added bonuses. Loads of different areas, I like to stroll along the foreshore, visit the cacti and the fernery, or the glass house. Keep your eyes out for the colony of very large, cute fruit bats that have taken up residence in the grounds. Parking nearby isn't great, go to the Domain Parking lot on the weekend (but not on the weekdays - its super pricey). You may want to combine it with a trip to the Opera House, which is right next door. Picnics in the Botannic Gardens are great (I like to go to David Jones Department Store Food Hall and pick up some gourmet goodies on the way.)

The Stunning Belle of Sydney. After being in the hustle and bustle of Sydney in the last few days of my trip, I decided to explore the Royal Botanic Gardens just before I head to the airport.After a short stumbling around from the Circular Quay Train station, i found the Garden!! The place was HUGE!!! Kudos to the team who kept the garden so picturesque! In fact, it was one of those rare moments that I felt bad I didn't have to pay anything to see something that stunning.Spring was IN, and so I was in for a great visual treat!! the colours of Spring! 1) Flowers, flowers and more flowers2) Birds, bees and A LOT OF flying foxes3) People chilling on the green grass with a nice book and mini picnic4) City dwellers taking a healthy lunch break by having a jog/sunbathe5) Wedding by the garden6) View of Sydney harbour Bridge and Sydney Opera House Definitely a place with great views! Especially for lovers of photography, nature and a breath of fresh air !
Gorgeous!. It's all good here! Perfect for wedding photos!! Just don't book your wedding here, it's too expensive!!

Beautiful gardens and views. Look for the huge bats up in trees!!. A peaceful oasis in the city center. There are huge colonies of bats hanging from the trees that fly out after sunset in huge swarms. We also saw lots of wild cockatoos.
Great views of Sydney's harbour and pleasant easy to walk paths. Bring a picnic and spend a very nice sunny afternoon.
Cheap and good to relax. You don't have to spend a lot to enjoy Sydney, it's fun to just walk around and see the sights of the Harbour and attractions

A real surprise!. After all these years, this was our first visit! We were surprised at the size, the views, the documented history and the level of maintenance. If you want a break from the city, this is where you must go - and do linger in the rose garden, it's just fantastic.

A world away but right in the city. A few steps from busy Circular Quay takes you to the Botanic gardens: a peaceful world away from the city bustle. Be sure to join one of the free guided tours held daily, you can learn about wasps which are specific to their tree, or see the eels that cross the lawns to get into the lake.The gardens were the second established in the world so are very significant.There are plants and trees from all corners of the world, lovely shady spots to picnic, a cafe and great shop for special presents .
Very Enjoyable Gardens. Was a very pleasant place for a stroll with lots of plants to see along with many birds
Wonderful for a walk or morning jog. The views, the different plants and trees, the greenhouses. A lovely restful place in the midst of a busy city.
Worth seeing. Good way to discover the unique plants of Australia.

Lovely place for a walk. Walked from the Blue Hotel through the gardens around to the Opera House. The Jacaranda's were in full bloom so the gardens were looking beautiful. At 8am it was peaceful and quite, just a few joggers and me. Bliss!
Right on the Harbour. Beautiful setting for picnics and right on Sydney Harbour then walk to the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. A great day out for no entry fees
Relaxing. Worth a visit to zone out for awhile, check out the flying foxes hanging from the trees. easy access from the city and circular Quay.

A little touch of paradise in central Sydney. If you've time, walk towards the back of the gardens, near The Domain, where, hidden away are quiet gardens and secluded short walks. It's easy to get away from the crowds and spot local wildlife, such as many pretty birds, butterflies and fruit bats.
RBG. Though it is small, you have to visit it if in Sydney. It is not Central Park in NYC, but it is a lovely spot to see & spend time while in Sydney, and to appreciate some history.
