Nice walk in a beautiful place.. I loved the royal garden where all the different kind of roses

Oasis between harbour water and cbd. Great place for jogging, having your lunch on the grass or just go for the massive collection of plants, trees and grasses. Very well kept and good restaurant within.
a haven for busy people. ancient plants in the walk through forest area, and the scope of the fernery. Also the water birds strolling around were just delightful.
beautiful garden.. Easy walk around these beautiful gardens. It is lovely to have a quiet place to walk and relax in Sydney.
A Wonderful Breakfast. This is just the most magic place for a Sunday breakfast/brunch. Great food, wonderful service and the lost amazing atmosphere. Seriously worth a visit.

Love the bats!. This is a great, free attraction that's conveniently centrally located. Whether you're just passing through on your way to somewhere else, or you've come there to admire the gardens and stroll around, there's a lot to see and enjoy.Among the many gardens are a palm grove, an herb garden, an aboriginal garden featuring native plants that were on the original garden site, a famous Wollemi pine, an Australian rockery, a succulent garden, a rose garden, and an indoor tropical greenhouse. Joggers and dog-walkers abound, and you'll see lots of cockatoos, parrots, kookaburra, and ibis casually wandering about. The "flying fox" bats are a breathtaking sight if you're not afraid of bats — they fill the trees by day and come out at dusk to hunt.In addition, there is a gift shop, a couple of restaurants and cafes, and lots of sculpture and art in various buildings around the site — I wish we had known more about what was there! Definitely print out a map from their website and highlight the areas you want to see, because the grounds are huge and you may miss a lot otherwise!
Beautiful. I enjoyed walking through the Gardens. The bats taking refuge in the trees were a nice treat and a great attraction.
Very photographic. We walked around to Mrs Macquarie chair, an good walk with a good view of the harbour bridge and opera house at the end. Very photographic gardens with lots to see.
Spacious, well laid out, and free!. We go everytime we are in Sydney. The Botanical Gardens here are better than nearly all the other ones we have visited!

Relaxing atmosphere with a great view to downtown. Here you can chill and relax like a lot a people do. And if your interested you can also learn a lot about australian plants. The whole area is more likely a park with some information about the plants growing in it.
Absolute recommendation, can be very well combined with the visit of the opera house.
excellent gardens. Beautiful gardens; lots of interesting trees, flowers and birds....and bats!

Lovely Quiet Side of Sydney. I have now been to the Royal Botanic Gardens twice now and enjoyed both visits so much.The Gardens are tranquil, clean and a great place to 'switch off' from the city for a while. It's well worth taking a seat for a while and appreciate just what is around you - the bird and animal life, as well as the lovely open space.The view across to the bridge and opera house gives a great photographic opportunity.

Beautifully laid out and maintained. We really enjoyed our stroll through the gardens and had to stop often to admire the flowers - never say such a lovely bed of poppies. There were strategically placed benches with great views of the city.

Sydney's most beautiful city park. There is a reason why so many wedding photographers bring their clients here for their wedding photos.This park has some of the best views across the harbour. In addition the flying foxes can be seen sleeping the tree tops.This is also a great place to go for a run, you would struggle to get a more dramatic route.
Wonderful blooms and scents. I walked the garden portion overlooking the harbor and sat on benches surrounded by beautiful blooms and aromas while enjoying the harbor breeze.
Royal Botanic Gardens. There are so many beautiful flowers and walkways here Just bursting with flowers and color. Try Your luck on the *wishing Tree" I did and it worked.

Hanging fruit bats. Looking for a stroll away from the city to relax and take a look at a vast collection of flora and fauna? This is the place to do just that. Look up when you are among the palm trees to see the fruit bats hanging upside down.

If you do not like Bats - keep away. The Botanic Gardens are to be seen. There are so many beautiful plants and they are a must see. I actually expected to see a few more flowering plants given the fact that we visited in November. But as the title goes - if you are scared of bats keep away.
GORGEOUS GARDENS. These are an absolute delight to walk around and all so close to the City as well.

Take the time to walk through the gardens!. The gardens are beautiful, the views from them across the harbour are well worth the effort. There is a short cut from the city across the gardens to Woolloomooloo Finger Wharf!

Gorgeous!. These gardens are enormous! The trees are very special for a Canadian. I also saw a white parrot, only to be seen in Pet shop in Canada. There are nice views of the harbour in the gardens. Don't miss it!
Simply beautiful. So convenient to the harbour and Opera House. A fabulous relaxing way to spend the day.
nature lovers delight. What a wonderful place, could have happily spent the whole day here, cannot think of anything negative to say, it is beautiful and interesting, such a haven in the big city.

A huge diversity of animal and plant life in the heart of Sydney!. You could spent hours in the park and see something different at every turn! Old, ornate fountains, the Governor's House, huge bats, wild Cockatoos, and interesting flowers/trees abound in the park. It is huge and is a beautiful peaceful property in such an urban area.
peaceful place for a quiet walk. so quiet yet in the middle of the city and open early the morning
Beautiful. I enjoyed this park. My friends and I went for a walk and sat in the grass, played cards and it was beautiful. It's hard to find a piece of nature in such a large city. I loved this.

Lovely oasis of calm in a busy city.. Make sure you visit the Botanical gardens, wonderful situation on the coast and full of beautiful trees and shrubs. Government House in the middle is open Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. Most surprising thing we saw-bats hanging upside down in the trees, and flying around in broad daylight. Much bigger than UK bats!
Green oasis. Pleasant spot in the centre of the city to get away from traffic and noise.
Bats in the trees :). I really enjoyed seeing all of the plant-life that is unique to this part of the world. The Gardens is right in the city and you can relax and enjoy the greenery.
beautiful. Try and go around the gardens, stunning! They are so well laid out and really pretty, good mixture of flora and fauna.

Nature's treat in the heart of the city. It's location is near the Opera house, the Art Gallery and Circular Quay, so there is really no reason to miss it. Stroll through the park to see plants that you may see no other place at a leisurely pace. Remembering that this garden architectural treat was started many years ago, gives credibility to the huge trees you will see. A very nice repose from the rush of city life.Just before closing at dusk we witnessed the exodus of the large fruit bats heading out for a night of feasting in the local suburbs.

Fantastic Garden. The Royal Botanical Garden is located right next to the Sydney Opera House. The property is massive. Being spring, it was exciting to see the new plants. I saw my very first Bat – there are a few trees in the garden that are full of them and of course at 2 in the afternoon they were all wrapped up in their wings and sleeping. These bats were called Grey-headed flying foxes. We walked over to the Pavilion Kiosk and had a light lunch then we stopped in the Palm Grove Centre for a little shopping but we did not purchase anything – we just found everything over priced. We walked for about 2 hours and we barely saw one quarter of the garden. We actually were getting tired from all the walking so we decided to head back to our hotel. If you are interested in gardens this is a must see but schedule a full day in order to see everything. Admission is free.

Great glasshouses and ideal for a stroll. Gardens have a decent range of plants and some interesting glass houses [entry fee about A$5.50 pp]. Lots of places to sit and relax, access also to Government House [free access to those gardens in the day time and some weekend tours inside the house too].

wonderous walk. i loved the gardens, very picturesque , lots of new and interesting plants, great places to sit and relax, take a picnic, the pavilion dones great food, i reccomend the sausage rolls. keep an eye open for the fruit bats and the Orb weavers at certain times of the year.Great llocation close the the opera house a quuick eacape from the city.
Really Royal. Wish we had more time here. Very relaxing. Lots of walking. Wear comfortable shoes.
Awesome Gardens. They're coming up on it's 200th anniversary, so lots of mature trees. Well worth walking around.

Oasis in the middle of the city. The gardens are truly an oasis in the middle of the city. Abutting at points along the water and cliffs, you forget that you are steps away from cars and people and the hustle and bustle of the CBD.The most beautiful walk is through the Domain and then left down the paths (passed the art museum on your right). Stay on the path on the right hand side of the road. The path hugs the water and winds to the left giving you amazing views of the Opera House. It deposits you right at the mouth of the gardens, where you can find hundreds of fruit bats hanging from trees.Pack a lunch or a snack, pick a spot near the water and relax.
Gardens to Dream of. Took one of the little trains for the guided tour, very informative and saved a lot af walking.
Beautiful, huge, and free. The gardens are downtown right by the the Opera House. It's a great place to see bats and cockatoos. It's serene and a great place to get away. Plus it's free.
Beautiful. Wonderfully maintained, such views of different parts of the Harbour.

Really nice. Great place to go for a walk or for a run. I don't think there are acutal 'gardens' lol, its a large park, similiar to Central Park in NYC. Its really nice there and worth to walk around. Great spot to take pictures.

Interesting & Beautiful. We took the 1 1/2 hour free tour. The guide was knowledgable, friendly and patient as we walked slowly through the grounds, pointing out interesting botanical and historical information.
I like any parks. I think there is nothing particular about the gardens, but I just like greens.

I love the fruit bats!. Beautiful, spectacular place. Get takeaway food from David Jones food court and have a wonderful picnic on one of the lawns. And watch the fruit bats take off into the sky at dusk, flitting over the opera house.

Bigger than you think. Loved the displays - and we were able to film wild bats hanging in the trees above us...and flying around during the day. Views across the bay to the Opera House and the bridge were brilliant.
Bats Everywhere. I find gardens to be somewhat boring although this was uniquely beautiful with the harbour and opera house in the background. There are a LOT of large bats, though, so watch out!
You could spend hours walking around and we did. So much to see and do..carve out 2-3 hours to walk and relax..Its the best botanic gardens and largest I've ever been
Delightful. Great views, various sections to the garden to appeal to various people. Flying Foxes in trees, etc

Go to check out the mad runners!. The botanical gardens are beautiful in their own right but more than their beauty, you get fantastic views of the opera house and bridge as you near that side. But the most important aspect is to get a slice of real Sydney culture, which is a bit of a must...the gardens are full of crazily fit people who do serious exercise in their hundreds and it's a great introduction to what Sydney is!
Scenic and relaxing. A perfect escape in the middle of the city with a view of the harbour
Go for an early morning walk.. Really great place for walks. Check out the flying foxes and then goto the harbor for the best view of the Opera House. Wild Cockatoos? Pure craziness.

Vast, well-maintained gardens with surprises around every turn. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney weren't even mentioned in my guidebook, but thank goodness I visited them because they became my favorite place in Sydney. The gardens are vast, stretching from the Opera House to the Mint, and they're full of well-maintained trees, flowers, and shrubs, many of which you'll never see outside Australia. You'll also see wild animals that most people have never seen outside of zoos, such as cockatoos, ibises, and flying foxes.The gardens reminded me of Central Park in New York because of the many "special locations" within the gardens, such as a rose garden, an herb garden, countless fountains and statues, a collection of succulents from around the world, and an oriental garden with lily pond. Non-botanical locations within the gardens--which, incredibly, are free of charge--include Government House, the restored mansion of the colonial governor, and the Art Gallery of New South Wales.The gardens are open seven days a week during daylight hours. Once I discovered them, I made a point of strolling through them each day, even if I was ultimately headed elsewhere. The winding paths through the gardens are a delightful eastern route if you're walking from the Opera House or Circular Quay to Hyde Park or the Central Business District, for example. If you're in Sydney for even a brief one-day trip, the gardens should make your must-see list if you have any interest in plants, wild animals, or natural beauty.

nice area! love all the greenery. this place is HUGE. i think you can walk around there all day! i love how sydney is a huge city and then theres the botanical gardens to compliment it. lots of greenery/lawn space for people to hang out / picnic / etc. truly enjoyed walking through this area.
Relaxing time. Great for a walk in the morning, but you can spend a whole day in it.
Beautiful!. This garden is simply beautiful. A perfect place to enjoy beautiful Sydney weather. A must visit place if you are in Sydney.

Make sure you see the flying foxes. Love the Bot Gardens, love the fact that you can walk through all this lush greenery all the way around to the Opera House, such a spectacular ending if you start from the CBD and wander around from there to the OH/Circular Quay. Also the Flying Foxes and the Eels in the ponds are really amazing, kids will love seeing them, just make sure you do look up when you hear the chatter of the flying foxes (huge bats) because otherwise you will miss out on my favourite thing at the Bot Gardens!

Best photo opportunity from Lady Macquarie's Chair. Walk around to the point of the Botanical Gardens jutting out into the harbour, this is the best morning photo opportunity in Sydney capturing the Opera House and Harbour Bridge in the one shot. Have lunch in the restaurant. Walk up to the Art Gallery of New South Wales, next to the gardens.
Interesting. Lovely walks but spoilt by the presence of some drunken individuals making a nuisance of themselves.

wonderfully green!. For a European to visit this garden is like to visit to a new world. there are so many wonderful trees and flowers and birds and flyinf foxes. the plants have so many new forms and colours! it's really impressive. the best place in sydney! have lunch there or just a walk, really it's a magical place. the part that borders the see it's very nice.
Go see the flora and the bats!. Intensely beautiful. The climate in Sydney allows the Botanic Gardens to host many more species than I am used to in the United States. Love the bats!
Really Big. You could walk hours looking a lot of species of plants and looking the spectacular view from the botanic gardens. It's amazing.

This place is huge and amazing. We took the train through here so did a very light tour to say the least. However what we did see meant we realized you could spend days here and not see it all. Some really amazing stuff. If you're a garden buff I could see this being like a candy store of new and cool plants to see. For the rest of us this is a very beautiful stroll through some stunningly pretty plants.

awesome, lush, calm and great for a picnic. take in the sites of the most amazing view, enjoy to flora and take along a picnic and enjoy a truly magnificent garden in Sydney. I love it here and I regret not going often enough
Superb. what a brilliant place with surprises round every corner, from fountains to statues and so much wonderful wildlife..and its's all free!

WOW not just a garden full of plants!!!!. We had a day to kill until our midnight flights, one in our group suggested the Royal Botanic Gardens...oh no! was my first reaction, don't get me wrong.... I like plants etc, but the thought of walking around all day (no shopping) was not what I considered a 'fun' thing to do...but it WAS free..Well how wrong was I !!!!!!!! We went to the main shop area & waited for the guided tour, which is well worth doing. It is truly an amazing place, the history of the place is awesome. I particularly liked the area where the early convicts had a garden that didn't grow anything (I could definitely relate to that, it's a bit like mine LOL!)....Sorry I'm regressing :) The bats were stinky, but sort of cute & I made sure I didn't stand under any trees, if you know what I mean. We saw some great statues & amazing flowers.All in all it was a good day & we got a workout to boot!!!!!
GREAT LOCATION. We were taken there for a party and to see the "O" lit on the Sydney bridge with fireworks at night. I don't think I actually saw the gardens themselves.

Great free place to kill some time - check out the bats!. The park is beautiful and there are bats in the trees by the cafe - just look up! Watch out for the birds... they landed on the tables around us, knocking over coffee cups and stealing peoples sandwhiches... the kids loved it.

An Aromatic, Beautiful Place. The Royal Botanic Gardens are a beautiful place. It's very green and luscious, with soft grass to sit and read on. Reading under the shade of an oak tree is a lovely thing to do on a pretty day, with the sharp winter air cutting into your cheeks.The Botanic Gardens also have a lovely view. The cockatoos are more than willing to oblige to jump onto your shoulder or outstretched hand for a piece of bread for some food. The restaurants are nice and there is a large variety of birds in the Gardens. There is also a large amount of bats - an animal species which I enjoy observing and personally love - in the Gardens and in most of the trees.A must go, though.
Great running track. Take one of the best scenic running, or jogging or walking tracks. The air is always fresh off the harbour. Take time out to check-out the flora.
Morning walks. The botanic gardens are a great lace for a morning walk, with good views of the harbor, the bridge, and the Opera House.

Unbelievable Gardens. We went back several times to the gardens. The cafe is a great resting stop, and if you want that phote of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge in the same picture, then walk around to the arrival plave of Queen Elizabeth - the monument when she first set step on Australia.
pretty. Lovely place in Spring. Amazing colours. Love the grounds and space for exploring by children

the best we've ever seen!. The botanical gardens can really be divided into two parts, the first containing Mrs Macquarie's Chair, a great lookout point, and then the main part of the gardens, where the number of exotic trees and plants is overwhelming. There are lovely walks, a great cafe and lots of activities for children. Nearly-tame, colourful birds are everywhere to be seen. We were there in springtime, so we saw flying foxes hanging head-down in the trees! The aspect we liked most was the sign that said: "Please walk on the grass"!

Worth a visit.. The gardens are only a short walk from the opera house. They are well planted with extensive views over the harbour. Many exotic and unfamiliar birds habitate the park. We were also fascinated with the fruit bats but they are causing a lot of damage -plans afoot to move them on by sonic disturbance. Use the park as a pleasant walk from the opera house to the central business district.
Fantastic Free Activity. If you've got some time to kill in the city then a wander around the Royal Botanical Gardens is a must. Truly one of the worlds best parks
Scenic. It's beautiful to walk around and from the harbor you get some amazing shots of the opera house and bridge.
Beautiful and worth the stroll!. The grounds are open to the public and worth the stroll.
it's ok to walk on the grass!. I loved the sign as I walked into the gardens - smell a rose, hug a tree, walk on the grass.

Really enjoyed the grounds. On a couple day stop in Sydney my wife and did a lot of walking around the Rocks, Darling Harbor and Circular Quay. One of the areas that we really enjoyed was walking through the botanic gardens. We really enjoyed all the informative signs about at the trees. We also liked seeing all the birds in the park. We were there in September so that I can imagine that everything would be extra beautiful once the flowers and trees are in full bloom. We were there for a couple of hours and barely made it though half the park.

my favourite Sydneysiders!. The fruit bats (called flying foxes here)) hanging in the trees are almost more interesting than the amazing plant species on offer here. Well worth spending time here it's extraordinary

Big, lots to see. Lots of birds, flowers, trees. good signs maps and information. liked everything. I took alot of pictures and walked my feet off. I was there in the Spring so it was very colorful. Very clean too.
Very nice. It's big and got good plenty of native and exotic plants. Great view to the habour and easy access. I enjoyed seeing the plants in the grass houses too. Nothing I disliked about it so far.

A haven in a bustling metropolis !!. Go for a stroll, go for a jog , go flat out !! The Gardens cater for all. Nothing beats an early morning stroll as the City awakes then back to your Hotel for breakfast and a coffee or two. I am always amazed at how clean and tidy the Gardens are , a real credit to the staff . It is also the pefect location for a quite afternoon with a bottle of wine , some cheese and crackers and your best girl or just sit, watch the harbour traffic and read a good book !!

Do you like bats?...I mean, REALLY big ones...Lol. I visited the gardens when I was meandering Sydney Harbor. It is right next to the Opera House so an easy stroll. Very lovely relaxing walk, very well cared for gardens and I enjoyed my time there (although I was not there in prime season seeing it was Fall). When we were walking the gardens, however, you come to this path that leads through a mini-forest. As you come closer, you here this loud screech, squeaking which sounds like a pack of rabid birds....what is it I wondered? Bats...and not just your ordinary tiny american type bats, but giant fruit bats...Lol...there were hundreds if not thousands of them hanging from the trees. Not sure if this is just a fall season thingy, but good lord they were every where!! It was broad daylight and they are as active as ever. It was totally cool!!! If you are bat sensitive or odor sensitive, I suggest you stay away...haha...but for those of you that are fascinated with that kind of thing, it's awesome to behold. Also got to see wild cockatoos being fed in the park too...

Beautiful and varied. The Royal Botanic Gardens is a large area with a variety of different gardens within it. I liked the herb garden with its formal layout with a beautiful sculptural sundial in the centre. The bats in the Palm Grove were an interesting curiousity - there are a lot of them! From the lower part of the gardens there are beautiful harbour views and lawns which make a good place for a picnic. On the day I was there, there was a craft show in the Lion gate Lodge which had some stunning pieces on display. It's possible to spend a bit of time here with the number of activities on offer.

MUST see while in Sydney!. Royal Botanic Gardens are beautiful gardens in the heart of Sydney. If you like nature you have to come and see their rare plants, trees and roses. You can bring a blanket, have a picnic and enjoy the company of cockatoos and sacred ibises. You can also spot hundreds of flying foxes sleeping on trees in the park. There is also The Government House open for visitors, a lovely pond, tropical centre in a shape of a pyramid and some sculptures.Walking in the park you can see the Opera House and Harbour Bridge.RBG is a great place where you can spend a lovely sunny afternoon - close to nature and fabulous Sydney attractions.

Better than expected. I had heard we should check out the botanical gardens next to the Opera House so after our tour we walked over thinking it would take about 20 minutes. We ended up spending 2-3 hours there! The area was much larger than I had thought and we really enjoyed walking around the harbor taking in the pretty views, the neat trees, and of course the huge bats. We also had a nice lunch there. The Govnt House looked really beautiful but unfortunately they weren't doing tours when we were there, would have loved to see the inside. If we were in Sydney longer or lived there I could see spending an afternoon there...having a picnic, reading a book, etc just to enjoy the area more.

Nicest botanical gardens I have ever visited. Pros: Fantastic species variety, drop-dead harbour and city views, immaculately clean, no homeless encampments as exist in many other public parks. Free!
Cons: Had trouble locating a drinking fountain
Overall: Fabulous!!!

You Must See the Bats & Cockatoos!. We were not going to visit the Royal Botanic Gardens this time in Sydney because we've seen beautiful gardens around the world and were exhausted, having already walked for days around Sydney. But when someone told us about the bats and cockatoos, my kids wanted to go. Well, once in the jungle section, we looked really hard for the bats in the trees hoping we wouldn't miss them. We had no idea how big and plentiful they were - and impossible to miss. There were hundred hanging up in the trees around dusk. The only disappointment is that we didn't see any flying. Then, we made our way over to the cockatoos (after asking a docent where they were) and had quite a treat! Other tourists were feeding them Pringles and candy but we happened to have almonds which, we soon found out, they LOVE. After making the rounds with the nuts and getting our fill of photos, the birds actually starting chasing after my son when they saw he had a pocket full of almonds. It was like a scene from "The Birds" but my son, thankfully a fast runner, had a good time with it. If you go, please take a natural food that the birds can eat - not junk food.

We cancelled other plans to spend more time in the Gardens!. My husband and I had planned to go to the Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney, and then check out some museums, but there was so much to see in the Gardens that we didn't make it to any museums. We loved seeing all the different trees and plants, and were amazed at how green the Gardens were even though we visited in winter. ("Winter" for people from the Canadian Prairies means something totally different!) And the best part was that it was free!The Gardens are divided into areas that showcase different types of plants and trees, such as the Fern House and the Cactus Gardens. The path along the water provides a great view of the Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. An interesting historic attraction, Mrs Mcquarie's Chair, is at the north edge of the park. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Sydney make up a great green-space in a big busy city, an escape for joggers, tourists, and even casual fishermen. It must get pretty busy in summertime, but I imagine it would be worth seeing the lush plants and colourful flowers.

Beautiful gardens with harbour views. The Sydney botanical gardens are always well kept with plenty of lawn space to relax or picnic. The views of the harbour just spectacular. Many blooms appearing now in Spring. One can walk onwards to Wolloomooloo for more views and visit the Art Gallery and Domain. There is a restaurant in the Botanical gardens, and also a cafe in a nice outdoor setting. I patronised the cafe but found the food quite expensive

Beautiful. Awesome and free. This was a highlight of our trip. These are the most well-manicured, and beautiful gardens I have ever seen. Other cities (Victoria BC) you would have to pay to see this. The exhibits are all signed, and give good information. Mrs. Macquaries point has fantastic views of the harbour. For tourism it's awesome. If I were a local I would be frustrated with this place. It is huge amounts of open green space in the heart of the city, but you aren’t allowed to do any recreation there other than walking/jogging. Bikes and rollerblades aren’t allowed. Neither is flying a kite, or playing Frisbee. Sort of a shame. But there are signs that tell you to walk on the grass, smell the flowers, but just stay out of the flowerbeds. Certain areas are gated off overnight, but the bulk is 24 hr unrestricted access. A must-see in Sydney, especially if Australian flora are new to you.

Cockatoos/Bats OH MY!!. This is the coolest park with semi tame cockatoos roaming a round in groups and big fuzzy brown bats literally hanging around on trees and flying overhead year round. Such a wonderful experience to see these creatures up close.

Birds galore inside the city. Thoroghly enjoyed two hours walking through the beautifully maintained gardens and being entranced by the floral aromas. To add to this be able to have Sulphur Crested Cockatoos land and climb over our bodies was indeed a thrill to our American visitors.

Best walk in Sydney ... and it's free too!. If you're dropping by Sydney, make sure you visit this place!Entrance is free, and there are a few ways to get in - either near the Opera House, or from a few other entrances along the city, or via the Domain - all gates are free and open during daylight hours.Take a walk along the water for an amazing sunset view of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge, or walk into the many gardens.Tip: If you happen to come during spring time, check out the amazing cherry blossoms at the Spring Walk, next to the Macquarie Wall in the Middle Gardens. You will not regret it. Plan on at least 3 hours if you're an avid photographer and a flower lover.Or you could just pick your spot and lie along the manicured green lawns.

excellent gardens. very very nice gardens which are in best location to see the harbour bridge and opera house!! Should attend the guided tours as it helps. The tour is every day 10.30 am and 1 pm weekdays. last about 1 hr

Nice but you have to pay extra for the main amenities. The Royal Botanic Gardens are great since you can find all Australian wildlife there, specially in terms of flora. It is a very relaxing place, where you can go for a walk or even sit there and read a book. The entrance to the Garden is free, but you have to pay for the main amenities, and it is not cheap. Avoid going there from 1pm onwards, it is quite full of people and you cannot enjoy the Garden as you are supposed to do. It was a very nice experience.

My favorite place in Sydney. I used to work a block from here, and I would go for lunch all the time. I love the botanic gardens, it's an escape from the city, within in the city. Picknicking and Sunday fundays with friends in the park during spring and fall, when its not quite warm enough for the beach, were just awesome. The grounds are immaculate, and it is right off the ocean. A must see if you're in Sydney.

Simply Stunning. Spend an afternoon strolling through these beautiful gardens and see the birds, bats and many different plants. Finish up with a picnic at Mrs Macquerie's point where you can watch the sunset behing the opera house and harbour bridge - excellent pictures from here also.
So much to see - loved it all!. This was my 3rd time through - first time for taking a guided walking tour. Highly recommend this.

Must do walk. On your first visit to syney, enter the Botanic Gardens from the NSW Art Gallery end as the first thing you do. Walk up Mrs Macquarie Road and keep going. When you turn the corner at Mrs Macquarie's chair, you will fall in love with Sydney!

Great For Scenic Walks & Nature. This place is amazing! Really cool native plants flowers birds and . . . bats!My wife and I wlaked around the gardens during our stay in Sydeny as part fo our honeymoon. We loved the walk from the Opera House round to Mrs Macquaries Chair taking in the cockatoos that are as numerous as pidgeons are back home as well as some gourgous plants and flowers. Well worth setting aside a few hours here!

Beautiful and Tranquil. Lovely place to take a stroll at any time of the day. Amazing to see flying foxes hanging in the trees and the cockatoos and other birds in the gardens. We spent two or three hours just wandering around and it was delightful.

Absolutely beautiful!. This was one of my favorite things in Sydney. The city was definitely busier than I thought it would be and this was a piece of heaven amongst all the millions of people! My husband and I found a little sandwich shop and grabbed some lunch to go have a picnic in the park. We saw so many different kinds of birds in just 30 minutes it was incredible! I love finding something like this that is FREE so this was by far my most favorite experience in Sydney! Oh and the bats hanging from all of the trees....just amazing!

Take food for the Cockatoos - and your camera!!!. Extraordinary experience. Take nuts or (I don't know what else) for the cockatoos. The birds on the south-ish side of the park, near the museum will use you as a perch to eat your offerings, and you will get pictures of a lifetime.

A quiet spot in the middle of Sydney. We were amazed by the grey headed foxes hanging from the trees all over the garden.As we visited in winter, there weren't that many flowers to be impressed by, but the cuckatoos were such a great experience.We brought sunflower seeds (unsalted) to feed them, and they would sit all over us. I tell you, they are big birds!The park is so quiet, clean and friendly. If i ever come back to Sydney I will visit again!
A beautiful garden in lovely setting. Right on sydney harbour this was a lovely morning to stroll through these gardens.See the native fauna was a delight.It's a must see in SydneyGreat views too

hidden gem in the city. As the name suggests, the Botanic Gardens offers a large range of plant life and is it's own little eco-system. The surprising part to me was how colonies of bats have so thoroughly made it part of their home. It's so nice to see that a city with the size and hustle of Sydney, can still find room for generous park land. Good for the soul.

Central refreshing & beautiful park. This park makes great for switching off the stress and enjoying some quality relaxing time. Bring a blanket and lay down on lanes. Lots of runners along coastwalk may either be interesting to watch from a distance or straight annoying when walking.

Do not forget the camera. When you go into the garden do not forget the cameraRare trees and flowers in a variety of forms and colors surfaces decorated with green grass and blue water. You could spend hours here but even if you have a short time don't give up. take your time to see and enjoy. Not every corner ia always open but the parrots make up for all

Beautiful Escape from the city. We found the Royal Botanic Gardens by chance~ I spent the morning strolling the gardens after taking a nice long walk through the Sydney Harbour bridge~ the gardens were breath taking~ I was able to see different species of birds and bats~ visited the gift shop and bought gifts~ I would highly recommend a walk through and allow yourself to be taken away by the views of the harbour surrounding the gardens~ very close to the Opera House and city center~

Not your ordinary park: Bats & Parrots!. We almost didn't go due to time restraints, but it was well worth the visit! Pros:+ Not your ordinary park: we were amazed to see so many Flying Foxes (bats) hanging from every tree - almost as normal as seeing birds! That's something you don't see at a regular park everyday!+ friendly parrots. we were shocked to see so many white parrots flying around too. We saw a group of kids and parents feeding them in the middle of a field.+ the park was clean, safe and well kept. + There was an outdoor theater which we regret not buying tickets for. A must-see if you can get tickets beforehand online - especially during summer nights. The seats are facing the bay with a screen propped up near the shore. + plenty of australian flowers and trees to see, so you are never bored. + great view of the bay and the city!+ Free - unless you want exclusive tours at their special green houses. CONS:- none! take out one hour of your time after dinner or lunch to stroll around the park - you'll definitely find something beautiful or interesting.

A great escape from the city. I always come here when I visit Sydney. Like walking along London's Southbank, I think the walk around Sydney harbour, past the Opera House and through the gardens is ond of the worlds great city walks. I brought my children last time & they loved the cockatoos and especially seeing the hundreds of giant fruit bats in the trees. The gardens offer welcome respite from the busy city streets & a chance to get close to (well manicured) nature - for free!

Great Views and Landscapes in Botanic Gardens, Sydney. Last week My friend and I went to Sydney Opera House in order to show them its fantastic architecture. They came from Brisbane and I have made a Sydney tour for them. Suddenly I found a beautiful amazing landscape named Royal Botanic Gardens near that and I suggest them to see it. IT WAS BEAUTIFUL! Lots of wide green areas, lots of flora species, BATS, birds, pond, views and cafe are there to make you relax and calm. (exclude bats! ;) )Also, the previous Government House was located there and you can have a indoor free tour. Besides, there is a small part for rare floras of the world.In almost all of the Sydney top attractions, you didin't see this landmark. But if you have a little time, I really advice to see this place.Enjoy your visit!Pejvak

Excellent and extremely enjoyable.. I am usually not a garden type of person however my wife is. Therefore I always ended up going to various gardens and pretend I am enjoying it. The Royal Botanical is wonderful. It has wonderful view, open spaces, benches and restrooms. It has wild cockatoos that my family enjoy playing with. They will fly and land on your arms. You are not supposed to feed the birds but it is obvious that they have been hand fed by the visitors as they are very friendly. There is also bats flying from the garden towards the opera house at dusk that my family enjoy watching. Good place to relax. Great view from the 'Mrs Macquarie' point. Enjoy.

Stayed for 2 hours. Wished it was more.. We are father, mother, and 2 young boys (6 and 2.5). We were staying in Sydney for 4 days. Got a bit tired of Sydney's busy pace. Took a short break at the Gardens. It was so beautiful, serene, and open. Great views everywhere, well maintained, and you can walk on the grass! We walked around just for a few hours. We passed by and interacted with lots of cockatoos. I wished we had more time to spend here. But highly recommended even if you dont have much time in Sydney.

Take your camera for the birds!!!. What an amazing place to visit right in the middle of the city. The birds are just incredible and not afraid of people so you can get up close and take some fabulous pictures. Don't leave the park without trying to see the flying foxes, they are the bats that have a bright orange and yellow belly and are quite fascinating to watch.

Serene and beautiful. Right in the middle of a bustling city, the Botanic Gardens are beautiful. Pathways lead through the gardens, taking a visitor through the vibrant and colourful gardens. Trees, flowers, lawns and shrubs provide a varied landscape that can inspire, relax or entertain the visitor. The larger iconic buildings of Sydney’s skyline are easily seen from many places in the Gardens, but there is a sense of peace in the grounds that can only really be found by getting close to nature. Come to photograph, picnic or just to relax. The Botanic Gardens are great.

A city retreat. "Come walk on the grass, hug the trees, and talk to the birds," one of the opening signs states in welcome.One of my coworkers highly recommended spending some time in these gardens, and she was quite right. The garden boasts some of the biggest, most diverse trees and other plant life. You try to capture these on a camera, but it just doesn't do it justice. In the end, it's best to pack a picnic and spend an afternoon lounging around and enjoying the views, sounds, and smells (mostly good but a bit foul near to where the flying foxes are residing, but they should be gone soon as the city will be moving them in May). There are a variety of birds roaming around which include the ibis and white cockatoos, the noisiest of the bunch but quite fun to watch. Don't miss out on lovely sun sets, which present some of the best photo opportunities. You can spend either a couple of hours or a couple of days in these gardens; it all depends on how you structure your day. There's also a little red train people can take to tour the gardens, but I didn't bother since I like to take my time and see everything at a rather slow pace. This is a place that you can go to at any time as admission is free, so if your day in Sydney has even an hour gap, go and hang out.

A nice walk after visiting the Opera House. We set out with the intention of visiting the Opera House, the Government House within the Botanic Gardens and the actual gardens without realising how long it would take. The Gardens are huge, so make sure you take water and even some snacks if you want to stop for a mini picnic. We set off after breakfast (maybe 9.30am)and lunch time had well and truly passed by the time we ate at 3pm.I was quite surprised by the strong exercise culture that Sydneysiders seem to have. I have never seen so many people jogging, stretching and doing other muscle related activities during the middle of a weekday. The Botanic Gardens seem to be more about being a space for public use than beautiful gardens, but I guess that's really nice too. Seeing Mrs MacArthurs chair and lazing in the grounds of Government House were my highlights.
Look up for the bats!. The gardens were nice, next to the harbour and a walk from the city. So many bats!

great gardens but terrible restaurant. the gardens are great but the botonical garden restaurant is terrible. the staff made a mistake on the bill, forget being apologetic, they were rude and racist. reccomend all not to visit the restaurant.

Nice for a Sunday walk. This garden entrance fee is free and you can see a lot of families and couples lying on the grass or walking along the Sydney harbour. On new year's eve thousands people come to the garden to see fireworks on the harbour bridge. Just 10 minutes walk from the central city. I used to live in Sydney and often went to the garden for a walk and just to relax. :)

Rainy and Wet walkabout. It was a raining heavily and very humid afternoon when I walked around the path in the Royal Botanic Garden. The park was well kept and as it is adjacent to the Opera House and the sea, it is very scenic. Many wedding couples could be seen taking photos there.Due to the rain and the humidity, I did not venture too far into the park. With the limited visit, I found it to be a decent attraction. But I preferred the Opera House and the Bridge as more attractive places to visit in the vicinity.

beautiful for a stroll. great place for a stroll to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city for a few minutes - including some of the biggest trees I've ever seen, some cute cockatoos, plus the Government House and grounds, palace rose garden, oriental garden, palm forest and Conservatorium of Music

Must do while in Sydney. An amazing botanical garden with various vegetation and wild life. What a pleasure to walk through, so much to see that we spent hours just relaxing and walking around. There are various amazing looking native trees, and birds all around the park. We saw hundreds of Fruit Bats, cockatoos, and other cool looking birds. Very romantic strolling through the park and tons of places to sit, relax and enjoy the sea breeze.

The most beautiful park. The Sydney Royal Botanic Garden lays in the Sydney Harbour just right of the Opera House. It is definately the most beautiful urban park I have visited. There are hundreds of exotic trees and plants all with signs of information. Paradise for a botanic freak. The views of the Sydney skyline is amazing itself, along with the harbour and small lakes and benches in the park this is the place to relax in Sydney central business district. You could bring your own food and have a picnic under a tree or go to one of the cafes in the garden. The cafes are very expensive - I think I payed 6 AUD for a 0,33l istea. Be sure not to litter the park, you will be spoken to by an angry parkguard. Be sure to spot the flying foxes (bats). There are hundreds of them hanging in the trees. Also, look out for Sulphur-crested Cockatoos! These beautiful parrots will be all around you if you bring them some food - they love grapes but even bread is good. Fun! There are also smaller very colourful parrots that can eat from your hand. Coming from Norway were all the birds are grey I think this was the higlight of the RBG. There are also freshwater eales living in the lakes. Creepy but cool! This is the place to have a photoshoot so make sure you have your camera! Stay here for as long as you want. I spent hours! There is also guided tours if you'd like that!
Wonderful!. Beautiful gardens even in the winter. Look for the flying foxes - Yikes!

Take the Free Tour!!. Volunteers conduct a free walk every morning at 10:30, which is a great way to learn more about the park and both the flora and fauna. The tour lasts 90 minutes, but our guide was so enthusiastic she kept extending it (with all our permission). She was just so passionate she would say "Oh, you really must see this," and off we'd go to something else. Since it was the middle of winter, I thought that the tour might be a little less than inspiring. I was wrong. We learned all about the fruit bats, eucalyptus, Australian bees, fig trees, the Wollemi pine tree discovery, cockatoos, paper bark trees, lorikeets, etc. The 90 minutes went by too quickly, and we had barely scratched the surface of what the gardens contain. Different tour guides give different tours. There are other tours scheduled as well, such as the Aboriginal Heritage tour, and there was a second tour scheduled that day due to the holidays, so check the website. The tours meet at the Palm Grove Centre, conveniently located next to the gift shop, which had some of the nicest souvenirs I found in Australia. I suspect this is a tour I could take again and again and always learn something new, so I'll definitely put it on my list of activities for the next time I'm in Sydney.

What a lovely place. I loved this park. It is so well kept with a great number of plants and funny birds. It's easy to spend a half day or even more here, especially if it is a winter sunny day like when we visited. Apart from plants and birds, the views of the Opera house are spectacular from here and it was great fun to people watch, especially Sydneysiders jogging during their lunch break. It's very difficult to say what we liked best among the cactus, the tree ferns and the colony of fruit bats.

Beautiful Place to visit - close to Sydney Opera House. Although I prefer the Brisbane Botanic Gardens, this is a large area to walk around to have a look at all the wonderful trees, hanging bats, numerous birds, Gallery of New South Wales. If you are tired, you may take one of the mini-trains, especially great for a visit with children.

Our family couldn't get enough of this garden and the incredible bats. We spent 10 days in Sydney and came here almost every day to run in the park and marvel at the plants and birds. The garden has thousands of varieties of plants -- and nearly as many amazing fruit bats (a.k.a. flying foxes) hanging from the trees. My kids, ages 11 and 8, were amazed by the sites. We have photos and details on our blog post http://away-together.com/2010/02/11/sydney-wet-and-wild/I never would have thought that the botanic garden would rank as my favorite spot in Sydney, but it does! I hope to come back some day.

lovely, relaxing place. It is a wonderful place on a sunny day, you can have a picnic there or just lie on the grass and look to the sky... walk around to have a look at all the wonderful trees...do not forget to look out for the bats hanging around even during daylight! Very cute!

Relaxing and Peaceful but Watch Out for Bikers. A beautiful place to walk with great views. Magnificent trees, wondrous birds, and the ocean at your side. Do not forget to walk on the grass. They have signs telling you to do so. This walk could take an hour or more and it is attached to all the major sites.
Great place to visit!. We really enjoyed walking around the gardens...it was quite relaxing and not too crowded.

Superb. Not sure there's anything new I can add to the other positive reviews. I'm not particularly interested in gardens but I loved these (as well as the completely different Chinese Garden of Friendship). The harbourside setting and sunny weather helps but essentially this is a very accessible and relaxing place with as much in the way of interesting plants as you choose to take. Don't worry about trying to see everything. but you won't want to miss the flying foxes (aka fruit bats) while they are still there - the Gardens Trust plan to relocate them because of the damage they cause. A useful bonus is that the gardens open earlier than other attractions (7:00 am) if you want to be out and about early to make the most of your time in Sydney. Free admission (except for the Tropical House) is nice too.

Don't miss. The other reviewers are right, the Gardens are wonderful. The views are beautiful and I took many photos. Look for the bats in the trees near the tropical garden and nearby are cockatoos in the trees. I got great photos of them. I was there in July, winter in Australia, but it was very mild and many flowers were in bloom. Walk out to Mrs. Macquarrie's Chair on the point. I went back to the Gardens several times during my week in Sydney.

A great place to wander, relax, take photos or just enjoy the view. Make sure you spend some time exploring the Botanic Gardens while in Sydney. Even if parks aren't your thing this is a great place to see some views of the Opera House, Harbour Bridge, Harbour in general or to just relax and people watch. You can also use the walking route along the harbours edge to walk to Mrs MacQuaries Chair which is a popular tourist sight.The Gardens themselves aren't what you may expect. They are basically a park with just some nice plants in and some good views. The name makes it suggest some dedicated establishment like London's Kew Gardens but it's basically a national park with some great views. Having said that you really do need to explore them even if it's just as a place to escape the chaos that can occur in Sydney at busy times of the day.There are some nice plants and birds in there though for anybody that wants to see them.If that hasn't persuaded you - for any movie buffs out there this is where the closing scenes of Mission Impossible 2 were filmed (that scene near the Opera House with Tom Cruise and the girl).If that didn't work I don't know what to suggest - just visit them and you'll see what I mean. It'll be worth it for sure.

Lovely and relaxing. We arrived in Sydney at lunchtime and had the afternoon to do something, but were too tired to do anything inparticular so we had a wander through the botanic gardens. At the time they were getting ready for the new years celebrations but it was so peaceful and relaxing. The sights were amazing without having to do anything or pay anything to see them. We saw the swimming pool perched on the edge of the water, Wooloomooloo looked very nice (and expensive and full of lovely boats) and the views of the bridge and opera house were fantastic. Neither of us are into gardens or flowers but it was such a lovely afternoon and they were such wonderful gardens, definately worth a wander through!

Don't miss it on a visit to Sydney. A peaceful oasis in the middle of the city, the Botanic Gardens offer spectacular and unique views of the harbour, Opera House and the bridge. The city skyline makes a dramatic backdrop to the gorgeous plant and animal life of the park. The wide open lawns offer a welcoming spot for a picnic. Peer up into the trees and spot one of the many bats hanging out above you. Magical.

We loved it here. Beautiful spot to get pictures of Opera House with Bridge behind it. The grounds are very well kept and they have signs that say Please walk on the grass, The birds we saw were unique. And the bats, wow that was amazing (and not at all creepy). We spent a whole morning here one day. Do not miss it.

Great views - and free!. The botanic gardens have a prime spot along the waterfront - right next to the Opera House. I'm not that keen on plants, but there are some real stunners in here. And the atmosphere in the gardens is a lot less hectic than the rest of the touristy bits of the city. The views of the city skyline through the foliage are brilliant. Best of all it's free to enter!

not just for plant lovers. A stroll through parts of the gardens is well worth it, even if you are not an expert or extremely interested in plants. There are plenty of interesting sights, including birds (screeching cockatoos who let you take their photo up close), bats sleeping in the trees, fountains, palm trees, and of course a large variety of plants with interpretive signs. It's a peaceful break from the hustle and bustle of the city, and a 15 minute walk will get you to fantastic views of the Sydney skyline over the water.

Absolutely gorgeous gardens. My wife and I spent an afternoon walking through the gardens and this has got to be one of the highlights from our short trip to Sydney. Way better than the Harbor Cruise, and comparable to seeing an Opera in the Opera House. The succulent garden is amazing and the indoor tropical forest really gives you an idea of the different plants of Australia. The bats are cool to see hanging around, and the Australian birds wander around you as well. The lower gardens are wonderful for a stroll along the beautiful harbor.
